HEADLINE: Stock Slide Sinks Hopes in Industrial City 

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN

DATELINE: YORK, Pa., March 15 

 BODY:
The stock market's shrapnel is spraying all over this industrial town, just under 200 miles from Wall Street. Like many Americans, the city's truck drivers and clerks, nurses and assembly line workers are new and largely accidental participants in a game that was once played exclusively by men who wore suits. 
 Starting in the late 1980's and encouraged by tax breaks, the men and women who work here in the Harley-Davidson plant or at the air-conditioner factory bought into their employers' 401K retirement plans and watched them grow and grow year by year. Then a year ago, at the peak of the market's heady rise, their fantasies of condos in Florida began shriveling, and for many this week, they collapsed. 
 Over deep-fried chicken at the R & D Luncheonette downtown on North Duke Street, Barbara Ruby, 48, said the markets have hammered her 401K and dashed her hopes of early retirement. "I thought I'd be leaving my job by the end of the year," said Ms. Ruby, a customer service worker at the York Water Company. "I want to go do something fun in horticulture, start my own little business." But the market's slide has left her unsettled. "Now, do I have to rethink my whole plan?" she asked. 
Another customer was Barbara Zinn, 41, an accounts payable clerk at a communications company. Only within the last year did she and her husband, a paper company worker, begin investing in 401K plans. She contributes $50 a month and he $130 a week. "I never wanted to start it, and they talked me into it," Ms. Zinn said. "Ever since, I've always had minuses on the statements."
During the 1990's, the city of York prospered -- helped along by well-paid, unionized industrial workers, established construction businesses and flourishing banks and financial services. The city, with a population of 41,000, witnessed a remarkable democratization of the stock market with the proliferation of 401K plans and other tax-favored investments like Individual Retirement Accounts.
The 401K plans, particularly, became popular among employers because they relieved them of providing conventional pensions, which assured retirees of a steady and predictable check regardless of the stock market's ups and downs. With deductions from their pay and varying amounts of employer contributions, workers on 401K plans have assumed most of the risk and burden of providing for their retirement. 
"The manufacturing worker was not even aware of the crash of '87," said Jack H. Grim, manager of the Janney Montgomery Scott securities office on East Market Street, York's main commercial artery. "But he's extremely aware of it today." Many are stunned. "I can see people pulling in their horns," Mr. Grim said. 
With the market's drubbing, investors in York are wary of President Bush's proposals to let them invest part of their Social Security payroll contributions in the stock market. 
Barbara Ruby, chastened by the fall of her 401K, doubted that she could make any better informed investments than government economic institutions. "I'm not smarter than Greenspan," she said. 
Kurt Dagenhardt, 46, who usually votes Republican, built up a sizable 401K fund by making his own investments. He did so well, in fact, that he was able to retire from his job as a salesman for a kitchen cabinet manufacturer and move home to York from Texas to be near his aging parents. 
But eventually he wants a Social Security benefit that he can depend on like the one that helps sustain his parents. "I think that the government should continue to shoulder the Social Security program rather than leave it up to individuals," he said.
Mr. Grim predicted that the Dow Jones industrial average would leap 1,000 points the day Congress enacted a plan permitting workers to determine a part of their retirment investments, and that workers' Social Security funds would rise over the long term. Still, he added, he thought it would now be difficult to assure workers of an ever-rising Dow. 
The Japanese market has been down for more than a decade, he said. "That's never happened here," he said. But if it did, "it would be extremely precarious," he said. 
Among Mr. Grim's 1,000 clients, mostly people who earn less than $100,000 a year, is his sister-in-law, Holly Shearer. A nurse practitioner who lives in Mechanicsburg, north of York, she said: "I'm concerned. I'm feeling very nervous." 
Ms. Shearer said she and her husband, Sam, manager of a Sears store, had gone on a spending spree last year, amassing a credit card debt. But two months ago, Ms. Shearer said she reduced her contribution by about 80 percent to pay off the bills. "Right now," she said, "I want to be safe and take my losses." 
Those close to retirement do not have that luxury. Marlow Palmieri, 60 and the president of the United Auto Workers local at the York air-conditioning plant, said that until last spring he had around $45,000 in 401K stock funds. Fearful that he was putting funds for his imminent retirement at risk, he shifted all but $11,000 of his savings into a cash fund. Since he made the move, the $11,000 in stock has fallen to $8,000. "I've been putting in $50 a month and then $100 a month all these years and I just got lucky," he said. 
The crowd at the Rose Haven bar is generally a little further from retirement. Nearly everyone coming into the smoke-filled bar with a homey feel across from the York International air conditioner plant is in the market in some way, most through 401K plans, but many, too, through their own accounts with brokerage firms. 
Everyone here has a story about wins and losses, including the bar manager, Kelly Snyder. About four years ago, she received an unexpected check for $2,000. Unfamiliar with the market, a tipster told her about a company that has since become Sirius Satellite Radio. She bought 500 shares for $1,875.
On March 3 last year, the stock had reached $69, bringing her total investment to $34,500. Today, Sirius was trading at $19.75 a share. Though Ms. Kelly is still ahead, she feels chastened. "I'm not happy about that at all," she said. "But I've had fun with it. I still think it's going over $100 a share."
As the bar's television drones with hourly reports from Wall Street, Jim Bell, the customer with the least to fear, plays the naysayer. Mr. Bell, who is 75, still works, driving trucks for $10 an hour. He also collects more than $1,000 a month in Social Security. He has a camp trailer, a custom van and he raises rabbits for show on the side. "We are headed for a crash," he said, thumping a fist on the bar. "It's going way more down."
At 70, investors must begin withdrawing funds from their 401Ks. "I pulled beaucoup out to remodel the house," said Mr. Bell. And on the advice of his broker, he put his additional withdrawals into relatively stable utility stocks. 
Crash or no crash, most of the Rose Haven's customers seem willing to stick it out. They have innoculated themselves against panic with a verbal vaccine called "the long haul." 
Jim Dellinger, 47, and his wife work at the nearby Giant Foods, where they have enrolled in 401K plans. Mr. Dellinger, a baker, has put most of his money into a Fidelity fund that has fallen 12 percent this year and a Janus fund that has dropped 16 percent. 
As the market slides, Mr. Dellinger said: "I think about it every day. I have basically my life savings in there." But with his retirement 15 or 20 years off, he said: "I do have a long time. I'm in it for the long haul."
But for such investors, holding on in the market does not always mean holding on to battered funds and stocks. Most 401K plans permit employees to allocate their savings among high-risk and low-risk mutual funds, and some have been shifting their funds as the market has fallen.
Steven Zinn, 35, a letter carrier, watched his stock fund investment drop from $71,000 to $48,000. "I pulled everything out of the stock market three weeks ago," he said. "I put it in government securities, which is guaranteed 6.5 percent. I don't think the market's quite down to where it's going to be at its low." 
An investor's age is a factor in the risks people here take. While Mr. Zinn has opted for a conservative strategy, he said he was planning to take a much bigger risk with a $5,000 fund he has set up for his 3-year-old daughter. The money's in a bond fund now -- but not for long. "I'm going to take $2,500 of that and put it in science and technology," he said. 
On East Market Street, Craig L. Ludwick, 34, who manages the Farmers Fire Insurance Company, put his 18-month-old son into an aggressive growth equity fund. "It's down substantially -- 30 percent in the last six months. But my philosophy is, you stay the course."

HEADLINE: Developers Chosen for New Pennsylvania Station 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
State officials yesterday chose the operators of the Frankfurt airport and a Dallas real estate company headed by Roger Staubach to create a new Pennsylvania Station on Eighth Avenue within the James A. Farley Building, better known to New Yorkers as the General Post Office.
 Groundbreaking for the $788 million project will take place this fall, said Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation and its Pennsylvania Station redevelopment subsidiary. The new Farley-Penn Station, as state officials call it, is scheduled to open in December 2004. 
 Neither Fraport A.G. -- Frankfurt Airport Services Worldwide nor the Staubach Company has had firsthand experience developing a transportation and commercial hub in a city center, though Mr. Staubach said two of his executives had played roles in the revitalization of Grand Central Terminal and of Union Station in Washington.
"The responsibility is enormous, but I know we have the talent," he said. Mr. Staubach, best remembered as a star quarterback for the Dallas Cowboys, has been in the real estate business for 24 years. His company employs about 1,000 people nationally.
Mr. Gargano cited another reason for selecting Penn Station Ventures, as the Fraport-Staubach group is called, over a team composed of LCOR and the Tishman Urban Development Corporation or a team composed of Jones Lang LaSalle and the Turner Construction Corporation.
"What set P.S.V. apart was their commitment of an equity investment," Mr. Gargano said, although he did not specify the amount, in part because the final deal has yet to be negotiated. "It demonstrated that they were willing to back up their vision with a financial stake."
Mr. Gargano also expressed confidence in the collective experience of the partnership, noting that Fraport "is the owner and manager of Europe's leading intermodal transportation hub."
Under plans prepared by the architectural firm Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, Amtrak will move across Eighth Avenue into transformed spaces within the Farley Building. The neo-Classical landmark sits above the west end of the passenger platforms, making possible its use as a railroad concourse. The Farley building was designed to complement the original Pennsylvania Station, which was razed in the 1960's.
Penn Station Ventures would hold a 35-year lease on Farley-Penn Station, with Staubach handling leasing of the 100,000 square feet of retail space and Fraport overseeing transportation.

HEADLINE: Boroughs' Rise Driven Largely By Immigration 

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT

 BODY:
The vast majority of the growth that helped propel New York City's population count to a historic peak in the census figures released yesterday occurred in Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx, in neighborhoods that have been rapidly transformed in recent years by the arrival of an unprecedented number of largely Hispanic and Asian immigrants.
 Latinos now outnumber blacks in New York City for the first time, the 2000 census figures show. Nearly one in 10 New Yorkers is Asian. The proportion of blacks remains stable at just under one-quarter of the city's official population count of 8,008,278, with an increasing number of them foreign-born. Whites, many of whom have died off or moved away, have dwindled to just over a third. 
 "You've got a big decline in the native-born population and a big increase in the foreign-born," said Emanuel Tobier, a professor of economics and planning at the Robert Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University. "The future middle class of the city is in the foreign-born population. So it's really a dramatic change."
It remains to be seen how much of the overall increase is explained by actual growth and how much by better counting. City planners believe at least half the increase in the census figures reflects real growth.
The largest increase occurred in Queens, where the population count grew by more than 11 percent, compared with 1990 numbers that had been adjusted to take into account the undercount in the 1990 census. That increase of more than 225,000 in Queens accounted for nearly half of the city's overall increase of 456,000 and more than a third of the increase in the count for the entire state.
The counts for Brooklyn and the Bronx each rose by more than 85,000 people, even though the Census Bureau's estimates had suggested that the population in those boroughs would shrink. Those jumps accounted for another third of the overall change in the city's count. Staten Island contributed the rest, with an increase of nearly 60,000, or 15 percent, the largest percentage increase among the boroughs. Manhattan's population remained roughly stable.
The numbers suggest significant growth in a city whose official population count had previously peaked at 7.894 million in 1970 and declined abruptly to slightly more than seven million. But better counting could also be a factor: the Census Bureau believes it missed fewer people in 2000 than it missed in 1990.
In addition, the city was allowed to add 370,000 households to the Census Bureau's address list that it says had been missing, many of which the city believes may have gone unnoticed and uncounted since the 1970's or 1980's. Figures to be released later in the year by the Census Bureau may indicate the extent to which those additional households, the equivalent of a medium-size American city, affected the count.
"I think we're comfortable saying that probably at least half of the total growth is real, not just a function of better counting," Joseph B. Rose, the chairman of the City Planning Commission, said yesterday. Mr. Rose has said the city must now determine what percentage of the growth was real to decide infrastructure needs.
Whatever the explanation, the increase is expected to have profound economic and political ramifications. Among other things, it is expected to make the city eligible for more federal and state money, affect crime rates and per capita income figures, shift the political balance of power in the state and enhance the city's reputation as a thriving place.
The last time the population count approached eight million, in 1970, New York was very different. Subway ridership was falling, crime was rising and immigration was still barely a force in the city, said Kenneth T. Jackson, a Columbia University historian who is the editor of the Encyclopedia of New York City.
"In 1970, people felt that cities in general and perhaps New York in particular were falling from some previous pinnacle of importance and success and that the future was not going to be as bright as the past," he said. "But I think in the year 2000, what's interesting is that people have a sense of the city as the place of the future."
The numbers released yesterday were limited to population counts and breakdowns by race and Hispanic origin. They did not include data on where the current New Yorkers came from. Those details are scheduled to come out later. But planners and demographers already have some sense of which neighborhoods have experienced heavy immigration and from which countries.
In Queens, which has attracted large numbers of South American and Asian immigrants, the number of Hispanics rose to about 556,000, or nearly a quarter of the borough's population. Asians jumped to nearly 17.5 percent. The number of non-Hispanic whites in the borough dropped by more than 200,000 to less than on third of the population, as white residents died or left.
According to an analysis by The New York Times, communities with especially large increases include Jackson Heights, East Elmhurst, Corona, North Corona, Woodside and Long Island City. There also appeared to be significant increases in East Flushing and in the area in southern Queens that includes Woodhaven, Ozone Park, Richmond Hill and South Jamaica.
In Brooklyn, the non-Hispanic white population also declined by about 70,000, to just over one-third of the overall count from nearly 40 percent. The number of non-Hispanic blacks dropped slightly. The number of Asians rose significantly, to 184,000 from about 118,000, while the number of Hispanics rose slightly. Nearly one in every five Brooklyn residents is Hispanic.
As for the Bronx, the non-Hispanic white population dropped to nearly 195,000 in 2000, from about 272,000 in 1990. Whites now make up just 14 percent of Bronx residents. The Hispanic population grew to nearly half the borough's population, while non-Hispanic blacks declined slightly, to less than a third of the borough. Neighborhoods that grew markedly included Morrisania in the South Bronx and a number of communities in the northeastern part of the borough, including Baychester, North Baychester and Eastchester.
In Staten Island, non-Hispanic whites remain more than 70 percent of the population. But Hispanics now make up 12 percent of the borough, and Asians nearly 6 percent. Much of Staten Island's growth was centered in the southwestern part of the island, in places like Tottenville, where there was a relatively large amount of new construction in the 1990's.
The population of Manhattan, meanwhile, remained stable at about 1,530,000, when comparing 2000 figures with adjusted 1990 figures. In Manhattan, the percentages of non-Hispanic whites and blacks dropped only slightly, while the numbers of Hispanics and Asians rose.
Citywide, slightly fewer than 5 percent of all New Yorkers identified themselves as multiracial.

HEADLINE: Silicon Valley Investors Cool to Silicon Alley 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO 

 BODY:
Benjamin I. Goldhagen thought that raising investment money for his start-up in New York would be easier than the marathon he ran over melting glacial ice in Antarctica.
 It wasn't. 
 That is why Mr. Goldhagen, the founder and chief executive of the RedTop Company, which makes software, traveled more than 2,500 miles last month -- as did executives from 25 other companies in the New York region -- to look for investments at the Alley to the Valley conference in Silicon Valley in Northern California. 
But with venture capitalist firms stung by the impact of falling stock prices and a declining ability to recoup their investments through initial public offerings, young New York companies like RedTop have found it particularly hard to find investors. Many venture capitalists have curtailed their searches for new investments to focus on companies they have already financed, many of which need cash infusions to survive. 
"A lot of pretty good companies are in traction right now, with a couple of million dollars in revenue, shutting their doors because they can't get funding," said Robert Keith, a managing partner at TL Ventures, a national venture capital firm that finances several New York companies. "It's pretty disturbing. In the next few years, I think Darwin is going to show his teeth."
The first Alley to the Valley conference, in 1998 attracted many new dot-coms, like Wit Capital, HotJobs and StarMedia. A few weeks before the conference, DoubleClick, an Internet advertising company in Manhattan, had made a successful initial public offering. This year there were fewer media dot-coms and more software and technology companies.
During the dot-com boom, Mr. Goldhagen, whose company makes business software for health care providers, repeatedly refused New York venture capitalists' suggestions that he add a .com to his company's name to improve investment opportunities. "I did not play the game," Mr. Goldhagen said.
Now, after cobbling together $9 million from friends and family and getting his company to the point at which it is ready to take the next big leap, Mr. Goldhagen finds himself unable to attract new investors.
"The way races work," Mr. Goldhagen said, "is that sometime along the way it's going to be painful. But you just have to say that 'it's O.K., it's painful, but you got to keep going to finish the race.' But this is nearly impossible."
Three years ago, when AlleyCat News, a Silicon Alley trade magazine, and the New York City Economic Development Corporation sponsored the first Alley to the Valley conference, many New York companies sent representatives to San Francisco. Their goal, said Janet Stites, the publisher and chief executive of AlleyCat News, "was getting West Coast attention by saying that there were these emerging companies in New York, and the city wanted to say that they would do whatever they could to make the environment comfortable for early-stage companies."
Last year, the companies returned to the West Coast to point out their successes. This year, they were on a search for money. "Now people are clearly aware that New York has this technology community," Ms. Stites said. "Now, it is taking these companies on a road show and making sure venture capitalists know that these companies are looking for investments." 
Optimism was in short supply at the conference, which was held at the Palace Hotel in San Francisco's financial district. Sandeep Tyagi, founder and president of Inductis, a Summit, N.J., company that develops software for accounting companies, put on his best face and gave what he said was a nerve-racking slide-show presentation of his business model to a sparse audience of about 30.
Afterward, he found that his audience was not rich with venture capitalists. Instead, the room was filled mainly with other chief executives in the same boat. "There were very few people looking to do funding," he said. "It's just really tough right now."
Silicon Alley, which is driven by media companies, has often seemed three steps and three decades behind Silicon Valley. When the dot-com boom of the late 1990's began to spread across the country, one of the largest disadvantages that New York companies faced was a lack of established venture capital firms. 
But it did not take long for venture capital firms to sprout up in New York. Flatiron Partners, which was started by Chase Capital Partners in 1996, was one of the first firms to focus on Silicon Alley investments. By 1999, the annual investments by venture capital firms in the New York area had jumped to $2.6 billion, up from $390 million four years earlier, according to VentureOne and PricewaterhouseCoopers. The investments helped put Silicon Alley on the map, even if they were dwarfed by the $15.3 billion invested in Silicon Valley in 1999.
But as the stock market valuations of technology companies began to drop last summer, so did the market for initial public offerings. Only 13 companies in the New York area made initial public offerings in 2000, compared with 42 such offerings in 1999, according to IPO.com and Thompson Financial Securities Data.
Venture capitalists began to retrench in 2000. They and others say it has been particularly difficult for entrepreneurs in New York because its young venture capital industry invested so heavily in Silicon Alley's worst-hit dot-coms, like LivePerson and StarMedia. So technology entrepreneurs in New York are looking to Silicon Valley, because that is where most of the money is.
Timothy C. Draper, the founder and managing director of Draper Fisher Jurvetson, who spoke at the conference, said he thought that young New York technology companies would have a hard time finding venture money unless they were in certain subsectors. "There will always be opportunity for early-stage venture capitalists who take risks," he said. "In New York, it will probably be in media, financial services and some sciences."
Daniel H. Ahn, a former New York banker who is now a principal at the Woodside Fund, a venture capital firm in Redwood Shores, Calif., and a speaker at the conference, took a more pessimistic tone. Mr. Ahn said that his firm might invest in a company " on the East Coast, but only if we can find a partner who can play baby sitter."
During his presentation at the conference, Mr. Goldhagen pulled out slide after slide showing that the mental health software market was virtually untapped, and tried to show that his company was ahead of the handful of others. He told the audience he sought $15 million to help keep RedTop running smoothly until the company reaches profitability.
Afterward, outside the presentation room, Mr. Goldhagen said he was encouraged to keep trying, but was told that without a prime backer in New York, he would have a hard time. "We had West Coast venture firms come by and say, 'We love your company, but get us a lead investor in New York,' " he said. 
He added later, "For a company like ours, we have to suffer because of the mistakes and bad moves of the companies who came before us."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 11, 2003

 CORRECTION:
On Thursday, June 12, 2003, The Times published an Editors' Note stating that ten additional articles by Jayson Blair, who resigned on May 1 as a reporter, were found to include misrepresentations or possible borrowed passages. An accounting of those articles was published online at nytimes.com/corrections.html. This article was among those described. The description:

'Silicon Valley Investors Cool to Silicon Alley'
 In this article about the struggles of Internet entrepreneurs in obtaining funds,Mr. Blair quoted Benjamin I. Goldhagen, founder and former chief executive of Redtop, as saying, 'The way races work, is that sometime along the way it's going to be painful. But you just have to say that it's O.K., it's painful, but you got to keep going to finish the race.' But this is nearly impossible.' Mr. Goldhagen said that he did not say 'But this is nearly impossible.'

SECTION: Section A; Column 6; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1571 words

HEADLINE: THE CENSUS/NEW YORK; 
CITY POPULATION TOPS 8 MILLION IN CENSUS COUNT FOR FIRST TIME

BYLINE:  By SUSAN SACHS

 BODY:
The population of New York City surged past eight million for the first time, a 6 percent growth spurt in the last decade that outpaced the state and suburbs for the first time in decades, according to figures released yesterday from the 2000 census. 
 The city became the engine of state growth, a change from the past. It grew by 456,000 people to 8,008,278, accounting for more than two-thirds of the total state population gain. A decade of sustained immigration, combined with several years of prosperity, helped drive the increase by drawing newcomers and persuading New Yorkers to stay put, officials and analysts said. 
 The Bronx, once the byword for urban blight, continued a rebound that began in the 1980's, posting a 7 percent gain in population. Queens and Staten Island, magnets for the immigrants who have helped restructure the city's ethnic balance and push Hispanics past blacks as the city's biggest minority group, had double-digit growth. 
The figures released by the Census Bureau contain population breakdowns by race and ethnicity, but they do not show how many people are immigrants from out of the country or out of the state. Nor is it clear how much of the increase is due to a more accurate count, although city officials say they believe that at least half the city increase reflects actual growth. 
Over all, the state grew at a slower rate of 4 percent, sharpening the contrast between the metropolitan area and the upstate region, where only a handful of towns and cities showed any growth at all. 
The population increases and decreases are based on figures for 2000 and on 1990 data for the state that were adjusted to make up for the estimated undercounting. The city population began to slip in the 1950's and grew only slightly or declined in every 10-year census until 1990. The 1980's provided the first sign of a rebirth, and the latest census figures indicate that the turnaround has become a full-fledged recovery.
The census figures offer just a preview of a more detailed demographic picture to come. But they have immediate implications for economists, businesses and politicians. 
As the numerical center of gravity in the state, New York City may be able to bulk up politically to match its demographic weight. It will gain two seats in the Assembly and one seat in the State Senate, and it could gain the muscle needed to resist attempts by upstate lawmakers to eliminate an urban Congressional seat.
The state expects to lose 2 of its 31 seats in the House of Representatives because its population increases were behind those of Southern and Western states.
The statistical evidence that New York City was center stage after decades of slow growth or decline clearly delighted Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who said the city got bigger because it became a better place to live. 
He also credited the increased population figures, in part at least, to the city's "detective work," which provided the census takers with more than 370,000 household addresses added during the past decade or missed in previous counts. 
"The flight from the city has declined a lot," the mayor said. "People were leaving because they worried about crime, the economic mix in the city, the fact that they would have to pay high taxes. So a lot of it is a better count. And a lot of it is because the city is doing so well."
The city, he added, will press its advantage with state officials. "We will make the point to the state that we are the primary reason for their jump, so that when the analysis is done as to how we distribute money the city should benefit from this," Mr. Giuliani said. 
The non-Hispanic white population of the city continued its slow decline, dropping nearly 12 percent. And the march of people to the suburbs -- the postwar story of big American cities -- has continued. But for the first time in decades, the suburbs' gain, of 5 percent, was not New York City's loss.
"This is about the changing prospects of New York and big cities," said Robert Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association, a planning advocacy group. "These places are really safer, cleaner and more livable. The other related change is demographic. Baby boomers can live wherever they want. The kids are out of the house. They're tired of mowing the lawn. So we have this big countertrend of folks staying in the city or moving back in. That was an aberration until this decade."
The suburbs still attract people, but no longer just white people fleeing the city. 
Once-pastoral areas at the outer edge of the metropolitan area showed robust growth. Dutchess County grew by 7 percent and Putnam by 13 percent, for instance. Growth was slower closer to the city, where vacant land for new housing long ago became a premium in Nassau, Rockland and Westchester Counties. In that inner ring, population grew by only 4 percent.
The figures, however, mask real changes taking place along the fringes of New York City, where some of the traditional distinctions between city and suburb have been blurred. 
In the inner suburbs, Hispanics made up more than 12 percent of the 2000 population, but just under 8 percent in 1990.
Although immigrant flows are not broken out in the census data, the effects of more than 15 years of steady immigration can be seen. Statewide, for example, the Hispanic population grew by more than 25 percent in the past decade, with new clusters of Latinos in upstate cities as well as New York and its suburbs. 
In Albany and the area around it, the Hispanic population grew by nearly 50 percent, and in other upstate counties by nearly 40 percent. 
A similar trend was evident beyond the near suburbs, in once-rural areas that have increasingly become the first stop for new immigrants. About 10 percent of the population is Hispanic, more than non-Hispanic blacks. 
"The suburbs are definitely becoming more diverse in the sense that the black and Latino and Asian populations of the suburbs are rising," said John Mollenkopf, director of the Center for Urban Research at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York.
"It's still a small share compared to the city," he added. "But you're also seeing more pockets of poverty than in the past that make them more like the city."
In a reflection of the diversity that has characterized the city over the last 15 years, 5 percent of people identified themselves as members of more than one race. Nationally, just 2 percent did so. 
"One reason is that we have a higher diversity now, with the presence of new immigrants who came to the U.S. with a different view of what we call race," said Clara E. Rodriguez, a professor of sociology at Fordham University and the author of a book on changing racial identities, "Changing Race."
Her research found that many people, particularly Latinos, change the way they classify themselves for the census from decade to decade. 
"As they change their context and go to school, move to different areas or change jobs, they come to see that the way they see themselves is different from the way they are seen by others," Dr. Rodriguez said.
The picture of the state will remain out of focus for some time. The census figures released now do not provide information on the gender, employment or national origin of people. That data, and other details, will be contained in census reports to be issued over the next year or so.
For New York City and its suburbs, which have undergone the broadest demographic change, the data to come will be needed to understand the diversity.
The general racial and ethnic totals, for instance, do not distinguish between a Hispanic from Mexico and one from Chile; between a white person who may be a new Russian immigrant and a third-generation Irish-American; or between a black from the West Indies and a native-born African-American. 
Demographers and planners also will not know for some time how much of the population increase is based on new people -- that is, a net gain from the excess of births and new arrivals over deaths and departures -- or simply better counting. 
The distinction is important, not only for examining the census procedure. New arrivals to the city may take over the housing or classroom seats of those who leave. But they may not correspond in age or training to those who left. So they do not necessarily fill similar jobs or make the same demand on city services, like transportation, schools and public assistance. In short, they change the economic and social mix. 
More accurate counting, however, may well be at the heart of some growth figures. 
Monroe County, for example, grew slightly during the decade despite a population loss in the city of Rochester, which was hit hard by a loss of thousands of jobs at Eastman Kodak, once its biggest employer. The new census data show that Monroe County grew by 12,411 people. 
But it also had provided the census takers with a roster of 15,000 addresses that it said were missed in the 1990 census. Other torpid upstate cities, like Buffalo, did not revise their lists of addresses.
"We're happy to declare victory and go home," said Kent Gardner, director of economic analysis at the Center for Governmental Research in Rochester, which helped the county put together the list of addresses. "But from the statistician's perspective, the fact that we here had attention paid to that critical aspect of the census suggests the numbers may be of different accuracy in different communities."

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 36

LENGTH: 4700 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. 
* denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "AFRICAN FORMS," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through Aug. 8). This show forgoes the figurative sculptures and masks that made African art a foundation of Western modernism to concentrate on supposedly humbler stuff, objects of physical adornment and daily use. With some 400 objects created by 156 ethnic groups, it proceeds in clusters of related carved wood neck rests, stools and boxes; ivory hairpins and snuff bottles; all kinds of jewelry; baskets and ceramic vessels; as well as spoons, weapons and musical instruments. The show is pervaded by elegance, economy of form and a sensitivity to materials that is both intensely spiritual and protomodern. Figurative sculpture and masks may be the "high art" of Africa, but there is no low. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50, students and 65+ (Roberta Smith).

* "COMMITTED TO THE IMAGE: CONTEMPORARY BLACK PHOTOGRAPHERS," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through April 29). This sharply installed survey of 94 artists covers several decades of work, much of it by a generation of photographers who came of age in the 1960's and 70's. The pictures are sorted by broad themes (people, beauty, family, religion, etc.), and formal polish tends to predominate over conceptual grit. The terrain is, over all, unsensational ordinary life, with the heat now and then turned up high. Images of urban churchgoers, Louisiana sugar cane cutters, the magnetic Billie Holiday and children in African refugee camps sit side by side. The eclectic array has its share of bland entries, but there are dozens of wonderful artists here, and their collective spirit is persuasive. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 am. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of the month). Admission: $4; $2, students and 62+ (Holland Cotter).

"THE COS COB ART COLONY: IMPRESSIONISTS ON THE CONNECTICUT SHORE," National Academy of Design Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, between 89th and 90th Streets, (212) 369-4880 (through May 13). From 1890 to 1920, Cos Cob, Conn., was a hangout for American Impressionist painters, led by John H. Twachtman, J. Alden Weir, Childe Hassam and Theodore Robinson. Writers and journalists added to the scene's buzz. Though art talk and theorizing ran at fever pitch, in practice the Cos Cobbers put out a quiet, conservative brand of Impressionism that emphasized a bright palette, pastoral subjects and a concentration on what the novelist and critic William Dean Howells once called "the smiling aspects of life." Still, as a footnote to American art history, Cos Cob deserves recognition. Even though this is not the most urgent exhibition in town, it includes some lovely paintings, produced by the group's minor artists as well as its stars. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, noon to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5 (Grace Glueck).

"A FAMILY ALBUM: BROOKLYN COLLECTS," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5931 (through July 1). This big, uneven but frequently transcendental grab bag of an exhibition celebrates collectors of art or antiques who live in or come from Brooklyn. Eighty-six collectors of all stripes lent some of their prized possessions. The grand, wildly pluralistic total of more than 300 items includes ancient Egyptian heads, Navajo rugs, 20th-century kitsch and 21st-century avant-gardism. The exhibition covers all the bases and includes some real masterpieces, like an early Miroesque painting by de Kooning or a vividly realistic Roman portrait of a worried-looking man from 40-20 B.C. Hours and admission: See above (Ken Johnson).

* "ANDREAS GURSKY," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9400 (through May 15). The giant pictures in this mid-career retrospective of Mr. Gursky, the 46-year-old German photographer, are so eye-poppingly, drop-dead gorgeous that in this world, where no good turn goes unpunished, you may feel compelled to react with suspicion and reserve. But knee-jerk resistance at the sight of the nondescript global emblems of new capitalist sprawl that he photographs is short-circuited by sheer awe at the incredible, sublimely weird, almost erotic glamour he imparts to them. The work is instantly attractive to the point of alarm, which is the feeling of falling in love. You might as well give yourself over to it and worry about the consequences later. Hours: Thursdays through Tuesdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; until 8:15 p.m. on Fridays. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

"HERE AND THERE/AQUI Y ALLA: SIX ARTISTS FROM SAN JUAN," El Museo del Barrio, 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, East Harlem, (212) 831-7927 (through May 20). The six ambitious, cosmopolitan Puerto Rican artists in this show -- four men and two women, all in their 30's, all working with some form of installation -- are a lively crew. Minimalism isn't their scene; nor, in any overt way, is politics. For the most part, they are into sound, color, humor and unfastidious beauty, with several media cooking away simultaneously. The results are a high-spirited, obstacle-ridden, outre-and-proud sort of show, the kind you move slowly, even cautiously, around in, rather than one you breeze through. Hours: Wednesday through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; $2, students and 65+ (Cotter).

* "KENNETH JOSEPHSON: A RETROSPECTIVE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through May 27). The first full-scale career assessment for one of the earliest and most inventive explorers of photography's character and the issues of perception and representation that it raises. In the 1960's, when Mr. Josephson began commenting on it, the truthfulness of photography was still a myth with a powerful hold on the imagination. Best of all, his philosophizing is often served up with a generous portion of wit. Much of his work has never been exhibited, and he is not nearly as well known as he deserves to be. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8, students and 62+ (Vicki Goldberg).

"MATERIAL AND MATTER," Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500 (through April 1). This is a permanent collection show with a go-getter twist. Half the work is from the museum's holdings; much of the rest is on loan from commercial galleries and adds up to a wish list for the future. The museum already owns the fine pieces by Benny Andrews and David Hammons; the loans include work by smart younger figures like Nayland Blake, Odili Donald Odita and Romuald Hazoume from Benin. In its cool way, the show is a hot mix. (Also on view is a small solo show by the San Francisco artist John Bankston, made up of pages from a visual novel-in-progress. Part 19th-century slave narrative, part fairy tale and part homoerotic S-and-M fantasy, it is as understated as it is sophisticated.) Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Fridays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $5; $3, students and 62+ (Cotter).

* PAUL McCARTHY, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through May 13). From his far-out position where the psychic security of Hollywood's packaging of sex and violence doesn't exist, Mr. McCarthy taps veins deep in the collective subconscious, far beyond where most shock artists have the audacity or intelligence to operate. He has been a cultish presence in Los Angeles for years, and his moment has finally come in New York with this retrospective and shows at Luhring Augustine in Chelsea, Deitch Projects in SoHo and, in collaboration with the Public Art Fund, at the public atrium on the northwest corner of 56th Street and Madison Avenue. We see an artist of wild highs and lows, of black comedy, cheap jokes, unspeakable actions, dry formalism and some real fiascos -- the mark of an artist risking failure, a good sign. There is something beyond mere Pop parody or social provocation in the work, something to do with deep private needs and desires, which we perceive secondhand as comic pathos. It is art as tough therapy, disturbingly honest. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, noon to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, artists, students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* CHARLOTTE SALOMON, Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200 (through March 25). Put aside as much as possible the grim death that has boxed Salomon, like Anne Frank, into the eye-glazing, inviolate category of Holocaust artist, a disservice to her. "Life? Or Theater?," her quasi-fictional diary of text and nearly 800 pictures cued to musical themes, will make you feel that you are in good company while flattering your intelligence. The allusions are varied, the tone at times surprisingly light. Film was a big inspiration to Salomon. Images vary among close-ups, flashbacks, long shots and montage. She had an illustrator's gift for distillation and paraphrase. The result is a complex meditation on the connection between love and art. It is a coming-of-age story about a woman squeezing a whole life into one great gesture. Ultimately, the energy counts most, a civilizing energy. "Take good care of it," Salomon told the man to whom she entrusted the work before she was shipped to Auschwitz. "It is my whole life." So it was. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Tuesdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $8; $5.50, students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* "THE TREASURY OF BASEL CATHEDRAL," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through May 27). The jewel-embellished gold and silver liturgical objects and reliquaries in this show exist on some exotic outer fringe of beauty, where the crass and the ineffable meet. Together they have a cliffhanger of a tale to tell, as frustrating as it is uplifting. (They were preserved as an ensemble until Basel city politics intervened in the 19th century.) There's the rarity factor: almost none of the 75 works have visited the United States before. And it's hard to remember the last time anything quite like their single-minded incandescence radiated from a local museum. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:15 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 8:45 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 65+ (Cotter).

* "VAN GOGH'S POSTMAN: THE PORTRAITS OF JOSEPH ROULIN," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9400 (through May 15). This revelatory micro-exhibition reunites five portraits of the postal worker Joseph Roulin, whom van Gogh met while living in Arles in the south of France. The show affords an excellent opportunity to study the painter's craft as he processes a single motif through a series of approaches from painterly naturalism to richly patterned symbolism. It is fascinating as well to see the portraits in light of the biographical background. Roulin cared for van Gogh after the famous ear-cutting incident, and he grew in the artist's imagination from an amusing local character to a figure of Christ-like benevolence. Hours and admission: See above. (Johnson).

* "VERMEER AND THE DELFT SCHOOL," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500 (through May 27). Genius does not flourish in a vacuum. That's the simple lesson vividly conveyed by this alternately tousled and crystalline exhibition. With 15 Vermeers -- nearly half his known paintings -- serving as ballast, this exhibition almost giddily spotlights a succession of artists, tracking the emergence of an increasingly effortless illusionism in Delft in the 1650's and 60's. Flower still lifes, whitewashed church interiors, townscapes and genre scenes by Pieter de Hooch, Carel Fabritius and Gerard Houckgeest are part of the mix, along with drawings and a breathtaking selection of small landscapes by artists you've never heard of. All this contextualizing sharpens one's sense of Vermeer's achievement, but it also spells out the milieu without which he would not have been Vermeer. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

Galleries: 57th Street

FLAVIO GARCIANDIA, Galeria Ramis Barquet, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 644-9090 (through March 24). The elegant abstractions in this Cuban painter's New York debut have savvy, sharp-tongued titles like "I Insulted Brice Marden in Havana (Twice)," which they don't quite live up to -- but that may be the point. They are the work of a skilled ironist whose works from the 1980's kept abreast of the decade's style-mongering tendencies. While similarly inclined, his new efforts are more subdued and transitional in feeling. But they indicate an artist with talent, touch and a healthy sense of skepticism, and leave one waiting for his next move (Smith).

* "OUR BEAUTIFUL AND TORMENTED AUSTRIA: ART BRUT IN THE LAND OF FREUD," Galerie St. Etienne, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 245-6734 (through March 31). This extraordinary show introduces the recently discovered work of two self-taught Viennese artists: Emanuel Navratil (1875-1956), who made large colored-pencil drawings that transformed his native city into a magical kingdom of fantasy architecture, intricate pattern and bourgeois contentment; and Josef Karl Radler (1844-1917), a retired porcelain painter whose fusions of writing and painting infuse scenes of the hospital where he spent his final years with a power akin to illuminated manuscripts (Smith).

ROBERT OVERBY, "Stairwell, Paul's Place," Grant Selwyn Fine Art, 37 West 57th Street, (212) 755-0434 (through April 1). Overby (1935-1993) is known for the latex rubber castings of rooms and architectural elements that he began making in the early 1970's. This show features the ghostly imprint of a whole stairwell. Suspended in the middle of the gallery, the boxy volume, with details of moldings, wall textures and various fixtures preserved in the fleshy, dirty yellow rubber, seems at once preposterous and scientific (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

BRIAN ALFRED, Max Protetch, 511 West 22nd Street, (212) 633-6999 (through March 24). A current minitrend has some young painters using tape to stencil hard-edged, 1960's-style acrylic pictures of the modern built environment. Mr. Alfred, having his first solo exhibition, is an adept practitioner of the genre. The cheerful neo-Pop surfaces of his pictures of a swimming pool, a great suspension bridge or a building being demolished mask rueful emotions about utopian modernism (Johnson).

GLEN BAXTER, "Unmitigated Ramifications," Lombard-Freid, 531 West 26th Street, (212) 967-8040 (through March 24). This delightfully witty cartoonist, familiar to readers of The New Yorker, is at his best when he gently mocks pretentious high culture, as in his image of two cowboys lounging around a campfire. Holding up a small canvas, one declares, "Working out here helps me to address the problem of the notion of the nonrepresentational as an absolute" (Johnson).

SOPHIE CALLE, "Double Game," Paula Cooper Gallery, 534 West 21st Street, (212) 255-1105 (through March 24). This French-born Conceptual artist is a world-class snoop. Her art consists largely of spying on people -- cleaning rooms in a Venice hotel, for example, to get a line on their anonymous occupants. In TriBeCa in 1994, she adopted a public phone booth for a week, stocked it with snacks, drinks and flowers and stationed herself nearby to chat with its users and listen to telephone talk. As a diarist, Ms. Calle is amusingly deadpan, and her obsessively detailed reports on her antics have a certain fascination. But she is no great shakes as a photographer, and the long sequences of shots documenting her actions are less than compelling (Glueck).

THERESA HACKETT, "Going Off," Florence Lynch, 147 West 29th Street, (212) 967-7584 (through March 31). Airy or oceanic blue flux and little boxes in loose grids are the bipolar terms of Ms. Hackett's expansive, doodlelike drawings. In her whimsical play with patterning and collage, and the addition of three-dimensional elements like piles of fabric swatches, there is an appealing idiosyncrasy (the work of Diana Cooper comes to mind) that would be worth pushing into more unpredictable territory (Johnson).

ROBERT F. HAMMERSTIEL, Cristinerose, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 206-0297 (through March 31). This Austrian photographer focuses on the dog industry to critique capitalism. Photographs of dog leashes alternate with small mug shots of dog owners. Each in a series of thin boxes displays a dog portrait and an actual syringe used for inserting identification microchips under the animal's skin. This may sound like a parody of some kind of neo-Marxist Conceptualism, but it is not particularly funny. Perhaps Mr. Hammerstiel is serious: that would be funny (Johnson).

CHRIS LARSON, "The Gastral Colony," Rare, 435 West 14th Street, (212) 645-5591 (through March 24). The main attraction of this interesting young sculptor's New York debut is a trio of bizarre machines designed, it seems, to perform possibly torturous operations on human bodies. Remarkably, these contraptions with their levers, plungers, gears and clamps are assembled almost entirely of rough-hewn wood. They have an antique, folksy look, as if they had been built by a loony Amish inventor (Johnson).

MICHAEL LAZARUS, "Exceptance," Feature, 530 West 25th Street, (212) 675-7772 (through April 7). Combining glossy enamel paint and elements of Modernist abstraction and Asian patterning, Mr. Lazarus makes symmetrical panel paintings -- with cutouts, in some cases -- that revolve around the image of a simplified mask, part jack o'lantern, part skull. These cheerfully decorative works have slightly sinister implications; they could be icons for some secret cult (Johnson).

BEVERLY SEMMES, Leslie Tonkonow, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 255-8450 (through April 14). An artist known for her sculptures in the form of gigantically oversize women's clothing, here presents something monumental and absurd but abstract: a great, vaguely fecal mound of convoluted, fat, stuffed tubes of electric green nylon. Gallery personnel are wearing overalls made from the same material, which creates a mysterious sense of industrial purpose (Johnson).

LEON TARASEWICZ, Gary Tatintsian, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 633-0110 (through March 31). Mr. Tarasewicz, selected to represent Poland in the Venice Biennale later this year, paints brushy striped compositions on canvas and, more interestingly, turns whole galleries into striped environments. Here fuzzy brown stripes alternating with blue, white or green wrap around a series of thick partitions and cover one wall, creating an enveloping interplay of Minimalist structure and humming painterly surface (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

"AT THE EDGE: THE HORIZON LINE IN CONTEMPORARY ART," Dorsky, 379 West Broadway, near Spring Street, (212) 966-6170 (through April 14). This 15-artist group show might have taken a less literal, more imaginative approach to its potentially rich theme, but it offers some pleasing pictures. These include three small, delicately atmospheric seascapes painted by Pat de Groot and assorted expansive photographic landscapes or waterscapes that range in style from lush color pictures by Stuart Klipper and Richard Misrach to the Minimalistic black-and-white approaches of Hiroshi Sugimoto or Tom Bamburger (Johnson).

CHRIS MARTIN, Malca, 580 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 966-8854 (through March 31) and at Sideshow, 319 Bedford Avenue, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 486-8180 (through March 19). Mr Martin is a perennially interesting and admirably unfashionable painter. At Malca, a canvas measuring 10 by 36 feet and bearing a stack of white rectangles topped by a flying-saucer-like form, looks like a giant sign made by a nonartist who had a close encounter of the third kind. At Sideshow, pictures of orange or yellow boxes against sky blue fields are richer as paintings and transcendentally suggestive as images (Johnson).

ERIN O'KEEFE AND VINCENT SZAREK, Sandra Gering, 476 Broome Street, (212) 226-8195 (through March 24). Two sculptors each combine Minimalist structure and lush material: Ms. O'Keefe arranges colored blocks and mirrors in boxes behind squares of frosted glass, creating blurry, spatially ambiguous compositions. Mr. Szarek, borrowing from custom-car culture, fabricates sleek, undulating wall works with glossy automotive paint jobs; one beauty sports a sumptuous candy-colored cherry red metalflake coating (Johnson).

ROBERT SCHMID, Sears-Peyton, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 966-7469 (through March 31). With sensitive, assiduous craft, Mr. Schmid paints small-scale copies of blurred, smeared, double-exposed or otherwise distorted snapshots of people, city streets and natural landscapes that were taken with a defective camera. He organizes these images into gridded compositions that have a moody, cinematic quality (Johnson).

Other Galleries

ROBERT JACK, "Webs and Flow," 123 Watts, 123 Watts Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-1482 (through March 31). With sharp instruments, a delicate touch and considerable industry, this young artist makes densely accumulative abstract drawings. Many are grid-based; others suggest geological surfaces or bundles of nerves; some involve holes repeatedly poked in long rolls of graph paper with a heating element (Johnson).

Last Chance

* BODY AND THE EAST: FROM THE 1960'S TO THE PRESENT, Exit Art/The Third World, 548 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 966-7745 (through tomorrow). Organized in 1998 by the Museum of Modern Art in Ljubljana, Slovenia, this exhibition surveys the body and performance work of some 100 artists or artists' collectives from 14 former Soviet bloc countries. It represents a tremendous effort of retrieval, adds many new names, locations and artworks to the constantly expanding map of postwar art and offers further proof that American and Western European artists did not and do not act alone (Smith).

"CONFRONTATIONAL CLAY: THE ARTIST AS SOCIAL CRITIC," American Craft Museum, 40 West 53rd Street, (212) 956-3535 (through today). This intermittently interesting show makes an inconsistent case for clay as a medium of social criticism, but it offers some fine ceramic works, including Robert Arneson's grisly, charred head on a pedestal, "Nuclear Warhead"; Nancy Fried's sensitive rendering of her own naked, corpulent torso with one breast lost to surgery; Ann Agee's assortment of sex toys glazed in traditional Delftware patterns; and Cynthia Consentino's figurines representing young schoolgirls brandishing handguns or assault rifles. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50, students and 65+ (Johnson).

* OSKAR KOKOSCHKA, "Memorial Exhibition," Marlborough Gallery, 40 West 57th Street, (212) 541-4900 (through tomorrow). This show is a continual reminder that Kokoschka, who died in 1980 at 93, gave his whole self, without evasion and without stinting, in everything he did. It begins with his portraits of the composers Webern (1914) and Schoenberg (1925); continues with his big cityscapes, with their attention to telling detail; and makes a strong case for his late watercolors, in which the image is briskly defined and the color has an irresistible energy. This hand never shook (John Russell).

* HARRIET KORMAN, Lennon, Weinberg, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 941-0012 (through tomorrow). In her beautiful new paintings, it looks as if Ms. Korman has achieved a harmonic convergence of all her painterly energies. Each squarish, medium-size canvas offers a flat, thinly but sensuously painted harlequin patchwork of richly hued, interlocking shapes. Klee, Miro, Kandinsky and Mondrian come to mind, but these paintings have their own fresh, contemporary feel (Johnson).

"THE OPULENT EYE OF ALEXANDER GIRARD," Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, 2 East 91st Street, (212) 849-8400 (through Sunday). The first comprehensive look at the multifaceted work of this architect and designer. Girard's contribution to contemporary design was a free approach that incorporated all sorts of visual stimuli, from Italian stage sets to Mexican folk art to motifs from modern technology, making exuberant use of color, pattern, texture and ornament. In photographs, models and objects, the exhibition displays his fabrics, graphics, interiors, furniture, tableware, radio cabinets and much else. A whole room is devoted to the more than 300 fabric and wallpaper designs he created for the Herman Miller Furniture Company from the 1950's to the early 1970's, with fresh patterns and colors that pushed the limits of middle-class taste. While Girard may not have been a heavyweight in American design, he was one of its liveliest figures. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays until 9 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $8; $3, students and 62+ (Glueck).

* "PERFECTING MANKIND: EUGENICS AND PHOTOGRAPHY," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 860-1777 (through Sunday). A timely exercise wildly disproportionate in significance to its size, this one-room show tackles the complicated story of photography's supporting role in eugenics, the pseudoscience of human breeding. Via 19th-century composite portraits of Jews, snapshots of "Fitter Family" and "Perfect Baby" contest winners and early Nazi photographs of Aryans, it tracks the arc of eugenics' popularity, an object lesson for this era of genetic engineering. And it shows the dubious results of an unreflective faith in technological science, in this case the new technology of photography, which seemed at the time a reliable instrument of reason. The exhibition is a reminder that photographs almost always say less than people think or want, and sometimes precious little except about the prejudices of the viewer. Hours: Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6, students and 62+ (Kimmelman).

"SIX AMERICAN PAINTERS AND THE PHOTOGRAPH," Zabriskie, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 752-1223 (through tomorrow). This illuminating show takes us back to a time long before big color photographs began to invade the territory once occupied solely by painting. For Konrad Cramer, Ralston Crawford, Yasuo Kuniyoushi, Ben Shahn, Richard Pousette-Dart and Charles Sheeler -- each represented by black-and-white photographs and modest paintings or drawings -- photography could stand on its own or inform the composition of paintings, but it never called into question the need for painting the way it does today (Johnson).

"ANDY WARHOL: PHOTOGRAPHY," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 860-1777 (through Sunday). When Warhol died in 1987, he left some 100,000 photographs in the form of prints, contact sheets and negatives. This exhibition is the first major examination of this material and focuses on its relationship to Warhol's photo-based paintings, early and late. Taken strictly as a display of photographs, the show feels a little thin, mostly because his output in the medium was almost willfully insubstantial. But as a fresh take on his hugely influential work and complex personality, the results are entertaining and sometimes revealing. Included is one of his "time capsules," cardboard boxes that he periodically filled with the material clutter of his life, then sealed, dated and stored away. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6, students and 62+ (Cotter).

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
A change at TWBA illustrates concerns over a slow economy.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
THE LEADER of one of the three large worldwide agencies operated by the Omnicom Group in New York is suddenly being replaced in a surprising shift that speaks to the increasing concern along Madison Avenue over the economic slowdown.
 Omnicom, the world's second-largest agency company in billings and third largest in revenue, is replacing Michael Greenlees, who has been president and chief executive at TBWA Worldwide in New York since May 1998. TBWA, which includes the well-known TBWA/Chiat/Day agency, is the smallest of the three Omnicom global networks, after BBDO Worldwide and DDB Worldwide. TBWA has billings estimated at $6.5 billion from brands like Apple, Energizer, Levi's and Nissan. 
 Mr. Greenlees, 54, is being succeeded by Jean-Marie Dru, 54. Mr. Dru reported to Mr. Greenlees as president and chief executive for the TBWA international operations, supervising offices in all countries outside the Americas. Mr. Dru was deemed instrumental in helping to persuade Nissan Motor not to leave the agency last summer. That was a considerable accomplishment because the company is TBWA's largest client, as well as Omnicom's second largest, after DaimlerChrysler.
The change in leadership at TBWA is a sign of the increasing scrutiny of agency performance as the economy sputters and uncertainty grows over whether clients will proceed with the spending plans for 2001 that they made as recently as December.
There is less tolerance for underperformance, much less bad performance, as the wagons are circled in case the economy and consumer confidence deteriorate further and an actual advertising recession begins. As a result, the ability of top agency executives to care for and feed current clients effectively, as well as skillfully and successfully woo potential clients, looms larger.
For instance, Mr. Greenlees was not identified with any one TBWA client the way Mr. Dru is with Nissan Motor; the absence of such relationships can be harmful.
"I don't know how else it could be anyone else," said a senior agency executive. "He saved the Nissan account." The executive, who once worked with Mr. Greenlees, spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Mr. Dru will work with Lee Clow, who will continue as chairman and worldwide creative director at TBWA, based in Playa del Rey, Calif., which is a principal office of TBWA/Chiat/Day.
Mr. Dru, who has been based in Paris, will move to New York. The online edition of the trade publication Adweek reported on Tuesday that Mr. Greenlees would leave TBWA and identified Mr. Dru as a front-runner for the top job.
Mr. Greenlees is not being dismissed. Rather, he is taking what was described in a news release from Omnicom as "a new leadership position" at the agency company, focused on "working to advance its e-services strategy."
Pat Sloan, a spokeswoman for Omnicom, declined to elaborate on that vague wording; she said there would be further word about Mr. Greenlees's new duties and title "in the very near future."
Omnicom has been ahead of its competitors in the realm of interactive advertising, taking stakes in many top agencies specializing in Internet marketing, which are managed by a unit named Communicade.
The release took pains to praise Mr. Greenlees's performance, noting that under his tenure, billings rose to $6.5 billion last year from $5.1 billion in 1998. But the agency had difficulty landing additional worldwide clients, falling short, for example, in a review for the Delta Air Lines account in 1999. Delta left Saatchi & Saatchi in New York for the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago.
Mr. Greenlees joined TBWA months after Omnicom acquired the GGT Group in London, an agency company he founded and expanded until it ran into problems after losing large clients at one of its agencies, BDDP Worldwide. The acquisition, which gave Omnicom control of agencies including GSD&M in Austin, Tex., and Martin/Williams in Minneapolis, ended Mr. Greenlees's plans to keep expanding GGT as an independent agency company so it could compete against Omnicom and other giants like Havas Advertising, the Interpublic Group of Companies and the Publicis Groupe.
At TBWA, Mr. Greenlees succeeded Bill Tragos, the "T" in TBWA, who retired after presiding over the merger of TBWA with Chiat/Day.
That merger, along with the merger of BDDP into TBWA, produced a worldwide agency network that included disparate units that were all charged with cooperating on creative and account tasks but that were used to operating on their own. The challenge of helping to reduce the fractious relations among the various fiefs and building a cohesive TBWA fell to Mr. Greenlees, who encountered difficulties there.
The departure of Mr. Greenlees is the second time in three months that a top executive of TBWA has left the agency. In January, Bob Kuperman, president and chief executive at the North American operations of TBWA/Chiat/Day, joined an Omnicom sibling, DDB, as chairman of its flagship New York office.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Greenlees's position may have been undercut because he was not linked to any one client. (TBWA Worldwide)

HEADLINE: UAL and AMR Join Other Airlines in Issuing Profit Warnings 

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN

 BODY:
The country's two largest airlines warned investors yesterday that a decline in passengers amid a weakening economy would hurt their first- quarter results more than expected.
 By issuing the separate warnings, the two airlines, the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, and the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, joined most other major carriers in predicting either bigger losses or lower-than-expected profits for the quarter. Only Continental Airlines and Southwest Airlines have not issued formal warnings. 
 United said that its loss would be substantially deeper than the loss of $2.82 a share that analysts had forecast. The company, which had expected to break even this year despite months of labor woes, said that it would probably end up losing money and would try to cut $200 million in expenses. 
"The softening of the U.S. economy has had an industrywide effect on business travel demand," James E. Goodwin, United's chief executive, said in a statement. "While our 2001 business plan assumed a challenging financial environment, the economic situation has deteriorated more than expected." 
Analysts expected AMR to earn 34 cents a share during the quarter. But in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said that softening passenger demand combined with a brief labor disruption at Kennedy Airport and winter storms in the Northeast and Dallas would result in "a modest loss." 
Earlier this week, Delta Air Lines, the third-biggest American carrier, said that it would post a loss of $85 million to $110 million for the quarter, blaming passenger worries over a potential strike by its pilots. Fourth-ranked Northwest Airlines, which is facing a potential strike by mechanics in May, said Wednesday that it would lose as much as $150 million. Before that, US Airways had also warned that earnings would be well below Wall Street forecasts.
Analysts had been expecting a warning from United, but some were taken aback at American's prediction of a loss.
"This is a surprise," said Raymond E. Neidl, an airline analyst at ING Baring in New York. "It's not as bad as Delta and Northwest, but it is a surprise."
Investors seemed to take yesterday's news in stride after the earlier warnings from the other carriers. The share prices of most of the major airlines, with the exception of US Airways, rose yesterday. AMR was up $1.73, closing at $34.54. UAL closed at $36.55, up $1.45. Both trade on the New York Stock Exchange.
Mr. Neidl said it appeared that economizing by business travelers to avoid paying high last-minute fares was a bigger factor in the airlines' weakness than any actual fall in the number of passengers. He still expects the economic slowdown to be relatively mild, he added, meaning that the industry could recover in the second half of the year. 
"If they can get the labor contracts squared away and get some help from lower oil prices, the second half of the year can be salvaged," Mr. Neidl said.
But Kevin Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, warned that "if things don't pick up by midyear, the losses for the first quarter could end up becoming losses for the entire year."
Southwest Airlines, the industry's low-fare leader, traditionally does well during economic downturns, because travelers look for bargains. A spokesman for Continental said that it, too, had seen some softening, particularly in business travel, but the airline has not issued a formal warning. Continental did say that its first-quarter earnings would be hurt by a winter storm that forced many cancellations at its Newark hub earlier this month.
Like Delta and Northwest, United and American are in contentious labor negotiations in which unions are asking for large wage increases, citing the record profits earned by the airlines since their last contracts were signed in the mid-1990's. 
Mr. Murphy speculated that the airlines were probably not too unhappy to report bad economic news right now. "If I were a manager, I would certainly be using the soft landing for everything I could get," he said. "Clearly labor has to be sobered by this whole experience."
