HEADLINE: The Man Who Could Not Say No Cries Uncle 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY 

 BODY:
IT was not supposed to end this way for the man named Gulotta. The name alone meant royalty in Nassau County for two generations. When Thomas S. Gulotta left his job as county executive it was supposed to be for higher office, not because his career had unraveled.
 And yet, here was Mr. Gulotta, tan and trim at 56, bowing out before his time. Here he was, seated at his wooden desk in his fourth-floor office on Tuesday, with a glass of water in one hand and his wife Betsy's hand in the other, surrounded by reporters who were in turn surrounded by the knickknacks he had collected over 14 years in office, the antique picture frames, a photo of John Marshall on the wall that he had used as a mirror to straighten his tie, a digital clock inscribed with a quote by Pericles: "Be ruled by time, the wisest counselor of all." 
 Mr. Gulotta, who had once said he believed that timing can be everything in life, was here, tinged by sadness, to say it was time for him to go. 
"With every chapter in your life that closes, a new chapter opens," Mr. Gulotta said after the television cameramen turned off their lights, which had always made his gold cufflinks, his pinky ring, his silver hair shine so brightly. "I look at this with mixed emotions, but I am comfortable with the decision that I made."
In the hours after Mr. Gulotta delivered his eight-minute address, pundits who had both loved and vilified the man were writing his political obituary: so much promise, yet so many flaws. Gifted with the people, yet cursed by failed economic policies that were derided by critics as Gulottanomics.
"He epitomized the failings, the arrogance and the laziness of unchallenged power," said Robert P. Zimmerman, a Democratic National Committee member who lives in Great Neck. "He defined government through token gestures and political gimmicks. And after you've given a citation to everyone with no cavities in the neighborhood, people want substance and vision in their elected officials."
It was the same complaint countless members of his own Republican Party had hurled at Mr. Gulotta since the county's multimillion-dollar budget deficits, plunging credit ratings and mammoth debt began setting off alarms 18 months ago.
His departure, said Joseph N. Mondello, the chairman of the county Republican committee, is the end of an era in what is perhaps America's quintessential suburban area, home of Levittown and strip-mall shopping, Gold Coast mansions and single-family houses filled with former Democratic urbanites who fled the city and joined the ranks of Nassau's Republican machine and its promise of a better life.
The question now is whether the party, known for its almost Chicago-style patronage system and ironclad rule, will be purged by Mr. Gulotta's exit or if an angry electorate will continue to punish it in November.
"While there are those who may take issue with some of his policy decisions, it is clear to me that he wanted the best for Nassau County," Mr. Mondello, originally from Brooklyn, said of Mr. Gulotta in a statement that belied all of the venom of their longstanding rivalry. Mr. Mondello said he hoped history would view Mr. Gulotta favorably. Clearly, it was a legacy Mr. Gulotta once seemed likely to build. 
Thomas Stephen Gulotta was born in Oceanside on April 27, 1944. He played stickball in Lynbrook and wore a child's three-button suit when his father, Frank A. Gulotta Sr., a war hero, was sworn in as district attorney and Nassau's first Italian-American elected official.
Though his mother, Josephine, wanted him to play piano, young Tom Gulotta was tone deaf. Instead, he was elected by one vote as student president at Malverne High School, studied ancient history at Trinity College in Hartford, toyed with the idea of becoming a doctor and wound up in law school at Columbia, where he missed the war in Vietnam.
Politics was the predictable route. He was first elected to the State Assembly in 1976, as a protege of Joseph Margiotta, Mr. Mondello's predecessor as party boss. It was two terms later that Alfonse M. D'Amato, the presiding supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, won a United States Senate seat and Mr. Margiotta, who traced his ancestry to the same Sicilian village as the Gulottas, picked the 36-year-old Mr. Gulotta to complete Mr. D'Amato's term.
Mr. Gulotta won that seat again, twice, before he stepped in to fill the term of Francis Purcell, the county executive who, in a classic Nassau Republican maneuver, retired to give Mr. Gulotta the advantage of incumbency when he ran for a full term.
Mr. Gulotta was a relentless campaigner, sleeping four or five hours a night and keeping a withering schedule of ribbon cuttings, Eagle Scout ceremonies and retiree dinners, events he was shuttled to in a black four-door 1989 Ford Crown Victoria that had logged more than 176,000 miles as of last October.
Many in the party said they had wanted Mr. Gulotta to run for governor in 1990, a year when two challengers to Mario M. Cuomo split the G.O.P. ticket. And even if Mr. Gulotta had not beaten Mr. Cuomo then, the Republican thinking goes, he, rather than George E. Pataki, would have been perfectly set up to win in 1994.
On Tuesday, as he announced that he would leave office after his term runs out at year's end, Mr. Gulotta ticked off all the positive things he wished he had been given more credit for: lower crime, lower unemployment, rising home values, low office vacancy rates.
"I guess he was a lot more powerful than people realized," joked Herbert D. Rosenbaum, a professor emeritus of political science at Hofstra University, noting that all of those social barometers were holding true throughout the region, if not much of the nation. "He didn't take credit for the crime decline across the country, at least."
Critics said the one thing a county executive undoubtedly has control over is the county books, its budget.
Mr. Gulotta, who took office in 1987, depicted himself as a conservative fiscal manager. But he spent lavishly on police, parks, golf courses and other services residents had grown to expect. Many Republicans said he wanted to be like Santa Claus, giving to all and being loved for it.
"He has done, I think, a good job, in terms of, from our perspective, law and order," said Gary DelaRaba, the president of the Police Benevolent Association, who stood in the back of Mr. Gulotta's office Tuesday. "He put more cops on the street when they were needed the most. He did a lot of innovative deals that he probably didn't get the credit for that he should have, or at least he led the charge that allowed us to succeed. If he had a fault, it was a fault that he didn't want to raise taxes. Expenses go up in everybody's household. What are you going to do?"
Once, early on, Mr. Gulotta had tried to cover those costs, when he proposed a 25 percent property tax increase to close a deficit in 1992. But Mr. Mondello and others rejected it, and Mr. Gulotta was scalded by a close re-election fight the next year.
From then on, his budgets avoided the slightest increase in the general tax rate -- an ailment Judith A. Jacobs, the Democratic presiding officer of the County Legislature, once referred to as Mr. Gulotta's "post-traumatic-tax-increase syndrome."
In lieu of taxes, a string of fiscal gimmicks took hold: using one-time revenues, like money from the sale of a hospital, for example, to pay continuing costs; borrowing $100 million a year to repay homeowners and merchants who successfully challenge their property tax assessments; underestimating costs, like overtime for correction officers; and overestimating revenues, like those from the sales tax.
To hear Phoebe B. Goodman, the executive director of the Nassau Citizens Budget Committee, tell it, it is not all Mr. Gulotta's fault. Yet, she said, the costs of government did not stop rising, and Mr. Gulotta's budgets left many questions unanswered.
"If I went to spent $1,000 on clothing, you want to know what I am going to spend it on, what I'm going to use it for," Ms. Goodman said. "Is it just for me? Is it for the whole family? Is it for five years or three weeks? And all of these things that you would like to know to tell if it is a wise expenditure or not, you could not find in his budgets. Ever. It was not a planning tool."
Mr. Gulotta once said he and his fellow Republicans "were a team protecting the taxpayers." And he blamed them for accusing him "of dropping the ball and the team is scrambling when we should be pulling together to reach the goal."
But that is all behind him now. There will be plenty of time for analysis and talk of legacy. His future is wide open, and he has a $2.5 million campaign war chest that he can use for any political cause he sees fit. But when asked about specific plans, he invoked the words of his father.
"He said, 'Never gear your decisions by what the next step might be,' " Mr. Gulotta said. "He said, 'Gear your decisions by what you believe is in the best interest of the people that you are serving.' "
Many this week gave Mr. Gulotta credit for his decision. They said at least he was not run out of office, like Mr. D'Amato, former Mayor Edward I. Koch or former Governor Cuomo. Others credited him for showing class in announcing his exit.
"He did not do it in a Nixonian way," said Lisanne Altmann, a Democratic legislator. "He did it with grace, and I give him credit that way. There was no self-pity. I am sure he was wondering what his dad would think."
By all accounts, his father loomed large in his life. He was there when Mr. Gulotta faced his first election for county executive, in 1989, but he was terminally ill. The 82-year-old man was confined to a hospital bed in the living room of the family home, on Walnut Street in Lynbrook. But he kept by his bed a calendar.
"I would try to stop by the house, every day or every other day, to offer him some encouragement," Mr. Gulotta said recently. "And I could see on the calendar that each day he was crossing off one day at a time until Election Day.
"And although we didn't talk about death, he kept saying to me, 'I just want to be here to see you elected.' And I feel very fortunate he was able to share in the joys of that victory. I know he had a great deal of pride. And within a month and a half after that, he passed away."
In 1997, his last election, Mr. Gulotta's wife, Betsy, asked him to make it his last. Last weekend, he made her happy when they decided it would be. Now, he said, he wants to travel the country with her and their three children.
One night last October, the couple went to a movie, "Remember the Titans," at the Bellmore Playhouse. They walked out hand-in-hand and went to the Apollo Diner, in East Meadow. Over coffee, they told how they met.
She was from Tarrytown, and working at the Museum of Natural History. He was at Columbia at the time. Each, led by friends, wound up at the same mixer in the city.
"As soon as he walked in the door, I saw him standing there against the wall, over on the other side of the room," Mrs. Gulotta said. "And I am trying to figure out, 'Well, how am I going to meet that guy over there.' "
For Mr. Gulotta, "it was love at first sight." Tom made his move when Betsy went for a glass of beer. He reached around her waist and put his cup next to hers. "Would you please fill my cup, too?" he said.
"And that was it," she said.
Later, they went up to the roof, and he gave her his jacket. When they left the mixer, he walked her part of the way home. But before they parted, he said, "I bet you don't remember my last name."
But she did. "Gulotta."

HEADLINE: Glen Cove to Wall St., by Water 

 BODY:
Long Islanders who live on the North Shore and work on Wall Street will have a new commuting option in mid-May: a high-speed commuter ferry from Glen Cove to Manhattan.
 On Tuesday, Mayor Tom Suozzi of Glen Cove announced the Island's first high-speed ferry service to Manhattan -- a 45-minute trip from Glen Cove to Pier 11, a block from the New York Stock Exchange. 
 "This is both a major development in the city's Waterfront Revitalization project and an asset for the region," said Mayor Suozzi, who recently announced his decision to run for Nassau County Executive this fall. 
An excursion ferry from Glen Cove to New London, Conn., and to Martha's Vineyard, off the Massachusetts coast, during the summer is now operated by Fox Navigation.
Based on the 30-year agreement between Fox and Glen Cove, the city's Industrial Development Agency will construct a boat basin, ferry-terminal building and parking lot, giving Fox the exclusive right to operate the commuter ferry.
In return, the company will pay a license fee of $1 million over two years and will pay a facility use fee of 5 percent of every ticket sold. Estimates are $20 to $25 for a round-trip ticket. The Glen Cove agency will own the permanent ferry terminal, with Fox having the option to buy it by the end of the year for $4 million.

HEADLINE: Cisco Is Building Corporate Campus Outside Boston 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN DIESENHOUSE 

DATELINE: BOXBOROUGH, Mass. 

 BODY:
THIS erstwhile farming community of 5,000 is morphing from apple-picking country to a development center for the latest computer data networking equipment. The driver for the transformation is Cisco Systems Inc., the world's leading maker of networking equipment, which is building a $250 million, 1.2-million-square-foot office and research and development campus on two sites here.
 The campus, which the company calls the New England Development Center, could double the amount of commercial space in this 10-square-mile town on Greater Boston's outer beltway, Interstate 495; bring in about 3,000 jobs; fatten the tax rolls; and add 150 acres to the town's reserve of open space. Coupled with a 674,000-square-foot manufacturing plant that Cisco opened in October in Salem, N.H., and almost 700,000 square feet of space it is developing in neighboring Littleton, it forms the base of Northeast operations for the company, which has revenues of $20 billion. 
 Some New Englanders may be known for their frosty temperaments, but officials of little Boxborough radiated considerable warmth to close the deal with Cisco. "Boxborough's been one of the friendliest communities to work with," said Christine Garvey, Cisco's vice president for worldwide real estate. The two sites here have the capacity for as least another 500,000 square feet of commercial space, and the town agreed to give the company a 15 percent property tax break over 20 years. "The tax arrangement was even more welcoming," she added.
A week ago, however, the company announced plans for companywide cutbacks, including the elimination of up to 5,000 jobs, which could result in a retreat on its plan here. A spokesman said that the company was "still evaluating where reductions will be" and that in general its difficulties "may mean we'll adjust the scale or timing" of a project. 
The largest segment of the New England Development Center -- seven buildings on 370 acres -- is devoted to research and product development, areas in which the company does not intend to scale back, according to statements made a week ago by the chief executive, John T. Chambers. Already the foundations are in for six buildings on the site, and the steel is up on two. 
According to Ariane Mahler, a securities analyst for Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, Cisco needs this project, and with about $7 billion in cash, can afford it. Since the campus will bring together 11 companies in the region that Cisco spent $9.9 billion to acquire since 1994, "its efficiencies could save them money in the long run," she said. "They don't have a cash-flow problem, and given the environmental problems and higher costs of developing in California, they need this."
William Backlean, an analyst for SunTrust Equitable Securities, added: "Technology isn't dead; it may just be delayed a little. New England has gone through cycles before." Indeed, much of this town's existing commercial space, about 830,000 square feet, was developed in the 1980's by companies that have since closed operations here: Digital Equipment and NEC.
DESPITE the current uncertainties, Cisco chose Boxborough for reasons likely to outlast this downturn. Indeed, the fact that it must build six-foot-high underground tunnels with skylights for migrating Blandings turtles that cross the site hardly fazed it. In expanding near its headquarters in San Jose, Calif., Cisco has encountered lawsuits and referendums seeking to protect burrowing owls and tiger shrimp that have delayed its development efforts. "The scale of ease here is better than we experienced for many California sites," Ms. Garvey said.
Of approximately 17.5 million square feet of space the company currently occupies, about 10.5 million is in Silicon Valley; 2.5 million in Raleigh-Durham, N.C.; 1 million in Richardson, Tex.; 3 million in Europe; 250,000 in Japan; and 200,000 in Israel. According to the current plan, the company's New England projects will add 2.5 million square feet to the total. 
A major lure of this quaint town with its whitewashed church, stone walls and antique one-room schoolhouse is its location in the Massachusetts technology corridor. Populating a quadrant that radiates from Boston about 40 miles north to New Hampshire, west to I-495 and south to Hopkinton on the Massachusetts Turnpike are scores of young, small technology companies that are developing the new products and cultivating the engineering talent that could fuel growth at Cisco.
Furthermore, the region's top-flight universities, solid core of venture capital firms financing technology start-ups and deep pool of skilled labor are Cisco's lifeblood. Sweetening the mix, it costs about half as much to develop a campus in suburban Boston as in Silicon Valley. Last summer, Cisco paid $15 million for 508 acres here and $16 million for its 90 acres in Littleton.
Cisco is not alone in rediscovering New England's charm. In the last few years, venture capital firms have invested about $6 billion a year in companies in the Massachusetts technology corridor. At the end of 2000, the 70 million square feet of office and research and development space there had a vacancy rate of about 4 percent, net new space leased of 4.5 million square feet and gross asking rents ranging from the low $30's a square foot annually to the low $50's. 
Currently in the corridor, buildings with about four million square feet are being developed for multitenant use with 60 percent of the space preleased, while another five million square feet is being developed by technology owner occupants. The roster of those building in the area includes Sun Microsystems, Sycamore Systems, EMC, Lucent Technologies and Oracle.
"What these big gorillas see here is access to quality labor, plenty of electric power reserves and space that's half the cost of California," said Jim McCaffrey, a partner at Boston-based Meredith & Grew Oncor International Inc., a real estate services firm. 
They have also found large parcels of land that they can purchase for projects of one million to two million square feet. Given the national slowdown and the volatility in the technology industry, land ownership means companies like Cisco can adjust the pace of development without being the captive of a developer.
"The big question for Cisco is, where will they find the workers?" said Len Owens, a partner at McCall & Almy Inc., a Boston-based real estate advisory firm. With the unemployment rate in Massachusetts at only 2.4 percent in January, technology companies still find it challenging to attract and retain workers.
BUT Cisco is confident that its central location in Boxborough will be an easy commute for its current regional work force of about 2,600 and will attract others leaving defunct dot-coms, Ms. Garvey said.
Last July, Cisco purchased the 90 acres in Littleton, where it is planning to put up three buildings with a total of 640,000 square feet, and two sites here. One is a 138-acre parcel that had a 277,000 square foot building on it, which the company renovated and occupied in January. Last September, construction began on its major parcel, the 370 acres here just off I-495 that will have seven buildings and cost from $200 million to $300 million to build, according to Ms. Garvey. Cisco is financing the development itself.
Here, Cisco will relocate the 11 companies it has purchased. The complex, which was designed by the Cambridge-based ADD Inc., features 900,000 square feet of two- to four-story red brick, aluminum and precast concrete buildings set into the wooded site traversed by walking paths and recreational amenities. The internal systems will have two to three times the usual capacity for electric power and data connections of normal office buildings. 
Early last year, Cisco presented its plan to the town, said Natalie Lashmit, the town administrator. In the late 1980's, Boxborough had rezoned the land on its border with the town of Harvard for commercial use. Last spring, residents decided at town meetings that they would prefer to have one large occupant on the site rather than several smaller ones to more easily resolve issues like redirecting traffic and installing new underground utility lines on Cisco's campus. The town will also get 154 acres of open space, including the 60 acres for the turtles and 10 acres for recreation facilities like jogging trails and a soccer field.
Already, residents are seeing the upside of this massive project. Their tax bills have dropped about $50 on a average bill of $5,000; and residential real estate prices have increased about 10 percent and commercial prices 15 to 25 percent, she said. Meanwhile, Ms. Lashmit said, "Residents with house lots are sitting on them to see what happens."

HEADLINE: DEVELOPMENT; 
On the Waterfront

BYLINE:  By ROBERT WORTH 

DATELINE: YONKERS 

 BODY:
PLANS to renovate this city's industrial waterfront on the Hudson River have come and gone like passing barges since the 1960's. Despite its spectacular views of the Palisades and proximity to New York City, the half-mile strip of shoreline has remained mostly vacant, thanks in part to the city's lasting political and image problems. 
 Now the city is trying again. It has reached a critical point in a $200 million public and private effort to transform the waterfront and adjacent downtown area from an unsightly industrial relic into a magnet for businesses and commuters. 
 "After decades of talking about it, the waterfront is finally becoming everything it could and should be," said Mayor John D. Spencer, who has made reviving the area a centerpiece of his five years as mayor. 
Next month, a private developer is expected to begin construction on Hudson Park, a $55 million project near the water's edge that will include two towers on either side of Main Street with 266 apartments and about 22,000 square feet of office and retail space. The developer, Collins Enterprises of Old Greenwich, Conn., has an option to build another 250-unit building just north of the waterfront.
Arthur Collins II, the company's president, said the city's willingness to invest in the area was a key factor in his decision. 
"You now have a city that is committed to spending the money to redevelop their downtown, that's the bottom line," Mr. Collins said. 
The city began its current redevelopment effort about five years ago, bolstering the police presence to make the area safer and rezoning it to suit new developers. Since then, it has spent about $110 million in federal, state and local dollars on new construction and rehabilitation, said Jim Pinto, director of the office of downtown and waterfront development.
Work began last month on a 1.5-mile-long esplanade park on the water with trees and a marina, designed by Ehrenkrantz Eckstut & Kuhn, the firm that rebuilt Battery Park City and Baltimore's Inner Harbor East. 
This summer, Metro-North expects to begin a $35 million renovation of the train station. The city also hopes to lure commuters with ferry service to Manhattan from the City Pier, which was refurbished five years ago with $2.7 million in federal funds. And to help accommodate new traffic, a building on Hudson Street will be converted into a parking garage and office space.
The city also hopes to revive the entire downtown area, now a low-rent mix of discount stores, tenements and fast-food restaurants. Work has begun on a new home for the city library and Board of Education offices in the old Port Authority building on River Street. The old Trolley Barn building on Main Street will be the site of 37 live/work lofts to be marketed to people working in Internet-related businesses. 
The new plan is expected to create 500 to 700 jobs, and within five years it should create an additional $6 million in sales tax revenue and $2.5 million in property taxes, said Edward Sheeran, executive director of the city's Industrial Development Agency. 
Already, the city's investment has lured private businesses to the area. 
"We took a chance on the city and their commitment," said Joseph Cotter, the president of Hudson View Associates, which has invested $25 million over the past two years on a two-acre industrial complex north of Main Street known as I-Park. 
The complex includes Kawasaki Rail Car Inc., which customizes and installs electronics on subway cars for New York and other cities, along with a number of smaller tenants, and is now about 90 percent leased, Mr. Cotter said.
But downtown's revival "is not a slam dunk," Mr. Cotter said. Although many companies have been eager to take advantage of the area's low commercial rents -- which range from $14 to $18 per square foot -- others are still leery of an area that has been troubled for so long, he said.
And some believe the city's investment is too small. "The current plan is not big enough," and Yonkers needs a longer-range strategic plan, said Leon Shilton, a real estate finance professor at Fordham business school who has studied Yonkers for several years.
To truly turn the area around would require either a major employer, who could invest more in the area, or a much larger investment in high-end housing, which the city cannot afford, he said.
Still, Yonkers does seem to have moved beyond the difficulties that sank its last major redevelopment effort, a 1,850-unit condominium complex called Pierpointe on the Hudson that was proposed in 1979. That project was put on hold when a federal court imposed a moratorium on new construction in 1987 as part of the city's long-running desegregation lawsuit. 
The subsequent collapse of the real estate market doomed the project, though its backers did not finally give up until 1993. Only one building was completed: a 136-unit condominium called Scrimshaw House by the water's edge off Main Street. The building is now fully occupied, after many years with vacancies when the market values of the units were declining, said Charlie Meyer, the treasurer of the building's condominium board.
And the arrival of the Collins apartments could inject new life into the downtown economy, said Robert Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association. "Residential always has to come first," he said. "It may take a while before it reaches critical mass, but I'm pretty confident Yonkers will make it." 
The building should have no trouble drawing tenants, thanks to the current shortage of apartments in Manhattan and Westchester, said Susan Gombocz, a relocation counselor with Houlihan/Lawrence Relocation Management. Rents at Hudson Park will average $2,150, Mr. Collins said.
Some local advocates have argued that the city has not done enough to include residents of the downtown area, many of whom are low-income minorities, in its plans. 
"We're quite frankly concerned about how this gentrification is going to impact the community, and the extent to which displacement of families could occur here," said Leonard Buddington, the president of the Yonkers chapter of the N.A.A.C.P.
But Symra D. Brandon, a city councilwoman whose district includes the waterfront and downtown, said that she expected the new development to benefit everyone in the area, and that only 30 to 40 people would be displaced.
"For there to be progress, there will have to be some displacement," she said. "This is the closest to a real development we've ever come."

Construction is to begin next month. In addition to apartments renting for more than $2,000 a month, it will include office and retail space. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times) Drawing (Do H. Chung & Partners) Map of Yonkers.

HEADLINE: The Victorious Home Buyer's Final Lap 

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
AFTER several months of searching for a home, Tamara and Nicholas Lauritano found what they wanted in Branford, Conn.: a 2,000-square foot condominium with a living room, dining room, family room and two and a half baths. So the newly married couple, both 30 years old, visited a realtor, signed a contract to buy the home, submitted an application for a mortgage, retained a lawyer, arranged for a house inspection and notified the landlord of the date they planned to vacate their apartment in West Haven. 
 As first-time home buyers, little did they know what could go wrong -- and often does -- in the last lap of the process. 
 From the moment they strike a deal with sellers to the final handshake at the closing, buyers must run a gantlet of lawyers, real estate brokers, mortgage lenders, surveyors, inspectors and insurers. The lucky ones may encounter nothing worse than unexpectedly high closing costs, but the unlucky few may confront everything from serious plumbing problems in their new homes to not-so-sophisticated financial scams. 
The Lauritanos' close was scheduled for Jan. 15 of this year, two weeks before the couple planned to move out of their apartment and into their new home. But the evening before the closing, as they arrived at what would soon be their home to give it the final once-over (known as a "walk-through"), the sellers broke the bad news.
"They told us there had been an accident the night before," Mrs. Lauritano said. "The upstairs toilet had overflowed, ruining our bathroom on the lower floor and the family room. The place was a wreck. And so were we." Their worries went beyond the physical damage. The Lauritanos stood to lose a special interest rate they had negotiated with their broker that was good only until Jan. 15, their closing date. Otherwise, they could take out a different loan through the broker but at a higher interest rate, or they could look for a different lender altogether. 
The Lauritanos decided to go through with the closing, at which time the distraught couple told their woes to their lawyer, Maggie Sullivan of Stratford, Conn. She promptly negotiated with the sellers' lawyer, and the two of them agreed to withhold $3,500 of the seller's proceeds and put the money in escrow until the repairs were completed satisfactorily.
Because the Lauritanos had to vacate their apartment to allow the new tenants to move in at the end of the month, they had little choice but to move into their new home while the repairs were still being made. 
"They ended up doing beautiful work, and we love our house," said Mrs. Lauritano, a director at TutorTime Child Care Learning Center in West Haven. In addition, the lawyers agreed to compensate the new owners out of the escrow fund for Mr. Lauritano's having to take four days off from his job at Sikorsky Aircraft in Stratford in order to be home during the repairs. 
Still, "I wouldn't wish what we went through on anybody," Mrs. Lauritano said. "It was a stressful experience." 
With 6.02 million homes sold last year, according to Orawin Velz, an economist with Fannie Mae, the nation's largest source of financing for mortgages, it would be an exaggeration, especially in the recent seller's market, to say that the frustration level associated with closing on a home is anywhere near that of finding an affordable home to begin with. But try telling that to Jeffrey Fried, a lawyer in Manhattan, who with his wife, Caryn, a sales engineer for a Manhattan software company, closed four months ago on a split-level house in Jericho on Long Island. 
"After we moved in, I said to my wife, 'We're not moving any more,' " Mr. Fried said. 
Part of that frustration reflected their search for a house, a search that Mr. Fried said probably took them through almost 100 houses. "A lot of times we'd see three houses at night during the week," he said, "and on weekends we'd sketch out the best plan of action that would allow us to see as many as four open houses in a single day." 
But it wasn't just the interminable house hunting that led to Mr. Fried's vow to stay put. Almost as upsetting, he said, was closing day, when all the interested parties were gathered together waiting for everything to be legitimized -- only to learn that the required homeowners insurance policy on their property had not been properly issued.
"The insurance broker had sent it to me dated from November 2000 to November 2000, instead of to November 2001," Mr. Fried said. "I called him to ask him to fax us a valid certificate, but he was at lunch so we had to wait and wait. Finally, at the end, everybody sat around with their hands out, and we wound up handing out checks all over the place."
Most closings, however, even for first-time buyers, turn out to be relatively painless, and even postponed closings are rarely as insurmountable as they appear. "If for some reason they don't close, they wonder about such things as where they're going to sleep that night," Mrs. Sullivan said. "But most of the time things work out smoothly because the parties involved usually cooperate with each other, especially if they keep their egos out of it."
Things went smoothly indeed for Robert Jackson, a nurse practitioner who with his wife, Pamela, a social worker in Westchester County, recently bought a four-bedroom house for themselves and their two sons in Greenburgh, near White Plains. "We didn't know what to expect at the closing," Mr. Jackson said, "but we had heard a lot of horror stories."
One such story was that they could expect to hang around for hours and hours during the closing. Another was that they should take lots of blank checks because closing was going to cost them a small fortune.
"But we were in and out in less than three hours," Mr. Jackson said, "and we only had to write two or three checks." 
Mr. Jackson attributed the relatively painless closing to Jessica Bacal, a lawyer in Katonah, in northern Westchester County. "She drilled us in what to expect," he said, "and she and the seller's attorney had worked out everything before we got there."
STILL, as the Lauritano and Fried experiences show, even under the best of conditions the journey from contract to ownership involves a series of steps that, although intended to insure an orderly transfer, often induce anticipatory Sturm and Drang, especially in home buyers new to the process. 
Those steps include the mortgage application and its approval, the sales agreement, home insurance and title insurance to certify that the property is free of liens and easements. That journey also frequently includes the guidance of a lawyer, a termite inspection and the hiring of a house inspector to comb the property to see if anything needs to be repaired. 
At the closing, where the mortgage lender actually presents the check to the buyer, who then presents it to the seller, the buyer should be prepared to write checks for real estate taxes, the prorated cost of utilities, including oil left in the tank, as well as recording taxes and, in some parts of the metropolitan area (but virtually unheard of in Connecticut) a tip for the "closer." The closer, who is usually an independent contractor (and sometimes a lawyer) hired by by the title company for the closing, is the factotum who helps control the flow of paperwork and thereby helps set the closing's tempo. 
Closing costs in the New York metropolitan area typically run 5 to 7 percent of the purchase price of a home, so the buyer of, say, a $250,000 house should be prepared to part with at least $12,500 at the closing. 
Ms. Bacal, the lawyer whom Mr. Jackson praised for her handling of his house purchase, said she keeps a checklist and gives a copy to her clients so that nothing is overlooked or forgotten as the closing date nears. She added that many real estate brokers are also helpful, because among other things "they tend to help get such things as the electricity, gas and water bills put into the name of the new buyer."
But merely presenting clients with a checklist may not be enough. "Some time ago I told a client to bring checks to the closing for those payments, including the fuel adjustment," Ms. Bacal said. "He brought the checks, but when it came time to write the amount for the fuel adjustment, he said, 'I hope you don't expect me to have money in this account.' When we saw everybody's puzzled look, he said to me: 'You said bring the check. You didn't say anything about having money in the bank to cover it.' " 
Yet buyers and sellers are not the only ones to slip up; the real estate grapevine sags beneath the weight of anecdotes about closing mix-ups. For example, lawyers who forgot to tell their clients to have certified checks at the closing. Or told them the wrong time, day or place. Or the bank officials who scheduled the closing but did not show up themselves.
George Tzimopoulos, a real estate lawyer in Manhattan, told of a client, a lawyer in Pennsylvania, who came to New York to attend the sale of a Manhattan co-op apartment that was part of an estate for which he was the executor. Toward the end of the closing, the bank's lawyer began to distribute checks to the seller, broker and anyone else with a financial interest in the property. 
But when Mr. Tzimopoulos noticed that the check for his client was made out to the wrong person, he requested a corrected check. "When the bank's counsel suggested that the closing be adjourned until the next day, I objected, because he was going back to Pennsylvania that very day," Mr. Tzimopoulos said.
So the bank's lawyer made phone calls until he found a branch that was still open and had somebody there who could issue a new check. Then he hopped into a taxicab, and returned about an hour and a half later with the proper check.
While many steps required to buy a house or a condominium are similar, there are also differences. Buyers of condominiums in Connecticut have five days after receiving ownership documents -- which they must be given before the closing -- in which they can cancel the transaction, Mrs. Sullivan said. "When they do back out," she said, "it's usually because they're not allowed to have animals."
Prospective buyers or their lawyers should examine the condo's financial statements for the last few years, Mr. Tzimopoulos said, and examine the minutes of the board of managers to see if the building requires major repairs or if any lawsuits are pending. 
Purchases of co-op apartments, while basically similar to any other home purchase, have differences whose roots are in the type of housing being acquired. In buying co-ops, the purchase is not of real property but of shares in a corporation that give the owner the right to live in the apartment. 
Those hoping to buy a co-op must present the co-op board with a written commitment for the loan and provide detailed financial and personal data, data on which board members are likely to base their approval or rejection. And they would probably be wise to have the cooperative bylaws and the proprietary lease to the apartment reviewed by a lawyer or someone else familiar with the law governing co-ops.
There is no law in New York, New Jersey or Connecticut requiring a buyer to hire a lawyer or buy title insurance, Ms. Bacal said. "But I wouldn't represent someone who would not purchase title insurance," she said. "It exists to protect the buyer."
Stuart A. Christie, a former real estate lawyer in Manhattan and now assistant director of commercial real estate leasing for Trinity Real Estate, is equally adamant that buyers protect themselves with title insurance. "It took me years to understand that the basic principle of real estate ownership is your right to the property you own," Mr. Christie said. "And title insurance insures that you have that right. If you have title insurance and it turns out that the people who sold you the property don't own it, or if there's there's some other problem with the ownership of the property, you're insured against loss." And unless there is a clear title to the property, he added, "no bank will ever lend any amount of money."
That is also true of additions to a property that for whatever reason are not approved or violate a state or local ordinance. Mr. Tzimopoulos said he had a friend who bought a house in Glen Cove, N.Y., that had a deck in the rear, but it turned out that the deck had not been approved. "But the bank made approval a condition of making the loan," Mr. Tzimopoulos said, "so because they were scheduled to close in a week or two, he tore the deck down." 
There is also no legal requirement that buyers hire an inspector to check on the condition of the property, although some lenders insist on it to reduce the odds of being stuck with a white elephant because the buyer could not afford to replace the boiler, pipes, roof and the many other things that can go wrong.
"Not every buyer wants an inspection, especially a first-time buyer," Mrs. Sullivan said, "because they have their minds set on the house and it's hard to temper their excitement. When they do hire inspectors, some of them don't even bother to spend time with them. So sometimes I say to them, 'You'd spend more time inspecting your auto than you'll spend looking at this house, and the house will cost you 10 times the cost of the car.' " 
Woody Dawson, a longtime house inspector in Cheshire, Conn., said the main reason people do not want their prospective house inspected is that they want the property so badly that either they do not care what the inspector finds or they are afraid of what a thorough inspection might find. 
"The one thing buyers should understand is that there is no perfect house, no matter how much you pay for it," Mr. Dawson said, "and my best advice to sellers is that they have their property inspected before putting it up for sale, so that there are no surprises."
THE final stages of taking possession of a home can be full of surprises, and not all of them good. 
Pat Alberelli, a clinical data coordinator at Burke Rehabilitation Hospital in White Plains, had received approval from Anvil Mortgage Banking Ltd. of Orangeburg, N.Y., for a loan of slightly more than $200,000. She was planning to move her family last month from an apartment in Mount Vernon to a three-bedroom house in Cortlandt Manor, in northern Westchester County, that she was buying with her son Angelo Infelice. 
But the day before the scheduled closing, she received a phone call from her lawyer, Ms. Bacal, telling her that Anvil's bank attorney had phoned to say there was no financing available for the closing. "The next day I read in the newspaper what the problem was," Ms. Bacal said. The New York State Banking Department had suspended Anvil's license for 30 days and was considering revoking it altogether because, it said, the company had "routinely engaged in deceptive acts and practices" 
Among other things, the banking department said, Anvil had accepted $500 application fees from 7,633 mortgage seekers last year -- a total of almost $4 million -- but "could not reasonably expect to be able to fund any significant portion of the applications" because it had only $5 million available.
Mrs. Alberelli said she was one of many who had paid Anvil a $500 application fee at one of its many widely advertised seminars for first-time homeowners. Eric Kotch, Anvil's president, said that the company had acted lawfully, adding that it had "helped hundreds of first-time buyers' purchase homes" and that he looked forward to the hearing before the New York Banking Department.
In the meantime, Ms. Bacal contacted the Newburgh, N.Y., branch of the CTX Mortgage Company of Dallas and arranged a loan with what she and Mrs. Alberelli said was a better rate than that initially promised by Anvil. As a result, Mrs. Alberelli was able to close last Monday and moved in two days later. "It's hard to believe that nightmare is over," she said, knee-deep in boxes.
"One reason I was able to arrange a mortgage and quick closing is that Patti kept all her documents from the beginning," Ms. Bacal said. "So she was able to produce all the necessary papers, including tax returns and W-2 forms. Plus the seller permitted Patti's son Angelo to make a minor repair required by CTX." 
Because everybody cooperated, Ms. Bacal said, this was one time that a closing was concluded to the satisfaction of everyone involved. As an afterthought, she said, "If only all closings were as tranquil, not to mention expeditious."

At a Closing, the Check Writing Never Seems to End
At the closing last week for the house Pat Alberelli and her son Angelo Infelice bought for $194,900, checks were written for the following services and taxes:
Title company, $3,675, including mortgage tax and state, county and town taxes for 2001 that are due next month.
Bank loan origination fee, $1,600.
Escrow fund to cover school tax, county tax and homeowner's insurance, $1,600.
State mortgage tax, $1,472 (an additional $499 was paid by the bank).
Per diem interest on first month mortgage payment, for which the principal would not be due for another month, $820. 
Bank's lawyer, $750.
Appraisal, $360.
Mortgage recording fee, $96.
Deed recording fee, $90.
Inspection fee, $75.
Credit report, $12.
Payment for Mrs. Alberelli's lawyer, Jessica Bacal, was "at the high end" of Ms. Bacal's usual fee "that ranges between $1,000 and $1,500 if there are just the normal headaches."

HEADLINE: Back From the Abyss 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: WEST ORANGE 

 BODY:
THE for-sale signs, like symptoms of some fast-spreading malady, began cropping up all over town until nearly 600 homes were on the market, many of them languishing for months, their prices edging downward. It was 1997 and despite the region's revved-up economy, West Orange looked as if it were sliding into the abyss. 
 Perched at the edge of New Jersey's most distressed urban places, this classic postwar suburb of 45,000 people faced a welter of seemingly intractable problems. Taxes were soaring, test scores at its vaunted schools were sagging and the town administration, besieged by a string of well-publicized scandals, appeared to be spinning its wheels. White flight, the self-perpetuating sickness that helped drain vitality from prewar suburbs like Irvington, East Orange and Orange, looked as if it had found another victim. 
 But in a remarkable act of self-resuscitation, West Orange pulled itself from the brink. Then, according to real estate agents and residents, it began to thrive. In the past two years, property values have jumped 40 percent, and with fewer than 200 houses on the market, bidding wars have become the norm. Developers, bullish on West Orange's future, have put up more than 2,000 town houses, some of them fetching a half-million dollars. The auto theft epidemic that once claimed 425 cars a year has been cut by 21 percent. And last summer, in a public relations bonanza that lured tens of thousands of tourists to its 12 square miles, the town played host to the Cow Parade, an arts event shared including such cities as Zurich and Stamford, New York and Chicago.
Optimism, most everyone agrees, has suddenly replaced dread. "West Orange has become easy for me to sell," said Ken Baris, a local real estate agent. "The bad news seems to be a distant memory."
Not that West Orange is a model of municipal perfection. Taxes remain steep, the schools have become overcrowded, and the urbanized slice of town abutting Orange is still struggling for stability. Retired residents, weighed down by high property taxes, continue to depart for less expensive towns to the south and west. 
But for the time being, West Orange is weathering the kind of shifting demographics that might have devastated a community a generation ago. Although whites still dominate the town, with 62 percent of the population, the latest census figures released about 10 days ago show that the town's black population grew by 250 percent in the last 10 years, to 7,848 from 2,286. The number of Hispanics, both black and white, nearly tripled to 4,514 from 1,640 in 1990.
As a model, its successes and failures offer valuable lessons.
Rather than fret about the implications of such change, West Orange officials have publicly embraced the numbers as proof that theirs is a community that welcomes diversity.
"To me it shows that people here are enlightened thinkers," said John F. McKeon, the mayor since 1998. "I think we are a shinning example of a place that accepts and celebrates all kinds of people."
A new suburb that until recently was predominantly white, West Orange is grappling with the kinds of change that many American suburbs can one day expect to face. 
While it has benefited from the region's thriving economy -- and its proximity to Manhattan, 15 miles to the east -- West Orange's turnaround was jump-started by resurgent civic activism and public relations pizazz inspired by a newly elected slate of leaders who refused to let their town slide into a cycle of despair.
Residents and real estate executives largely credit the mayor -- an energetic lawyer who won office by promising to clean house -- with helping to turn the tide of pessimism.
"When I came into office, the community had lost faith in itself and many people were ready to run away from our problems," Mr. McKeon said. "What I always would tell people, to borrow a phrase from F.D.R., is that we have nothing to fear but fear itself."
For West Orange and many of its older residents, fear was something they had known in another era. Largely undeveloped until World War II, the town grew at first with the Jews, Italians and Irish who had eagerly left Newark and its densely built suburbs.
Like many new communities of the 1940's, 50's and 60's, West Orange was a place well insulated from the urban woes that only seemed to intensify after the 1967 riots in Newark, just two miles away. Its schools were among the nation's finest and its ranch and split-level houses were affordable for a population that was solidly middle class. 
As of the 1980 census, the town was TK white. But like other enclaves just west of Newark, West Orange began to attract upwardly mobile blacks in the 1980's. While some longtime residents joined the exodus to the fast-growing subdivisions of Morris, Monmouth and Ocean Counties, most saw no reason to leave. 
It was in the 1990's, however, that the trickle turned into a flood. Most of those leaving were the town's original settlers, now empty nesters, who were looking for smaller homes and lower taxes. But the spate of bad publicity that buffeted the town in the mid-1990's clearly shook public confidence in West Orange's future.
In a political melodrama that persisted for years, the police chief, Robert Spina, was convicted of abusing his wife. In 1996, a year later, he was convicted of warning a drug suspect about an impending police raid. Perhaps more troubling to many was that the police chief was the son of Samuel A. Spina, the mayor of 17 years. 
For months, Mr. Spina refused to dismiss his son, ignoring candlelight vigils and a Town Council resolution demanding his suspension. (Mr. Spina's son had replaced Edward Palardy, who resigned after pleading guilty to federal tax evasion charges. Another black eye came in 1998, when the former township attorney, Joseph Dooley Jr., was indicted on charges that he stole $179,000 from clients in his private practice.) 
After Mr. Spina's conviction, residents began a petition drive to force a recall election for the mayor. In April 1997, after the group had collected 5,500 signatures, Mr. Spina announced that he would not seek re-election. 
But by then, property values were slumping, fueled by the growing glut of homes on the market. A spate of auto thefts contributed to the sense of insecurity.
"Every time we seemed to recover from the bad news, something else would come along," said Kevin Keogh, 35, the council president, who won office in 1998 along with three other newcomers. "Friends were moving away and no one had confidence in the town. We were really at a low point."
After his election with 80 percent of the vote, Mr. McKeon set about shaking up the status quo. To forestall further tax increases, he negotiated more favorable contracts with town workers and hired a grant writer who found $500,000 to spruce up the fraying neighborhood near Main Street. To counteract nervousness over crime, he pressed local shopping centers to hire off-duty police officers.
Over the past four years, Mr. McKeon has used spending curbs and new sources of funds to freeze municipal taxes. To help boost the town's self-image, he hired an in-house public relations expert to publicize a flurry of new initiatives, including an anti-hunger campaign that encourages residents to place canned goods at their curb with their trash and recyclables.
A group of residents formed a public relations commission to help spread the good news to real estate agents and the media.
"Frankly, people were misinformed and hearing things that may or may not have been true," said Lisa Scalora, the commission's chairwoman. "We wanted to get the word out that West Orange has a lot to offer."
Part of the challenge stems from West Orange's sprawling geography. Spread across two folds of the Watchung Mountains, it does not have a traditional downtown, and its newer sections lack the majestic pre-war architecture that often draws a lpot of interest among the S.U.V. And while it is well-served by Interstate 280, which cuts through the town's midsection, West Orange has no direct train service to Manhattan, another selling point that has helped revitalize its neighbors. "In some ways, we've been overshadowed by the successes of Montclair, Maplewood and South Orange," Ms. Scalora said. 
"That makes West Orange's job a little more difficult," said. James W. Hughes, dean of the Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "But then again, there are significant price differences, which gives it an affordability advantage."
And in the promotional video and glossy brochures West Orange has produced, the town has relentlessly crowed about its other assets: five golf courses, a slew of high-end restaurants and two forested preserves that comprise a fifth of its 12 square miles. Diversity, public schools and a generous level of services have also become much-touted selling points. 
The recent run-up in house values, real-estate brokers say, is partly a case of catch up. Barbara Margulis, a sales associate at Burgdorff ERA in Livingston, said many homebuyers had been drawn by prices that were appreciably lower than surrounding communities.
"I think all the good P.R. is finally working," Ms. Margulis said. "West Orange is selling very well."
As for the many new arrivals, they say they feel as if they have discovered a bargain. With a $240,000 housing budget, Jessica and Steve Jacobs said they gave up on Livingston, Caldwell and Verona after months of viewing small homes on busy streets.
"All we were able to afford were cramped Cape Cods on tiny lots," said Ms. Jacobs, 32, a school teacher from Bloomfield who has a 2-year old son. "My husband would say, 'It's cute, but where are we going to put the baby?' " 
The large three-bedroom split level they were able to afford in the Pleasantdale section, she said, offset the town's higher taxes. 
But the renewed interest in West Orange has created some unforeseen consequences. The turnover in older housing and surge in new construction has brought a wave of newcomers with school-age children. Having sold off school buildings during an enrollment dip in the 1980's, the town has been struggling to accommodate the wave of new students without large-scale construction. While its schools are still considered among the finest in the state, education officials can not seem to keep up with the influx of newcomers, who have pushed enrollment to 5,900 from 4,452 in 1993. Next year, the board of education expects the school population to surpass 6,200.
REDWOOD elementary school, for example, has 450 students this year, up from 302 in 1993, said the principal, George Dixon. Four trailers set in the parking lot have helped contain the overflow, but a lack of space has forced the school to curb its performing arts program. The gymnasium, which houses the school stage and cafeteria, has to accommodate six lunch periods and three-and-a-half hours of physical education.
"We're frankly running out of creative solutions," said Mr. Dixon, who has on occasion had to give up his office for scholastic activities. "I joke that I'm going to put my desk on wheels."
Education advocates say West Orange is shortchanged by the state's school-aid formula, which provides up to 90 percent of the budgets for places like Orange, East Orange and Newark. West Orange taxpayers, by contrast, provide 90 percent of the town's school dollars. The method for dispensing aid is flawed, they say, because West Orange is categorized as affluent, largely because it includes Llewellyn Park, a 425-acre gated community with some of the state's most expensive homes. 
Mary Ann Roland, a parent who has been lobbying Trenton for relief, says the wealth of Llewellyn Park statistically cancels out the town's large working-class population and its pockets of poverty.
"Most people who live here are two-parent families working hard to make ends meet," Ms. Roland said. "It's just not fair."
In recent years three attempts to bolster the $70 million school budget through public referendums have been voted down, largely by older residents opposed to any tax increase. The West Orange Tax Reform Association has helped direct the taxpayer revolt that killed the initiatives, including one last year that would have raised taxes an average of $288 a year.
John Schmidt, a securities executive who serve as the association president, said the school board could improve its finances by negotiating tougher contracts with the teachers' union and privatizing janitorial and bus services. With an average salary of $61,000 -- compared with the statewide average of $50,000 -- West Orange teachers, he said, are among the best paid in New Jersey. Mr. Schmidt also said he would like to see a reduction in personal days, sick days and the union's generous health and dental benefit package.
"Our teachers get one free period a day," said Mr. Schmidt, a Llewellyn Park resident whose children attend parochial school. "How many people get a 45-minute break for a four to five hour day? They already get three months of vacation."
School board members and education officials say they are already operating with fiscal prudence. West Orange teachers are paid more, they say, because they by and large have more seniority -- and experience -- than the statewide average. They also add that the salaries reflect the going rate in Essex County, which has a higher cost of living than other counties. You get what you pay for, said Ms. Roland, 41, a bookkeeper whose daughter is a 5th grader at Redwood. We have great teachers in this town. Id hate to lose them.
West Orange Advocates for Schools and Community, a group that has been fighting for increased school funding, contends those who oppose the referendums are ultimately hurting their own pocket book. In a few years, these people are going to want to sell their homes, said Jack Quinn, the groups president and a former school board member. By investing in our kids, theyre investing in their property values. 
In the meantime, the superintendent, Jerry P. Tarnoff, said the town is moving forward on scaled-down expansion plans for several schools, including a new gymnasium, cafeteria and science labs for the high school. Obviously were been doing the best we can with limited resources, he said.
Despite the frustration over taxes and overcrowded schools, many lifelong residents say the worst of times are behind them.
"I've seen the good and the bad, and now I'm seeing a lot of good," said Ms. Scalora said. "Everyone feels the buzz, and its just incredible."
Fifteen years ago, several racial incidents at a local school prompted Harold Phipps and some of his neighbors to form The Concerned Black Citizens of West Orange. But those earlier fears of racial strife, Mr. Phipps said, have long since faded.
"These days, black families are moving to all parts of town and finding acceptance," said Mr. Phipps, a resident since 1975. "It's no big deal anymore."
Michael Kay, the planning board chairman, agrees. Several years ago, he and his wife considered moving out of town -- but then had a change of heart.
"We decided we just couldn't live anywhere else," said Mr. Kay, who grew up in West Orange. As the father of a high school freshman, Mr. Kay said he was thankful for the growing diversity.
"I like the fact that my kids are going to school with kids from all over the world and that there are no issues of discomfort," he said. "I look at it as a giant gift you give your children."

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: ECONOMY; 
TAX REVENUE

BYLINE:  By Anne Ruderman 

 BODY:
 State tax revenue totaled $53 million in February, 3.5 percent below estimates, mainly because of lower corporate and inheritance taxes than projected. 
The state treasury department said that in a budget of $20 billion, a $53 million shortage in one month was not significant. State revenue for the first eight months of fiscal year 2001 came to $13 billion, which was $52 million below the expected total. Anne Ruderman

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS: VOWS; 
Janeen Saltman and Alden Levy

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
CALL it a love story from the annals of the dot-com recession.
 When Janeen Karen Saltman and Alden Ben Levy met face to face for the first time, adoring fireworks did not go off, nor did hearts instantly melt into a puddle of love-addled goo. 
 No, Mr. Levy yelled at her. 
In May 1999, Mr. Levy, known among his friends for his cool sense of humor and elegant manners, had just helped to found an Internet company, iConnect.com, and had hired Ms. Saltman to plan the company's opening-day party for June in downtown Manhattan. Ms. Saltman, a tall, slender brunette with a giddy lilting laugh, had just started her own party-planning firm, JKS Events. 
Mr. Levy, with allergies so intense they can require frequent medication, had only two requests: no shellfish, no fragrant flowers. Somehow the signals got crossed. When Mr. Levy, now 35, arrived for the party, he found lushly blooming, heavily fragrant bouquets of gardenias scattered around. 
"The first thing I said to her was, 'The flowers stink!' " Mr. Levy recalled. "I had to run home and take an allergy pill." He added, "Janeen thought I was going to fire her on the spot." 
Ms. Saltman, fearful of losing a new client, offered to remove the flowers immediately. Mr. Levy growled at her to come around the next day to pick them up. And that was when he knew something other than a wheezing cough was stirring deep within him. "I could tell that he was feeling some chemistry," said Nick Patnaik, a college friend of Mr. Levy's who attended the party.
It was with some trepidation that Ms. Saltman, now 29, stopped by the offices that day. But Mr. Levy, emboldened by antihistamines, had softened his approach. He asked her out for dinner and she said yes -- on the condition that he hire her to plan more parties for him. Things moved quickly from there. They went out the next night, and the next. They had brunch with her parents. Ms. Saltman still remembers where they went and what she wore on their first three dates -- a major sign of feminine infatuation. ("On our second date, it was a little black sweater set and open-toed shoes," she said.)
About a year after they met, Mr. Levy built a Web site asking her to marry him. While Mr. Levy, who said his company "is on its last legs," switched to working as an Internet consultant, Ms. Saltman planned their wedding: a masquerade ball on March 10 at the Essex House in New York.
Ms. Saltman, who loves theatricality, asked the 150 guests to wear masks with their ball gowns and dinner jackets, and so the couple exchanged vows before an audience of plumed swans, clowns, a pig, a gorilla and sequined butterflies. The bridesmaids wore white, with feathered wings affixed to their shoulders -- "ethereal birds," Ms. Saltman called them. The bride, who said she was dressed as Queen Esther, the Jewish heroine from the Purim story, wore a light green dress with a tiara. After the ceremony, Mr. Levy threw on a velvet cloak and a "Phantom of the Opera" mask for the reception. 
Ms. Saltman said that part of what drew her to Mr. Levy was that even though he can be intense about his own work, he is also enthusiastic about her career. "Alden is behind me all the way," she said, waving her hand at the room of costumed guests. "Most guys would think this was just too crazy."
At the wedding, Curtis Hougland, a friend of the couple, who wore his eyeglasses awkwardly over his mask, said, "The most important thing to remember is that it is a testament to her great love for him that she stuck by his side through the dot-com bust."
The bride mused that there is something about a man with terrible allergies that "brings out nurturing qualities" in a woman. "Anyway, now we don't have to deal with it," she added, noting that while Mr. Levy is still her most difficult client, he always watches his medication during allergy season. 
"And I only bring home nonfragrant flowers," she said with a laugh. "Tulips. He likes tulips."

HEADLINE: PULSE; 
More Carry, Less Cash

BYLINE:  By Ellen Tien 

 BODY:
For the last few years of the handbag timeline -- from Gucci bamboo to Prada bowling -- the only way to own a fabulous pocketbook was by emptying your wallet. This season, whether due to a tottery economy or just a much-needed dose of common sense, retailers are offering handbags with high brand appeal at less than half the price of the status staples. 
 For spring, Saks Fifth Avenue came out with its first private label line, which features a trim woven leather pocketbook (left) with red patent leather trim called Venetian Blind, $290, and the Hornback tote, an alligator-pressed calf bag with bamboo handles, $395. 
 Bergdorf Goodman introduced bags by the chic midpriced label TruTru, including a large, luxurious leather carryall for $395. And next month, Lancel, the popular Paris-based leather company, will open its first flagship store in New York, which means polished leather handbags with Parisian appeal at a starting price of $200.
Leave it to French women to figure out the fashion math: you can't spend all your money on a pocketbook when you still have to buy . . . shoes.

HEADLINE: COPING; 
Drug Laws Hurt Children Too

BYLINE:  By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
THE three young people came from Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn, and what they had in common was that one or both of their parents had spent years in prison under the 1973 Rockefeller drug laws.
 Those laws set stiff penalties for drug possession and use, swelling the state prison population to 70,000 today from 13,000 in 1973. On Tuesday, as part of the Drop the Rock campaign to repeal the laws, about 35 children are to go before legislators in Albany to tell their stories. 
 The children gave a preview of those stories recently when they gathered in the office of Robert Gangi, the executive director of the Correctional Association of New York, a prison watchdog and policy group. The association is one of many religious, women's and prisoners' rights groups seeking what they call a more humane and cost-effective and less racially biased way to fight drugs. 
Ninety-four percent of the drug offenders in New York State prisons are black or Latino, even though studies show that most drug users and sellers are white.
The children talked about the human cost. They were fuzzy on some details, but what emerged were portraits of parents with drug problems. Imprisonment created a wave of problems for the children, as grandparents or the foster system stepped in.
Using children to humanize complex political and social issues is an old tactic. But Drop the Rock is a noble effort with special resonance in many black and Latino neighborhoods, where generation after generation of mothers, fathers, sisters and brothers have been sent to prison for long stretches. Drug policy experts say many of those convicted belonged in treatment, school or work programs instead. The children's stories are not just reasons for advocating the repeal of the Rockefeller laws. They are vivid reminders of the lingering effects of drug use and the persistence of the crack epidemic of the 80's. That horrific epoch fractured families, caused neurological damage in children and produced high rates of crime and AIDS infection.
"We have eliminated whole generations of parents," said Dennis Walcott, president of the New York Urban League. "People lose sight of the problem because of a good economy, but with the economy slowing down, I'm not sure what will happen."
Leonette A., 13, who lives in Manhattan, said her mother went to prison for unknowingly holding drugs for a drug-dealing friend. It was the same year that Leonette's father died. Her brothers were 2 and 3 at the time and began acting out as they got older.
Leonette, an eighth grader, said she became severely withdrawn after being sent to live with her grandparents, who had a hard time handling three young children. She also remembers hitting her classmates for no reason.
Sha-king Graham, 19, from the South Bronx, said both his parents were drug addicts who were in and out of prison for years for drug selling and possession. He was born addicted to crack and had problems learning to read. He was abused in a series of foster homes, he said.
After he and his four sisters were left on their own, one sister was killed in a confrontation with the police only minutes after her drug-dealing boyfriend gave her a gun to hold.
"I've seen it all," Mr. Graham said. "I think I just numbed myself to my surroundings."
Those hoping that the Rockefeller laws will be repealed say too many of the people swept up by the laws were like these parents: nonviolent drug addicts who desperately needed treatment. It costs $32,000 a year to keep an inmate in prison, compared with $17,000 to $21,000 for residential drug treatment.
Mr. Gangi said no one associated with Drop the Rock thought that people who use or sell drugs should go scot-free just because they had children. Rather, he said, a more nuanced approach was needed.
One of the toughest provisions of the Rockefeller law mandates a 15-year-to-life sentence to anyone, even first-time offenders, convicted of selling two ounces or possessing four ounces of cocaine or heroin. 
Nine days ago, nearly two months after he pledged to loosen the Rockefeller laws, Gov. George E. Pataki released a detailed bill that would sharply reduce some prison drug sentences, but would also add new penalties for marijuana convictions. Last Monday, the State Assembly responded with its own proposal, which includes greater judicial discretion and more drug treatment options. 
Critics of the old law hope that whatever bill is finally adopted takes into account these things that cannot be quantified: the broken families, the disrupted lives.

SECTION: Section 3; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 945 words

HEADLINE: PRELUDES; 
Therapy for Dot-Com Survivors

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
'HI, I'm Jen, and I'm an entrepreneur. I work 72 hours a week." Pause. "Sometimes I feel totally, utterly alone, like I'm on a rickety old bridge connecting huge gorges in an Indiana Jones movie. It's nice to know there are other people out there who feel the same way I do."
 Many in the audience nodded knowingly as Jen Dalton shared her growing frustrations of operating a fledgling business in an increasingly tough economy. The 65 others who had gathered at Microsoft's campus in Mountain View, Calif., to attend a half-day "Sustainable Entrepreneur" workshop last month took turns talking about their troubles. Many had seen their dot-com businesses fail in recent months, and they were there to take an "honest look at the way they are running their lives and how it's not working," Nicholas Hall, 31, the workshop organizer, said. 
 Some people might call it group therapy for Adult Survivors of Dysfunctional Dot-Coms. Whatever the label, it is the latest coping mechanism for entrepreneurs whose companies have gone under or are struggling. But instead of the now-ubiquitous "pink slip" parties for the rank and file, these self-help workshops target the man or woman at the top. 
"The entrepreneur himself had this huge idea, got a jillion people to sign on and then it all fell apart," said Ms. Dalton, 30, who started a career- and business-consulting company called idea girl in San Francisco six months ago. "You think of yourself as the biggest loser."
Joan Indursky-DiFuria, co-founder of the Money, Meaning and Choices Institute in San Francisco -- the folks who put the phrase "Sudden Wealth Syndrome" into the lexicon -- said many of her clients are now dealing with "Sudden Loss of Wealth Syndrome." Symptoms include feelings of shame, guilt and humility. "Even though they know the economy is largely responsible, they thought they should have been able to conquer it," she said. The institute's goal, she added, is to help people find balance between work, life and money. 
There are other places where failed entrepreneurs can go to explore their real and perceived inadequacies. Since January, Nigel Henry, 39, a business coach in Oakland, Calif., has been running his day-long "Master Unleashed" workshops twice a month in the San Francisco Bay area (fee: $150 each). He said being laid off or watching your company fall apart is a good time to ask the question, "What am I doing on the planet?" Although he also does individual coaching, he believes the group dynamic is more powerful. "Each person brings a new dimension on the same subject, so you get the benefit of everybody's perspective," he said.
In February, Mr. Hall, who also founded Startupfailures.com, an online support community, unveiled the first "Sustainable Entrepreneur" seminar, which costs about $100. (Participants can opt to take part in a three-month follow-up luncheon series for additional fees.)
The biggest problem, Mr. Hall said, is that the identity of so many entrepreneurs is wrapped up in their companies, and when the businesses die, "they're left without a personal vision."
"One guy, a graphic designer, lost all of his clients in one month," he said. "All of them gone, boom. I'm trying to help entrepreneurs see how to fit their work into their life as opposed to fit their life into their work."
That is not always easy to do, as Mr. Hall discovered when he invited visitors to his Web site to take a survey about how they felt after their businesses failed. Two-thirds of the 400 people who responded said their physical well being had suffered and their confidence was rattled.
Mr. Hall also knows about failure; he has seen three of his start-up companies (in financial services and the beverage and Internet industries) implode. Now, it seems, he has found success in failure.
"There are so many workshops that help start-ups raise money and things of that nature," he said. "I hope the kind of work I'm doing becomes more of a holistic approach to training for the entrepreneurs."
If the New Age vibe seems a little prominent, well, it is. On the other hand, the workshops are not all deep breathing and sun salutations. Mr. Hall injects humor throughout, like the contest to see who had the most credit card debt or who had taken the shortest vacation. (Winners were given scissors and sun block.) But participants are also asked to take long, hard looks at their goals. "We look at the model of sustainability, some people refer to it as a balanced life," Mr. Hall said. "I look at the different practices in my life that have enabled me to enjoy the journey, despite the fact that some of my start-ups haven't worked out so well."
SOME people, of course, shun the group atmosphere and seek one-on-one therapy. Dr. James P. Osterhaus, a clinical psychologist in the greater Washington area and co-author of "The Thing in the Bushes" (Pinion Press, 2001), a book about preventing business failure, sees a number of recovering dot-comers both in his private practice and at the Armstrong Group, a management consulting firm in Fairfax, Va., where he also works. "A lot of the work we do is grief work," he said. "They lost money, a lifestyle. They work through the stages of grief: shock, disbelief, anger, depression and acceptance."
Ms. Dalton, for one, compared the life of an entrepreneur to the life of a soldier. "The thing is, we're all fighting by ourselves and our failures are that much more intense because they are ours alone," she said.
Her goal, she said, is to try to live in the here and now, not compare herself to her seemingly more successful peers.
And if she happens to make $300,000 a year in the process, well, she certainly won't complain.
