HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
2 Prophets Of Disaster See Trouble Once Again

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
MR. DOOM and Dr. Gloom are back. You remember them. They were the Wall Street economists who in the 1970's argued that the Federal Reserve had missed the boat, until Paul A. Volcker came along. They are pushing a new message today -- that the Fed has once again missed the boat. And so far there is no salvation.
 The gloomy pair are Henry Kaufman and Albert M. Wojnilower. In those earlier days, they were the powerful chief economists at Salomon Brothers and the First Boston Corporation, respectively, and their dim outlooks shook markets. Salomon and First Boston are gone now, obscured in mergers, but Mr. Kaufman and Mr. Wojnilower, operating as independent financial consultants, have sustained their gloom. For months, they have warned that a new disaster is unfolding. 
 For them, stock-price inflation -- and now deflation -- have come to play just as important a role in shaping the economy as ordinary inflation in goods and services, but the Fed has refused to acknowledge this shift. Certainly a family's multiplying stock market wealth or, conversely, its evaporating portfolio are powerful influences on economic activity, just as powerful as a few dollars more for groceries, or a few hundred dollars more or less for a new car. 
Mr. Kaufman says Alan Greenspan's failure to acknowledge this shift "was a massive contributing factor to the stock market bubble," now pricked. Mr. Wojnilower adds that the Fed chairman should have started warning back in the 1990's that the surge in stock prices was too dependent on credit -- not so much margin debt, but shares purchased with consumer loans, through mortgage refinancing and home equity loans, and corporate borrowing.
"We're in a mess," Mr. Wojnilower said, adding that there is no way to "restart the economy. We will have a period of very modest growth."
The stock markets, in sum, have driven the economy for the past five years instead of the other way around -- a structural change that the Fed still has not recognized. Ben S. Bernanke, a Princeton economist whose research reflects Fed thinking, put it this way last week, "As long as the Fed keeps its eye on economic growth and on stabilizing consumer price inflation, then the economy will remain stable even in the face of large stock market fluctuations." 
Mr. Kaufman and Mr. Wojnilower rose to fame by recognizing an earlier structural change, and its consequences, before others did. Deregulation in the 1970's had removed ceilings on interest rates. As a result, the Fed, trying to control inflation, encountered difficulty in applying the usual tactic of raising interest rates to discourage lending. That had slowed the economy in the past and with it the inflation rate. But without the ceilings, lenders simply raised the interest that they charged for loans and thus maintained a profitable spread over the rising cost of attracting deposits to lend.
"It did not matter how high rates went as long as spreads were preserved," Mr. Kaufman said. Borrowers, in turn, counted on inflation to make their loans cheaper to repay.
With Mr. Volcker installed as chairman, the Fed belatedly recognized the dangers in this structural shift and began to shove up rates. Understanding the dynamics, Mr. Kaufman and Mr. Wojnilower forecast that the Fed would have to get rates above 20 percent to discourage borrowing and cut inflation. They were right, but they were forever dubbed Dr. Gloom (Mr. Wojnilower) and Dr. Doom (Mr. Kaufman), sobriquets the severe 1981-1982 recession validated.
Now the economy is once again restructured -- this time around stocks -- and the edifice is once again unwinding. Rising stock prices, for example, financed a rush of capital spending, which in turn fueled the economic boom. In a falling market, this spending is being cut back. Similarly, consumers financed some spending by selling stock. Falling prices dilute this tactic.
Rather than acknowledge the bubble and the market's bull-in-a-china-shop role in the economy, Mr. Greenspan spoke in 1996 of irrational exuberance as a possibility, but insisted thereafter that the market responded to the economy, not the other way around. If a bubble existed, he said, that would be evident only after it burst, and the Fed would deal with the blow by cutting rates.
Well, the bubble is bursting and the Fed is cutting rates. That is perhaps the only remedy left. All the earlier opportunities to soften the market and its impact on the economy -- by leaning on lenders, for example, and by instilling in Americans the dangers of an overvalued market -- are gone now.
Like everyone, Dr. Doom and Dr. Gloom are scrambling for solutions. While Dr. Doom wants the Fed to cut rates by a full percentage point when it meets on Tuesday, Dr. Gloom favors a tax cut for shareholders. Either solution is grasping at straws.

HEADLINE: Web Comes Up Fast on the Outside 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG 

 BODY:
IT was post time at the Happy Valley Racecourse here, and Serena Yuen hopped nervously from foot to foot.
 Usually, Ms. Yuen studies the odds and past records of horses before deciding which one to back. But as she clutched her betting stub, she acknowledged that something less scientific had lured her: the name "Forever Gold." 
 As the horses thundered by, Ms. Yuen's face registered the hope and pain familiar to anyone who has ever blown $50 on an also-ran. "I couldn't even see the horse's shadow," she said bitterly, as Forever Gold turned to dross. Then anger gave way to fresh hope, as Ms. Yuen unfolded a racing form and plotted her strategy for the next race. 
Ms. Yuen, a homemaker in her 40's, is one of more than a million Hong Kongers who bet regularly on horse racing. Each year, they pour nearly $11 billion into the coffers of the Hong Kong Jockey Club, based on shrewd calculation, odd hunches or the simple belief that a horse named Forever Gold cannot lose.
In the process, they have transformed the Jockey Club into a money machine -- a giant cash register sitting at the heart of this pecuniary city. The club gives away the bulk of its profits in donations, which makes it by far the largest charity in Hong Kong and one of the largest in the world. Measured by the dollars it donates each year, it rivals the Rockefeller Foundation.
"It's hard to overstate the influence of the Jockey Club," said Michael DeGolyer, the director of the Hong Kong Transition Project, an academic survey of public attitudes here. "It's like the most prestigious golf club, the Kentucky Derby and the Carnegie Foundation, all rolled into one."
For 117 years -- through war, Japanese occupation and Hong Kong's rough passage from British colony to Chinese metropolis -- nothing has disrupted this efficient parting of gamblers from their money.
Until the Internet. 
The explosive growth of online gambling has helped erode the Jockey Club's revenue by 10 percent from its peak in 1997. The number of Hong Kong Internet users who visit gambling sites has nearly doubled in the last six months, and the Jockey Club faces a rising threat to its once-impregnable franchise.
"If this doesn't get curbed, we could really see things fall off a cliff," said Lawrence T. Wong, an aerospace engineer and former Ford Motor executive who has run the Jockey Club since 1996. 
Mr. Wong estimates that the Jockey Club loses about $7 billion a year to unauthorized gambling on races, which in Hong Kong refers to any bets that are not placed through the club. While much of that goes to the illegal bookmakers who have always loitered in the shadows of Happy Valley, a growing percentage is flowing to offshore Internet sites with names like Easybets.com.
IN 1995, there were fewer than a dozen online gambling sites. Today, analysts figure there are 700 to 1,200. Many operate in Caribbean countries like Antigua, the Bahamas and the Cayman Islands, beyond the reach of law enforcement agencies in the United States and Europe, let alone Hong Kong.
The Internet sites offer customers the convenience of wagering from their own PC's on basketball, soccer, tennis and Formula One auto racing, not to mention horse racing. Because the sites are not taxed and have little overhead, they can afford to offer a better deal to bettors than the Jockey Club.
NetValue Ltd., a research firm, estimates that 41 percent of Internet users in Hong Kong, or 442,590 people, visited at least one online gambling site in December. That compares with 36 percent the previous month and 22 percent in October.
Internet gambling is also growing in Europe and the United States. NetValue, based in Paris, estimates that three million people a month in Britain visit gambling sites. In the United States, nearly 35 million people do. 
"In most businesses, you can build entry barriers, whether it's investment or labor," Mr. Wong said. "Our fear is that it doesn't take very much to set up a Web site. The revenue growth is not even a straight line; it is exponential. It's a bit like the dot-com phenomenon two years ago."
The specter of accelerating losses has led Mr. Wong and the Jockey Club to organize a very public campaign to amend Hong Kong's gambling ordinance, which was passed 25 years ago. The local government recently introduced a bill in the Hong Kong legislature that would prohibit offshore, Internet gambling.
LOBBYING is a big departure for a club that is accustomed to conducting its affairs -- whether horse racing or philanthropy -- out of the public view. It is also out of character for Mr. Wong, a buttoned-down American businessman who spent 29 years at Ford, much of it in engineering jobs, before rising to run its Taiwan operation in 1993. 
"I'd like to do things quietly," said Mr. Wong. "But we've got to send a message to people about what's legal and what's illegal. Every citizen in Hong Kong should feel this is important. It's their money."
There is a clear subtext: If Hong Kong does not act, it could lose the nearly $148 million inannual charity distributed by the club. That is a problem for a city in which the government provides little social welfare, and in which there is little tradition, outside the club, of private philanthropy.
Moreover, the Jockey Club pays the government $1.6 billion a year in taxes and betting duties. That accounted for 11 percent of Hong Kong's total tax revenue in the 1999-2000 fiscal year. And it is one reason the city can maintain an income tax rate of 15 percent, one of the lowest among developed economies.
"The wealth of the Jockey Club has taken a lot of pressure off the government," said Mr. DeGolyer at the Hong Kong Transition Project. "It has allowed the government to maintain Hong Kong's tradition of free markets."
Still, the club's campaign is stirring a noisy debate here about the desirability, or even practicality, of curbing the patronage of offshore Internet gambling. Despite its reversion to China in 1997, Hong Kong still views itself as a free-market bastion. Some opponents of the legislation say the government has no business restricting the use of Internet gambling services, as long as the sites are licensed in their own territories.
Others contend that the authorities could never enforce a law that banned betting through offshore companies. Just to try, they said, Hong Kong would have to use measures that could infringe on personal privacy, like monitoring e-mail traffic from local Internet service providers to overseas Web sites.
"Should we go this far? Should we limit people's rights?" asked Sin Chung-kai, a member of the legislative council who opposes a sweeping new amendment against offshore gambling.
"Under the proposed legislation, a British person visiting Hong Kong who borrows a mobile phone to place a bet on a Manchester United game would be committing a crime," Mr. Sin said. "That's too harsh."
Mr. Sin, a member of Hong Kong's Democratic Party, said he supported cracking down on unauthorized local companies that offer Internet gambling. But he said that imposing a gambling ordinance overseas -- as the United States has tried to do -- would place Hong Kong in an untenable position.
OTHER critics of the bill say it would have its harshest effects on the Macao Jockey Club in the former Portuguese colony of Macao, 38 miles across the Pearl River delta from Hong Kong. Younger and smaller than its Hong Kong rival, the Macao Jockey Club depends on bets from Hong Kong wagerers for up to 60 percent of its revenue. Barring offshore gambling would choke off that stream.
Mr. Wong acknowledged that Hong Kong could not enforce such a law with complete success. But merely passing it, he said, would demonstrate a commitment to protecting the city's biggest source of charity.
Nor is Mr. Wong content to stop there. He would like Hong Kong to reduce or eliminate its 14 percent betting duty, and to tax the Jockey Club on profits, as if it were a regular corporation. That would let the club offer a higher dividend on bets, making it more competitive with the Internet services.
Just in case his lobbying campaign falls short, Mr. Wong is quietly pushing ahead with a plan to offer online betting on the Jockey Club's own Web site. The club began a pilot program last fall with 500 customers who have telephone betting accounts with the club. Even when the service is expanded, Mr. Wong said, it will be available only to Hong Kong residents.
He said he did not expect the Internet to be a major source of betting revenue for the club, but merely another way for existing customers to gamble. Mr. Wong has reason to play down the project: the club does not want to be seen as exploiting the same technology that it seeks to curb when competitors use it.
"We're proceeding very slowly," Mr. Wong said. "We don't want people to say, 'They have a Web site, so they're like everybody else.' "
At its heart, the debate over online gambling is a debate over the role of the Jockey Club in Hong Kong society. Few dispute the club's contribution, symbolized by the dozens of schools, hospitals, parks -- even an entire university -- built on club donations.
On the other hand, gambling pervades Hong Kong more than many other places. The government even chose to mark the turn of the millennium last year with a midnight horse race. For thousands of people here, betting on the ponies is a debilitating, lifelong habit.
Lo Kin Fad, 56, has come to Happy Valley every week for 20 years. Mr. Lo, a fruit seller, said he generally bets $10 a race several times a night. He was losing on a recent night, but noted that he won $516 on Valentine's Day.
"Sometimes when a horse is losing, I keep betting on him until he wins," Mr. Lo said, pulling nervously at his frayed sweater.
Doris Ho, the manager of charities at the Jockey Club, sums up the ambivalence this way: "A lot of people say, 'The Jockey Club will take care of it; let's leave it to the Jockey Club.' But then they turn around and say, 'We don't like gambling; we don't want off-track betting in our town.' "
DOING good was not uppermost in the minds of the British colonials who began racing horses here in 1846. To build the Happy Valley course, they had to drain a fever-ridden swamp. Sir John Davis, the governor of Hong Kong who approved the plan, did not even mention it in his correspondence to London, for fear that Whitehall bureaucrats would veto the project.
In the early days, horse racing was the province of wealthy colonial clans like the Jardines, founders of the trading firm Jardine Matheson. The Chinese played little role in the sport, except to work as stable hands.
The Jockey Club was formally established in 1884; it admitted its first Chinese members in 1926. By the end of the 1930's, Chinese businessmen had made their way into the owners' circle. It was not until Mr. Wong's appointment in 1996, however, that the club had a chief executive of ethnic Chinese descent.
Racing continued through World War II, when the Japanese occupied Hong Kong, though the Jockey Club was badly demoralized. Imperial Army officers requisitioned the best race horses to ride triumphantly through the colony.
After the war, Hong Kong was inundated by refugees fleeing the Communist revolution in mainland China. Housing was in desperately short supply, and the refugee camps were teeming with tuberculosis.
The Jockey Club, which had been donating money since 1914, decided to formalize its charity. Starting in 1955, it pledged to give away its entire surplus, after taxes and operating expenses. That decision helped the club win the coveted prefix "Royal" from Queen Elizabeth in 1960. (Like most colonial institutions, it dropped that part of its name in 1996 to prepare for the era of Chinese rule.)
The Royal Hong Kong Jockey Club was an indisputably British institution. Its chief executive was usually a retired British general, and the stewards -- members of its board -- were drawn from the British banks and trading firms that dominated Hong Kong's commercial life.
In the club's heyday, it was said that Hong Kong was run by the Jockey Club, Hong Kong Bank, Jardine Matheson and the governor -- in that order. 
Few people feared for the future of the Jockey Club after the handover to China. No less an authority than Deng Xiaoping promised that the races would go on. But even fewer foresaw the Asian economic crisis, which plunged Hong Kong into a deep recession and dulled the public appetite for gambling.
THE Jockey Club's revenue from betting fell in 1998 for the first time. Betting revenue rose 2 percent last year, but Mr. Wong attributed that to an increase in the number of days in the racing season. Average daily attendance and betting revenue has fallen since 1997 at both Happy Valley and Shatin, a newer race course operated by the club in Hong Kong's New Territories.
"We never recovered from the crash," Mr. Wong said.
Given that Hong Kong's economy is growing again at pre-crisis levels, Mr. Wong said he believed that a chunk of the Jockey Club's business had migrated permanently to illegal bookmakers and online gambling services.
Last year, he said, the Hong Kong police raided an illegal bookmaker on a race day at the Shatin course. Though it was only the day's third race, with six more to go, the bookmaker had collected $12 million in bets. If 10 other bookmaking rings like that were operating in Hong Kong that day, Mr. Wong said, their daily take would have equaled that of the Jockey Club.
Old-fashioned illegal bookmaking tends to be controlled by Chinese gangs known as triads. The police have had some success in smashing these rings, but the syndicates are becoming more elusive because they now use laptop computers and operate from hotel rooms across the border in mainland China.
Established gambling services like Victor Chandler, Ladbrokes, and William Hill are another threat. Legal in Britain, these outfits offer betting by telephone on sports like professional basketball and Premier League soccer. Victor Chandler has an office in Hong Kong, where residents can open accounts.
A representative of Victor Chandler told a prospective customer that it did not offer bets on Jockey Club races. He also noted that transactions were processed in the firm's office in Gibraltar -- a proviso that allows Victor Chandler to claim it is not offering gambling in Hong Kong. 
"They are not illegal per se," said Betty Fung, the deputy home secretary of Hong Kong, who oversees gambling. "But the fact that they are unauthorized in Hong Kong means that our revenue, our betting duty, and also charitable donations will be affected if people continue to bet on these games."
MOST elusive of all are the Internet gambling services. Easybets.com, which is registered in Antigua, operates a Chinese-language Web site that offers bets on Hong Kong horse races. With a PC and credit card, betters no longer have to venture out to the track, drop in to one of the Jockey Club's 125 off-track betting centers or even use its telephone betting service.
Just as the Internet dissolves barriers in the world of information, these Web sites make a hash of the rules and regulations that protect one country from activities that are unlawful on its territory but legal elsewhere.
"Normally, you have a traffic cop saying this is the way business is conducted, with the input of both governments," said Timothy P. McNally, the executive director of security at the Jockey Club. "But now, everybody is rolling through the intersection with no stoplights, no controls, no regulation." 
Mr. McNally, recruited by Mr. Wong in 1998, is the former head of the Los Angeles field office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He oversees routine security issues, like trucking millions of dollars in bets to the bank and ensuring that jockeys are not bribed to throw races.
But he also advises Hong Kong's police and anticorruption agency about how to combat online gambling. Among his assignments at the F.B.I. was investigating child pornography rings on the Internet.
For all the warnings about online gambling, Mr. Wong and his lieutenants know that the Jockey Club must also buff its image. Horse racing is seen by many people here as an old person's sport, just as it is in the United States. The image of grim-faced fans clutching racing forms is hardly appealing.
Mr. Wong has tried to counter that by installing sushi bars and fancier seats at the tracks. He also brought in a prominent German horse breeder, Winfried Engelbrecht-Bresges, to upgrade the caliber of the sport.
By offering some of the biggest prizes in racing -- the average purse is $100,000, while the richest, the Hong Kong Cup, is worth $1.8 million -- Hong Kong has lured world-class jockeys and horses to Asia. (The purse for the Kentucky Derby is $1 million.) In its ads, the club promotes jockeys in the same way that the National Basketball Association promotes top players.
"We have to be aggressive because we know there is more and more competition," Mr. Engelbrecht-Bresges said.
SOCCER, in particular, is luring away younger fans and their betting dollars. The World Cup next year is expected to unleash a torrent of betting in Hong Kong -- so much so that the government said this month that it would consider legalizing gambling on soccer matches. If it does, the Jockey Club will most likely argue that it should be the sole agent for taking bets.
The Jockey Club is also no longer shy about its good works. Where once the club donated anonymously, it now requests that beneficiaries put the club's name and insignia on new buildings.
In its annual report, the club lists 170 organizations to which it donated money last year. The gifts ranged from $6.1 million for a youth camp at a hospital to $32,000 to hold a tree-planting day.
"When I joined the club, I found that the attitude here was a bit unhealthy," Mr. Wong said. "We were almost apologetic to society because we were in the gaming business. People thought we were a profit-making company, because we didn't communicate to them where the money went."
So Mr. Wong, trim and 61, finds himself explaining the Jockey Club -- to the public, to the government and to the news media. It is an odd turn of events for a man who, before taking the helm of the club, had spent exactly one day at a race track -- as a young Ford executive in Detroit.
Then again, his memory of that day neatly sums up his current challenge. "I was afraid if anyone saw me," he said, "my career would be over."

HEADLINE: How Did They Value Stocks? Count the Absurd Ways; 
Those Lofty 'New Economy' Measures Fizzle

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
IT has now become painfully clear, and last week's gyrations only added more proof, that Wall Street is a different place than it was even a short time ago. A brutish, bearish market has brought with it deflated hopes and new realities.
 Among the harsh realities one stands out. Of all the hot air generated during the great bull market of the late 1990's, none propelled stock prices further than the notion that new economy stocks were a breed apart and should not be held to stringent, old economy investing standards. Internet companies and cutting-edge telecommunications concerns, after all, were revolutionizing the world. So, the thinking went, their share prices deserved equally radical valuation methods. Out went traditional methods used by securities analysis that prized earnings. In came freewheeling measures of worth, like revenue growth, Web site traffic and even customer "share of mind." 
 "The view was, 'We've got a new technology, therefore it's perfectly okay to have a new way of approaching the income statement and balance sheet,' " said Anthony Maramarco, a portfolio manager at the Babson Value Fund in Boston. "But sooner or later you have to generate cash and if all you're doing is using cash, you can only play that game for so long." 
That game, as investors are learning to their extreme distress, is definitely over. When stocks were galloping ahead, investors were happy to take their eyes off earnings and seize instead upon surging "page views" to justify high stock prices. Who needs positive cash flow when the numbers of "engaged shoppers" are flying? Why bother with the ways of Graham and Dodd, the classic value-hunters, when Wall Street was offering investors the lure of new investing metrics?
Henry Blodget, Merrill Lynch's celebrity Internet analyst, may have put the new economy view best on Jan. 10, 2000, when he wrote in a report, "Valuation is often not a helpful tool in determining when to sell hypergrowth stocks." Mr. Blodget was referring specifically to Internet Capital Group, an incubator of Web companies that was trading at $173.88 then -- and $3 a share now.
But he could have been discussing any one of the many highflying stocks that caught investors' fancies.
In their infatuations, perhaps the biggest mistake investors made during the bull market was to believe corporate propaganda about which numbers supposedly provided the best window on the state of their operations.
"Public relations is driving financial reporting," said Jack Ciesielski, publisher of The Analyst's Accounting Observer newsletter, and president of R. G. Associates, in Baltimore. "Everybody's picking the metric they will be judged on. But investors are partly to blame for not wanting to live with what the earnings were telling them. It sounds lame or unhip but, if the earnings aren't there, why grasp at straws?"
Now, with the prices of almost all these former highfliers in the cellar and the overall stock market deep in bear market territory, investors are seeing how wrong they were to ignore excessive valuation levels and to buy stocks based on ephemera like "engaged shoppers" or so-called pro forma results. Suddenly, new economy rationalizations to buy stocks look as ludicrous as the old economy measures looked hopelessly quaint a year ago. Shellshocked investors -- who have lost almost $4 trillion in market value since a year ago -- are wondering just what hit them and how to pick up the pieces.
Survivors of previous market fads that fizzled have some advice. The best thing investors can do to keep their portfolios safe from future devastation, they say, is to learn from their mistakes. Only by understanding how they allowed themselves to embrace the new economy valuation fad can they inoculate themselves from such ills in the days ahead.
Lesson One is as simple as caveat emptor: when investors rely on others for investment research, they must be extremely careful. Since the analysis provided by most big brokerage firms is tainted by their use of upbeat research reports as magnets for investment-banking deals, the painful truth is that investors who buy and sell individual stocks have to learn to do some of their own research on companies to judge their results and their prospects. Just in time for annual report season, stock investors have to go back to perusing balance sheets and income statements.
'THERE ought to be a law in this country that before you're allowed to buy a stock you have to be able to read its balance sheet," said Bill Fleckenstein, a money manager at Fleckenstein Capital in Seattle. "That's where companies try to hide everything. That's where all the shenanigans show up."
A close scrutiny of balance sheets was decidedly missing during much of the late-1990's bull market, even in many Wall Street analysts' reports. As a result, many investors missed such warning signs as bloating inventories and rising accounts receivables that foretold a slowdown in sales at many technology companies. These included Gateway, Cisco Systems, Nortel Networks and Alcatel.
Steve Galbraith, an equity strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said that in the final years of the technology stock boom, equity investors took on the role of financing fledgling companies -- early in their development -- that venture capitalists had traditionally assumed. Normally, companies cannot go public without a track record that proved their ability to turn a profit.
Not this time around. "The entire seasoning period for relatively high-risk equity investments was condensed into months, not years," Mr. Galbraith said. As a result, in the first quarter of 2000, fewer than one in five companies that made initial public stock offerings had profitable operations. In 1995, almost two-thirds of new issuers were profitable when they took their stocks public.
Another measure of how willing many investors were to suspend their disbelief during the mania was the period in 2000 during which the more money a company lost, the better its stock did, while the more money a company earned, the worse its stock fared. Think Amazon.com, iVillage and Priceline, all of which took pride in the amounts of money they were spending.
Just as investors felt that earnings were no longer a necessary ingredient for stocks to steam skyward, neither did they find reason for concern when companies appeared to be burning through their cash. On July 12, 2000, for example, Michael Parekh, an Internet strategist at Goldman Sachs who oversees a group of analysts that cover 60 Internet companies, including Inktomi, DoubleClick and AOL Time Warner, wrote a report arguing that the cash burned by dot-com companies was "primarily an investor sentiment issue" and not a long-term risk for the sector.
Eight months later, a lack of cash has brought about the demise of hundreds of Internet companies and has hammered the results of leading companies like Yahoo. Mr. Parekh was correct that it was not a long-term risk for the sector. As it turned out, it was an immediate risk.
Mr. Parekh said on Friday that the slowdown in the economy that followed his July report suddenly changed the entire picture. "Cash burn is a critical issue for us and it is not a metric we ignored," he said. "But we've had a whole new set of issues around the economy which temper the pace at which traditional companies are spending on technology. These companies were making progress in the third quarter, then on top of that the universe of all these companies got hit by the economy slowing down."
Of course, analysts like Mr. Parekh cannot be held entirely accountable for the money investors have lost in new economy stocks. Investors themselves must take responsibility for succumbing to a market fad. After all, they allowed themselves to be convinced that these companies were in fact different from traditional concerns and should be subject to less-stringent valuation standards.
Every bull market has its own peculiar investment fad, of course. In the great one of the 1960's, for example, the conglomerate was king. Companies like Litton Industries and Textron thrived by swallowing up other companies on the theory that owning different kinds of businesses with different business cycles would protect them from downturns in the economy.
BETWEEN 1966 and 1969, when the ardor for conglomerates was at its height, investors believed that their share prices could never fall. Then, in 1970, they plunged, and with them went the conventional wisdom.
More recently, the investment fad was to justify exorbitant prices of technology stocks based, in part, on a litany of so-called nonfinancial metrics. These included customer loyalty, Web-site traffic and "engaged shoppers." Never mind that none of these translated into profits or even, in some cases, revenues.
Mary Meeker, a star Internet analyst at Morgan Stanley, was among the many Internet and technology analysts citing upbeat "usage metrics" as reasons to buy stocks. In a report on drugstore.com published in October, Ms. Meeker cited the company's popularity as a Web shopping destination as a reason to own the stock. She noted that page views per user per month rose to 14.9 in the third quarter, up from 12.5 in August. Then she pointed out the superiority of drugstore.com to competitor PlanetRX's monthly page views of 10.3 as an indication that drugstore.com customers were more satisfied.
"Additionally," Ms. Meeker pointed out, "drugstore.com maintained a level of 48 percent engaged shoppers (a unique user who views at least three minutes of content within the category) ahead of PlanetRx, which had 45 percent." No mention of whether an "engaged shopper" ever became a spending shopper. Drugstore.com recently traded at $1.16, down 54 percent from its price when Ms. Meeker penned her report. (PlanetRx, which Nasdaq has de-listed, is trading at 29 cents a share.)
Last week, Ms. Meeker explained that her use of nonfinancial metrics began back in 1993 with Intuit and AOL and had proved, in those cases, to be a fine way to measure future performance. Both companies lost money initially on their customers, but Ms. Meeker said she thought that if they kept their customers happy they could expand their customer base. And that would in turn drive revenues and, later, earnings. She was proven right.
"The value of a business is its future cash flows," Ms. Meeker said. "The challenge is figuring out what those future cash flows are. If a company wins in its marketplace, if the market is attractive enough and big enough, and if we can find the company that is going to be a leader, the challenge is to find out how customers can be monetized."
About drugstore.com, Ms. Meeker said the jury was still out. "These things take a long time to evolve," she said. "If there is a health and beauty market online, we think drugstore will be a leader. If there isn't, the stock will continue to be a disappointment."
Wall Street analysts were not the only ones citing nonfinancial metrics as key to investors. Last year, in its Global Online Retailing Report, Ernst & Young tried to identify performance measures most valued by e-commerce investors. The study of 31 public companies spanned 18 months, beginning in early 1999. In the second quarter of 2000, Ernst & Young found that investors were concentrating on two factors: gross profits (earnings before many expenses like depreciation and interest costs) and total Web-site visits. Net income, perhaps because so many e-commerce companies had none, was not relevant.
Another nonfinancial metric was the so-called share of consumers' minds that a company demonstrated. Homestore.com, for example, had a "leading mind share among consumers" according to a Morgan Stanley research report dated Oct. 20, 2000. The proof for this claim was that approximately 72 percent of the total time spent by Internet users on real-estate-related Web sites in September was spent on Homestore's properties.
But having a leading mind share could not keep Homestore.com's stock from sliding 26 percent to $19.31 since that report.
Ms. Meeker said: "On Homestore.com, our point of view is that many people will look for homes online and Homestore will be in a leading position. We're willing to make a bet that they will be able to monetize those users."
Mr. Ciesielski, the accounting expert, said investors' interest in nonfinancial information was not detrimental when combined with financial analysis. The problem is, during the Internet craze, investors weighed the nonfinancial data too heavily, he said. 
'I USED to cover railroads and airlines, and they used to have this wonderful nonfinancial information every month about miles traveled or carloads loaded," Mr. Ciesielski said. "Analysts looked at that, but just to reinforce where earnings were going to go. They weren't grasping at straws. If carloads were going down, you knew earnings were going down."
Although many chastened investors have sworn off the use of Internet page views or engaged Web shoppers to help them make their stock picks, another bull market promotional practice by corporations continues apace even after the bear has awakened. That is the peddling of so-called pro forma numbers, which eliminate pesky expenses from a company's results and make earnings look better. Using Alice-in-Wonderland explanations, new economy companies said that for them these figures better reflected their operating results than those arrived at using generally accepted accounting principles.
How pro forma earnings are conjured varies by company, but often excluded are line items like interest expenses and payroll taxes, thus burnishing the company's results.
Asking investors to ignore these costs -- which the companies must pay in cold, hard cash -- is asking them to accept a fiction about a company's results.
In the old days, companies would include pro forma numbers in financial statements after an acquisition to reflect how the two newly combined companies would have performed if they had been joined for the entire year before the merger. Now, pro forma numbers mean something much more sinister and are becoming practically ubiquitous. Anyone interested in the traditional earnings number has to dig deep into the press releases.
To measure how common pro forma numbers have become, investors can search the Web sites of BusinessWire.com or PRNewswire.com to find companies using them. In a three-day period alone last week, a search on PRNewswire produced 36 citings of pro forma figures.
Companies accentuating the positive through the use of pro forma numbers include Palm, Intel, Yahoo and Cisco. More obscure companies that do so include Stanford Micro Devices and Engage.
At Yahoo and Cisco, for example, pro forma operating income meant excluding the expense of payroll taxes. At Level 8 Systems, a software provider, a net loss of $4 million in the third quarter last year was transformed into pro forma net income of $1.8 million by adding back noncash charges like depreciation and amortization of intangible assets.
The creativity goes on and on. Mr. Ciesielski thinks that the vast number of corporations using pro forma figures have made earnings releases increasingly dubious. "The whole concept of what's earnings and what's on the cash-flow statement has become so bastardized that nothing makes much sense any more," he said.
INVESTORS can thank the raiders of the 1980's for the current love affair with pro forma numbers, Mr. Ciesielski said. "Back then, people would look at companies with ugly earnings, but they had good cash flow underneath because depreciation was big," he said. The leveraged buyout boom, he said, "was largely fueled by amateurs trying to find companies with big depreciation charges."
"And in the 90's, we all jumped on that, taking out the parts we didn't need to prove our point," he added.
Mr. Ciesielski advises investors to pay no attention to pro forma numbers and to do their own math to find out where companies really stand.
Byron Wien, chief United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley, is fearful that companies that spin their results using pro forma figures could do serious damage to investor confidence in the financial markets. "Corporations have a lot of flexibility in how they report results," he said. "Nobody knows more about the truth than the corporate executives themselves. Taking a short-term view of truth may make things look good in a quarterly report. But it will ultimately catch up with them."
That is a good description of what seems to be happening today.

HEADLINE: The American Risk in Japan 

BYLINE:  By Jeffrey E. Garten; Jeffrey E. Garten, dean of the Yale School of Management, is author of "The Mind of the C.E.O."

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN 

 BODY:
We have often seen how the fate of the American economy cannot be divorced from global markets, and how even a spark abroad can create a fire at home. In 1987, for example, the stock market crash was precipitated in part by a dispute between Washington and Bonn over interest rates and trade. In 1998, a financial crisis that began in Thailand ultimately spread until it forced a dramatic bailout of one of America's largest hedge funds -- a rescue that prevented an implosion of many American banks. Now Japan is the trouble spot that ought to keep us up at night.
 When Tokyo's economic bubble burst in the early 1990's, we held our breath because it seemed the world's second-largest economy couldn't go into a tailspin without taking the global marketplace with it. In the end the fallout was contained, but that was the result of unusual circumstances. America was entering a powerful business expansion, Europe was boosted by a new common currency and a burst of internal deregulation, and Mexico, India, China and other nations were reaping the rewards of having recently opened their economies to foreign trade and investment. In that heady environment, Japanese stagnation didn't have as much global impact as we feared it would. 
 The current global economic scene, in which America and Japan together still account for over a third of global production, is starkly different. America is headed for recession, European growth is slowing and most emerging markets are fragile. With other engines of the world economy spluttering, further deterioration of the Japanese economy could finally have a serious effect on us.
Today, Japan's economic growth is stagnant, property values are declining, government and corporate debts are at an all-time high. Despite the fact that Tokyo has poured trillions of yen into public works and lowered interest rates to negligible levels, not only has the economy failed to respond, but serious deflation is in the air. Adding to the woes, the country's political leadership is in meltdown, with Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori having agreed to resign next month, leaving behind a fractured one-party system of exhausted politicians bereft of new ideas for how to reverse Japan's descent.
One looming problem is that as the Japanese economy contracts, so could American exports. This would hurt the earnings of many of our most important companies, further impairing their stock prices. But the Japanese banking system, already choking on bad debts, is the major point of vulnerability. The reason is that Japanese banks carry much of their reserves in the form of Japanese equities, and the major stock market index has now declined to its lowest levels in more than a decade. If some Japanese banks become insolvent, that could impair the health of foreign banks that have extended loans to them or that have other complex financial relationships. A crippled banking system would be unable to extend credit and would therefore drag down Japanese companies, too. In recent days, the Japanese government has acknowledged these acute problems, but given its miserable track record, whether it will address them effectively is another question.
If Japan's problems mount, companies there could begin liquidating their investments abroad. In the late 1980's American officials and business leaders worried that Japan would sell some of its American holdings as leverage to get the United States to ease its pressure to open the Japanese economy to trade. Most experts concluded that would never happen because the value of the Treasury securities held by Japanese was so vast that selling some would weaken the price of the billions they still held. However, if Japanese investors become sufficiently desperate now, selling may be the only option.
Japanese entities still own some $350 billion of Treasuries, about 25 percent of all such holdings outside of the United States, not to mention hundreds of billions of other marketable bonds and stocks. Japanese firms own some $150 billion in direct investments in America, more than those held by any other foreign country except for the United Kingdom. And Japanese companies employ over 550,000 Americans.
A Japanese sell-off of American assets could mean more downward pressure on our softening economy -- more surplus property, more layoffs. It could mean that the Japanese would exchange dollars for yen, weakening the dollar, which in turn would lead to increases in the price of imports that are now crucial to our economy. Rising prices in a no-growth economy -- stagflation -- may be more possible than we think.
Everyone wants and expects the Federal Reserve to bail out the economy, not only by lowering interest rates on Tuesday when the Open Market Committee meets, but also by lowering rates over the next several months. But if Japanese investors sell off their American assets and cause the dollar to sink, the Fed could face an agonizing dilemma. On the one hand, cutting interest rates could help revitalize the economy and the stock market. But it could also further weaken the dollar by making dollar-based returns less attractive, thereby discouraging European and Latin American investors from continuing to invest in American securities.
We have seen how herd-like markets can run wild, and were there to be a precipitous decline of the dollar, the Fed would have to consider holding rates steady or even temporarily raising them. This is not a position that Alan Greenspan would want to be in. As consumers, investors, employers and employees, neither would we.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/William B. Frels; 
Mairs and Power Balanced Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
WILLIAM B. FRELS finds a lot of the conservative growth he wants in companies based in the Upper Midwest, which account for one-third of the $42 million Mairs and Power Balanced fund.
 "These are companies in our own backyard," Mr. Frels said from his offices in St. Paul, Minn., overlooking the Mississippi River. "We have an unusually large number of attractive companies in this region. We know them pretty well and the information flow is good." 
 A hefty chunk of the fund's holdings are clustered in the Twin Cities area itself: Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, the St. Paul Companies, the H. B. Fuller Company and Supervalu Inc.
His local focus has paid off for investors. The fund returned 7.9 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, compared with 3.9 percent for its domestic hybrid peers and 4.5 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, according to Morningstar.
Beating the market is impressive, given that just 62 percent of the fund is invested in stocks; the balance is in bonds. Over all, the portfolio yields an average of 3.1 percent, nearly triple the yield for the S.& P. 500 .
Mr. Frels, 61, works closely with his three colleagues at Mairs and Power, which manages about $600 million for institutions and individuals. The firm also runs the $570 million Mairs and Power Growth fund, which returned 9.6 percent a year, on average, in the three years ended Thursday, Morningstar said.
For the balanced fund, Mr. Frels looks for companies with above-average growth prospects over the next three to five years, focusing on companies in Minnesota, Illinois and Wisconsin. Among the 45 stocks, the sole overseas holding is Barclays Bank preferred shares.
He uses no computer screens to identify purchases, relying instead on his and his colleagues' collective 127 years of experience. "Most of our investment ideas are word-of-mouth," he said. "We talk to companies and find out who their strong competition is."
They do not need many new ideas, he added: the fund's portfolio turnover rate is an exceptionally low 12.5 percent a year. Low turnover also helps minimize taxes for investors.
To capture growth, Mr. Frels looks for high-quality companies of any size that hold dominant market positions or particular areas of expertise that give them a competitive edge. Because he wants minimum annual earnings growth of 10 to 12 percent, he avoids cyclical and slow-growing industries like automobiles.
Management is key. He looks for management continuity and for executives who own significant stakes in their companies.
Mr. Frels says he will not overpay for growth. "We don't like to pay more than twice the company's growth rate," he said, adding that he hopes to buy stocks whose price-to-earnings multiples are no more than a company's earnings growth rate.
While financial stocks are the biggest sector, at 19.1 percent of the fund's equity assets, Mr. Frels has raised the technology stake, from 8.3 percent to more than 10 percent, as stock prices have deflated.
The bond part of the portfolio is generally concentrated in high-quality issues, usually Treasuries and corporate bonds rated A or higher. But, he said, the slowing economy has created good opportunities in medium-quality corporate bonds, which are yielding an average of two to three percentage points more than Treasury issues. He has split the bond portion equally between corporate and government issues, though the more typical mix is two-thirds government and one-third corporate bonds.
Expenses are a low 0.93 percent a year, partly because Mairs and Power reduces costs by marketing the fund in only 12 states. These include New York, New Jersey, California, Texas, Florida and Arizona.
In January, Mr. Frels bought shares of H. B. Fuller for an average cost of $36.46. Fuller manufactures a wide variety of adhesives used in the building and automotive industries, among others. "The adhesives business grows slightly faster than the U.S. gross domestic product," Mr. Frels said, "but Fuller has shown an ability to increase its market share in the past." Management has been moving out of slower-growth adhesive products, he added, into faster-growing, more profitable ones. He expects earnings to grow 10 percent, on average, over the next five years. 
On Friday, shares closed at $40.38. Another favorite is Corning Inc., which produces high-technology glass and ceramic products. Corning, which formerly produced glass and cookware, is now a world leader in fiber optic cable, Mr. Frels said, adding, "They hold a leading position in the communications industry, which we feel will continue to be one of the fastest-growing industries over the foreseeable future."
HE trimmed his position last winter and early spring, when the stock price, floating on the technology bubble, peaked at $113.32 in the third quarter of 2000, adjusted for splits. He repurchased some in February at an average cost of $34 a share. Despite the economic slowdown, he expects a five-year earnings growth rate averaging 20 percent. "Earnings have flattened out with the sharp cutback in capital spending," he said, "but we feel that it's a very temporary condition."
Corning shares closed Friday at $23.18.
In January, Mr. Frels bought 7 7/8 percent bonds due in 2009 issued by Supervalu, a Minneapolis food wholesaler, for $968.50, a discount from their $1,000 face value. Supervalu also operates grocery store chains that include Cub Foods, which has more than 125 discount superstores, mostly in Minneapolis, St. Paul, Chicago and Denver. "The bond is being priced more at the low end of the investment-grade range," he said. "We feel that the quality of the company and its finances are better than the bond rating suggests."
The bonds closed Friday at $979.60.

HEADLINE: GRASS ROOTS BUSINESS; 
Downtown Revival Comes to the South

BYLINE:  By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Davenport Institute for Public Policy at Pepperdine University. His column on the Main Street economy appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: grassrts@nytimes.com

DATELINE: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. 

 BODY:
FOR much of his career, Patrick C. Sommers lived and worked in some of the world's most established urban business centers, like Chicago, London and Toronto. Yet today, Mr. Sommers, now chief executive of the Sirsi Corporation, a private company that makes software for libraries, finds himself comfortably ensconced in the small urban core of this technology-rich city of 177,000.
 "I am a big-city guy, but I like it," said Mr. Sommers, 53. 
 His attraction to Huntsville and Sirsi's restored brick headquarters here reflects a broader trend that is only now sweeping Southern cities. For much of the last two decades -- even as Northern and Western cities enjoyed urban recoveries -- virtually all growth in the old Confederacy took place along the periphery.
Today this is changing. In cities throughout the South -- from Charlotte's "uptown" to Atlanta's burgeoning midtown to downtown Houston -- there has been a rapid growth of urban development. Local business leaders and economic development professionals say it was necessary not only to bolster the local economy but to lure workers.
Yet despite recent changes, most Southern metropolitan areas still have a very low percentage of their office space actually located in their central business districts. Whereas metropolitan regions like Chicago or New York have more than half of their office space in their central business districts, Southern cities like Nashville, Memphis and Atlanta have at least three-quarters of their office work force located in suburban and peripheral locations. 
Inman Allen, president of the Ivan Allen Furniture Company in Atlanta and a long-term observer of southern urban trends, blamed the South's slow urban development on historic trends. For one thing, the South embraced industry later than cities in the Northeast or Midwest. And by the time the Industrial Revolution hit the South with full force, largely after World War II, development patterns favored suburban areas. At the same time, the South often lacked financial backing for development.
But more recently, many Southern cities, including Huntsville, have rediscovered the economic advantage of developing dynamic urban cores, said Mr. Allen, whose father, Ivan Allen, served as mayor of Atlanta from 1962 to 1970. For one thing, it makes it easier to recruit young workers, who often come from the East or West Coasts and are critical to technology and business service firms. 
Like other Southern cities, Huntsville's growth has been slow and steady. In 1950, the city had a population of 15,000 with an economy centered around cotton and agriculture. But it was transformed into a sprawling, high-technology metropolis with the arrival of Dr. Werner von Braun and his rocket team, who were working for the Army. In 1960, NASA established the George C. Marshall Space Flight Center at the Army's Redstone Arsenal here.
Starting in the late 1960's, spinoffs from federally funded aerospace research and development fed a growing private industry. And over the last decade, Huntsville has enjoyed some of the fastest growth in technology in the nation. The city now ranks fifth among major metropolitan areas in terms of software workers per capita, according to a recent study by the Software and Information Industry Association. Many large computer and telecommunications companies, such as the Computer Sciences Corporation of El Segundo, Calif., Cinram International of Scarborough, Ontario, and Nokia of Finland, plan major expansions for this area.
Huntsville's technological base is becoming less federally oriented -- its dependence on government contracts has dropped to 50 percent today from 80 percent a decade ago. And workers being recruited by local businesses are less oriented toward suburban living than when aerospace businesses predominated. 
ASHOK K. SINGHAL, president of the CFD Research Corporation, a software maker that employs 120 workers, two-thirds of whom have Ph.D.'s, says that many software writers look for a stimulating urban environment. Couples in which one person has a career in a more culturally oriented profession -- such as graphic arts or advertising -- sometimes refuse to move to Huntsville because its working environment, which has been based on industrial office parks, is often viewed as boring. 
Dr. Singhal said these factors, combined with what is widely described as the "Alabama" stigma, which is associated with images of racial prejudice and rural backwardness from past decades, sharply limits recruitment. "Huntsville has done well to create the atmosphere and lifestyle that we have, but the suffix 'Alabama' hurts us more than anything," Dr. Singhal said. "This is one of our biggest recruiting problems." 
In 1997, to create an environment that would attract the necessary high-technology workers, Sirsi decided to move from the Cummings Industrial Park outside Huntsville to the city's then-struggling downtown. Its main office is now a former Kress Department store built in the early 1900's.
Jim Young, one of the firm's three co-founders, says the move appealed to the more urban, eclectic tastes common among Sirsi employees. A large proportion of the company's recruits, Mr. Young said, come from major cities. Mr. Young said the tastes of these workers were quite different than those of the traditional "number crunching" technologists who predominated the industrial parks. "We have more creative people who want a more relaxed environment close to the museums and the theaters," he said. "It's a different kind of place."
In many ways the atmosphere at Sirsi -- which has 1,000 customers, including libraries at Stanford University, the United States Census Bureau and Britain's House of Commons -- seems more like that of a company in the South of Market neighborhood of San Francisco or Boston's cyber district than that of a Southern boomtown. Employees work in brightly colored cubicles near exposed brick walls; part of the work space is given over to Lego toys and plants. "We didn't set out to make it like a Boston company, but it ended up that way," Mr. Young said.
At first, Sirsi's move downtown seemed a bit odd to many longtime residents of Huntsville. Yet as the company has expanded, nearly doubling its work force in the last three years, the relaxed and funky ambience of the company's headquarters has served as a major inducement when recruiting people into the company, said Debbie Collins, its director of administrative services. Half of the company's highly educated workers are foreign born.
Before Sirsi moved in three years ago, the downtown "was half empty -- people looked at it as absolutely dead," said Lynne Lowery, a Huntsville native and director of the Huntsville Association, the city's historic preservation group. Now most of the 100-acre area -- dominated by late 19th- and early 20th-century structures -- is either fully occupied or under restoration, not only for offices but for retail shops and restaurants. Other companies, including AniVision, a software company specializing in computer games, as well as several banks and professional service providers have added to the transformation of the downtown.
"Working downtown is really different," said Cheryll Milius, 34, a Los Angeles native, who is a customer consultant at Sirsi. "There's more walking. You don't have to drive to go out for lunch with people. I never expected this could happen in a place like Huntsville."

GRAPHIC: Photos: At the offices of Sirsi, a software maker in Huntsville, Ala., Doug Childs, standing, made his cubicle into a castle with Lego blocks. (Photographs by John Godbey for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends; 
AIDS Groups Revive A Fight, and Themselves

BYLINE:  By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IT was difficult not to hear echoes of the past when members of Act Up, the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, staged a "die-in" last week outside the headquarters of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America here. The props -- cardboard tombstones, chalked body outlines -- were familiar. Only the rallying cry, "medication for every nation," was new.
 The AIDS activist movement was born in the late 1980's with the pharmaceutical industry as its nemesis; at that time, the issue was access to experimental medications and the price of AZT. Then drug cocktails turned the disease, at least for many people in this country, from a killer into a chronic illness. The industry became a savior, the activism lost its urgency and the epidemic fell off the American radar screen. 
 Now AIDS is back on the front page, and the activists are back in business, drawing strength from their old enemy. 
This time, drug makers are caught in a squeeze play, hemmed in on one side by moral outrage over the plight of Africans dying for lack of medications readily available in the United States, and on the other by an intense pharmaceutical pricing debate here at home. 
"Africa is the most dramatic example of a situation where drugs are available that would make a big difference and yet people can't afford them," said John Rother, vice president of AARP, formerly the American Association of Retired Persons. "It may be very dramatic in Africa, but it is really a very similar situation on a day-to-day basis to seniors in this country who do not have drug coverage." 
Americans had a quick course in pharmaceutical economics during last year's presidential campaign. They found out that elderly people must sometimes choose between buying pills and food and often go to Mexico or Canada to buy cheaper drugs. They learned that pharmaceuticals cost more here than anywhere else in the world. They became acquainted with the concepts of intellectual property and patent rights. 
These issues are now playing out on the global stage. In South Africa, protests erupted this month over a lawsuit brought by 39 big drug companies seeking to block the country from buying inexpensive generic AIDS drugs. At the same time, Cipla, an Indian drug maker, has asked South Africa for permission to sell its inexpensive versions of 8 of the 15 anti-H.I.V. drugs sold in the United States.
Pharmaceutical giants have been left scrambling for some kind of redemption. "The drug companies, in the public discourse, have begun to look a little bit like the tobacco companies," said Dr. Ronald Bayer, professor of public health at Columbia University. "This story is not just news, it is morally compelling news." 
Last week, Bristol-Myers Squibb announced it would sell two H.I.V. medicines in Africa at just below cost, and would not use its patent on one, Zerit, to stand in the way of generics. The week before, Merck pledged to offer its two AIDS drugs to poor nations at cost.
In both instances, the drug makers took the highly unusual step of disclosing just what "cost" means, and the difference between it and what Americans pay is staggering. Bristol-Myers is offering Zerit at $54 a year, compared with $3,589 in this country. Merck's Crixivan will be priced at $600 a year in Africa, compared with $6,016 here. 
But the price cuts in Africa could backfire in the United States. "It triggers the perception that the companies are sitting on big profits and can lower their prices," said Drew Altman, president of the Kaiser Family Foundation, a nonprofit research group. "What a terrible dilemma for the companies. The more they do the right thing and lower the price of AIDS drugs in the rest of the world, the more it hurts them domestically." 
The manufacturers, for their part, argue that they use the markup to underwrite research. That's a claim activists dispute, saying the companies often rely on government-funded science and inventions by startup biotech firms. At the same time, pharmaceutical executives resist linking domestic politics to the international AIDS crisis. 
"The debate that I have had to live through for the last few years is, 'Why do your drugs cost less in other countries, and isn't that unfair?' " said one pharmaceutical executive. "Whereas this debate is, 'Your drugs should cost less in other countries.' "
Still, it is no accident that Africa's plight is gaining attention now. Africans did not start dying of the disease yesterday; public health officials have been warning of a third-world AIDS holocaust for at least a decade. Today, the World Health Organization estimates that 25 million Africans are infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, which causes AIDS. But only about 10,000 are getting the drugs that could save their lives.
 IN 1999, with the presidential campaigns cranking up, AIDS activists, particularly members of the vocal Act Up chapter in Philadelphia, saw an opportunity to bring the disparity to the fore. They began shadowing Vice President Al Gore, staging noisy rallies that painted him as the pharmaceutical industry's front man in trade talks with South Africa. 
It was an unsettling accusation for a candidate who made the high cost of pharmaceuticals for senior citizens a centerpiece of his campaign, and it worked. The Clinton administration reversed its policy of seeking sanctions against poor nations that, like South Africa, attempt to force down the price of patented AIDS drugs by allowing generics onto the market. And the Bush administration, in a move that surprised the advocates, has kept the Clinton policy in place.
"Luckily, a few reporters started listening to us when we started dogging Al Gore, primarily because the election itself was so boring that they needed a twist," said Eric Sawyer, who helped found Act Up in 1987 and organized the Gore rallies. "But as a result, the public again became engaged in the whole horror of the global AIDS crisis."
In lowering prices, the drug companies make the case that they are doing their part. But many African nations are unable to afford even these rock-bottom prices, and some lack the infrastructure to deliver the life-saving pills. So the debate is already shifting away from the pharmaceutical industry, and toward the question of what wealthy nations can do. 
The question now for the activists is whether they can keep the debate from shifting too far in that direction. They insist they won't allow drug companies to foist the problem off on the government and avoid dropping prices further. "The lower the price," said Katie Krauss, a member of Act Up's Philadelphia chapter, "the more people you can treat." 
At the same time, though, they will be making demands on the Bush administration, both for funding and easing of patent restrictions overseas.
At last week's demonstration, there were signs that this is already happening. A couple of the protesters, veterans of the heady days in the late 1980's when Act Up members disrupted trading on the New York Stock Exchange, turned up in sport coats and ties. They had an important meeting to attend after the die-in, at the United States trade representative's office.

GRAPHIC: Photo: One of perhaps 25 million Africans infected with H.I.V. undressing at his home near Durban, South Africa. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: The Nation: Vertigo; 
Econ 2001: Tips for the Shellshocked

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
THE longest economic expansion on record turned 10 years old this month. Some celebration.
 The yearlong swoon in technology stocks spread to old-economy shares last week like foot-and-mouth disease. Industrial production and corporate profits continued to tumble, stepping up pressure on the Federal Reserve to slash interest rates again when it meets on Tuesday, maybe by more than the half-point everyone expects. Hovering over the growing pessimism at home was the shadow of Japan, whose seemingly endless economic and financial woes grew even more acute, further unnerving Wall Street and policy makers in Washington. 
 Is this just a wrenching slowdown to a more sustainable rate of growth after several boom years? Is it the end of the expansion and the beginning of a relatively brief and shallow recession? Or is this what happens when a bubble economy bursts? 
No one knows.
But while it is impossible to predict with certainty where the economy is headed, there are a number of lessons to be gleaned from the experience of the past decade that will frame the decisions ahead:

Lesson No. 1:
This is not your father's business cycle.
The ups and downs of the economy used to follow a predictable path. Economic growth would accelerate until it overheated, setting off inflation. The Federal Reserve would raise interest rates, the economy would fall into recession, the Fed would cut rates -- and the whole cycle would begin again.
At least one of those elements is part of the story this time around: the feeling among some analysts that the Fed jacked rates up too much in 1999 and 2000. But there is much that seems to be different.
For one thing, the economy's ability to respond to change seems to have sped up in the past few years. From supermarket scanners to sophisticated inventory management systems to CNBC, businesses and consumers can draw on vast quantities of information about what is happening as it is happening.
Whatever this period is -- a recession or a slowdown -- it could be over quickly because the problems and solutions are much more immediately evident than in the past.
But the downturn could well turn out to be more extended than in previous cycles. According to one theory making the rounds, this cycle is not so much about demand exceeding supply -- the usual trigger for inflation -- but about overinvestment by businesses in technology, equipment and factories.
In short, the problem may not be too much money chasing too few goods, as in the past; indeed, this cycle has been characterized by an almost total lack of inflation. Rather, it may be too much investment chasing too little return. In that case, the economy might not get back on its feet until businesses begin investing heavily again, and they won't do that until they work off their overcapacity. 
And that process could be delayed by consumers, whose confidence has been eroding. Individuals helped fuel the investment boom by sinking their money into stocks rather than savings accounts. But now they find themselves with shrinking portfolios, heavy debt loads and little in the way of a buffer to help them through tough times.
Some economists think the idea of overinvestment leading to a sustained downturn is exaggerated. But others say recent corporate announcements of steep reductions in capital spending, plus faltering sales and profits among technology companies, suggest there is something to the notion.

Lesson No. 2:
If productivity fades, we're toast.
Perhaps the most fundamental question facing the economy is whether the resurgence in the growth rate of productivity will hold up or fade away with the Nasdaq and the ranks of 24-year-old millionaires.
Productivity is a basic measure of business efficiency, or output per hour, and after languishing for more than two decades it suddenly accelerated about six years ago. 
The assumption is that the improvement is the payoff from the remarkable technological advances of recent decades and the willingness of American businesses, driven to stay competitive in a global economy, to invest heavily in computers and other advanced hardware and software. 
Powered by resurgent productivity, the economy has been able to grow at an annual rate of more than 4 percent in recent years, driving unemployment down to around 4 percent, a 30-year low, while inflation declined. Productivity growth was behind the regular upward revisions in projections of the federal budget surplus. 
Because higher productivity implied bigger profits and higher rates of return, the United States became even more of a magnet for investment from abroad.
Among the pessimists, there are two related strains of thought about productivity: that the gains have been largely limited to the technology industry, and that the improvement will wither as the economy slows. Optimists, led by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, believe the gains are here to stay and have already lifted a broad spectrum of industries, leaving the economy fundamentally more efficient and competitive.

Lesson No. 3:
Markets rule.
With the trend toward deregulation and free trade in the United States, and with the triumph of democratic capitalism abroad, market forces reign over the global economy.
That has proven to be a positive development in most respects, especially when the economy and the financial markets appeared to have been freed from the laws of gravity.
But markets extract a price, particularly when things are not going well. Just ask the millions of individual investors who made buying stocks and bonds a mass-market sport in the belief that doing so was more or less a one-way bet. At a minimum, a serious downturn or a recession is sure to set off a renewed debate about the degree to which social and economic challenges should be left to market forces. 
Remaking the Social Security system to include personal investment accounts, for example, could be a tough sell for President Bush at a time when workers are seeing minus signs on their 401(k) plan statements. And opening American markets to more foreign competition could be hard if unemployment rises substantially.
Still, market forces create a discipline that leads governments, companies and investors alike to think hard about the soundness of their financial decisions. "The good thing about markets is not that they avoid mistakes, but that they compel you in a speedy fashion to correct them once they are identified -- sometimes in draconian fashion," said Kermit L. Schoenholtz, chief economist at Salomon Smith Barney and Citibank.

Lesson No. 4:
Policy matters.
 During the 1980's, Japan was the rising economic power and the United States was widely seen as a has-been. Japan is now a case study in how not to manage an economy. And the United States, for all its recent troubles, has remade itself as the world's most reliable engine of growth.
In that role reversal is a lesson: political will and policy choices play a critical role even in a borderless and deregulated global economy.
The United States dealt quickly with its savings and loan crisis in the early 1990's, shutting down insolvent banks and selling foreclosed properties at big losses. Faced with a similar situation, Tokyo dithered, and a decade later its financial system continues to teeter near insolvency.
While the Bank of Japan was reluctant at first to cut interest rates, the Federal Reserve has responded quickly and flexibly to changing economic conditions. While Japan has run up staggering budget deficits without stimulating its moribund economy much, the United States is paying off the national debt.

The Test
Seeing clearly.
It is hard enough to make good policy choices when the economy's condition is clear. It is much tougher when the outlook is so murky -- and when the economy's basic structure seems to be evolving rapidly.
Will lowering interest rates still pack enough of a punch to avert a recession, or at least pull the nation out of one quickly? Would a big tax cut give the economy a boost, or send the government down the path of budget deficits and higher interest rates?
Most uncertain of all is the shape of politics in an era of post-prosperity. This is now a nation of investors, and the stock market averages are its collective pulse. It is not yet clear whether Americans will remain calm in the face of turmoil, or whether they will demand that their leaders pay a price for ushering in this wild ride.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Heaven help us: A statue of George Washington reaching toward the New York Stock Exchange. (Jake Price)

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
Bear Market Becomes a Reality

BYLINE:  By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
The bear is out of hibernation.
 For months, gloomy corporate profit warnings and reports that the economy was slowing took bites out of the markets. 
But last week, the cumulative effect of months of bad news seemed to overwhelm investors and send them scurrying for the exits. On Monday, the broad market measure S.& P. 500 fell into bear territory for the first time since 1987 and the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite fell through the 2,000 level for the first time since December 1998. 
 And the bad company news persisted. Motorola and Compaq announced large job cuts and McDonald's, Northwest Airlines and Oracle issued profit warnings.
 The Dow industrial average had its worst week since October 1989, ending at 9,823.41, down 821.21 points or 7.7 percent. The S.& P. 500 fell to 1,150.53, down 82.89 points or 6.7 percent. The Nasdaq composite finished at 1,890.91, down 161.87 points or 7.9 percent.
 The selloff in the equity markets, and expectations of an interest rate cut when the Federal Reserve meets this week, helped send bond prices higher. The yield on the 10-year Treasury bond ended at 4.76 percent, down from 4.94 percent from the week before. 
 DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN
