HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
City Kid + Old Tappan = Winning Equation

BYLINE:  By HARVEY ARATON 

DATELINE: OLD TAPPAN, N.J. 

 BODY:
Lenny had the answer and he knew it was right. You could hear it in his voice. You could see it in the half smile of satisfaction under his Yankees cap.
 "You sure?" asked Lauren Vaughn, one of his classmates in Chris Broking's math skills class, with whom Lenny was checking his work. 
 "Y equals minus 2," he said, as sure of himself as he would be identifying a windmill dunk from a finger roll.
Granted, this two-step algebraic equation was not what the students were up to in high honors, but the result was correct. Mr. Broking patted him on the shoulder, and the 6-foot-6 Cooke leaned back contentedly and stretched his long legs into the aisle.
Two points added to his mounting self-esteem, to the credit of the 18-year-old drop-in who recently plopped himself opposite the principal to say, "This is the first time since I was a kid that I don't feel dumb."
There are no generalizations being made here, no condemnations. Lenny could have gone to class and done the work in Brooklyn, or at LaSalle Academy in Manhattan. He just didn't, and maybe, back in the city, he was a basketball prodigy too caught up in an athletic gold rush whose prospectors filled his head with hoop dreams that don't leave room for anything else. Maybe he needed some life-altering event, such as the birth of his son, Anahijae, last year, to rally himself in the academic arena before he was too far behind.
So this is just one teenager's story, because it was Lenny's idea and no one else's to ask Brian Raimondo's mother, Debbie Bortner, if he could move into her home last spring, transfer to Northern Valley Regional High School in Old Tappan, along with Brian, his former teammate at LaSalle. The grand basketball plan, if there was one, didn't have a Disney finish. Brian broke his wrist a week before his buddy became eligible last month, and the Lenny-led Golden Knights reeled off a run of victories before stumbling in overtime against Sparta in the state tournament two weeks ago.
Lenny didn't bring his A game in the first half, apologized to his team, and was reminded that being the basketball star at a school like Old Tappan means never having to say you're sorry. "I felt like I let people down, but nobody acted like it was a big deal," he said.
The principal, Anthony L. Panico, didn't even attend the game because that same weekend, the school's most time-honored team was winning another state title, the 15th in 16 years. Walk through the front entrance of the school, look left, and there sits the trophy case, crammed with the keepsakes of . . . Academic Decathlons? 
This, again, is no suburban stereotype, as the inflation of athletes' worth is hardly exclusive to any socioeconomic group. Panico and his staff admit that they like their sports and they sure loved watching Lenny flaunt his diversity of skills, while bending over backward to fit into their team. 
He scored 50 points in one game, as little as 22 in another. "What would be the point?" he said when someone asked if he could score 100 points in a league that hadn't seen the likes of him, the way Dajuan Wagner of Camden did earlier this season during a 90-point rout in another New Jersey high school game.
For about a month, Old Tappan rode a wave, and Thomas Kaechele, the athletic director, held his breath. He knew Lenny had a temper, had seen it during summer-league games. The legend of Lenny was sweeping Bergen County, but so was the pressure for him to be city-dominant, worthy of the college scouts who slipped quietly into the crowd. There were provocations, the kids at Ramapo chanting "S-A-T" and the Wayne Hills team triple-teaming him with flailing elbows and foolish taunts.
" 'Where's your son, where's your son?' they kept saying," Lenny said. "I'm not ashamed of my son."
He played calmly through the extracurricular activity, showing his stuff, displaying his growth. These tests, actually, were pushovers, compared with those he had already aced.
"He was a child who had been educationally deprived," said Terri Kelly, a biology teacher who privately mentored him two hours daily last summer. Lenny walked into her life with his shoulders slouched but soon amazed her with his determination to press on in an academic environment he quickly learned would push back. 
He is one of only six African-American students at Old Tappan, but it would be another stereotype to paint the school as a homogeneous country portrait. Panico said it wasn't easy integrating a Korean immigrant student population that is now at 23 percent. The Korean parents, who once sent the principal to South Korea so he could better understand them, initially did not want their kids mingling too much, playing sports. The basketball team Lenny played on was one-third Asian.
"My biggest pride in this deal," Panico said, "is that our kids have got as much from knowing Lenny as he got from being here."
The logical assumption is that he will be going within a few months. He has no basketball eligibility left and one more academic year until he gets a diploma. The prep schools want him for their road show revues but, hold on, Lenny says he's got a big decision to make.
"I don't want to go someplace where my grades fall back," he said. 
It's a long shot that he'll stay. The unopened letters from the major colleges are piling up. He is dreaming about leading St. John's back to the N.C.A.A. tournament that he's watching closely these days -- perhaps with his distant cousin, the St. John's point guard Omar Cook.
The big time beckons, but for now, there are ribbons to sell for an AIDS awareness program, assignments to complete and 4-year-old Matty Iovino to check up on in the school day-care center.
"Lenny took an elective course in child development," said Terri Shea, the boy's mother and a special education teacher. "The first day, Matty sat on Lenny's lap, and it's been hero worship ever since."
He was just Lenny to the kid, not Lenny the basketball player, maybe the best player Old Tappan will ever know.
"You're kidding," Panico said, almost in disbelief when Kaechele called to deliver the bad news of the Sparta defeat and the abrupt ending of the Lenny Cooke era. "We lost?"
That would depend on how one keeps score.

HEADLINE: Hoping to Shore Up Prices, OPEC Agrees to Cut Output by 4% 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: VIENNA, March 17 

 BODY:
Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed today to cut 4 percent from their oil output, or one million barrels a day, in the hope of shoring up prices at a time of weakening demand.
 The cut, which was at the upper end of most analysts' expectations, is aimed at keeping prices from falling further in the face of a seasonal dip in purchases and an overall decline in global economic growth. It will take effect April 1, OPEC said. 
 The cartel's members pump almost 40 percent of the world's oil, and their decision will affect retail prices for gasoline and other refined products in importing countries like the United States. One analyst predicted that gasoline prices could rise sharply, but others said the impact would be less significant.
The organization announced its decision after two days of talks in the Austrian capital. 
"The present weaker world economy and the traditional sharp downturn in demand associated with the second quarter both clearly point to the need for a correction in oil supply, and the conference has taken the decision to stabilize the oil market," OPEC announced.
Unlike other meetings of the group in recent years, this one unfolded against a backdrop of economic fragility, with stock markets from New York to Tokyo registering steep losses in share values. Consumer confidence has suffered, and fears of a recession are growing.
These economic conditions complicated OPEC's efforts to arrive at a suitable cut in production, oil ministers said.
"We have to follow this situation continuously," the organization's secretary general, Ali Rodriguez, said after the meeting. "The slowdown in the economy was entirely present in our analysis."
The unusually long time it took the group to reach a decision attests to the difficulty delegates faced in working out the specifics.
OPEC will trim its output quota to 24.2 million barrels a day from its current level of 25.2 million barrels. Energy analysts had generally forecast a decrease of at least 500,000 barrels a day.
The production cut will be the organization's second of the year so far. Members agreed in January to lop 1.5 million barrels off their previous quota, a decrease that took effect Feb. 1. The current global economic weakness appears to have reinforced the case within OPEC for deeper cuts.
The organization also was anticipating a slowdown this spring in seasonal demand for heating oil and gasoline as the weather starts to warm in many importing nations.
Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Ali Naimi, said the organization expected non-OPEC producers like Russia, Mexico and Angola to cooperate by holding back some of their own oil from the market. Iran's oil minister, Bijan Namdar Zangeneh, said non-OPEC countries would probably trim their supply by 200,000 barrels a day. 
Analysts noted that last month OPEC members produced some 500,000 barrels a day above the target they agreed to in January. This amount of overproduction means that even if cartel members were to reduce their official output by one million barrels a day, the actual decrease might equal only half that.
The organization is trying to stabilize prices at around $25 a barrel for an average of seven benchmark crudes. The OPEC average price has slid in recent months from more than $30 a barrel.
The cut will apply to all of OPEC's 11 members except Iraq, which does not take part in the group's production agreements because its oil exports are regulated by the United Nations.

HEADLINE: Spring Break Job Fair: Free Stuff, Few Offers 

BYLINE:  By JIM YARDLEY 

DATELINE: SOUTH PADRE ISLAND, Tex., March 14 

 BODY:
The music blared over the beach as the midday scrum of college students partook in the usual rites of spring break -- beer drinking, standing around, beer drinking, maybe a little volleyball. But inside a white tent filled with corporate booths, students like Christiaan Best were looking for jobs.
 The tent, called Spring Break Career Expo, was not a typical blue-suit job fair. The applicants arrived shirtless or in string bikinis. One student carried an iguana on his shoulder. The corporate recruiters wore wraparound sunglasses and flip-flops and, in the words of one, wanted "to project an image of cool." 
 For this generation of college students, the fact that Fortune 500 recruiters would venture into the belly of the spring break beast bespoke the booming decade in which they came of age. But as students collected water bottles and other corporate freebies, the hip presentations and slick brochures could not obscure that the once overheated job market was cooling, and fast.
"It scares the hell out of me," said Mr. Best, 20. He is a University of Texas junior majoring in mechanical engineering who has had a summer internship with an engineering company fall through and is desperate to find something for his resume. 
The first booth Mr. Best and other students encountered, Motorola's, offered free Frisbees, but no jobs. The company announced 7,000 layoffs earlier in the week. A Motorola representative, Cindy Herrick, admitted, "We probably would not have chosen to come if we had not already committed." 
Other companies had openings, but some jobs might have seemed deflating for students weaned on legends of dot-com riches: Footaction, the shoe store chain, was hiring assistant store managers starting at $20,000.
Mr. Best grew up in Austin, Tex., where the affluence of the technology boom gave him outsized job expectations. He managed a boat store last summer and recalled how "Dellionaires" -- Dell Computer employees who have cashed in stock options -- would ask for the most expensive boat on the lot. Last month, Dell announced that 1,700 employees would be let go, the first large-scale layoffs in company history. Many smaller technology companies in Austin face even tougher times. 
"I thought I could just throw my resume out the window and somebody would give me a job," Mr. Best said. "They were hiring so fast."
Scott Pressman, the job fair's organizer, said he was holding his third annual event at South Padre Island and his fourth in Panama City, Fla., another spring break mecca. "When we first started, these companies couldn't have enough students," he said, noting that conventional job fairs often failed to attract a crowd. "We thought, 'Why not take the companies where the students are?' "
In the tent, there were no sit-down interviews, a situation that probably benefited those students who had lunched on beer. But all the students filled out registration forms with their name, major, university and grade-point average that were provided to companies for follow-up recruiting. Many students admitted their main motivation was "the free stuff," and many recruiters admitted that marketing the corporate brand was as much a goal as hiring.
There were jobs. Chili's, the restaurant chain, was looking for managers; Ernest & Julio Gallo, the winemaker, was hiring. ("Our industry is recession-proof," a Gallo recruiter said.) Recruiters with Raytheon and Lockheed Martin said they wanted electrical engineers and software engineers. But Eric Horton, 37, a Lockheed engineer, said his company also wanted students to "know that Lockheed Martin is down here on spring break, having fun. You know, kind of like we're not your father's Oldsmobile anymore."
Mr. Horton's bonhomie did little to soothe the anxieties of Madhav Narasimhan, 23, a graduate student in electrical engineering at Texas A&M University. "It's impossible," he said of his efforts to find a job. 
Meredith Kerr, 24, a senior majoring in journalism and advertising at Southern Illinois University, admitted she was nervous, too. "Are the jobs still out there?" Ms. Kerr asked. "Is the money still out there?" She hinted that she might delay her job search and head to graduate school to make herself more marketable.
Other students were more confident, if not in the economy, then in the stability of their chosen professions. Kristen Schiller, 23, a Saint Louis University senior, said her field, physical therapy, was thriving. Artie Donald, 22, a junior at Sam Houston State University, said he would not accept less than $62,000 a year as a computer programmer. He said his computer science major and his job experience in computer software and hardware helped him relax about his prospects.
"I figured the dot-com craze would collapse anyway," Mr. Donald said, his sunglasses hooked on his shirt. "There was never anything holding it up."
Perhaps the future will still be so bright, to quote the song, that Mr. Donald will have to wear his shades. To be sure, most students packed onto the beaches were more concerned with finding the hottest bars or avoiding police speed traps than with following the stock market or the latest employment report. 
Dave Boedeker, 21, a Central Missouri State University senior, said he had no idea that the white tent on the beach was a job fair.
"Right there?" Mr. Boedeker asked, holding a cup of beer. "Are you serious?"
He said he knew his future, anyway. He was going to a thong contest.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Students on spring break last week at South Padre Island, Tex., filled out registration forms, above, at a job fair on the beach. Companies like Motorola talked with students and offered Frisbees, below, but few jobs. (Photographs by Brad Doherty for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Lucent Layoffs Are New Hires to Other Technology Firms 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

DATELINE: MURRAY HILL, N.J., March 14 

 BODY:
On its face, the January announcement that Lucent Technologies, New Jersey's third-largest private employer, was going to lay off more than 10,000 employees worldwide was yet another sign of a weakening economy.
 But to people like Bruce F. Magown, the chief operating officer of Knoa.net, a small software firm that has had a hard time finding qualified technology workers, the layoffs at Lucent looked like a glass half full. 
 Mr. Magown is among the New York area technology executives, headhunters and venture capital investment firms who are hoping that many of the 2,000 Lucent employees being laid off in New Jersey will help fill the region's demand for technology workers and spur entrepreneurship. Lucent will still have almost 18,000 employees in New Jersey. 
"The pool of applicants has increased tenfold since the shakeout at Lucent began," Mr. Magown said. 
For nearly a year, layoffs in Manhattan's Silicon Alley have put thousands of dot-com workers into the job market. But technology executives have said that those layoffs have done little to allay the shortage of workers in their industry because there is little need for people who can make pretty Web sites. 
Instead, executives said, they are seeking programmers and researchers, both of whom remain in short supply. Unlike dot-coms, Lucent, which is headquartered on a sprawling campus here and is the parent company of Bell Labs, has a history of producing some of the nation's top telecommunications research.
"Since we announced this reduction, we've gotten hundreds of calls from competitors, recruiters and others who want our people because of the skills they have," said William T. Price III, a spokesman for Lucent who went to pains to note that the company was not cutting workers from its core research areas.
Still, the large-scale reorganization that Lucent announced it would undertake will mean the departure of many seasoned executives and mangers, as well as researchers involved in some areas that are no longer considered central to the company's missions.
Economists who have studied the effects of layoffs in the region caution that it is much too early to determine the impact of the Lucent shakeout. Few of the employees who are to be laid off have been notified. The economists add that the overall condition of the area's economy could affect the ability of entrepreneurs to find investments for new companies and the demand for technology workers.
But already executives and recruiters say that the hiring market for technology workers has begun to show signs of improvement, and several venture capital firms in the region said that they had been getting about five business plans a week from workers at Lucent.
"You cannot minimize the impact of large-scale layoffs and the pain it inflicts on a local economy," said Marc M. Goloven, the senior regional economist at J. P. Morgan Chase & Company. "But in many instances in the area there has been a positive response that has boded well for future economic growth, if not immediate economic growth."
Mr. Goloven points to places like the mid-Hudson Valley, where I.B.M. eliminated more than 8,000 jobs during the mid-1990's. By the time the dust had settled during the widespread downsizing of the time, Dutchess County had lost one out of every five jobs. But now many of those former I.B.M. workers are credited with starting the small technology and service companies that are fueling what has become one of New York State's fastest growing local job markets. 
On Long Island, the same growth occurred after the Grumman Corporation decided to lay off more than 7,400 workers in the wake of its 1990 merger with Northrop. Former Grumman executives, engineers and workers helped build the 1,600-company technology corridor that has helped spur job growth in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. And in Rochester, many of the city's telecommunications and technology companies can trace their roots to Kodak's layoffs during the 1980's.
Lucent's presence in New Jersey has already been credited with leading to the creation of hundreds of companies made up of former employees. The company itself and its predecessors helped develop the first commercial system for adding sound to motion pictures and a host of other breakthroughs that include innovations in lasers, satellites, electronic switching and the UNIX operating system. On average, four patent applications come out of the company each workday.
Already, Flatiron Partners, a venture capital firm based in New York, has helped arrange the hiring of one Lucent executive as the chief executive of a technology company in which it has a significant investment. GeoVideo Networks, a small company developing Internet video technology, recently hired Phil Thompson, a former Lucent Internet executive, as its senior vice president and hopes to hire more Lucent employees.
Lucent has also encouraged entrepreneurship throughout its corporate culture with several programs, including the Lucent New Ventures Group, which invests in companies that are spun out from its own research labs and executive suites. GeoVideo, which has offices in New York City and New Jersey, is one of those companies.
"We have actually had the good fortune of hiring some good people out of Lucent and Bell Labs," said Chris Pfaff, the chief communications officer at GeoVideo. "We have DNA from several Lucent ventures. We hope to have more."
Mr. Goloven said that after companies like Lucent make layoffs, they often fill the market with "a highly skilled work force that can immediately make contributions in other companies."
Despite the optimism, some say that the possible benefits of any layoffs could be negated by several economic factors. Theodore M. Crone, a vice president and economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, said that if the economy continued to weaken, investments would decline and fewer opportunities for entrepreneurs would follow quickly. At the same time, Mr. Crone said a weakening economy could reduce the demand for technology workers.
"We have to go out a few months to see if the information technology job market's demand still outstrips the supply," he said. "But there, it is still likely that there will be a need for Lucent employees."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 22, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about small technology companies in New Jersey that are hiring thousands of workers laid off from Lucent Technologies misstated the year of a merger between Northrop and the Grumman Corporation, which laid off thousands of workers on Long Island in 1990. It was in 1994, not 1990.

HEADLINE: With Bull Market Under Siege, Some Worry About Its Legacy 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The bull market, born in 1982 amid recession and concern that the American economy was terminally ill, is being measured for its coffin.
 A requiem may be premature for an animal that arose stronger than ever after reports of its death in the 1987 crash. But whatever its immediate prospects after the worst week for the Dow since 1989, this bull will long be remembered for the changes it has made in America. 
 It changed the way people lived and the risks they were willing to take. It led to Americans becoming more dependent on stock market profits than ever before -- and gave them confidence that there was little need to save. 
The 1990's economic boom spurred the bull market, and was in turn increased by the spending that the bull market encouraged. Stock options became widespread, making millionaires of even low-level employees in companies that became stock market favorites.
The stock market, once viewed by many as a highly risky place where amateurs were likely to suffer if they were not nimble, came to be viewed as a sure thing, at least in the long term.
"Individual investors got hooked on equities," said Robert Glauber, the chief executive of the National Association of Securities Brokers and a former Treasury undersecretary in the first Bush administration. "It went too far, and they came to think that equities were riskless."
In 1999, as the bull market reached its zenith, the net worth of American households rose 14.1 percent. "It influenced the size of the homes we live in, the type of cars we drive, how we go on vacation," said Douglas R. Cliggott, a strategist at J. P. Morgan Chase. "Because of the extraordinary improvement in the average American's net worth, it made us feel comfortable carrying what by historic standards would have been an extraordinary amount of debt."
Already, the stock market's fall has put a dent in Americans' wealth. Household net worth fell 2 percent in 2000, the first such fall since the government began keeping track of the statistic after World War II. Households had experienced a small increase even in 1974, during the worst recession since the 1930's.
The loss of wealth reflects the fact that by 1999 Americans had 60 percent of their investments and savings in the stock market, double the proportion they had in 1982, according to J. P. Morgan Chase. And that understates the real figure, since retirement funds like 401(k)'s are excluded. Never before in American history has the wealth of so many been tied to Wall Street's fortunes.
"I'm old enough to remember when you went into a bar during the summer, they were watching a baseball game," said Byron Wien, the chief United States equity strategist for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "Now, they're watching CNBC."
The bull is now, at best, wounded. In the final years of the great rise -- one that saw the Dow Jones industrial average climb 1,409 percent from the 1982 low to the early 2000 high, while the Nasdaq composite index soared 3,072 percent -- the biggest winners were the technology stocks. Now some of the highest flyers in the boom are dead, and even the best are down 50 percent or more from their highs.
The Nasdaq composite, dominated by technology stocks, is now down 63 percent from its peak of last March while the Dow, which had held up much better because of its old-economy concentration, is off 16 percent from its peak, after losing almost 8 percent last week. The Standard & Poor's 500, a widely followed index of large companies, is down 25 percent from its high.
If the bull is dead or dying, it will leave a society that has depended on it far more than anyone could have anticipated even a decade ago. Corporate America went deeply into debt to buy back stock and obtain shares to issue to employees, confident that share prices would keep rising. 
Family finances were reshaped. Far fewer companies now offer traditional defined-benefit pension plans that promise guaranteed incomes to retirees. Instead they offer defined-contribution benefit plans like 401(k)'s, where the investment risk belongs to the beneficiary. When times were good, with stock prices rising and inflation quiet, people felt comfortable saving little money outside of their 401(k)'s.
Now, if the perception spreads that the days of easy money are over, that could persuade Americans to save more to finance their retirements. Savers would benefit in the long run, but the adjustment would further depress economic activity in the short run, damaging business profits and perhaps hurting stock prices even more.
Such a situation was foreseen by no one in the summer of 1982. The Dow was trading under 800 and bearishness was rampant. Inflation and interest rates were high, the American economy was in recession and pessimism was widespread regarding the ability of American business to compete with foreign companies, particularly those of Japan.
The stock market was lower than it had been in 1966. To make matters worse, the accountants were cracking down by changing rules that had made it possible for companies to ignore how underfunded their pension plans really were. To comply with the new accounting requirements, companies would have to find ways to make large contributions to their pension plans.
Or, they could find ways to reduce their obligations. In that atmosphere the trend toward defined-contribution plans took off. Workers were forced to decide how to invest their retirement money. While much of that early investment went into bonds and money market funds that were paying high rates of interest, as time went on and rates declined, more and more savers were forced to consider putting some money into stocks.
Those who took the plunge did well. American business was embarking on a golden age as its efforts to become more competitive bore fruit. Corporate profits, at 7.5 percent of national income in 1981, grew to 12.5 percent by 1997. 
In 1987, it all appeared to end with a crash. The Dow fell 22.7 percent in one day, and the bull's obituaries were written.
But the bull was not dead. By late 1989 the stock market was back to its old highs. The lesson learned was not that stocks are risky; it was that money is to be made by buying when prices fall.
Stock options were relatively rare in 1982, but as the bull grew they became far more common. And at many companies, particularly technology companies, they were offered not just to senior executives but to many others, all the way down to the lowest levels. In the Seattle area, where Microsoft is based, so many became wealthy that the local housing market was distorted, a fact that may have helped lead to strikes in recent years at Boeing and The Seattle Times, where such wealth had not flowed even though living costs were on the rise.
For the companies that issued such options, the benefits included loyal employees -- the options would be canceled if the worker quit -- and inflated profits, since accounting rules did not require that the value of the options be treated as an expense. The companies even got a tax break when the options were exercised to buy stock.
But as more options were exercised to buy shares, companies worried that shareholders would be offended that their stake was falling -- dilution is the Wall Street word -- because of the new shares being issued. So companies bought back more and more of their shares to avoid such dilution. For many companies, those purchases used up most of their available money, so they had to borrow for investments in their businesses. During a period of unparalleled corporate prosperity, the debt of corporate America grew substantially.
At the peak of the bull's vigor, Internet stocks went wild. It did not matter that many had no profits and little hope for any. There were voices of caution, but they were soon discredited as the share prices kept rising.
"I used to get that look that people reserve for benign idiots and small children when I would say that Amazon.com would have to become the retail sales industry for the United States to grow into the market capitalization it had at its peak," recalled Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company. Amazon is now down 90 percent.
As the new-offerings market grew to a fever pitch, the goals of those starting businesses seemed to change. Where once the dream was to start a business and watch it grow and become profitable, more and more seemed to see the initial public offering as the end point, when the money would have been made.
Now the illness of the bull, and speculation that it has already died, has put new pressure on Americans to decide whether stocks are still the best long-term investment and that buying on dips is a good strategy. So far, Americans seem to be putting much less money into stocks but to be avoiding selling if they can. With Treasury bonds paying less than 5 percent interest, the investment alternatives are not especially attractive.
Mr. Glauber, the N.A.S.D. chief executive, expresses confidence that the old aversion to stocks will not return. "I think they will still conclude that equities are an important part of their long-term portfolio," he said.
On Wall Street, most strategists think the stock market is at or near a bottom. Abby Joseph Cohen, the Goldman, Sachs strategist, recommended earlier this month that investors put more money in stocks, which she viewed as undervalued even before last week's plunge. She set a target of 13,000 for the Dow by the end of this year.
That may prove accurate, but all forecasts are inevitably colored by recent history. Now, that history shows years of strong gains.
Many years ago, in a very different environment, this newspaper reported that James L. Freeman, the director of research at First Boston, was reflecting the prevailing Wall Street opinion when he forecast that "the market's going to take the ultimate dive" before prices were likely to turn up. "Batten down the hatches," he advised.
That article, headlined "Dark Days on Wall Street," was printed on Sunday, Aug. 15, 1982. No one knew it, but a great bull had been born the preceding Friday.

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Sunday about the fading bull market misidentified the organization led by Robert Glauber, who said investors had come to see stocks as risk-free. It is the National Association of Securities Dealers, not Brokers.

HEADLINE: THE RIGHT THING; 
When Good Ethics Aren't Good Business

BYLINE:  By JEFFREY L. SEGLIN; Jeffrey L. Seglin teaches at Emerson College in Boston and is the author of "The Good, the Bad, and Your Business" (John Wiley & Sons). His column on business ethics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: righthng@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
STORIES about courageous chief executives who, when faced with business pressures to do otherwise, choose to do the right thing invariably end up reading like morality tales. The message? Good ethics leads to good business results.
 The fire that devastated Malden Mills Industries just before Christmas 1995 was just such a story. Rather than collect the insurance money, lay employees off and shutter the textile company, Aaron Feuerstein, the owner, promised to keep the employees on the payroll while he rebuilt. Mr. Feuerstein rescued the business, saved about 3,000 jobs and kept the town of Lawrence, Mass., where the company is based, from economic disaster. 
 While stories like Mr. Feuerstein's are inspiring, they add to the myth that good ethics and good business always go hand in hand. That is simply not the case.
"One could argue that responsible management and doing the right thing are often characterized by the same things," Jon P. Gunnemann, a professor of social ethics at Emory University, said. "But you can't infer that every decision about the right thing to do is necessarily going to be good for the company. Sometimes, doing the right thing can have tragic consequences."
A prime example may involve Ed Shultz, the former chief executive of Smith & Wesson, the gun manufacturer based in Springfield, Mass. Last March, in an attempt to defuse lawsuits the company was facing from at least 29 municipalities that held handgun manufacturers responsible for violent crimes, Mr. Shultz entered into an agreement with the federal government. He said that Smith & Wesson would include locks on its handguns, research and implement "smart-gun" technology that would only allow the owner of a gun to operate it and improve the way retailers sold its products. Much of this, said Mr. Shultz, was already being done.
"It was a business decision," Ken Jorgensen, a company spokesman, said. Tomkins P.L.C., the British company that owns Smith & Wesson, wanted to sell the company, a goal that was impossible as long as the lawsuits were pending. The company knew the reaction to the agreement with the federal government might be harsh. "There wasn't any question there was going to be a hit," Mr. Shultz said. "The question was how big the hit would be and for how long."
As it turns out, the hit was huge. The company was vilified by its customers, retailers and perhaps most vocally by the industry lobbying group, the National Rifle Association. 
Sales dropped off dramatically, and by October the company announced that it was laying off 125 of the 725 employees at its Springfield plant. Mr. Shultz left the company in September to run another company that had been sold by Tomkins.
Why would a company very publicly decide to implement changes in its products that it knew would likely meet with disapproval among its core constituents? Up until this time, Mr. Shultz said, the company had done everything dictated by the government that it had to do in manufacturing guns -- no more, no less. But the decision to do more, he said, "came because I couldn't answer the question, 'Was I doing everything I knew how to do to prevent accidents?' " When he asked himself, "Would I put locks on our guns if it might save one child? The answer was yes." It is a decision that seems particularly poignant given the recent Santana High School shooting in Santee, Calif., the latest in a string of tragedies involving firearms.
"I had to make those decisions based on the tradition of the company and my own beliefs of what's right," said Mr. Shultz, who still describes himself as "a rabid gun owner." He said the formal agreement made sense because Smith & Wesson was already doing most of what the municipalities were asking for.
In the short-term, Smith & Wesson is suffering consequences that from a business standpoint might be considered tragic. What adds to the tragedy is that no other manufacturers followed Smith & Wesson's lead and the deal ultimately unraveled.
"Shultz may have done something that was in the best long-term interests of the company -- making it seem like a corporate citizen and just doing the right thing -- but since the law doesn't require others to do it, in the short run it may have hurt the company," said Joseph W. Singer, a law professor at Harvard and author of "The Edges of the Field" (Beacon, 2000).
THE thorny dilemma for company managers then is what to do when deciding between doing the right thing and doing what is best for the business. Ultimately, the ethical choice is clear: do the right thing regardless of whether you are rewarded for doing so.
"If you take your morality seriously," Mr. Gunnemann said, "then what's most important to you is not the bottom line, it's whether you can sleep at night."

HEADLINE: The Skies Are Blue And The Chips Are, Too 

BYLINE:  By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
THE year was 1978. The airline was Braniff. The Halston-clad "air hostess" trainee was a woman named Doreen Lawrence. And she was learning how to walk, the Braniff way.
 "They told you to imagine a string running from your bellybutton to your chin that you had to keep tight so you would have good posture, an arched back," she said. "And to imagine that you were holding a dime with your . . . well, with your rear end. And then when you walked, you had to walk so that your knees almost crossed, which made you kind of swish like a model on a catwalk." 
 She added: "I suppose we learned emergency procedures. I really don't remember it." 
Of course, Braniff disappeared into thin air long ago, but Ms. Lawrence is doing her walk again. She's teaching it to the 250 or so flight attendants who work for JetBlue Airways. The cut-rate airline, which started last year at Kennedy Airport, is trying to usher a little style back into the in-flight experience. It is also advancing the crazy idea that even cost-conscious airline passengers care about look, feel and attitude, almost as much as they care about getting there on time and in one piece.
In the Zagat 2001 survey of American airlines, published this month, JetBlue was rated the second-best economy airline, behind Midwest Express, which serves food on china with silverware and linen napkins, spending an unusually high sum of $10 per passenger per meal.
JetBlue's service does not aim for that kind of elegance, but the Zagat survey, based on the votes of 20,000 passengers, still quoted JetBlue customers who raved about it, calling the new airline a discount "role model," and saying they thought it was already succeeding in "trying to be the U.S. version of Virgin Atlantic." On the business side it appears to be succeeding as well. It turned a profit after only six months in the air.
JetBlue is focusing on good service at a time when lousy airline service is getting a lot of attention. Just last Tuesday, "Dateline NBC" reported on an eight-month examination of how airlines treat customers, finding no shortage of rudeness, lost luggage and lying about delays.
JetBlue's founder, David Neeleman, who grew up in Salt Lake City, wanted not only to bring a little civility back to flying, but also to give his New York-based airline a sense of New York style. Gray leather seats, each with live television, so New Yorkers would not have to suffer even a minute of media withdrawal. Uniforms that were hip and dark.
Originally, the uniforms were to be black, but their designer, Stan Herman, switched to navy blue as a nod to the airline's name. The Web site, www.jetblue.com, is funny and knowing, as is the message that greets callers on hold, acknowledging how everyone hates being on hold. There are no in-flight meals (just a beverage and a bag of blue potato chips), because they are seldom more than an insult on a tray. Most important, the attendants are supposed to have a different approach, confident but not cocky, friendly but not too friendly in that Southwest Airlines "we're all having a party, y'all!" way.
To that end, they hired Ms. Lawrence and another former flight attendant, Dean Melonas, to train the staff in service with retro flair. At Braniff, Ms. Lawrence was serving cocktails on planes whose fuselages were splashed with swirling Calder designs and whose seats were covered with fabrics chosen by Alexander Girard.
Mr. Melonas started his career in 1978 as well, but at American Airlines, never known particularly for its style. But even there, Bill Blass was recruited to design uniforms, and a woman who had once groomed Miss America contestants was brought in to make over the flight attendants.
"That was a long time ago," he said wistfully late last month in Kew Gardens, Queens, where a new crop of JetBlue attendant trainees awaited his old-school customer-service wisdom in a nearby classroom.
In the flight attendant class, at JetBlue's headquarters, Mr. Melonas was trying to get that message across to 27 trainees -- 20 women and 7 men, ranging from 20 to 53. One woman, in her early 50's, had a law degree. Another, also in her 50's, had worked in financing for exotic cars but had always dreamed of becoming a flight attendant. A man in his early 20's had worked part time as an emergency medical technician, and a man in his 40's had been a elementary school phys ed teacher.
Only one had worked for another airline, but all had been passengers. And all seemed as demoralized as your average passenger at the way they had been treated.
"I'd like somebody to describe the experiences they've had on other airlines with the crew," Mr. Melonas said.
"Robotic," one man said.
"Phoning it in," a woman added.
"Right," Mr. Melonas said. Shifting into his motivational-guru persona, he added: "It's the I-don't-have-to attitude. And the we-don't-have-tos of the world are going to be working for some other airline, not this one."
The first signal to the trainees that something might be different came early on, when the airline brought in stylists to cut the students' hair and re-engineer their makeup. (Most airlines no longer do this.)
And for good measure, at the end of every training period, Ms. Lawrence makes everyone learn how to do the Braniff walk, even the guys.
"There are always a few guys who are too shy to get out there and strut," she said. "So when they walk by I let a dime go rolling on the floor and say, 'Hey -- you dropped that.' "
But how much of this new philosophy makes it out of the classroom and onto the plane?
On a recent flight to Fort Lauderdale, I checked in at the JetBlue gate, in Kennedy's soaring Terminal 6, designed by I. M. Pei & Partners. The woman behind the counter was actually friendly -- but not so much that she wasn't able to check me in quickly.
Once on board, I looked down the aisle and saw four flight attendants who looked as if they had been spirited in from the lobby of the Royalton Hotel. No ugly jackets, military accenting or epaulets. The men were in dark shirts with dark ties, some short-sleeve. The women had two-tone blue scarves knotted tightly around their necks, like chokers.
The attendants helped us put our luggage up in the bins. They announced that if we sat down and put our coats on our laps, they would come by and put them up for us. Very efficient. Almost gracious. They seemed to like what they were doing, or were faking it convincingly. They also all seemed to be from New York. (This turned out to be nearly true. Monica Camargo was from Maspeth, Queens. Carlos Olivo was from the South Bronx. Michael Annichiarico was from New Jersey. Bonnie Bolding was from Nashville, but she stressed that she really liked New York a lot.)
Once the plane took off, no beverage cart began stop-starting down the aisle at three inches a minute. Drinks were served from white plastic trays that looked like something the moonliner stewardesses would have used in "2001: A Space Odyssey."
The crew made sure we knew how to work our television sets, with their live satellite feed. I watched old episodes of "The Jetsons," which meshed perfectly with the retro-futuristic setting. Andrew Grossman, a bond analyst who had taken the same Jet Blue 5 p.m. flight to Fort Lauderdale five times in the previous seven weeks, was watching reruns of "Baa Baa Black Sheep," as he had during all the other flights.
"Very cool," he said, the blue glow glinting off his glasses.
On the flight to Fort Lauderdale, passengers were in such a good mood (despite a takeoff that was a little late) that when the flight attendants asked everyone to please help tidy up the cabin after landing, some people actually did. Because the weather was nice, the crew also opened both the front and back hatches, letting everyone deplane more rapidly. Those of us who walked down the back stairs onto the tarmac could pretend we were the Beatles.
All in all, it was not what you would call a luxurious flight. It was certainly not the "upper class" cabin on Virgin Atlantic, where you can socialize in the 747 lounge or snooze under a feather duvet. But then again, the flight didn't cost $7,000. If you book far enough ahead, a trip to Fort Lauderdale can cost $84 one way. And yet, the flight evoked no memories of People Express, the defunct airline so cheap it charged 50 cents for an onboard cup of coffee.
As corny as it sounds, JetBlue's New York personality isn't cool and lofty but warm and down-to-earth. The cabin crew makes a point of introducing the pilots by their first and last names. No "Captain Bob" or "Captain George."
"To me that always sounded like Captain Kangaroo was flying your plane," Mr. Melonas said.
On a flight last year to Orlando, the live television was on the blink. The natives were restless. When a man told Ms. Lawrence that he wanted to propose to his girlfriend on board, she decided to go for broke.
"I said: 'Ladies and gentleman, we're going to have some live entertainment. Direct your attention to Seat 16A. A man is going to get down on one knee and ask a woman to marry him.' "
"The guy looked at me. He said, 'Down on one knee?' I said, 'Down on one knee.' "
The man proposed. The girlfriend said yes. The crew passed out white wine to all the witnesses.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
The Future Won't Be As Good As It Was

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
TRILLIONS of dollars in household wealth has vanished in the sickening stock market fall of the past year. College education funds have been pounded and plans for early retirements probably pushed back as a result. But apart from some finger-pointing and gallows humor in investing chat rooms, investors seem commendably stalwart about the pain they have endured in this bear market, the worst in Nasdaq's history.
 Such investor stoicism is something of a puzzle to many veteran market observers. Since many novices entered the stock market in the 1990's, it was assumed these newcomers would panic and scream bloody murder when their beloved bull was gored. 
 But calm and quiet prevails, at least on the surface of the market.
There are signs of suffering in indicators like consumer confidence and purchases of consumer goods and capital goods, argued Peter J. Tanous, president of Lynx Investment Advisory Inc., a money management concern in Washington. "My sense is that the anguish that people are feeling, they are keeping to themselves because the losses are so big," he said. "Investors are internalizing the pain but it's being reflected in the economy. People are sitting on their hands and their wallets."
Mr. Tanous, author of "Investment Gurus: A Road Map to Wealth From the World's Best Money Managers," makes investor psychology something of a study. He fears that many investors are holding onto decimated stocks in the hopes that they will make a quick comeback, as some have in the past.
A big mistake, in Mr. Tanous' view. And he provides a bit of arithmetic to demonstrate why.
Take a popular stock like Intel, which has fallen 63 percent from its high of $75.81 in August. Many investors feel that Intel's dominance in microprocessors makes it a prime comeback candidate.
Assume that Intel's shares rise 15 percent a year going forward, an enviable return by any investor's reckoning. How long would it take for the shares to get back to their high of just seven months ago?
Seven long years.
Plug in the same assumptions of 15 percent annual returns for the rest of the most popular shares in America and the picture is sobering indeed. These stocks may certainly come back, but if they do, it will more likely be over a period of years, not months.
At 15 percent a year, Cisco shareholders would need to wait a decade for their stock to get back to its high of $82, seen last March. AT&T would climb back to its peak of last March in seven years. General Electric, which has lost a relatively modest 33 percent since its peak of last August, would need three years to return there.
Microsoft would see $115 again in six years, while Oracle shareholders would have to wait nine years to regain their shares' peak. Nine years would also have to pass before Sun Microsystems stockholders would again see the stock's high of $64.66.
Because it has fallen so precipitously in the past year, Yahoo would require even more patience from its stockholders: 20 years of 15 percent gains.
This exercise is not meant to advise investors to dump these shares. Rather, Mr. Tanous wants to show how investors will have to temper their expectations and learn to be satisfied with the lower returns that are more typical of the stock market.
While pundits and strategists quibble over whether the market has bottomed or has further to fall, Mr. Tanous said investors should instead bury any notion they may harbor that the bull market of the last decade will stir again.
"I can state with a great degree of conviction that most of us will never see a decade in the market like the '90's in our lifetime again," Mr. Tanous said. "And until investors taper their expectations to more normalized returns, they're going to be in for trouble."

HEADLINE: The Ties That Bind New York To Wall St.; 
Roiling Market Revives Debate Over Economy

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
Stock market meltdowns have a lot of unpleasant consequences: fortunes lost, retirements ruined, college funds flattened, stock brokers unemployed. But for New Yorkers, there's another, annoying one: political posturing.
 That's because the current turmoil on Wall Street is bringing back to a boil the debate over how much New York City's economy relies on the fortunes of its big financial firms. You may think that the answer is a straightforward one involving only economics and maybe history. You would be wrong. 
 Because the way people answer that question -- often framed as, "Is the economy too dependent on Wall Street?" -- depends almost entirely on which political party they belong to. "Yes!" say the Democrats. "No!" say the Republicans. "Aargh!" say the five people on the planet who have pored through the reams of statistics from both sides, struggling to disentangle politics from economics. 
So far, the fallout from the stock market's swoon has been remarkably small, at least on the jobs front. Although a number of financial firms like Morgan Stanley Dean Witter have said they are considering cutbacks, the carnage has been limited mainly to some high-tech types at Bear Stearns and the fruit baskets in Goldman Sachs's coffee rooms. Thousands of people are losing their jobs because of the merger of Chase Manhattan and J. P. Morgan, but those are related more to the changing nature of commercial banking.
The unemployment rate in the city actually fell in January, when adjusted for seasonal factors. But there has been a worrying jump in the number of people filing claims for unemployment insurance, said James A. Parrott, deputy director of the Fiscal Policy Institute, a research group that has been a frequent critic of the Giuliani administration's economic policies. Even so, Mr. Parrott noted, the claims are still at relatively low levels.
Even people who are not riveted by politics or Wall Street are now wondering whether the current stock market mess will crimp the city's economic boom, or crush it. More on that in a minute.
But political types have been debating the question for years, and the debate is heating up once again. For example, H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, who has announced that he will be a Democratic candidate for governor, is updating a report he issued in 1998 warning that the city was at risk because of its growing reliance on Wall Street to fill its coffers and fuel its economy.
The very mention of this report induces apoplexy in the Pataki administration. "Overdependence on Wall Street is a myth manufactured by Carl McCall," said Stephen Kagann, chief economist for the governor, who objects to the notion that the "city economy is a yo-yo on Wall Street's string." 
If Wall Street does call the tune, Mr. Kagann said, then nobody can say the recession of the 1990's was the fault of the policies of David N. Dinkins, who was then the mayor and is now supporting Mr. McCall, or those of Mario M. Cuomo, the former governor whose son Andrew is also a Democratic candidate for governor. Nor can the administrations of George E. Pataki and Rudolph W. Giuliani, both Republicans, take credit for the boom, which they attribute in large part to their tax cuts and other business-friendly policies.
Taking credit and laying blame are by no means the only factors that cloud the issue. On a percentage basis, Wall Street actually does not account for all that many jobs. Last year, according to Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller, the number was 183,500, less than 5 percent of the total jobs in New York. That's a smaller percentage than remains in the dwindling manufacturing sector.
But those investment bankers and brokers make a lot of money -- about 18 percent of all the wages paid in the city. And depending on how you figure it, their earnings account for a huge portion of the growth in wages in the city over the last decade.
Just their annual bonuses last year totaled $13 billion. That buys a lot of penthouse apartments and restaurant meals, limousine rides and Knicks tickets.
In fact, that puts a lot of people to work. Even Mr. Kagann says that the impact of Wall Street accounts for about a fifth of the city's economy.
And Wall Street pays a lot of taxes, directly and indirectly. The mayor took time at news conferences last week to reassure people that the city government would not be in financial distress if Wall Street's profits dropped, saying that the city was using cautious assumptions about how much revenue the financial firms would generate. For example, the administration says it is assuming that the securities firms will make only $5.1 billion in profits this year, even though they made $19.5 billion last year.
The administration also likes to point to new jobs outside Manhattan, particularly in Queens and Staten Island, to bolster its contention that the city has lots of industries that will not move in lock step with Wall Street's ups and downs.
Marc M. Goloven, the chief regional economist for J. P. Morgan, agrees. "It seems to me that the industry mix is far broader today than it was a decade ago," he said. In the 1980's, the last time Wall Street suffered a serious setback, most of the city's job growth was in government. Today, he said, it is the private sector that is producing new jobs.
Not everyone is convinced. "I personally don't believe the economy is any more diverse than it was a decade ago," said Mark M. Zandi, chief economist at Economy.com, which does economic analyses for clients on both sides of the political aisle. 
The stickiest issue here is a category of companies called business services. This includes everything from accountants to computer services to temporary agencies, and jobs in it have been growing like wildfire. Since 1988, this sector of the economy has added almost 79,000 jobs, and it now accounts for more than 9 percent of total jobs in the city.
Some economists point to this as a sign of diversity. Others, like Mr. Zandi, think business services are entwined with Wall Street because financial firms are their customers or, like the dot-coms, they rely on investment banks for financing.
The issue of how diverse the economy is has a big political dimension, too. Many critics of the Giuliani administration contend that only the wealthy have benefited from the economic boom of the last few years; the poor and middle class, they say, have lost ground. That view was on display at a forum for Democratic mayoral candidates on Thursday night, sponsored by the labor-backed Working Families Party.
Admittedly, the mayoral race has not yet focused much on economic issues. Of course, it hasn't focused much on issues at all; the four candidates who have announced that they are running for the Democratic nomination are still trying to make a dent in the public's consciousness, and there is no real Republican candidate yet.
But if times turn tough, debate over Wall Street's influence and the economy's diversity is certain to heat up in the mayoral race as it already has in the race for governor, politicians say. And economic policies do matter in political contests; many analysts attribute Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate victory to her emphasis on the economic problems of upstate New York, while her opponent, Rick A. Lazio, insisted that things were improving.
New Yorkers may be spared. Wall Street can and does turn on a dime. In 1998, for example, financial markets fell apart, and securities firms feared that they faced big losses. A few laid off people only to rehire them a few months later as business rebounded.
Even Alan Greenspan does not know if that is likely to happen this time; the stock market is in the worst shape it has been in in years. But New Yorkers surely hope the markets do recover, to protect jobs, preserve their portfolios -- and keep the politicians from burying voters in drifts of economic data.

HEADLINE: Disappointed Warrior 

BYLINE:  By Herbert Mitgang; Herbert Mitgang is the author of "Once Upon a Time in New York: Jimmy Walker, Franklin Roosevelt and the Last Great Battle of the Jazz Age."

 BODY:
 EMPIRE STATESMAN
The Rise and Redemption of Al Smith.
By Robert A. Slayton.
Illustrated. 480 pp. New York:
The Free Press. $30.
IT is arguable that the greatest legacy of Alfred E. Smith, the defeated Democratic candidate for president in 1928, was that he paved the way for John F. Kennedy, a fellow Roman Catholic, to be nominated and elected president in 1960. What is still hard to imagine is how much bigotry existed in many corners of the United States during the Roaring Twenties, an era usually depicted as fun-filled and prosperous rather than as infected by outright religious and racial hatred in politics as well as in everyday life.
"Empire Statesman," Robert A. Slayton's biography of Smith, is valuable because it describes the vitriolic mood of much of the nation during the 1928 campaign. The Ku Klux Klan mailed out thousands of postcards reading: "We now face the darkest hour in American history. In a convention ruled by political Romanism, Antichrist has won." When Smith's campaign train reached the Oklahoma state line, crosses were burned in the fields. "Parents were told that if a Catholic was elected, all Protestant marriages would be annulled, immediately rendering their children illegitimate," Slayton writes. "Pictures of the construction of the Lincoln Tunnel were passed out around the country, with captions explaining that it was a secret passageway to bring the pope from Rome to Washington."
Smith (1873-1944) was a product of the sidewalks of New York long before he became a national personality. He came from an Irish immigrant heritage, paid his dues in ward politics and rose in the ranks of Tammany Hall, where it helped to be surrounded by other ambitious machine loyalists. Some of the old ward bosses were corrupt, but Smith was not tainted by Tammany shenanigans. He never forgot, nor did he try to conceal, his origins.
Smith's favorite story about his background dated back to 1911, when he served in the State Assembly. During a debate, several Republican legislators, who boasted about their degrees from Ivy League colleges, tried to intimidate Smith by asking about his education. He replied, "I'm an F.F.M. man." A fellow Tammany assemblyman asked him to explain. "Fulton Fish Market," Smith replied. "Let's proceed with the debate."
Slayton, who teaches history at Chapman University in Orange, Calif., shows that Smith developed a social conscience early in his life. He advocated legislation to help the poor while campaigning for every political office, including the presidency. "To Smith, all of the differences of ethnicity and regionalism and race and religion in the nation would mean nothing, because they would be handled just in the same way these factors were handled in the Fourth Ward," Slayton writes. "Just like in the neighborhood, the people of New York State, and then America, would look at each candidate fairly and choose the best man or woman based on what he or she had done, not who he or she was."
Smith's bighearted views worked while he was running for the New York legislature and for governor, but he did not connect with people across the United States. His New York accent was no asset when he talked about "woik" on the "raddio." (By contrast, Kennedy's Boston accent was considered high-class.) Smith was ahead of his time in respecting the rights of labor unions and in introducing safety regulations in the workplace.
As one of New York's finest governors, Smith showed his greatest talent in his ability to pick talented advisers. His inner circle included Joseph Proskauer, a descendant of German and Austrian Jews who grew up in Mobile, Ala. After encountering anti-Semitism in law school, big law firms and the courts, Proskauer eventually served on the Court of Appeals in Albany. Smith was also far ahead of his time in promoting women to public office. Another close adviser was Belle Moskowitz, another descendant of Jewish immigrants, who grew up in Harlem. Moskowitz was publicity director of the Democratic State Committee; she edited Governor Smith's speeches, and most important, she advocated ideological goals for his administration. Moskowitz also introduced Smith to Robert Moses, who became the head of the state's parks system.
"Smith's greatest concrete achievement was his reshaping of the state structure," Slayton writes. "When he first took office there was corruption and chaos, a system better designed for running a feudal kingdom than a modern unit of government. . . . And he did it without ever forgetting some other values -- like mercy or justice -- and without sacrificing the needs of the poor, the working class or minorities."
The low point of Smith's life and career was his break with his successor, Franklin D. Roosevelt, a former ally in New York reform politics. Smith was anything but statesmanlike in his behavior toward Roosevelt. In 1928, Smith lost his bid for the presidency while Roosevelt won the governorship. "Thus, as the 1928 campaign began, Smith was running with a man he cared about but did not respect; Eleanor Roosevelt wrote, 'In many ways Governor Smith did not know my husband.' Al still woefully underestimated Franklin's abilities and skills, regardless of any evidence to the contrary, despite his very real affection for the man."
Smith wanted to make a second run for the presidency in 1932, but Roosevelt was in a strong position among Democratic candidates. He had been the first governor to advocate unemployment insurance during the Depression, and in 1928 had proven to be a superb campaigner all over the state, while Smith could not shake his national image as a Tammany politician from the Lower East Side. Roosevelt defeated Smith after a floor fight at the Democratic National Convention, increasing Smith's rancor. In his jealousy, Smith opposed the progressive legislation of the New Deal; he turned against himself and all that he had stood for by joining the reactionary Liberty League. Slayton calls Smith's turnabout one of the great tragedies of American politics in the 20th century.
If there was any redemption in Smith's career, it is to be found in the fact that he helped break down the walls of prejudice in American society, not only leading to Kennedy's election in 1960 but very likely to the nomination for vice president of Joseph Lieberman, the first Jew on a major party's ticket -- an act in the finest tradition of Alfred E. Smith. 

CORRECTION-DATE: April 8, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A review on March 18 about "Empire Statesman: The Rise and Redemption of Al Smith," by Robert A. Slayton, included an erroneous reference from the book to the judicial career of Joseph Proskauer, a political adviser to Gov. Alfred E. Smith of New York in the 1920's. Proskauer became a justice in the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court; he was never a member of the Court of Appeals.
