HEADLINE: Japan's Economy Lurks Low on Agenda as Bush and Prime Minister Prepare to Meet 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori of Japan arrived here this afternoon for his first, and likely last, encounter with President Bush, as both Japanese and American officials acknowledged that they had made virtually no progress on drafting a joint statement to reassure world markets that Japan had a firm plan in place to restore economic growth.
 The White House had hoped to transform Monday's meeting with Mr. Mori from a ceremonial first visit to a substantive discussion of the risks ahead for both economies if Japan is unable to resolve its looming banking crisis and stock market downturn. 
 But a senior Japanese official said today that Mr. Mori was arriving with "nothing new to say." 
Meanwhile, some Japanese financial officials have complained that the decline in the American markets is worsening Japan's long-term troubles, especially for Japanese banks holding American equities. 
The finger pointing between Tokyo and Washington has only complicated the politics of Monday's session. Japanese officials say they now hope Mr. Bush and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell will stick close to a prepared script, reaffirming the importance of the security relationship with Japan, apologizing for the sinking of a Japanese ship by an American submarine near Hawaii -- and going light on economic critiques. 
It remained unclear tonight what strategy Mr. Bush would choose in discussing the economy.
"The Japanese problems are humongous in comparison to whatever cyclical downturn is affecting the United States," said Kenneth Courtis, vice chairman for Asia at Goldman, Sachs, the international investment bank. "There is a Himalaya of debt crashing down on the Japanese economy, and the plan that the Japanese have now has only sent the markets in Tokyo down another 7 percent. This is the biggest problem in the world economy today, and it's made worse by super weak governments in Tokyo." That last item is not an issue Mr. Mori is likely to talk about.
Monday's visit marks the first of three international encounters for Mr. Bush this week in which his words, tone and body language will be watched with unusual care.
As Mr. Mori makes his one-day visit on Monday, Israel's new prime minister, Ariel Sharon, will be here seeing General Powell, as well as Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld; Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser; and the director of central intelligence, George Tenet.
On Tuesday Mr. Sharon, who met Mr. Bush in Israel three years ago, will come to the White House seeking the president's tacit approval of his approach to the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, far more cautious and hard-line than that of his predecessor, Ehud Barak.
On Thursday China's deputy prime minister, Qian Qichen, is scheduled to visit the White House, a session likely to be dominated by talk of China's foot-dragging on its entry into the World Trade Organization and Mr. Bush's pending decisions on whether to sell advanced arms to Taiwan and to move ahead with missile defense.
"In the space of one week," a senior State Department official said Friday, "we've got to make a start on the three toughest problems Bush is likely to face this year: Japan, the Middle East and China." 
Just a few months ago, the Bush administration thought it had a strategy worked out for two of these encounters: an elevation of the Japan alliance, which Mr. Bush's foreign policy aides say President Clinton allowed to deteriorate, and a repositioning of China as a "strategic competitor" and occasional economic ally, but not the "strategic partner" Mr. Clinton frequently talked about.
Mr. Bush also vowed that as part of his "humble" approach to foreign policy, he would not lecture the Japanese in public about how they should revive their economy.
"We have to regard Japan as a mature, independent country that determines its own destiny," Lawrence B. Lindsey, Mr. Bush's top economic adviser, said in an interview last week. "Even if we are the older brother and Japan is the younger brother, we have both grown up as democracies. When you are 14 and 8 years old there is a disproportionality in the relationship that doesn't exist when you are 46 and 40."
Many Japanese officials wince at the use of the big-brother, little-brother analogy, saying it has shades of the terminology used during the American occupation of Japan after World War II. But oddly enough, some Japanese bureaucrats argue privately that a more public critique of Japan might be politically useful to reformers in Japan, because it could help force the Liberal Democratic Party to justify long overdue economic changes that are resisted by its key constituencies.
The most important of such reforms, likely to be discussed privately on Monday but scarcely mentioned in the joint statement, is a cleanup of the huge real estate debts that threaten the integrity of Japan's banking system. The Japanese government made a halfhearted attempt at bailing out the banks three years ago, spending hundreds of billions of dollars of taxpayer funds to pump up the banks' balance sheets. But the banks and the politicians could not stomach closing many insolvent banks and selling off real estate at fire-sale prices to get the market going again, the strategy the United States used in the savings and loan crisis in the 1980's.
In Japan, that would probably lead to bankruptcies in the construction and retail industries, and large layoffs. But now the Japanese government, already deep in debt, cannot afford another huge bailout. Meanwhile, Mr. Mori is about to lose his job, and politicians do not want to make any difficult decisions before a national election, probably this summer.
"The question is whether we can wait that long," one of Mr. Bush's aides said last week.

HEADLINE: Plunge in Stocks Colors Debate on Size of Fed Interest Rate Cut 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve will meet tomorrow to decide how much to cut interest rates in an effort to revive the economy just when a falling stock market seems to have the power to bring on a recession.
 No one doubts that Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, and his fellow policy makers will reduce the federal funds rate from its current level of 5.5 percent when they gather in Washington. The question is can a big enough rate cut keep the 10-year-old expansion rolling. 
 Many on Wall Street are lobbying for a cut of three-quarters of a percentage point, or even more, to stop the sell-off of stocks. But other experts argue that a half-point cut is enough for an economy that, apart from the market, still has considerable strengths. 
"What I am concerned about is that we are heading into the unknown because of the stock market," said Ian Shepherdson, chief domestic economist at High Frequency Economics, who favors a reduction of three-quarters of a percentage point. "We have never had so big a decline in stock prices at a time when stocks were so widely held."
The debate over how far the Fed should go to reduce short-term interest rates -- thus influencing what lenders charge for mortgages, home equity loans and other credit -- reflects very different views of the market's impact on the economy.
The Fed's policy makers, including Mr. Greenspan, have soft-pedaled this impact. They have repeatedly stated that their goal is to target the real economy, asking themselves what must be done to increase lackluster consumer spending, work down a backlog of unsold cars as well as other goods, keep up home sales by reducing mortgage rates, and the like. The stock market, in this view, is just one ingredient in the mix.
But the meeting tomorrow will come after a week of plunging stock prices. And many are urging the Fed to recognize that the economy now dances to the stock market, not the other way around.
One important difference, they say, is that nearly 50 percent of American households now own stock, up from less than 10 percent in the early 1960's. And equities, at least until the recent plunge in the market, have become the most important single source of wealth in the country.
"The Federal Reserve has not been able to cope with this changing structure," said Henry Kaufman, the bearish Wall Street economist and consultant. He asserts that, among other shortcomings, the Fed has failed to incorporate into its interest rate policy the extent to which spending and borrowing respond to shifts in a family's stock portfolio. He wants a full percentage-point cut, perhaps enough in his view to end the stock market slide and the damage it is doing to the economy.
Such thinking, however, is widely challenged in academia, where the stock market's movements are often viewed as a less important influence on the economy than factors like the level of unemployment, the value of homes and the pace of wage gains.
"We take the view that the Fed should keep its eye on the inflation ball," said Ben S. Bernanke, a Princeton economist. "The stock market is relevant to the extent that fluctuations in stock prices affect the inflation forecast."
Mr. Greenspan is clearly focused on the real economy, not the stock market. In his last Congressional testimony, on Feb. 28, he concluded that "the sources of long-term strength in the economy remain in place."
That is certainly the case for home prices, which have continued to rise, on average. And for most Americans, homes represent a bigger investment than stocks. Partly because the Fed has cut rates by a percentage point since Jan. 3, the average interest rate on a 30-year mortgage has fallen to 6.96 percent from 7.38 percent in December.
What troubles the economy, Mr. Greenspan said, are the excesses -- too much inventory, for example, and too much capacity -- that built up in 1999 and 2000. These excesses "engendered a retrenchment that has yet to run its full course."
The stock market came up mainly in Mr. Greenspan's comments on consumer confidence. "There may not be a seamless transition from high to moderate to low confidence," he said. The "unpredictable rending of confidence is one reason that recessions are so difficult to forecast," he said.
Among the reams of statistics that Mr. Greenspan will take to the meeting tomorrow are preliminary findings for March from the University of Michigan's monthly survey of consumer sentiment. Those findings suggest that consumer confidence, while no longer falling, as it did in December, January and February, began in March to show the first effects of the Wall Street sell-off. 
"We have been talking to lots of people who say they are recession-proof," said Richard T. Curtin, director of Michigan's Consumer Surveys. "People always initially insist that a downturn will affect others more than themselves. But as the weeks pass, we get to the point where fear and uncertainty take over."
That may be just beginning to happen. For months, people told the surveyors that they viewed the future as bleak, both for the economy and their own finances, but that they saw their current circumstances as positive. That order reversed in March, Mr. Curtin reported Friday.
The preliminary findings for the month, based on 350 telephone interviews -- 100 of them last week, while stocks plunged -- found Americans optimistic that the economy, and the market, would rebound in 2002, but increasingly pessimistic about the present. An index measuring future expectations rose, while one measuring current conditions fell sharply.
The 100 households polled last week were "marginally less happy than the others," said Mr. Curtin, whose organization will conduct 150 more interviews before the final March results are announced in two weeks. "I don't think consumers have completely digested what has happened to the stock market during this most recent week, and until they do, we won't know the damage to confidence," he said.
At the same time, the stock market sell-off raises a new issue in the debate over tax cuts. The administration of President Bush has asserted that the tax cut will revive a faltering economy because Americans will spend most of the money they no longer must devote to taxes. But in interviews last week, White House officials mentioned the possibility that people would save some of the tax money or use it to pay down debt, now that shrinking stock portfolios can no longer justify the debt. 
"It is kind of hard for the administration to advocate savings and stimulus" simultaneously, a senior White House official said.
If Americans save most of the money from a tax cut or use it to pay down debts, the economy is more likely to remain sluggish.
"Seventy percent of the debt is owed by the bottom 90 percent of the population," said David Wyss, chief economist at Standard & Poor's DRI, a consulting and data gathering operation. "They are not the ones owning most of the stock, but many own some, and the falling market is making them nervous."
Most of the surge in stock ownership to nearly 50 percent of the population -- and 86 percent of households with incomes above $50,000 -- came since 1980, particularly with the advent of defined contribution pension plans, in which people save for their own retirement. The most popular of these savings vehicles, 401(k) plans, held $1.7 trillion in December 1999, the latest figures available.
Three-quarters of this money was invested in stock, according to the Investment Company Institute. And thousands of retirees who receive monthly or quarterly checks from these accounts will soon get checks for smaller amounts -- a fresh blow to consumer confidence. The pension payments, recalculated periodically, are based partly on a percentage of the value of each account. As stocks in these accounts fall in value, so will the pension checks.
That is certainly the case at TIAA-CREF, the teacher retirement fund, which recalculates its 401(k) accounts each March 31. Pension checks now go to 250,000 retirees, most of whom have at least some stock in their accounts. And when they get the next check, there will also be a letter from John H. Biggs, TIAA-CREF's chairman. He will remind them that while their pensions are now a bit smaller, last year they increased an average of 22 percent.
"I did not send them a letter last year, and they did not send me a thank you note," Mr. Biggs said. "But I will probably hear from them this year."

HEADLINE: Taliban Explains Buddha Demolition 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
With outrage still fresh around the world over the destruction of two giant Buddha statues in Afghanistan, a Taliban envoy says the Islamic government made its decision in a rage after a foreign delegation offered money to preserve the ancient works while a million Afghans faced starvation. 
 "When your children are dying in front of you, then you don't care about a piece of art," Sayed Rahmatullah Hashimi, the envoy, said in an interview on Friday. 
 Mr. Rahmatullah is in the United States on a mission to improve ties and ease the Taliban's isolation. A main focus of his visit, he said, will be to find a way out of the impasse surrounding Osama bin Laden, the terrorist suspect whose presence in Afghanistan has prompted international sanctions. 
Still, Mr. Rahmatullah expressed no remorse over the demolition of the two giant Buddhas, carved from a cliff in central Afghanistan 1,400 years ago and considered one of the world's artistic treasures. 
An adviser to the Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, Mr. Rahmatullah gave for the first time here the Taliban's version of events: how a council of religious scholars ordered the statues destroyed in a fit of indignation. 
The destruction, according to his account, was prompted last month when a visiting delegation of mostly European envoys and a representative of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization offered money to protect the giant standing Buddhas at Bamiyan, where the Taliban was engaged in fighting an opposition alliance. 
Other reports, however, have said the religious leaders were debating the move for months, and ultimately decided that the statues were idolatrous and should be obliterated. 
At the time the foreign delegation visited, United Nations relief officials were warning that a long drought and a harsh winter were confronting up to a million Afghans with starvation. Mr. Rahmatullah said that when the visitors offered money to repair and maintain the statues, the Taliban's mullahs were outraged. 
"The scholars told them that instead of spending money on statues, why didn't they help our children who are dying of malnutrition? They rejected that, saying, 'This money is only for statues.' "
"The scholars were so angry," he continued. "They said, 'If you are destroying our future with economic sanctions, you can't care about our heritage.' And so they decided that these statues must be destroyed." The Taliban's Supreme Court confirmed the edict. 
"If we had wanted to destroy those statues, we could have done it three years ago," Mr. Rahmatullah said. "So why didn't we? In our religion, if anything is harmless, we just leave it. If money is going to statues while children are dying of malnutrition next door, then that makes it harmful, and we destroy it."
"What do you expect from a country when you just ostracize them and isolate them and send in cruise missiles and their children are dying?" he said, referring to the sanctions and American attacks against Mr. bin Laden's base in Afghanistan after the bombing of two American embassies in Africa in 1998. 
"You don't recognize their government," Mr. Rahmatullah added. "It is a kind of resentment that is growing in Afghanistan." 
At the same time, he said the Taliban would not destroy statues actually being worshiped, and would not touch the Hindu temples still left in Afghanistan. 
Mr. Rahmatullah is due to meet officials of the State Department and National Security Council on Monday in Washington, where he will also speak next week at the Council on Foreign Relations, the Atlantic Council of the United States and the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies.
He would not disclose details of a possible new proposal for a way out of the standoff over Mr. bin Laden, the Taliban's fourth, saying he needed a signal from Washington first.
But there are reports in Pakistan that one option might be turning Mr. bin Laden over to a special tribunal, perhaps in The Hague, for trial by a panel of Islamic judges. 
The Clinton administration had rejected an Afghan trial, international monitoring of Mr. bin Laden -- whom Mr. Rahmatullah described as a nobody the Americans made into a hero -- or exile in another Muslim country. 
Mr. Rahmatullah's visit and the wide hearing he is getting have provoked criticism in Congress, particularly from supporters of India, which along with Russia has begun to give military help to the Taliban's opposition. He was given an American visa because he falls below the rank of the highest officials in the Taliban government, who are barred from traveling under an embargo.
Throughout a long interview on a range of subjects, Mr. Rahmatullah maintained the fiercely independent attitude of the Taliban, who have demonstrated repeatedly to the United Nations that they will cooperate with the world only on their own terms.
"They want to change our policies through economic sanctions," he said of the United States and other nations that pushed an embargo through the Security Council. "That does not work. For us, our ideology is first, then the economy. To try to change our ideology with economic sanctions is ridiculous."
Mr. Rahmatullah, who is 24 -- Mullah Omar, at 40, is the oldest of the Taliban's leaders -- grew up in a refugee camp near Quetta, Pakistan, and was educated in an Islamic religious school there. He learned to speak almost flawless English in a class for refugees.
On his first trip to the United States, he said he liked Americans more than he expected because he found them more open-minded than Europeans. He has been speaking at universities on the West Coast. 
Mr. Rahmatullah said the Taliban were in fairly desperate need of agricultural help to supply farmers who once planted opium and to teach them to grow other crops. The United Nations narcotics control program has told the Taliban it has no money for seeds, and drug-control officials wonder if the new ban on poppy cultivation can be sustained.
Mr. Rahmatullah said the Taliban were making strides in health and education with very little foreign help. He said medical or nursing schools for men and women had now opened in Kabul, Kandahar, Jalalabad, Herat and Mazaar-i-Sharif. 
A curriculum for the first seven years of general schooling had been prepared, he said, combining religious and secular subjects in separate schools for boys and girls. 
The Taliban has come under criticism for its treatment of women, who must be shrouded head to toe, cannot leave home unaccompanied by a male relative and have been removed from some jobs and schools where they might mix with men. 
Mr. Rahmatullah and his wife, Jamila, another former refugee, have just had their first child, a daughter. They named her Soriya. "It means the Pleiades -- you know, the stars," he said. 
Did he want her to go to school? 
"Of course," he said. "She will not be a good mother if she is not educated."

HEADLINE: Washington Memo; 
For Bush, a Chronicle Of Bad News Foretold

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18 

 BODY:
Normally, presidents are cheerleaders for the nation's economy.
 On Oct. 19, 1987, the day the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 508 points, or 22.6 percent, President Ronald Reagan said the historic fall was simply investors taking profits. The next day, he blamed Democrats in Congress. The day after that, Mr. Reagan proclaimed that the crisis "appears to be over." 
 In 1991, when the economy was last in a recession, President George Bush told Congress in his State of the Union address that there were "reasons to be optimistic about our economy." He predicted, accurately, that "we will get on our way to a new record of expansion and achieve the competitive strength that will carry us into the next American century." 
For President Bill Clinton, touting the economy posed no problem, since he presided over a period of unremittingly good economic news.
Now comes George W. Bush, who is presenting what an analysis in The Financial Times last week called "the novel spectacle" of a president "urging citizens to ignore good economic news and focus on the bad."
All week, the president talked about the economy "sputtering," and he wrapped up the week on Saturday by beginning his weekly radio address to the nation this way: "Good morning. For several months, economic indicators have pointed toward a slowdown, and now many Americans are starting to feel its impact. The stock market is causing worries, high energy prices are straining family budgets and some workers and small-business people have been directly affected by layoffs and slowing retail sales."
The fact of the matter is that the stock market did have a very bad week -- its worst in 11 1/2 years -- and many people are beginning to feel the pinch. But the economic news is not universally bad. 
The Labor Department reported that 135,000 jobs were created in February, and the unemployment rate remained low at 4.2 percent. Retail sales remain relatively strong, particularly for big-ticket items like cars. Almost certainly, given the growth in jobs, the economy is not now in a recession.
But Mr. Bush and his advisers clearly decided a while back that the best shot they had for getting the public to support and Congress to approve a large tax cut was to argue that the measure was essential to bolster a sagging economy.
Early in his presidential campaign, in December 1999, when the economy was on a roll, Mr. Bush outlined his tax plan to the Chamber of Commerce in Des Moines and suggested that economists might be wrong in forecasting continued economic growth. Just in case, he declared, taxes should be lowered because "if delayed until a downturn begins, tax cuts would come too late to prevent a recession."
Last September, with the campaign heating up, the economic horizon was still free of clouds, but Mr. Bush adopted a new slogan -- "education recession" -- and he began using it in his daily stump speeches.
"In some places, there is a recession in America," he said at a high school in California. "In some school districts, there is a recession, and this country needs to do something about it early, before it's too late."
He always used the term in the context of what he called a crisis in the nation's public schools. But if people took it in an economic context, the way the word recession is usually used, that was O.K. with Mr. Bush and his advisers.
As the campaign wore on, Mr. Bush seized on every piece of unfavorable economic news. In late September, for instance, after an increase in oil prices, he spoke at a container-manufacturing factory in Green Bay, Wis., and emphasized the possibility of a sharp economic downturn.
He began using the term "second wind," which he is still using today, to describe what a tax cut could give the economy.
On Election Day, the economy was by all accounts still strong. The unemployment rate was at 3.9 percent, a 30-year low. Consumer confidence was extremely high despite higher oil prices and fluctuations in the stock market. Economic growth in 2000 was expected to be the strongest since the end of Ronald Reagan's first term in 1984. A Bloomberg News survey of economists showed that they expected the economy to expand by a healthy 3.7 percent over the next 12 months.
But shortly after the election, weaknesses began to appear. Sales of autos, housing and computers began to slide. Less favorable statistics showed up on capital spending, corporate profits, consumer confidence, factory production, store sales, income, job creation and stock prices.
With the outcome of the election still being contested, Mr. Bush and his associates jumped at the opportunity to attribute the weakness to the Democratic administration.
On Dec. 3, Dick Cheney went on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" and declared, "We may well be on the front edge of a recession here."
That was just the beginning. On Dec. 15, two days after Al Gore conceded the presidency, Mr. Bush said, "Vice President-elect Cheney was right in echoing concerns, my concerns about a possible slowdown."
A week later, he told reporters: "I keep hearing talk about, you know, well, this is an administration that is trying to talk down the economy. That's foolish talk. All of us in the Bush administration will want the economy to be strong. But there are some clear warning signs, warning signs that will require what we believe is important action in the halls of Congress, such as tax relief."
On Jan. 3, after the Federal Reserve Board lowered interest rates for the first time in more than two years, Mr. Bush declared that a tax cut was "an integral part of economic recovery" -- recovery being a term usually used to describe what happens when the economy begins to grow after a recession.
In his Inaugural Address on Jan. 20, Mr. Bush called for a tax reduction "to recover the momentum of our economy."
On Feb. 8, when he sent his tax bill to Congress, he said: "The warning signs are clear. All of us here in Washington, the president and the Congress, are responsible to confront the danger of an economic slowdown and to blunt its effects."
On Feb. 13, there was a bit of good economic news, a report showing strong growth in retail sales in January. Asked about it by a reporter traveling with him on Air Force One, Mr. Bush said, "I think it's one good statistic amongst a sea of some pretty dismal statistics."
Last week, Democrats in Congress came close to blaming Mr. Bush for the bad stock market by saying that to bolster the case for a tax cut, he had scared consumers and investors.
"I think what we're seeing is a talking down of the economy," said Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader in the House of Representatives. "I think that kind of economic leadership is irresponsible. I think it's mismanagement of our economy."
But Mr. Bush's defenders discount the Democratic statements as petty politics. "To suggest that the president's words have caused any of these actions," said Ari Fleischer, the press secretary, "is as wrong as wrong can be."

HEADLINE: Conservatives Savor Their Role As Insiders at the White House 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18 

 BODY:
For many conservatives, the heady days of the first Reagan administration were as good as it gets. Until now.
 Two months into the Bush administration, the conservative establishment is getting an extraordinary amount of attention from the White House. Administration officials regularly attend the meetings of the important conservative coalitions. They coordinate lobbying strategy on issues like President Bush's plan for a tax cut. They take conservatives' recommendations on policy and appointments very, very seriously, and have assembled an administration that is "more Reaganite than the Reagan administration," as Edwin J. Feulner, president of the conservative Heritage Foundation, puts it. 
 In fact, conservative leaders say they feel like an integral part of this administration, rather than an outside constituent group, invited in for the occasional photo opportunity with the president. Many also say the contrast could not be more striking with former President George Bush, who alienated much of his conservative base even before he reneged on his "no new taxes" pledge. 
In short, says Grover Norquist, the president of Americans for Tax Reform and a leading conservative strategist: "There isn't an us and them with this administration. They is us. We is them."
The impact of this conservative ascendancy is clear on policy and staffing. The first few months have seen a string of victories for what Mr. Norquist calls the "center-right coalition," from reversing the administration's position on regulating carbon dioxide, to rolling back the new Labor Department rules aimed at preventing repetitive stress syndrome, to imposing a new ban on federal aid to international family planning groups that counsel or promote abortions. The conservative influence is felt not only on the major cabinet-level appointments, like Attorney General John Ashcroft and Labor Secretary Elaine L. Chao, but also the lower-tier jobs that are now being filled.
But the benefits flow two ways, particularly as the battle over Mr. Bush's signature tax plan moves to a Senate divided 50-50 between the parties. Conservative groups are providing the administration with additional organizational muscle, grass-roots networks that can be brought to bear on wavering senators and the incalculable security of a strong and contented base.
A good snapshot of this relationship comes every Wednesday, at 10 a.m., when Mr. Norquist convenes "the Wednesday meeting" -- an invitation-only gathering of more than 100 representatives from social, religious and economic groups in the conservative movement, as well as business and trade associations, Republican Congressional leadership offices and the major research groups on the right. These meetings, which began in 1993 to try to stop the Clinton health care initiative, are often focused these days on advancing the Bush agenda. The Bush administration has had at least one representative at every meeting.
And the lineup is often impressive: Lawrence B. Lindsey, Mr. Bush's chief economic adviser, briefed the group on the president's tax plan at one meeting last month, declaring, "We have a battle on our hands, but I think it's a battle we're going to win." 
Moments later, Ken Mehlman, director of political affairs at the White House, told the group that the president's tax cut would pass when the roar from the crowd enveloped the political leaders here in Washington -- as it did, he said, during Mr. Bush's inaugural address. "The key to this will really be what kind of grass-roots support we get," Mr. Mehlman said.
The Wednesday meeting is an important vehicle for building that support. "If you want to say, 'Hey, guys, we'd like your help on x, y and z,' there are 110 guys there," Mr. Norquist said. "They come out of that meeting, go back to their groups, and they're talking to thousands of people."
Many of the groups at the Wednesday meeting have, in fact, formally endorsed the tax cut in recent weeks and spread the word to their memberships. In some cases, they swallowed objections to particular parts of the bill, or, in the case of business, to omissions. Mr. Norquist argues that this reflects the new maturity of the conservative movement. At one point, he told the Wednesday meeting: "There's a patience that comes from being in power. We're going to be in power next year and the year after that and the year after. It enables us to play a salami-slicing strategy that the left did for 40 years."
Mr. Norquist's meeting ends at 11:30; shortly thereafter, many conservatives head to a lunch meeting that Paul Weyrich began in 1983, which draws about 70 conservative advocates. There, too, someone from the administration has attended every week; at one recent meeting, for example, conservatives expressed concern to an administration official about the issue of embryonic stem cell research, which is under review by the Department of Health and Human Services. 
"I've been through five Republican administrations, and the effort to communicate with conservatives and to understand our concerns and address our concerns and involve us in the process is the best of any of the Republican administrations," Mr. Weyrich said, "including Ronald Reagan. In fact, far superior to Ronald Reagan."
At the Heritage Foundation, Mr. Feulner says he talks to Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's political czar, a couple of times a week. (Mr. Norquist has known Mr. Rove for 22 years, since they met when they were both members of the College Republicans.)
When Mr. Feulner spoke to a reporter one recent afternoon, he had just returned from the swearing-in of Ms. Chao, a former Heritage Foundation official, as labor secretary. "My first time in the Oval Office in quite a few years," Mr. Feulner said. Still, he could see a lot of familiar faces, with Heritage alumni now scattered in jobs throughout the administration. Moreover, Mr. Feulner added, Mr. Bush was "quite enthusiastic" about some of the policy reports the foundation had sent him.
And at the conservative Family Research Council, Kenneth L. Connor, its president, says, "We are afforded access to the highest senior officials." When Mr. Connor's group held its two-day annual "Washington Briefing" for social conservatives this week, the speakers included Mr. Ashcroft; Mel Martinez, the secretary of Housing and Urban Development; and Tim Goeglein, a deputy in the White House Office of Public Liaison, whose portfolio includes religious and social conservatives. The president delivered a taped greeting, Mr. Connor said.
Mr. Rove is widely credited with creating the political structure that keeps conservatives so happily engaged. Mr. Weyrich suggests that the administration's attentiveness may stem from the closeness of the election, "that they're there by the grace of God, and if they don't pay attention to their coalition they won't be there."
But there may be an even simpler explanation, Mr. Norquist suggests: that Mr. Bush, unlike his father, came of age during a conservative ascendancy, and he is utterly confident in the power and appeal of his conservative beliefs.
Indeed, said Ralph Reed, the former Christian Coalition strategist who advised the Bush campaign last year, Mr. Bush had a long history as governor of Texas of working closely with "the grass-roots constituencies that were important to the Republican Party." 
Mr. Reed added, "They did not get everything they sought, but it was a very symbiotic, effective and transparent relationship, that was based on respect and in many cases longstanding friendships."
As the administration now confronts a recalcitrant Senate, after the House passed the tax cut on a party-line vote, conservatives are hoping to raise the heat. Some conservative groups, like the Issues Management Center, are running radio commercials in selected states. Mr. Norquist's Americans for Tax Reform is working to get state legislatures to pass resolutions in support of the tax cut -- particularly useful in states with Democratic senators.
Mr. Norquist recently participated in a conference call with hundreds of state legislative leaders, outlining the strategy; Vice President Dick Cheney helped make the pitch.
Conservative groups are also keeping close watch on the various departments; for example, Christie Whitman of the Environmental Protection Agency has drawn frequent fire from the right on global warming and other issues.
But some conservative leaders say the movement is simply less wary of the Bush administration than it was of previous Republican administrations. "Part of it is a more mature center-right coalition that isn't expecting to be double-crossed," Mr. Norquist said. 
Part of it, others suggest, is that many conservatives now see themselves less as outsiders than as part of a conservative establishment, with like-minded allies throughout the government. 
Indeed, there is a growing group of conservatives who have now moved in and out of government, Mr. Feulner of the Heritage Foundation said, gaining more and more credentials as they go. Officials at the foundation passed on 1,200 to 1,300 names and resumes to the Bush administration and say they are quite pleased with the results so far, at the cabinet level and at the next tier. Among the recent nominees particularly popular with conservatives was Wade F. Horn, formerly president of the National Fatherhood Initiative, a group aimed at "restoring responsible fatherhood as a national priority," who was nominated assistant secretary at Health and Human Services for family support.
Part of this evolution for conservatives, Mr. Norquist argues, is an ever closer alliance with the business community. "Part of what we're doing is bringing K Street and the business community in," he said, using shorthand for the lobbying community. "They should be an integral part of the center-right coalition. What does the business community want? Deregulation. Free trade. Tax cuts."
Mr. Norquist laughs at those who argue that the tension between economic and social conservatives will inevitably plague the Republicans. "It's like the physicists who tell you bumblebees can't fly," he said. "But bumblebees fly."

HEADLINE: A Musical Comedy Star? No, She Just Plays Them; 
Christine Pedi Keeps Making an Impression With Her Parodies of Broadway's Divas

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
For the last 10 years, while most musical-theater performers have been struggling to become Broadway stars, Christine Pedi has been impersonating them.
 Able to adjust her voice to the gutsy gravel of Elaine Stritch, the breathy vibrato of Liza Minnelli or the childlike chirp of Bernadette Peters, Ms. Pedi has uncannily inhabited each of those leading ladies and countless others as one of the quartet of players in the 19-year-old spoof "Forbidden Broadway." 
 Hear Ms. Pedi belt out "Curtain up, light the lights, and you better turn off all the mikes," and you could swear you were hearing Ethel Merman reincarnated. 
Watch her contort her mouth as she morphs into Patti LuPone or widen her eyes as she channels Carol Channing, and it is clear that what Ms. Pedi makes look easy is difficult and rare. Reviewing the latest edition of "Forbidden Broadway" in The New York Times, Ben Brantley called Ms. Pedi, who has played the most performances of any cast member, "the sharpest caricaturist of the group." 
In perfecting this kind of satire, Ms. Pedi is following in the tradition of revues like the 1950's "New Faces," which introduced performers like Imogene Coca, Eartha Kitt and Paul Lynde and used material by aspiring writers like Mel Brooks. Similarly, Betty Comden and Adolph Green in their early days wrote and performed sketches at the Village Vanguard as part of the Revuers, a group that also included Judy Holliday.
Gerard Alessandrini, who created and writes "Forbidden Broadway" -- which currently plays at the theater at Ellen's Stardust Diner and is updated regularly -- said that Ms. Pedi was notable not just for her ability to caricature actresses but also to conjure them. "She's more than a mimic," he said. "She's zeroing in on what makes them tick." 
Why 10 years? Why hasn't Ms. Pedi moved onto something else? Because, she said, she loves the show. Because it has taken her to other cities and keeps changing, which keeps it interesting. Because it is a steady paycheck, and Hollywood has not come calling yet.
In this way Ms. Pedi is like other performers who have had just enough fame to keep the fire going. She was nominated for a Drama Desk award in 1996 for her performance in "Forbidden Hollywood," which parodies movie stars. She made her Broadway debut in the revival of "Little Me" in 1998. She recorded some material for the recent ABC film about Judy Garland (although most of it ended up on the cutting room floor) and last week was among those featured in "Nothing Like a Dame," the annual all-female performance to benefit the Actor's Fund. Yet she still lives in a studio apartment in the theater district with a bed in the dining alcove and a postage-stamp kitchen, where she defiantly manages to turn out cookies for fellow cast members because, gosh darn it, she is determined to bake. ("I come out with bruises," she concedes.)
She remembers all too vividly what it took to get this far. She handed out samples of Godiva chocolate at a Bloomingdale's in White Plains and orange Crush and grape Nehi in the Waldbaums in Larchmont, N.Y. She played Carlotta the Gypsy Cow at an I.B.M. family day downwind of the petting zoo at the Dutchess County State Fair. ("I don't do pastures or pull a plow, my name's Carlotta, I'm a gypsy cow.")
She also handed out fliers for Bonds men's store; she thought she'd be giving them to passers-by in the mall outside the shop in Long Island City, Queens, not to drivers on the ramp from the tunnel. "That's why, whenever I see that guy dressed up like a cell phone on Ventura Boulevard" in Los Angeles Ms. Pedi said, "I say, 'There but for the grace of God . . .' " 
Ms. Pedi now has her fans, and she hustles to build and sustain that following, corraling people who come up to her after a show onto her mailing list (now with 600 names) and peppering them with fliers about her other events, like a Comden and Green review last fall (she proudly shows snapshots of her beaming between the songwriters); "Gypsy of the Year," the annual Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS benefit.
"My sister's pediatrician has come and wants to be on my mailing list," she said. "Those are the people you have to work at cultivating." 
Even the recent cabaret evening Ms. Pedi performed at the Firebird Cafe on Restaurant Row, West 46th Street, in Clinton, "Forbidden Divas . . . Undressed," was her own idea and produced at her own expense: $1,000, including $50 an hour for the piano player, $300 to mail the fliers (some of which she put up herself on the backstage bulletin boards of Broadway shows), $55 for the burgundy velvet gown on sale with a coupon at Lord & Taylor and $75 for the jewelry to match.
Ms. Pedi had planned to have two such solo evenings, but only seven people signed up for the first one, and she had to cancel it. The second one was full, though she said she knew everyone in the audience except members of the press. Another performance at the Firebird is planned for April 19.
In addition to Broadway legends like Gwen Verdon, Julie Andrews and Barbara Streisand, Ms. Pedi's "Forbidden Divas" included the movie star Sharon Stone ("I'd play Madame Bovary by showing you my ovary," she sings to the theme from "Rawhide"), whom Ms. Pedi has done in productions of "Forbidden Hollywood."
Her cousin came to see her cabaret performance. "It was so important that my cousin Vinnie liked it," Ms. Pedi said in a recent interview at her home, where the southern exposure makes the temperature a perpetual 85 degrees. "I never get to go to any of his backyard barbecues because I'm always working Sundays."
When Ms. Pedi was growing up in Eastchester, N.Y., the first cast album she heard was "My Fair Lady." The first cast album she owned was "Bye, Bye, Birdie." 
"When I heard that overture, I couldn't believe it," she said. "I couldn't believe how gorgeous it was." She said she was also influenced by her cousin, Tom Pedi, a character actor who was in the original productions of "Guys and Dolls," "Death of a Salesman" and "A View from the Bridge."
"Tom did it for the love of theater," she said. "He didn't care about the approval of anyone else. He did it because he loved to be onstage."
Ms. Pedi took singing in high school, performing mostly "Italian art songs about women who want to throw themselves off bridges," she said. Her parents, both hairdressers, owned a beauty salon that they sold when personal blow dryers became popular. Then her father, now retired, drove a bus, and her mother went into real estate. Ms. Pedi will not give her age except to say she is in her 30's and "old enough to remember the Beatles and young enough to have watched 'Sesame Street.' "
She went to Fordham University, where she studied communications and worked at the radio station, anchoring the news and becoming arts editor, which allowed her to see two or three Broadway shows a week. After graduating she played the Westchester circuit: the Pleasantville Music Theater, the Chappaqua Drama Group, the Harrison Players. She did voice-overs. She "temped and temped and temped."
In 1990 she went to an open call for "Forbidden Broadway." "I vowed that it was my last cattle call," she said. "I wouldn't sit in a room with 300 other girls and wait and wait and wait." 
The people from "Forbidden Broadway" asked her if she did impressions. She did her Italian grandmother, then Carol Channing. They gave her music to take home to do Patti LuPone and Ethel Merman. When she came for the callback a week later, she nailed both characters. "I thought this girl was tremendous," Mr. Alessandrini said.
Ms. Pedi started on the "Forbidden Broadway" national tour in 1991, spending 109 days on the road traveling to 67 cities with only 5 days off. The three days in Akron, Ohio, made a particularly strong impression. "I will never forget it as long as I live," she said. "Akron needed a lot of lovin'."
After five weeks in Salt Lake City, Ms. Pedi moved to a sit-down company of "Forbidden Broadway" -- meaning one that stays put -- in her case in Detroit, where she had a side baking business she called Musical Comedy Cookies; the advertisement showed a tap-dancing chocolate-chip cookie with a bow. Next came Japan ("because who's going to say no to Tokyo, right?"), then Denver. Finally she got the call she had been waiting for: Mr. Alessandrini asked her to join the New York company. She thought he would never ask. 
"I believe you work your way up the ladder," she said. "In my case it's been one rung at a time."
Just her luck, the show closed two months after she joined. Ms. Pedi said she wound up unemployed, weathering a winter of blizzards by apartment-sitting for her sister in Westchester. Then she got the call to do "Forbidden Broadway" in the Tiffany Theater in Hollywood in 1994. From there she went with the show to the Old Town Theater in San Diego, then to the Coronet Theater in Los Angeles. In early 1995 she began previews for "Forbidden Hollywood" in Los Angeles. Then "Forbidden Hollywood" came to New York. And finally in 1996 "Forbidden Broadway" came back, featuring Ms. Pedi. 
So who are her favorites? She said she liked playing her British characters: Judi Dench, Emma Thompson, Julie Andrews. The audience's favorite is Elaine Stritch ("You're so deadpan people think that you're dead"), and an ear nose and throat doctor recently told her she had a callus on her vocal chords to prove it. 
"It's all Elaine Stritch's fault," Ms. Pedi said.
As for Ms. Stritch herself, she has seen Ms. Pedi do her and said she accepted it graciously. "I felt I'd like to meet her," Ms. Stritch said. "First I'd slap her, then I'd talk to her about me. In that order." 
And how does Ms. Pedi prepare? Does she study videotapes of these performers, rewinding again and again to memorize their mannerisms? Does she listen to recordings over and over to perfect their intonations? 
"I just go to the theater," Ms. Pedi said, "and pay attention."

HEADLINE: Mir Deemed Triumph, Despite a 'Year in Hell' 

BYLINE:  By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19 

 BODY:
Like an aging movie star or a veteran baseball player who has gone past his prime, the Mir space station tends to be remembered for troubles in its declining years rather than the accomplishments of its earlier days.
 The Russian space station is scheduled to come down by the end of the week after 15 years of pioneering the concept of long-term human space flight. 
 The latest plans call for the 135-ton laboratory to incinerate in the atmosphere on Thursday or Friday after rocket firings bring it out of orbit, dumping tons of its remains in the South Pacific.
These days, the favorite adjectives for Mir seem to be decrepit, rickety, trouble-prone or aging; the common synonyms, "derelict," "rattletrap" or "orbiting junk pile." After years of showing the world how space flight can be done, Mir has an image shaped by latter-day problems, particularly those publicized in 1997 when every calamity seemed to befall the station. 
"Mir was a triumph that can be credited with many firsts in space," said James Oberg, a Houston-based expert on the Russian space program and former NASA engineer. "But what most people remember are the problems of 1997, one bad year out of 15."
During that year, Mir fell victim to its age and years of inadequate maintenance because of the Russian space program's shortage of money. The problems drew more attention than they normally would have, experts said, because they occurred while American astronauts were aboard the station as part of the cooperative Shuttle-Mir Program leading up to the new International Space Station project.
In 1997, referred to by some as Mir's "year in hell," an oxygen-generating canister ignited a hard-to-extinguish smoking fire. Later, a Progress supply ship testing new docking procedures crashed into the station, damaging and decompressing one of its six sections and endangering lives. Also that year, both of the station's oxygen-producing systems and its stabilizing gyroscopes failed and toxic antifreeze leaked into the spacecraft's atmosphere. Mir's main computer system also broke down, causing the station to drift several times, and there were several power failures.
Most of these problems were repaired, with American help and supplies, but Mir's reputation as a dilapidated station crippled by old age stuck.
Charles P. Vick, a space policy specialist with the Federation of American Scientists, said Mir would ultimately be remembered as a milestone in space exploration and the craft that showed long-term human habitation in space was possible. Russians rightly consider the station a symbol of their nation's leadership in space, Mr. Vick said.
"Mir is a major, major accomplishment of both the former Soviet Union and Russia," he said. "In many respects, it is an accomplishment on the level of the moon landing for the United States."
Russian pride continues to inspire calls to keep Mir aloft. But Yuri Koptev, head of the Russian Aviation and Space Agency, said the nation could not afford to maintain Mir and meet its obligations for the International Space Station.
During Mir's lifetime, Mr. Koptev said, Russia spent the equivalent of $4.2 billion to build and maintain the station. He said Mir's condition had deteriorated so much that astronauts were spending more than 80 percent of their time on repairs, leaving little time for research.
"The Mir has lived a wonderful life and must end it in a graceful way," Mr. Koptev said in endorsing the controlled deorbiting of the station.
A major part of the International Space Station, the $60 billion scientific outpost that a 16-nation consortium led by the United States is building in orbit, is the Russian service module, he said.
This segment, which provides living quarters and station control during the early stages of the project, is almost identical to the main section of the Mir and was built as the core of a planned Mir-2 craft.
"Many of the lessons of Mir are built into the new station, which literally has Mir-2 at its core," Mr. Vick said.
The Soviet Union launched the first segment of Mir, which was designed to last three to five years, on Feb. 20, 1986. Mir, named after a word that means both peace and world in Russian, housed 104 astronauts over 12 years and seven months, most of whom were not Russian. Mir became the first international space station by playing host to 62 people from 11 countries.
From 1995 through 1998, seven astronauts from the United States took turns living on Mir for up to six months each. They were among the 37 Americans who visited the station during nine stopovers by space shuttles.
The United States, which paid more than $400 million to Russia for the Mir visits, helped keep Mir operating, but the money also provided Americans and their partners in the international station project valuable experience in long-term flight and multinational operations.
A debate continues over Mir's contributions to science. During its existence, Mir was the laboratory for 23,000 experiments and carried scientific equipment, estimated to be worth $80 million, from many nations, according to a report in the March 9 issue of Science.
Experiments on Mir are credited with a variety of findings. For one, astronauts learned how to grow wheat in space. And, they made the first solid measurement of the ratio of heavy helium atoms in interstellar space. The measurement provides insight into the evolution of the universe.
Opponents of human space flight, who say satellites and robot spacecraft are the most economical way to collect data around Earth and beyond, say none of the scientific returns of manned missions justify the cost.
But for those favoring human space exploration, Mir showed that people could live and work in space long enough for a trip to Mars. Valery Polyakov set the record for a single stay in space, 437.7 days, arriving at Mir in 1994. Sergie Avdeyev accumulated 747.6 days in space in three trips to the space station. The longest American stay was that of Shannon Lucid, who spent 188 days aboard Mir in 1996.
While the Russians have learned much about human physiology in space, some Western scientists have complained that little of the material gathered has been has been published. They hope the more modern equipment and stringent standards of analysis for experiments on the new space station will yield more information about reactions of the human body to weightlessness and ways to combat deleterious effects.
Dr. Roald Z. Sagdeev, director of the East-West Space Science Center at the University of Maryland and a former Russian space researcher, said Mir's priorities were always as an engineering test bed. Even in the space station's early days, before maintenance took precedence, only 8 percent of the crew's time was dedicated to experiments, he said.
Mr. Oberg, the expert on the Russian space program, said Mir's greatest contributions include showing the world how to build, staff and maintain a space station, proving that humans can stay in space for an extended time apparently with no lasting ill effects and laying the groundwork for international space projects.
"Mir was a tremendous success, but it's time to move on to the next generation," he said. "The International Space Station will be better, but it owes a great debt to Mir."

EQUIPMENT TRANSPORTNASA developed standards for racks, or transportable storage units, allowing for easy loading and unloading of hardware. SPACE WALKSThe need for stable and maneuverable work surfaces on Mir prompted NASA designers to create a swiveling foot platform, capable of being carried and positioned in locations throughout the I.S.S.(Source: NASA)

HEADLINE: Rights Chief At U.N. Says She'll Leave In September 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 19 

 BODY:
Mary Robinson, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, said today that she would leave the job when her term ends in September and carry on the fight for human rights without the "constraints" that the United Nations imposes.
 In a surprise announcement to the opening session of the annual meeting of the United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva, Mrs. Robinson, 56, a former president of Ireland, said she would not seek reappointment when her term ends just after an international conference on racism. 
 That meeting, to be held in South Africa, is already surrounded by disputes, adding to problems that Mrs. Robinson has accumulated in dealing with crises as diverse as East Timor, Tibet and the Middle East. 
Early in her term, Mrs. Robinson, a human rights lawyer, began to feel pressure and engender criticism from governments and independent human rights organizations -- placing her in a damned-if-you-do, damned-if-you-don't position on many issues. She tried to steer a course between advocacy for the abused and respect for the sovereignty of governments.
Among the governments that criticized her was Russia, which in the General Assembly debate last year criticized her for outspoken comments on the situation in Chechnya. 
The executive director of Human Rights Watch in New York, Kenneth Roth, said in an interview that Mrs. Robinson's announcement had caught everyone off guard, being made in the week when Secretary General Kofi Annan is widely expected to announce whether he will seek a second term. Mrs. Robinson was among the first high-profile appointments Mr. Annan made as he tried to strengthen the power of the United Nations and its many branch offices.
"She vastly increased the profile of the position and demonstrated its enormous possibilities," Mr. Roth said. "I think she always struggled between her desire to maintain good diplomatic relationships with governments and the need to sometimes offend in the interest of protecting human rights. Often she made enemies both among governments that were receiving her criticism and human rights groups that hoped that she would do more.
"The tremendous challenge now faces by Kofi Annan is to find a replacement of her stature and her commitment to human rights. It was an act of courage on his part to name her in the first place."
Mrs. Robinson said today that Mr. Annan had advised her to "stay an outsider." She often was so independent that there were reports that she and secretary general were not always on the best of terms. "I have at times been an awkward voice, even on occasion for my colleagues within the U.N.," she said.
Mr. Annan said he heard of her decision today "with great regret." He said she had taken over an embryonic office and given it stature. "She has made a critical contribution to giving human rights a central role in the United Nations system," he said. 
Mrs. Robinson is the second person to hold the job of human rights commissioner, after Jose Ayala Lasso of Ecuador. The General Assembly created the post in 1993 after an international human rights conference in Vienna.
The high commissioner's role was very low profile when she arrived. She found herself burdened by a shortage of money to operate the Geneva office. A former top aide said that when she took the job she was disappointed in her staff. The budget improved measurably through her fund raising. But administrative weaknesses in the office continued. 
"I know some will feel that I should have sought to continue working from within the U.N., and I ask them to respect my decision," she said. "I will continue to work wholeheartedly for human rights in the way that I know best, as an advocate. I believe that I can at this stage achieve more outside the constraints that a multilateral organization inevitably imposes."
Mrs. Robinson brought to the appointment a strong record of advocacy in a career as a lawyer. She said in interviews that as a citizen of Ireland, which has suffered poverty and oppression under the English, she understood the problems of the developing world, still dealing with the effects of colonialism. She argued repeatedly that economic and social rights were also human rights. 
She had advocated closure on the colonial era, and with it the Atlantic slave trade at the racism conference that began on Aug. 31 in Durban. That drew criticism from industrial nations, as well as a few African leaders, who said the conference should be looking forward rather than backward to find ways to help the poorest nations now.
Most recently, Mrs. Robinson provoked outcries among women when she deferred to Iran and agreed that all women at a meeting on racism in Tehran had to cover their heads.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Shares Gain After Losses; Investors Await Fed Action

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
After a week of steep losses, stocks rose yesterday as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's expected move to reduce interest rates.
 Companies that would benefit most directly from lower interest rates and those that have been punished of late led a late rally. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 135.70 points, or 1.4 percent, to 9,959.11, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 20.28 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,170.81. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index gained 60.27 points, or 3.2 percent, to 1,951.18. 
The Fed's policy makers, who are scheduled to meet today, have already lowered short-term interest rates a full percentage point this year, and economists and market analysts expect the central bank to lower rates at least an additional half-point. Many investors and money managers are hoping the Fed will act more aggressively and cut short-term rates by three-quarters of a point.
While the Fed is about to answer one of Wall Street's most pressing questions, other uncertainties will remain, said Francis Gannon, senior equity portfolio manager for SunAmerica Asset Management. "Economic data points are telling us that things are not that bad," Mr. Gannon said. But even if the Fed aims a new rate cut at the stock market, "the earnings picture is going to remain very cloudy for a few quarters."
The Fed considers a full roster of economic data, and several economists said it would seek to avoid leaving the impression that its moves were dictated by the stock market alone, even though the United States economy has become closely tied to the market.
Still, "they've got to be concerned about a sharply negative reaction, particularly in the equity markets, to anything less" than a three-quarter-point cut," said Peter Hooper, chief domestic economist at Deutsche Bank North America.
Regardless of the size of a rate cut, "it still has to be good for the cyclical parts of the economy," said James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer for Wells Capital Management.
The Morgan Stanley cyclicals index, which includes companies that rely on an easy climate for financing, gained 13.20 points, or 2.6 percent, to 513.92. Several of its components, including Alcoa, Honeywell and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, are also components of the Dow, and those issues posted solid gains.
Despite the rally in cyclical stocks and the widespread belief that a rate cut is imminent, a sort of uneasy calm, measurable in somewhat thin trading volume, fell over Wall Street. Last week, the Dow had its worst weekly decline in more than 11 years, pushing it below the 10,000 mark, and the S.& P. 500 entered a bear market, generally defined as a 20 percent decline from its peak.
The market seemed shaken by "the full velocity of negativism, with every paper in the world talking about the bear market," said Charles Pradilla, chief investment strategist for SG Cowen.
"Many people who didn't play the game, very conservative investors, they start to nibble on the edges, and that's all you need on a day like today," he said.
Consider Ariba, a technology stock that gained more than 11 percent for no discernible reason aside from so-called bargain-hunting, Mr. Pradilla said. The shares are off a 52-week high of $173.50 and closed yesterday at $11.38, up $1.19.
Like-minded investors bought Qualcomm, which rose $7.88, or 15.7 percent, to $58.19; JDS Uniphase, which climbed $2.19, or 9.8 percent, to $24.63; and Oracle, which gained $1.38, or 9.8 percent, to $15.44.
The stock market's big losses last week occurred after months of corporate profit warnings and layoff announcements, complemented by economic reports detailing slowed production and rising inventory backlogs. Inflation, though, has been limited, and consumer confidence has not fallen as sharply as economists had expected.
Investors broadened their fears last week, pondering a slowdown that could extend past the technology sector into many older industries and past the United States into the world. Agricultural difficulties and a banking slowdown in Europe drew new scrutiny from Wall Street. So did Japan's deflating currency and its banks, which are heavily laden with bad debt.
Some stocks rose yesterday despite making negative announcements. Corning, for example, gained $2.02, to $25.20, even though the No. 1 maker of fiber optic cable said its profits this year were likely to fall below estimates.

HEADLINE: Public Interests; 
Anxious In Alabama

BYLINE:  By GAIL COLLINS 

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. 

 BODY:
The statue of Vulcan that normally looms over the city, commemorating its steel-making history, is lying in pieces now, undergoing a $1.5 million federally funded makeover. This project always comes up in Washington whenever somebody wants to complain about pork-barrel projects.
 Peculiarly, the pile of very large body parts includes three legs. "We paid for an extra foot?" demanded Ed Chism of Tuscaloosa, as he peered at the pieces at Vulcan Park. 
 I'm O.K. with helping to repair Vulcan, which happens to be the second-largest statue in the United States. The Statue of Liberty might be bigger, but unlike Vulcan it was made abroad and does not hold a huge flashlight that beams red whenever the city suffers a traffic fatality.
Anyway, if Alabama government had to pay the tab, Vulcan would probably be one limb short. These people do not like to spend money.
I came down here to watch what happens in a state when the national economy turns south. Alabama is an excellent place to study, since its tax receipts are plummeting and its government is second to none in its inability to handle a crisis.
When the economy started to slow down, tax revenues dropped and the Constitution required the governor to cut back funding for education in the middle of the school year. The K-to-12 schools and the colleges and universities are now at each other's throats over who gets the biggest hit. This state, which once led the nation in its ability to pit white workers against black workers in the factories, is now turning third-grade reading teachers against medieval history professors. 
One superintendent of schools, in a desperate attempt to get his community to cough up some local money for education, is threatening to cancel football. This is regarded as insanity, a word that nobody seems to apply to the fact that a state where only 16 percent of the public has college degrees is thinking about eliminating almost a quarter of the higher education funding for the second half of the year.
One really useful lesson in all this is that state constitutions are actually important. Alabama's was written a century ago, at the behest of the big agricultural landowners and steel-mill barons. Their political theory -- so elegant in its simplicity -- was that taxes on plantations and factories were undesirable.
This state also demonstrates the harm that politicians do when they encourage people to believe they're wildly overtaxed when they aren't. David Bronner, the head of Alabama's state pension funds, enjoys shocking Alabama citizens by telling them they pay $500 million less annually than the citizens of Mississippi.
"This is the most screwed-up tax system in America, bar none," said Mr. Bronner cheerfully. There's virtually no property tax, and the state is run mainly on receipts from an 8-to-9-percent sales tax. Sales taxes are unpredictable and they hit poor people hardest. Alabama has thoughtfully made its system worse through a series of exemptions, so that it taxes food, baby formula, diapers and shoes, but not haircuts, baby-cow formula, fertilizer or coffins. 
Everybody was very excited the other day when Senator Richard Shelby, the main man in Alabama Republican politics, gave a speech in which he suggested that the state raise the money for the schools by eliminating those sales tax exemptions for cars and coffins and combines and whatnot. "I had written a little piece for our newsletter, praising him for being bold and everything," said Paul Hubbert, the executive director of the Alabama Education Association.
Mr. Hubbert, who is one of the most powerful men in the Capitol, says education lobbyists approached Mr. Shelby about joining a bipartisan united front for tax reform and quality education. If everybody stood together, Mr. Hubbert claims, the Democratic governor and legislative leaders were ready to hold hands and take the heat.
Mr. Shelby's office says it doesn't know anything about such an overture. But anyway, the senator says the state tax structure isn't really his problem since he's a big-picture kind of guy.
Mr. Hubbert wrote a new article attacking Senator Shelby for chickening out. This is not entirely fair. The senator can be very forceful on some matters, such as federal support for the statue of Vulcan. "I will never apologize for my efforts to support worthy projects that improve Alabama," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS; 
Treasury Issues Dip on Profit Taking as Rate Move Is Awaited

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday as investors took profits and the market awaited the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates today.
 The Fed is expected to cut interest rates again, but the size of the reduction -- whether it will be half a percentage point or three quarters -- is still uncertain. 
 Last week's stock market decline, fueled by fears about America's slowing economy, Japan's fragile economic outlook and United States corporate profit warnings, sparked talk the Federal Reserve would need a more aggressive cut to bolster growth. 
But an unexpected upturn in consumer confidence and Wall Street's ability to stop heftier losses yesterday, convinced some investors the Fed would cut its 5.50 percent federal funds rate a half percentage point for the third time this year.
"The market will certainly be long going into the Fed meeting but people are sailing closer to shore in order not to be caught off guard just in case the Fed decides to cut only half a percentage point," said Brian Robinson, senior bond analyst at 4Cast. Last week, the Treasury market had rallied, driving yields to two-year lows amid talk of a three-quarter-point cut.
Yesterday, futures contracts traded on the federal funds rate indicated a roughly 56 percent chance of a three-quarter point cut, down from about 74 percent on Friday.
While the debate raged over how big the cut would be, traders and analysts said activity was relatively sluggish.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 13/32 , to a price of 101 15/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.81 percent from 4.76 percent on Friday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 11/32 , to 10 19/32 . The bond's yield rose to 5.29 percent from 5.27 percent on Friday.

HEADLINE: Ukraine's Tribulations 

 BODY:
Last November a farmer in Ukraine found the headless body of Georgy Gongadze, an Internet journalist who had accused President Leonid Kuchma of corruption. A few weeks later Mr. Kuchma's former bodyguard released tapes made before Mr. Gongadze's death that allegedly feature Mr. Kuchma discussing various ways to get rid of the journalist, including having him kidnapped. The tapes also include discussions from 1999 between Mr. Kuchma and his aides about using the prosecutor, militia and tax inspector to pressure journalists and the managers of state farms and factories to help re-elect him in November of that year. Mr. Kuchma charges that the Gongadze tape was electronically doctored, and he seems likely to survive the political crisis that has resulted. But the scandal has provided a glimpse of the abuses of power and corruption that have stunted Ukraine's development as an independent nation. 
 When the Soviet Union collapsed, Ukraine seemed like a candidate for success, with a well-educated work force and a border with Eastern Europe. The country made an enlightened decision to destroy its stocks of nuclear weapons. While Ukraine has cultural and historic ties to Russia, many Ukrainians are more oriented toward their European neighbors to the west. 
 But Ukraine's progress has been crippled by the kind of political manipulation allegedly revealed by the tapes. Until very recently, the economy was contracting by more than 10 percent a year. Corruption blocked investment and economic reform. Power and money rule the courts.
Lately there has been some progress. A group of responsible officials, led by the young prime minister, Viktor Yushchenko, has been able to pass some reforms. Yulia Timoshenko, until recently the energy minister, cleaned up the corrupt energy sector, allowing the government to collect taxes there for the first time. The reforms, and an economic upswing in Russia, allowed the economy to grow last year.
The tapes scandal could have some positive consequences. It has led to the first independent television coverage by news programs that Mr. Kuchma controls, and the first sustained street demonstrations for democratization and civil liberties. But Ukraine's reformers still face daunting obstacles. Mr. Kuchma rules as an autocrat. He fired Ms. Timoshenko, and after she joined an opposition political bloc she was arrested on charges of corruption. An investigation of the Gongadze killing by an official under Mr. Kuchma's control is, unsurprisingly, stalled -- although Mr. Kuchma recently accepted help from the American F.B.I. 
Because Mr. Kuchma's main opposition figures have been former Communists, the West has handled him gingerly. Washington has been appropriately critical during the tapes scandal, but should do more to press Mr. Kuchma for a full investigation of Mr. Gongadze's murder. Mr. Kuchma is nominally pro-Western. But his authoritarianism has done much to keep his nation from becoming a modern European state.
