HEADLINE: Trustees Extend Solvency Estimates for 2 Benefits 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19 

 BODY:
The government announced today that the principal Medicare trust fund would not run out of money until 2029, the longest period of solvency ever projected in the history of the program. And officials extended the life of the Social Security trust fund by one year, to 2038.
 The projected date of insolvency for the Medicare trust fund is four years later than the estimate made by the Clinton administration 12 months ago. 
 But the Bush administration said the long-term financial outlook for Medicare was bleak because health costs were rising rapidly. And it said Congress still needed to make major changes in Social Security to prepare for the retirement of 76 million baby boomers. 
The improvement in the condition of Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund surprised experts on the program. They had predicted that the trust fund would be depleted a few years earlier because Congress recently increased Medicare payments to health care providers, while economists have increased long-term estimates of health costs.
Unveiling the annual report on Social Security and Medicare, President Bush and members of his cabinet took what appeared to be good news and made it sound like bad news. 
Mr. Bush said the report underlined the need for Congressional action to strengthen Social Security and Medicare. "We have only so many years to get the systems back on track," he told Hispanic business leaders meeting at the White House. "It's time to quit the posturing and time to reform the systems."
Moreover, Mr. Bush said, "part of the Social Security reform must include allowing younger workers the option to take some of their own money and put it in the private markets, under safe conditions."
Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill, a trustee of the two programs, refused to say how the recent plunge in stock prices might affect the administration's effort to let workers divert some of their payroll taxes into private savings accounts.
"When you're dealing with 75-year estimates and actuarial science," Mr. O'Neill said, "what's going on in the market today almost doesn't matter."
Mr. O'Neill said the fact that Medicare's hospital trust fund would last four years longer than previously believed was no "excuse for complacency."
Independent trustees of the Medicare program agreed, noting that Medicare spending would more than double in 10 years.
Democrats rejoiced at the new estimate for Medicare. They said it showed that Congress could add prescription drug benefits without making radical changes in the structure of the Medicare program, which provides health care to 39 million people who are elderly or disabled.
The annual report on Social Security and Medicare is issued by a board of six trustees. Four of the six are federal officials, and two are scholars who represent the public.
In their report on Medicare, the trustees said, "The Hospital Insurance Trust Fund is estimated to be depleted in 2029 -- a significant improvement over last year's estimate of 2025."
The new date reflects both "stronger-than-expected economic growth and lower-than-expected program costs," the trustees said.
Robust economic growth for most of last year led to an increase in payroll tax revenues, the main source of income for the hospital trust fund.
Medicare spent less than expected last year because of "slow increases in health care costs generally, continuing efforts to combat fraud and abuse in the Medicare program," a reduction in the use of nursing homes and a reduction in the average severity and complexity of illness for hospital patients, the report said.
The trustees sharply increased their estimate of the long-term growth in health costs, as recommended by a panel of outside experts.
They also expressed concern that Medicare costs were growing faster than the economy as a whole. Medicare, taken as a whole, now accounts for 2.2 percent of the gross domestic product. This figure is expected to rise to 5 percent in 2035 and 8.5 percent in 2075.
The balance in Medicare's hospital trust fund is growing steadily and is expected to reach $650 billion at the end of 2010, up from $177.5 billion at the end of last year, the trustees said.
The assets of the Social Security trust fund are expected to reach $3.4 trillion at the end of 2010, up from $1 trillion at the end of last year.
Total income to the hospital trust fund exceeded spending last year by $36 billion, while income to the Social Security trust fund exceeded outlays by $153 billion. 
William A. Halter, the acting commissioner of Social Security, said, "In the last four years, we have added nine years to the life of the Social Security trust fund." In 1996 and 1997, the Clinton administration estimated that the fund would be exhausted in 2029.
Congress and the Clinton administration, working together, rescued Medicare's hospital trust fund from the brink of bankruptcy. In 1993, when Bill Clinton became president, the trust fund was expected to run out of money in 1999. Congress put off the depletion date by continually tinkering with the program, by trimming payments to health care providers and by shifting costs from one part of the program to another -- a measure denounced by many Republicans as an accounting gimmick.
In his budget blueprint last month, President Bush sounded an alarm about Medicare's financial condition, insisting that "there is no Medicare surplus" when the hospital trust fund is viewed together with a separate account used to pay doctors' bills.
Representative Pete Stark of California, the ranking Democrat on the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, said today's report showed that Republicans had overstated Medicare's problems. "The trustees' report makes clear that Republican claims about Medicare's so-called financing crisis are simply an excuse to raid the Medicare surplus to pay for tax breaks for the wealthy," Mr. Stark said.
But Representative Billy Tauzin, the Louisiana Republican who is chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, said, "The day of reckoning is fast approaching." While the hospital trust fund will not be exhausted until 2029, he said, it will spend more than it receives in tax revenues starting in 2016.
The outlook for both programs depends on many economic variables, including the productivity of American workers. In general, as productivity rises, so do the average earnings of workers. The Social Security trustees assume that productivity will grow more slowly in coming years than it has in the last few years. Some economists say the economic assumptions are so conservative that they make the problems of Social Security seem worse than they are.
The part of Medicare that pays doctors' bills and other outpatient expenses never runs out of money because it is financed with beneficiaries' premiums and general revenue contributions, which are set each year to meet the expected costs.
But the trustees expressed "great concern" about this part of the program, saying it would grow faster than spending from the hospital trust fund and could consume a steadily growing share of income taxes: 5.4 percent last year, 13 percent in 2030, 22 percent in 2070.

HEADLINE: In Albany, Budget Plans For Education Differ Sharply 

BYLINE:  By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 19 

 BODY:
Leaders of the State Assembly and Senate unveiled dueling budget wish lists this afternoon, highlighted by sharply divergent numbers on aid to education.
 First, the Assembly Democrats proposed increasing education aid by $1.7 billion a year for the next two years. Minutes later, scoffing at the Democrats' figures as irresponsible at a time of economic uncertainty, the Senate Republicans proposed slightly more than half that amount, urging an increase of $925 million for the next year. 
 "We have to be prudent, we have to be responsible," the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, told reporters this afternoon. "We are going to have one heck of a time, given what we're seeing so far already coming from the other house, trying to negotiate a budget in any sensible way this year." 
Mr. Bruno said he would set aside $4.4 billion in reserve to handle budget shortfalls should the economy sour. He also proposed a $1.8 billion package of tax cuts, chiefly for economic development zones, and $500 million in incentives for the biotechnology industry.
The Senate Republicans' budget mirrors much of what the Republican governor, George E. Pataki, proposed earlier this year, but there are some important differences. The Senate's proposed reserve fund is three times the $1.4 billion that the governor would set aside, and its education budget plan is more than double the $382 million increase proposed by Mr. Pataki.
Education financing is among the thorniest issues this year, as it comes against the backdrop of a judge's ruling that ordered a major increase in spending on New York City schools to provide a "sound, basic education."
State and city education officials applauded the Assembly's proposed budget today, calling it a wise investment toward meeting the court order. "Obviously, given the huge state surplus this year, you want to be able to make a down payment right now," said Stephen Allinger, the New York City school system's lobbyist. "It makes no sense to not take advantage of the prosperity."
The State Board of Regents, the policy-making body for the Education Department, has called for a $1.45 billion increase in school aid. The Assembly budget proposal actually exceeds that amount. The Assembly would also allocate money for the next two years, instead of one. Mr. Bruno flatly rejected that idea. "We're not even going to contemplate or think about that," he said.
The governor has already said he will appeal the judge's ruling, and Mr. Bruno has echoed his call. Today, Senate Republicans maintained that their budget proposal would comply with the judge's order. Like the Assembly proposal, theirs would channel 70 percent of the increased school aid to high-need school districts. Both their formulas would send about 37 percent of state education money to New York City, which has about 37 percent of the state's schoolchildren.
The Assembly proposal would restore $660 million to hire teachers in an effort to lower class size and expand prekindergarten classes. The Assembly budget also includes a new plan to recruit teachers to high-need schools by offering housing subsidies in the districts where they teach. "It addresses the need for equity," the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, said this afternoon. "It keeps the promise of smaller class size and universal pre-K."
Even by the standards of Albany, the budget negotiations are late this year. By state law, the two houses of the Legislature are supposed to come to an agreement by March 10 on how much money the state is estimated to generate in revenues. The Legislature has already missed that deadline. The Assembly and Senate revenue estimates vary widely, with Republicans expressing grave concerns about the extent of the economic downturn and Democrats slightly more optimistic about the potential for economic growth.
"This is the latest start I've experienced in the past six years," Mr. Bruno said. "There's a huge difference of opinion as to what's happening out there in the economy."

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
Uncluttering The Airspace At La Guardia

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
A YEAR after Congress went to the aid of airline passengers, a painful truth has emerged at La Guardia Airport: two airplanes cannot use the same runway at the same time. 
 This has come as a blow to the politicians determined to guarantee the constitutional right of every American to fly nonstop to an airport convenient to Midtown Manhattan. This right was deemed so important that Congress lifted the daily limit on flights at La Guardia so that small planes could arrive from places that were "underserved" (meaning they were in the politicians' home districts). 
 The result has been satisfying for some people, notably upstaters. If you have a frequent craving to fly nonstop from Ithaca to La Guardia, you've had your choice of five daily flights on a 37-seat turboprop plane. But since politicians did not provide new runways, La Guardia has become infamous for the nation's longest flight delays. 
The airport's managers have declared an emergency moratorium on new flights and are contemplating permanent limitations. The easy part of their job is figuring out how many planes per hour can land and take off. The hard part is deciding which planes get those slots.
If you value efficiency, you could allot the slots through an auction. Instead of the current system, in which planes are charged simply by weight, and in which a flight at 9 a.m. costs an airline the same as one at 11 p.m., you could make airlines and private pilots bid for each takeoff and landing slot.
The auction would force airlines to pay more for slots at the most popular times, lessening the temptation for them all to schedule flights at rush hours. The auction would probably banish the small planes now serving places like Ithaca, because 37 passengers on a turboprop couldn't afford to pay as much for the slot as 150 passengers on a Boeing 737. 
The auction would also banish the corporate jets that now pay a relative pittance to use La Guardia. Thanks to the power of their lobby in Washington, private-plane owners are guaranteed 6 of the 75 slots allotted each hour at La Guardia. That means that every hour, a dozen or two executives in corporate planes can use up the slots of six jets that could be carrying 1,000 passengers. And because the airport fees are set according to the weight of the plane, the private planes, like the small turboprops, are paying much less than big jets would be charged. 
WHILE a small plane pays less for the privilege of using the airport, it can actually take up extra time taking off and landing. That's because it flies relatively slowly, and it needs extra airspace when there's a large jet in front of it. Because the small plane is vulnerable to turbulence in the jet's wake, it might have to wait until the jet is four or five miles away before taking off.
An auction of slots would mean more big planes carrying more passengers, but would they all be from the same few airlines? Some economists, including Alfred E. Kahn, the architect of airline deregulation, fear that major carriers would buy up all the slots to protect themselves against upstart competitors. To maintain competition, Mr. Kahn said, an auction should be accompanied by vigorous antitrust enforcement against the major airlines. Another alternative, he said, would be for Congress to limit any single airline to no more than, say, a quarter of the slots at La Guardia.
The biggest problem with an auction would be political: how to tell voters upstate and elsewhere that they're not entitled to lots of nonstop flights to La Guardia. Even politicians calling for a limit on flights at La Guardia, like Senator Charles E. Schumer, are not suggesting that their constituents be grounded. Not many upstaters share the sentiments of Mr. Kahn, a professor emeritus at Cornell University, in Ithaca.
"With an auction, I'm sure our nonstop flights from Ithaca to La Guardia would disappear," Mr. Kahn said. "But they're a very inefficient use of a scarce resource. If there are other people willing to pay more to use La Guardia, let them have the slots. Maybe I'll have to fly through Pittsburgh to reach New York. Worse things have happened."
Convenient airplane flights are not a fundamental human right. They're a perk of living in a densely populated place, a compensation for the high prices and other deprivations of city life. "People who want to live in a rural, comparatively isolated community have to realize that it may be harder for them to see Broadway plays," Mr. Kahn said. "They have fresh air instead."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Stocks Rise as Investors Await Rate Cut From Fed
After a week of steep losses, stocks rose as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's expected move to reduce interest rates. The Fed's policy makers, who are scheduled to meet today, have already lowered short-term interest rates a full percentage point this year, and economists and market analysts expect them to lower rates at least an additional half-point.
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 135.70 points, or 1.4 percent, to 9,959.11, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 20.28 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,170.81. The Nasdaq composite index gained 60.27 points, or 3.2 percent, to 1,951.18. Page C9. 

Bank of Japan Reverses Policy
Japan's central bank changed course sharply in the struggle to revive the stagnant Japanese economy. The bank said it would try to stimulate consumer and business spending by pumping money into the banking system, by effectively cutting short-term interest rates essentially to zero and promising to keep borrowing costs negligible. In Washington, where President Bush was meeting with Japan's prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, officials at the Treasury and the White House were relieved by the bank's decision. A1.

The leaders ended their meeting with only a vague commitment by Japan to deal with bad loans and corporate debt. C2.

Energy Official Sees a Crisis
Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham said that the nation faced an "energy supply crisis" akin to the oil embargoes of the 1970's and indicated that the Bush administration intended to overhaul rules to ease fuel exploration and help energy production and distribution. A16.

A heat wave combined with the sudden failure of two large power generators prompted hours of rotating blackouts in California. A1.

Drug Wholesalers Agree to Merge
AmeriSource Health and Bergen Brunswig, the nation's third- and fourth-largest drug wholesalers, agreed to merge in a $2.4 billion stock deal. Market Place. C8.

Drug Maker Corixa Hits Roadblock
Corixa, which is racing to bring to market the first drug that delivers radiation directly to cancer cells, has hit a roadblock. The company said that the Food and Drug Administration has asked for more information about the drug's safety and effectiveness. The action is expected to delay approval for Corixa's drug for at least nine months and could allow a rival, Idec Pharmaceuticals, to reach the market first. Corixa's shares fell $1.56, to $9.50, while Idec shares rose $4.38, to $52.50. C4.

23 Opt Out of Coke Bias Settlement
A settlement of a class-action lawsuit that accused Coca-Cola of racial discrimination cleared a potential hurdle when only 23 members of the class chose to opt out. C7.

Microsoft Confronts Privacy Fears
Microsoft tried to defuse privacy and security concerns about its new .Net Internet strategy by saying the new technology would let computer users control how much personal data they make available for commercial use. C4.

Rig Blasts Add to Petrobas Woes
With its largest offshore oil platform still listing after a series of deadly explosions, Brazil's state-owned oil company, Petrobras, is struggling to ease the damage to its bottom line and reputation. World Business, Section W.

Australians Hail Mining Merger
Investors and analysts in Australia reacted jubilantly to the proposed merger of BHP and Billiton of Britain, driving shares of BHP up sharply. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: GULF ARAB STATES PREPARE A BAILOUT TO ASSIST ARAFAT 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 19 

 BODY:
Persian Gulf oil states are tossing a lifeline to the financially foundering Palestinian Authority in the form of a $300 million aid package. This will make Arab donors the Authority's chief source of budgetary support for the first time.
 Under a plan devised with the support of the International Monetary Fund and endorsed by Arab League finance ministers, the Islamic Development Bank is preparing to provide up to $40 million a month for six months from a new "intifada fund," Palestinian officials and foreign diplomats say. 
 Most of the money is coming from Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait, countries that until recently refused to provide direct aid to Yasir Arafat's semiautonomous government. The European Union and the United States have been the biggest donors until now. 
The six months of payments are in addition to the unpublicized transfer of $80 million in Arab grants and loans to the Authority since December, exceeding the $65 million it received from European governments. 
The Authority administers the Palestinian-controlled areas of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, running schools, hospitals and security forces.
Its revenues have been slashed by the current conflict with Israel -- a crisis that has halved Palestinian incomes, tripled unemployment and fueled popular anger not just at Israel but at the Authority itself. Without new financial support, American diplomats and United Nations envoys have warned in recent weeks, the Authority faces imminent bankruptcy.
"The Palestinian economy is on the brink of collapse, and the Palestinian Authority is beginning to disintegrate," Martin Indyk, the American ambassador to Israel, told business leaders in Tel Aviv this month.
Ultimately the political symbolism of this new Arab support could be as meaningful as the economic impact, Palestinian officials say. Egypt aside, most major Arab states have kept their distance from the Palestinian Authority, even while they have professed support for the Palestinian cause.
The Persian Gulf states were bitterly resentful of Mr. Arafat's support for Iraq during the 1991 gulf war. Kuwait, whose occupation by Iraq precipitated the war, responded afterward by expelling hundreds of thousands of Palestinian residents.
Iraq, like Syria and Libya, disdained the Authority as the misbegotten offspring of the 1993 Israeli-Palestinian peace pact, which it implacably opposed. European governments -- with the support of the United States and, more ambivalently, Israel -- unsuccessfully urged Arab states to share more of the aid burden.
But with the intense pro-Palestinian sentiment aroused in the Arab world by five months of violent confrontations with Israel, and growing concern over the potential impact of the conflict, the Arab consensus has suddenly changed, and the Authority is the beneficiary.
"The argument is straightforward," said one Palestinian participant in aid discussions with Arab leaders. "You cannot help the Palestinians economically while ignoring the central Palestinian institution, the biggest employer, the main provider of social services."
Now, he added, the wealthy Arab states will have "an investment" in the Authority for the first time. For Mr. Arafat, the aid provides an institutional lease on life while reducing his dependence on Western Europe and the United States.
Washington, barred by Congress from giving aid directly to the Authority, gave $57 million in January to Palestinian social programs.
"We now have the full support of the Arab countries," Muhammad Nashashibi, the Palestinian finance minister, said in an interview.
Still, he suggested, the Arab states could do more: $1 billion in aid would represent just 2 percent of the Arab countries' annual earnings from their investments abroad, he asserted.
Today a senior aide to Prime Minister Ariel Sharon said the Israeli government welcomed Arab and European aid for Palestinian social services but strongly objected to budgetary support for the Palestinian leadership and its security services.
"If the money goes to improve the welfare of the Palestinian people, we have no objection," said the aide, Ranaan Gissin. "But if it goes to pay the salaries of the people who shoot at us, it would be counterproductive."
The expected new Arab cash infusion will not revive Palestinian trade or put the jobless back to work, the architects of the plan acknowledge. But combined with smaller European Union grants and loans and tax revenue collected and currently withheld by Israel, it should be enough to keep schools and hospitals open and pay most government salaries.
Israel is under strong pressure from Washington and the Europeans to release $75 million in tax revenues that it has retained arguing that the money would indirectly underwrite terrorism.
"All we are doing is buying time," said a Palestinian economist involved in the negotiations with Arab finance ministers. "But time is very valuable right now to us, and also to the Israelis."
The six-month aid plan is expected to be formally endorsed at an Arab League summit meeting in Amman, Jordan, on March 27, even though many Arab leaders remain wary of Mr. Arafat and some worry that Arab aid might ease pressure on Israel to release Palestinian funds.
"It would be very difficult for the Arab League to back down from what has become a very public commitment to giving support to the Palestinian Authority," said a Western diplomat.
Some Arab states and wealthy individuals began giving aid almost immediately after the current Palestinian uprising -- "intifada" in Arabic -- began in late September. But that money was channeled directly to needy individuals and private charities, deliberately bypassing the Authority. The most publicized example was payments of $10,000 by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to families of people killed in the uprising.
More worrisome to Palestinian officials, though, are the millions in private Saudi dollars discreetly channeled to families of the dead or wounded through local Islamic foundations said by Western diplomats to be linked to the militant Hamas organization, which opposes Mr. Arafat's authority.
In Gaza City, for example, nearly every working day, Palestinians line up at the office of the Salah Association, handing over medical records and identification papers that are faxed to Saudi Arabia and checked against official Palestinian documents.
Money is then wired to a Gaza branch office of the private, Palestinian-owned Arab Bank: $5,000 for spouses or parents of those killed, $2,500 for the wounded. The Salah Association, which denies reports that it is associated with Hamas, says it has also distributed 200,000 Saudi-financed food baskets in the last two months.
"The Saudis are a generous people, and they have very high prestige among the Palestinians," said Jabar Hussein, the association's director. "Our relationship was already close, but this will make it even closer."
Until a few months ago, though, that generosity was less apparent.
In the first six years of the Palestinian Authority, when foreign aid donors provided more than $3 billion, Saudi Arabia and most other Arab states kept a conspicuous distance. More than half of the Authority's international financial assistance came from the European Union, followed by the United States with about a quarter of the aid.
Support from all of the Arab states combined rarely reached even 10 percent of the total, and by design, almost none of it went directly to the Palestinian Authority, which was continually dogged by reports of mismanagement and corruption.
But since last fall, the conflict with Israel has made support for the Palestinians a unifying cause for Arab states deeply divided over other matters.
In November the Arab League agreed in principle to donate $1 billion to Palestinian aid projects. Nearly $700 million was quickly pledged to the fund. But by last month only $10 million had been disbursed, Palestinian officials complained. They pressed the case in Arab capitals for immediate budget support rather than long-term project financing.
Some Western diplomats see the new Arab support as an indirect endorsement of the peace accord with Israel that created the Authority seven years ago. Others are less sanguine, noting the adamant Saudi resistance to Palestinian compromises over Jerusalem, for example.
"We really have no idea," one senior American official said, "what the long-term implications will be."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-11

Gulf Arabs Aiding Arafat, Despite Past Differences
Persian Gulf oil states are tossing a lifeline to the financially foundering Palestinian Authority, which is led by Yasir Arafat. A $300 million aid package will make Arab donors the Authority's chief source of budgetary support for the first time, with most of the money coming from Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait, countries that until recently refused to provide direct aid because of Mr. Arafat's support for Iraq during the 1991 gulf war. A1

Bush Policy on Middle East

Macedonia Set to Press Rebels

HEADLINE: Newspaper Publisher Quits to Protest Profit Goals 

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
Jay T. Harris, the chairman and publisher of The San Jose Mercury News, announced yesterday that he was quitting his posts and warned his corporate bosses at Knight Ridder that their profit targets for the financially squeezed newspaper risked "significant and lasting harm to The Mercury News as a journalistic enterprise."
 Journalists at the newspaper in California's Silicon Valley, who had been nervously anticipating layoffs that Mr. Harris warned of earlier this month, were stunned to hear instead that he had quit. News of his strongly worded explanation for his resignation ricocheted around the newspaper industry, a business that has been grappling with a sharp decline in advertising revenue, particularly in the larger markets. 
 Mr. Harris's action was hailed by many journalists who believe that newspaper companies too often choose to serve their shareholders at the expense of their readers and viewed with sorrow by at least one Wall Street analyst who saw it as a sign of some journalists' stubborn refusal to accept financial realities.
The push-and-pull at Knight Ridder between cost-cutting and maintaining the investment in journalism is not unique to the company or even to the newspaper business. Other industries that rise and fall with economic cycles, like semiconductor manufacturing, are faced with the same choices between meeting profit margins and reinvesting in the product in tough times. So Mr. Harris's action may well resonate far beyond the profession he joined three decades ago as a reporter.
Mr. Harris's e-mail dropped into his employees' in-boxes shortly after 1:30 p.m. yesterday. It began: "This is a letter I never thought I'd be writing to you.
"It saddens me to do so, and yet I do so with my heart at peace, my conscience clear and high hopes for the paper's future -- and mine as well." Mr. Harris, who had been publisher at the paper for seven years, went on to quote from his resignation letter to Knight Ridder's chief executive, P. Anthony Ridder, and other corporate executives, in which he said he was stepping down in the hope that his action would cause them "to closely examine the wisdom" of corporate profit targets.
The determination to maintain profit margins near or above 20 percent has led Knight Ridder management to turn back requests for financial flexibility from several newspaper editors and publishers. Declining advertising revenue, particularly high-margin help-wanted advertising, has made cost-cutting and rebudgeting a regular occurrence at Knight Ridder newspapers like The Miami Herald, The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Akron Beacon Journal in Ohio.
Yesterday morning, before Mr. Harris sent the e-mail message to his staff, Knight Ridder announced disappointing February results and lowered its expectations for first-quarter earnings. "The revenue environment continues to deteriorate, and we do not see relief in March," Mr. Ridder said.
In the first quarter of 2000, the company reported earnings of 74 cents a share; yesterday it said earnings would fall 15 to 20 cents below that this quarter. After an early downbeat statement by Mr. Ridder in February, analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had expected, on average, earnings of 71 cents a share.
Yesterday afternoon, after the journalists at The Mercury News had been in meetings discussing the events at the paper with a weekday circulation of about 287,000, they received a second e-mail, this one from Mr. Ridder and the top executives of the newspaper division.
It began, "This is a sad and difficult time for all of us." The message said that the resignation "came as a surprise. We asked him to reconsider, but he would not."
The management message also said that Steve Rossi, the president of the newspaper division, had met with Mr. Harris on Friday. At the meeting, the e-mail continued, Mr. Rossi said that he "wanted no layoffs of full-time newsroom employees and hoped to avoid layoffs of full-time employees elsewhere in the building. He acknowledged that this might mean restructuring in some business-side departments but stressed that he, like Jay, did not want to damage the long-term future of The Mercury News. We think it is important that you know that."
Neither Mr. Harris nor David Yarnold, The Mercury News's executive editor, returned telephone calls for comment yesterday. Polk Laffoon IV, Knight Ridder's corporate spokesman, said Mr. Ridder's e-mail to the Mercury News staff would be his only statement on the matter.
The pressures on The Mercury News were particularly painful because just last year it brought in about 30 new journalists to help cover Silicon Valley in its boom times.
In an interview yesterday, Lauren Rich Fine, a newspaper industry analyst with Merrill Lynch, said she was disappointed to hear that Mr. Harris had resigned. "If you have a publisher that resigns himself rather than cut costs," she said. "It's a strong sign that they have a culture there that is not comfortable cutting costs" when revenues are falling.
Pete Carey, who won a Pulitzer Prize at the paper, said of Mr. Harris, "He has taken the honorable route. He is not going to stay when he disagrees so fundamentally with the direction the newspaper should take during these hard times."
Geneva Overholser, a syndicated columnist and the former editor of The Des Moines Register, said Mr. Harris's letter of explanation was a "clarion call," and that "all of us in newspapers are indebted to this honorable man."

HEADLINE: THE CENSUS: Connecticut; 
Connecticut Population Shifts Toward New York

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
Fairfield County, with its verdant suburbs, flourishing economy and troops of New York City-bound commuters, became the most populous county in Connecticut in the 1990's, according to figures from the 2000 census released yesterday. The data suggest that Connecticut's center of gravity is shifting away from its traditional focal point, Hartford.
 Hartford lost a striking 15 percent of its population in the 1990's, some of it, apparently, to its own suburbs, according to the 2000 census data. Other large cities and smaller industrial towns also shrank, while once little-known communities far beyond the cities boomed. 
 The state's population as a whole increased to 3,405,565, up from 3,305,658 in 1990. That growth of 3.6 percent was below the national trend, and Connecticut will lose one Congressional seat, going down to five, as a result.
And at a time when immigration and racial and ethnic diversity are transforming states like New Jersey, three out of every four Connecticut residents are white, according to the census numbers. Hispanics in Connecticut rose to nearly 10 percent. Much of their growth was in shrinking cities like Hartford, New Haven and New London. Hispanics are now the state's largest minority group. 
Meanwhile, the proportion of non-Hispanic blacks stayed at just under 9 percent of the state's population. While the number of people in Hartford dwindled, blacks appeared to be moving out of the city into neighboring communities like Bloomfield, East Hartford and Windsor. The number of non-Hispanic whites in those and similar towns plunged.
The population increases and decreases are based on figures for 2000 and on 1990 data that were adjusted to make up for undercounting and overcounting in the 1990 census.
The fastest-growing county was Middlesex, which includes communities like Old Lyme, Old Saybrook and Essex along the Connecticut River. 
"We're a desirable spot, a green spot between urban areas," said Wini Olson, a regional planner with the Connecticut River Estuary Regional Planning Agency. But she said the growth had created a new problem, "McMansions along the river."
Thomas Cooke, an assistant professor of geography at the University of Connecticut, said: "What is happening on the outer reaches is Connecticut's version of sprawl. Middlesex County is growing because people are out there building their McMansions and commuting 45 minutes to work."
Fairfield County, where nearly one in four of the state's residents now live, was the second-fastest growing, inching out Hartford County as most populous. With a booming economy and job growth in the New York City area, the county's small towns as well as some cities grew. Economists attributed the growth in part to low unemployment, made possible by companies moving out of New York and relocating in Stamford.
Stamford alone grew by 8 percent, an increase that Edward Deak, a professor of economics at Fairfield University, traced to growth in the financial services sector of the economy; a proliferation of Internet businesses and computer-related services; some urban revitalization; and good access to New York City.
In stark contrast to Stamford, Hartford lost more than 20,000 residents in the 1990's, dropping from second- to third-largest city. The capital never recovered from the decline of the insurance and military-based industries in the early 1990's.
The largest city, Bridgeport, lost more than 4,000 people. New Haven, now in second place, lost nearly 9,000. Towns along the Hartford border, like East Hartford and East Windsor, also lost population.
Smaller cities suffered, too. New Britain lost 5 percent of its population and Bristol shrank slightly. 
Meanwhile, some of the largest percentage increases in the state could be found in smaller places like Sherman in Fairfield County, East Hampton in Middlesex County and towns like Sterling and Colchester.
Danbury also grew, by more than 9,000 people.
More than 2.6 million of the state's 3.4 million residents described themselves as non-Hispanic white; their percentage in the population dropped from 83 percent to 77 percent, using adjusted 1990 figures. In Litchfield County, they made up nearly 95 percent of the population, compared with 73 percent in Hartford County.
Hispanics in Connecticut rose from about 222,000 to about 320,000, but they remained concentrated in Hartford, New Haven and Fairfield Counties. The largest increase in Hispanics was in Hartford, where they are 40 percent of city residents. Their numbers also jumped in New Haven, Waterbury, New Britain, New London and Danbury.
In fast-growing Middlesex, however, Hispanics made up just 3 percent of the population, only slightly more than in Litchfield County.
The number of blacks in the state rose from nearly 272,000 to more than 295,000, the data show. They were also concentrated in Hartford, New Haven and Fairfield Counties, and practically absent from Litchfield and Windham Counties. Communities with large increases in blacks included many communities adjacent to Hartford, and Hamden, just north of New Haven.
At the same time, the number of non-Hispanic whites in those communities dropped markedly, though it is not clear whether those declines were largely attributable to deaths or to departures. The percentage of non-Hispanic whites in East Hartford dropped by 23 percent, in Bloomfield by 14 percent and Windsor by 13 percent.
Asians were concentrated in Fairfield County, though even there they were just 3 percent of the population. Less than 2 percent of Connecticut residents described themselves as multiracial. 
The census data released yesterday were limited to population and breakdowns by race and ethnicity.
Fred Carstensen, a professor of economics and director of the Connecticut Center for Economic Analysis at the University of Connecticut, said one of the most important issues will be "what has happened to the population in our core cities." Another, he said, will be questions of income distribution and inequality.
"Historically, of course, Connecticut is on average the wealthiest state in the country," he said. 
But Hartford, he said, is among the country's poorest cities. "I have heard it said that Connecticut is characterized by private wealth and public poverty," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 21, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the release of 2000 census figures for Connecticut misidentified the counties for Old Lyme and, in some copies, East Hampton. Old Lyme is in New London County, not Middlesex. East Hampton is in Middlesex, not Tolland.

HEADLINE: City Drain Continues, Despite U.S. Trend 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 19 

 BODY:
While early results from the 2000 census have shown resurgent populations in New York and many other cities across the nation, Connecticut's largest cities continue to suffer from a steady decline that began in the 1960's, according to census data released today. 
 As in previous decades, the only exception to the trend is Stamford, a corporate center in Fairfield County that continues to grow, even as populations shrink in Hartford, New Haven, Waterbury and Bridgeport, the state's largest city. 
 For the most part, the declining populations in Connecticut's cities parallel a decline in industry and in jobs, according to a study prepared last year by the state's Economic and Community Development Department. 
From 1960 to 1998, according to the state report, Bridgeport lost nearly 30,000 jobs. According to the 2000 census, Bridgeport's population is just under 144,000, down from more than 156,000 four decades ago. 
In New Haven, where new census data show that the population has dropped by 6.6 percent since 1990, more than 11,000 jobs were lost between 1960 and 1998, according to the state report. (The population comparisons are based on census figures for 2000 and on data for 1990 that reflect later adjustments to census figures to improve accuracy.)
But academics and other experts familiar with the shifting of Connecticut's urban landscapes suggest that a number of other factors are contributing to the cities' decline, including the appeal of suburbs and a lack of immigrants, who have been a large part of urban growth in other parts of the country. 
Connecticut cities are also not attracting recent college graduates -- the people in their early to mid-20's who have been contributing to housing crunches in New York, Jersey City, Hoboken, N.J., and other centers of new-economy jobs. 
"What's wrong with Connecticut?" asked Jay Gitlin, a history professor at Yale University and an expert on American suburbs. "That's a very good question.
"If you look at why New York has gained -- strong economy, lots of 20-somethings have moved in, putting a lot of pressure on the housing market," Dr. Gitlin said. "It's not that suburbanites are moving back to the city, it's other groups that are traditionally urban groups that are moving in. I know some of the people moving in -- they are my students."
Dr. Gitlin said Connecticut's urban decline was deepened by poor transportation and a lack of economic growth like that in New York and other large cities. But he also said there was a social angle to the drop. 
"I don't think Connecticut cities get the 20-something crowd because, let's face it, they are boring," he said. "The 20-something crowd, the new-tech groups, and the immigrant groups, why come here? We have not kept up with that cultural and technical economic expansion."
Matthew Nemerson, a former president of the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce, suggested that the strong economy of the 1990's had actually contributed to the decline of Connecticut's cities, by giving poor residents the means to leave the inner cities. 
"When people find that through hard work, their income is going up and families are formed and they are going to make decisions about how to spend the money they are making, many people are deciding to move out of the city," he said. "Because one, they can afford it, and two, they are concerned about finding the best location, usually, for their children."
And while young families with children are moving out, young single adults are not moving in, he said.
Mayor Joseph P. Ganim of Bridgeport said he believed that the city's population had stabilized after a sharp decline in the early 1990's and had actually increased somewhat from 1995 to 2000. 
"I think it's a positive sign when you look at what's happened in Connecticut's two other large cities," he said, referring to drops of 15 percent in Hartford and 6.6 percent in New Haven.

HEADLINE: JAPAN'S BANK ACTS TO SPUR SPENDING IN AILING ECONOMY 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 19 

 BODY:
Japan's central bank changed course sharply today in the struggle to revive the stagnant Japanese economy.
 The bank said it would try to stimulate consumer and business spending by pumping money into the banking system, by effectively cutting short-term interest rates essentially to zero and by promising to keep borrowing costs negligible until demand picks up and prices stop falling. 
 The announcement was a stunning about-face for the central bank, which for years had stubbornly resisted calls to give up its focus on keeping the money supply stable and flood the country with yen instead. Only the rate cut had been widely forecast, and that was expected to come only grudgingly.
"The bank has come to the conclusion that the economic conditions warrant drastic monetary easing, such as is unlikely to be taken under ordinary circumstances," the bank said in a statement. 
By trying to put more money into the hands of consumers and companies, the bank hopes to spur spending on goods and services, which would tend to push up prices. That, the bank hopes, would encourage consumers who had been putting off purchases to buy before prices went up much more. 
In Washington, where President Bush was meeting with Japan's prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, officials at the Treasury and the White House were relieved by the Bank of Japan's decision. But the two leaders ended their meeting with only a vague commitment by Japan to confront its huge problems with bad loans and corporate debt. Page C2. 
As economic growth slows around the world, the precarious state of the Japanese economy, the second largest after the United States, has taken on greater urgency. The country's banking system is riddled with bad debts, previous stimulus packages built around public spending have had little lasting effect except to run up the budget deficit, and a short-lived revival last year, driven almost exclusively by exports, appears to have fizzled out.
Consumers and business people alike have so little confidence in the economic future that they have reined in their spending, and the slack demand for goods and services has depressed prices and asset values throughout the economy.
The move by the bank today completed the reversal of a tighter-money policy put in place last September after the economy had begun to show some forward momentum. The bank's governor, Masaru Hayami, has since been berated for squelching a nascent recovery, not least by Western economists and finance ministers and an increasingly influential group within the nation's Finance Ministry who have been agitating against the Bank of Japan's tightfisted policies for several years.
Senior politicians have also made a habit of beating up on Mr. Hayami and the bank. "The Bank of Japan has been a very convenient scapegoat for politicians, who are facing a tough election this summer, a downward trend in the economy and increasing demands for structural reforms," said James Malcolm, an economist at J. P. Morgan in Tokyo. "Today's move by the bank is therefore almost symbolic, in that it's saying, 'O.K., we capitulated, now the ball is in your court.' "
By casting aside its longstanding objections and agreeing to give the political leadership's prescriptions for recovery a try, the bank has shifted the responsibility for the economy off its shoulders and onto the politicians' at a crucial moment. 
The Bank of Japan said its new policy was prompted by concerns about the ineffectiveness of Japanese fiscal and monetary policy over the last decade, about the slowing global economy, and about the pervasive deflation that is eroding prices, wages and asset values here. 
In practical terms, the central bank's board voted to increase the money supply by greatly expanding Japanese banks' capacity to lend. It will raise the amount of reserves the banks are required to keep in its custody by about 25 percent, to 5 trillion yen ($41 billion), and at the same time lend the banks the money they need to do so. With the greater reserves, the banks can lend much more without overstretching their capital. The move will have the effect of returning short-term interest rates to zero from 0.15 percent now. 
Moreover, the board said it would continue the policy until the consumer price index stops falling and remains flat or rises for a period of time. That commitment means the bank has implicitly adopted a tepid form of "inflation targeting," a policy of explicitly aiming to a step long urged on Japan by economists and long resisted by the Bank of Japan. 
The bank even suggested it would consider buying Japanese government bonds outright, a step it has resisted despite the blandishments of the political old guard. The move would guarantee the government will be able to finance its activities. But the bank said it would do so only when it deemed such purchases "necessary" -- and it did not define necessary. 
"This is quantitative easing, although an extremely modest version of it," said Ronald Bevacqua, chief economist at Commerz Securities in Tokyo. "But in the board's defense, this is an incredible change of direction for the Bank of Japan, which has denied the necessity for this type of easing throughout the entire post-bubble era. In the context of what is possible in Japan, this is not a bad first step."
While the policy board did not say what its next moves would be, it did open the door for further steps in the same direction. Two members of the board will step down this year, one of whom, Eiko Shinotsuka, was an ardent proponent of raising interest rates. The government will probably fill their places with candidates who are more dovish on monetary policy. 
"We believe today's measures will be the final easing measures in the current cycle," said Mamoru Yamazaki, chief economist at Barclay's Capital in Tokyo, referring to the bank's moves over the last two months to lower interest rates. "The next step would be outright inflation-targeting, but it would be a long time before such an action is taken."
Economists debate whether increasing the money supply will actually have its intended effect of stimulating activity. The bank cannot force companies and consumers to borrow, and most seem disinclined to do so, even at rock-bottom rates. The Japanese financial system is already awash with money, and bankers say that only the least creditworthy borrowers are asking for loans.
"Easing like this makes a lot of difference if there's a credit crunch," Mr. Malcolm said. "But currently we aren't in that situation in Japan -- although the risks of it may be increasing with a rise in bankruptcies."
In the United States, the Federal Reserve has several times acted to rapidly inject money into the banking system at times of impending crisis, most notably when a cash squeeze at an important institution like Citibank or Long-Term Capital Management threatened to disrupt financial markets. But deflationary conditions akin to those in Japan have not been seen in the United States since the Great Depression.
The bank's actions today may tend to push the yen lower against the dollar, as investors switch out of yen into currencies like the dollar where they can earn greater interest rates. A weaker yen would give a boost to Japan's mammoth exporters, which almost alone produced the brief surge in overall economic activity last year, and many analysts foresaw a decline in the yen's value even before the Bank of Japan acted. That effect will be undercut to some extent if, as expected, the Federal Reserve reduces United States interest rates on Tuesday. 
The yen was little changed in Tokyo trading after the bank's announcement, and fell slightly in value in New York to 123.03 to the dollar, near a two-year low. 
Still, the bank's eyes are clearly on domestic demand, not exchange rates. In its statement, it conceded the deflation Japan is seeing stems from too little demand, not only from structural factors like globalization or increased competition.
The government and the ruling Liberal Democratic Party have recently come up with plans to encourage Japanese banks to tackle their bad debt problems once and for all, and to unwind the longstanding system of mutual stock ownership between the banks and their biggest customers. Beyond prompting fears in world stock markets that the banks would start selling stocks heavily -- there is no sign that they have actually done so -- these plans are running into substantial political and practical obstacles, not least the requirement that banks set aside reserves to cover writedowns of loan and stock portfolios.
With the ruling party facing an uphill battle in elections for the upper house of Parliament in July, no painful measures are likely to be adopted before the fall.
In fact, senior politicians have amplified their calls for a supplemental budget of new public spending, even though the regular 82 trillion yen budget for the fiscal year that begins April 1 has not yet been enacted. Deficit spending from past supplemental budgets, long favored by policy makers and often urged on Japan by foreign governments, have left the country with a crushing national debt of about 130 percent of its gross domestic product.
"We're now at the limits of both fiscal and monetary policy, and that's where things get interesting," Mr. Bevacqua said. "The money's run out in terms of fiscal spending; they can't lower interest rates any further; and now, Japan's rich uncle, otherwise known as the U.S. consumer, has no money left in his pockets either."

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
WOOTTON, PHILIP H. JR.

 BODY:
WOOTTON-Philip H. Jr. On March 17, 2001. In Stamford, Ct. Age 82. An innovative Life Magazine editor and later a rancher in Colorado, Mr. Wootton was a 1940 Cum Laude Yale graduate in Economic Geology and Editor of Yale Scientific Magazine. He was born September 12, 1918 in New York City to Philip Henry Wootton and Anna Irving. In the mid 1950s, as Assistant Managing Editor, Mr. Wootton lead a team of Life editors and reporters who developed the concept of special issues and serials that underpinned the magazine's growth in the post-war, pre-television years. As Executive Editor in 1961 to 1963 among many other projects, he oversaw the Life Magazine special on the assassination of John F. Kennedy. Later, as Associate Director of research and development, he concentrated on multi-media development and contractual relations with broadcast and television companies. In 1971 Mr. Wootton purchased Singing River Ranch in Red Wing, Colorado. With his wife and family, Mr. Wooten ran the guest and cattle ranch for seven years. He sold the working half of the ranch in 1977 and retired, building a small cabin and barn nearby. Mr. Wootton was a longtime former member of the Woodway Country Club, a member of the Country Club of New Canaan, a former Board member of the New Canaan Nature Center and assisted regularly at Pegasus, a therapeutic riding program for the handicapped. Mr. Wootton's survivors include his wife of 58 years Marie Core Duffy Wootton of New Canaan, CT., two sons Philip H. III of Monroe, CT, William R. of Marlboro, VT., two daughers Constance Wootton Nichols of New Canaan, CT., and Elizabeth Ann Core Wootton of New Haven, CT., three nieces and a nephew and eight grandchildren: Justin, Peter and James Wootton; Russell and Clara Wootton; Elizabeth and Katharine Nichols, and Marina Wootton. 
A private interment will be followed by a memorial Mass at 11AM Saturday, March 24, at St. Thomas More Church, Middlesex Road, Darien, CT. Donations in memory of Mr. Wootton may be made to Waveny Care Center, Farm Road, New Canaan, CT. 06840 or to the New Canaan Volunteer Ambulance Corps, South Avenue, New Canaan, CT. 06840.
 WOOTTON-Philip. Retired editor of Life Magazine on March 17, 2001. Beloved husband of Marie Core Duffy Wootton. Loving father of two sons, Philip Henry and William R. Wootton and two daughters, Constance Nichols and Elizabeth Wootton. Grandfather to eight grandchildren. Funeral services Saturday, March 24, at 11 am in St. Thomas More R.C. Church in Darien, CT. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Waveny Care Center, 3 Farm Rd, New Canaan, CT 06840, or New Canaan Volunteer Ambulance Corp, South Ave, New Canaan, CT 06840.

HEADLINE: High-Stakes Showdown; 
Enron's Fight Over Power Plant Reverberates Beyond India

BYLINE:  By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: BOMBAY 

 BODY:
K. Wade Cline, a folksy lawyer from Houston with a round face and strawberry blond hair, is fit to be tied. As the top executive here for the Enron Corporation, the American energy multinational, Mr. Cline knows that the largest foreign investment ever made in India -- a majority of it owned by Enron -- is in trouble again.
 The state of Maharashtra has stopped paying its bills for the huge $3 billion power plant that sprawls along the Arabian Sea 100 miles south of here. After the nine tumultuous years it took to bring the project to fruition, the state now says it does not need and cannot afford most of the power. The resulting conflict is fast turning into a messy contractual dispute. 
 "Gosh dang it," Mr. Cline said. "I'm mad because they've waited so late, and we're running up against June when the bills will double." 
And that is just for starters. Next year, the amount the state's electricity board owes will more than quadruple to over $1 billion a year as the huge turbines for the second phase of the project come on line. Under the 20-year contract, the state and central governments have guaranteed they will pay the money if the electricity board defaults.
"Free us from Enron." That is the cry of Chief Minister Vilasrao Deshmukh, the top politician in Maharashtra, one of India's most industrialized states and home to Bombay, the nation's financial capital.
But so far, no one has come to his rescue. On March 8, the Dabhol Power Company, largely owned by Enron, invoked the central government's guarantee to pay up since the state had not, a commitment the central government says it will honor.
The stakes in this showdown are very high. The Dabhol project is fast becoming one of the fiercest battlegrounds in the debate about who wins and who loses from globalization. And it has the potential to sour foreign investors on India, a market of a billion people, and to sour Indians on foreign investors.
The worry that Dabhol could chill foreign investment is serious for India. More than 250 million people here live in abject poverty. The country needs to participate in the global economy in a way that broadly benefits society, economists say.
But investments by foreign companies in plants, factories and other projects in India fell sharply to $2 billion in 1999 from $3.6 billion two years earlier. China, the world's other highly populous developing country, attracted 20 times as much money.
The Dabhol project alone makes up more than 10 percent of the total direct foreign investment in India since 1992. 
Its woes have again raised questions about the financial wisdom of a strategy pursued not just in India, but in Pakistan, Indonesia and other developing countries. In an effort to attract private capital for electricity and economic growth, governments negotiated long-term deals, often in secret, with private companies for new power plants.
In the early 1990's, after India slowly began dismantling its centrally controlled economy and opening up to foreign investors, Dabhol became one of the first foreign-owned power projects approved by the central government in New Delhi.
The 2,184-megawatt project -- which Enron says is the largest gas-fired plant in the world -- has produced a raucous collection of anti-Enron crusaders. Among them are leftist political parties, consumer advocates and dogged individuals like Pradyumna Kaul, whose small management consulting office is piled with teetering stacks of documents, many printed from the Web.
Dabhol's opponents contend that the deal was meant to generate not just power, but bribes for politicians -- a charge that has never been proved and that Enron adamantly denies. The novelist Arundhati Roy, who has emerged as India's most impassioned critic of globalization and American influence, argues that such deals have benefited corrupt officials and foreign power companies, not the public.
"Once the agreements are signed," she wrote in a recent essay in Outlook magazine, "they are free to produce power at exorbitant rates that no one can afford."
But it is not just the foes of privatization who have questioned the deal with Dabhol, a joint venture of Enron (which owns a 65 percent share), Bechtel Enterprises and General Electric (10 percent each) and Maharashtra's electricity board (15 percent).
Back in 1993, when the project was just a twinkle in an executive's eye, the World Bank concluded that it was "not economically viable." The bank said that the type of plant proposed would produce too much power at too costly a price for the state.
A high ranking state official, who declined to be named, said that senior civil servants gave the same warning. "We knew what would happen, and they did it anyway for reasons they thought best," he said. "You're bankrupting yourself knowingly, willingly, deliberately."
There is also a growing consensus here that the problem with the Dabhol deal goes beyond its particulars. India's power sector -- inefficient, corrupt and heavily subsidized -- is hemorrhaging almost $5 billion in losses each year.
In Maharashtra, a third of the power is stolen or lost. More than $1 billion in delinquent bills are uncollected. And 9 of 10 customers pay subsidized rates.
The World Bank, said Edwin Lim, its country director for India, now strongly advises governments against guaranteeing contracts for new plants unless they also turn over distribution to private companies, which are more likely to reduce theft and collect bills.
The State of Maharashtra is desperately trying to figure out how to pay for Dabhol. Clearly the preferred solution for the state, the central government and Enron is that another state or company buys the electricity, but so far none have come forward.
In an interview, Mr. Deshmukh, the chief minister, called the power shockingly expensive. This fiscal year, electricity from Dabhol costs more than three times as much as other power in the system, state officials say.
A number of factors have driven up the price. The first phase of the project is fueled by naphtha, which has become much costlier because of rising oil prices. The bills are calculated in rupees, but tied to the dollar, so as the rupee has lost value the price here has risen.
Also, the state's electricity regulatory commission requires the electricity board to buy the cheapest power first, leaving Dabhol at the end of the line. Demand is much lower than the state had forecast. In recent months, the state has been buying only 10 to 20 percent of the power that Dabhol is capable of generating, while paying the plant's full fixed costs, Enron says. In Phase 2, twice as big as Phase 1 and fueled by natural gas imported in liquefied form, the state will also have to pay 75 percent of the fuel costs even if it buys no power.
Mr. Deshmukh, whose Congress Party narrowly holds office in a fractious coalition government, faces unpopular choices. In a country where many consumers are used to cheap or free power, the state can raise tariffs; go after big power thieves, many of them politically connected; collect delinquent bills; or slash spending on schools, hospitals and police.
For the state, the payments due for Dabhol will be huge -- more than Maharashtra's entire budget for primary and secondary education. 
The chief minister's hope that the central government will save the state is dimmed by the fact that two of the parties in power at the national level, the Bharatiya Janata Party and the Shiv Sena, are his chief political rivals in the state.
The Congress Party itself made the deal for the first phase of the Dabhol project, but it was the Bharatiya Janata Party and the Shiv Sena that agreed on the second phase -- after having beaten the Congress Party in 1995 state elections on a platform of throwing Enron into the Arabian Sea.
Suresh Prabhu, the power minister in New Delhi who is a Shiv Sena member from Maharashtra, said that if the state defaults, the central government would pay the bills, but the money would come out of the budgetary allocation to Maharashtra.
"We'll honor our guarantee without excuse," he said.
Mr. Prabhu's position, while reassuring Enron, should give state officials sleepless nights.
The latest crisis officially began in early February, when Dabhol Power first invoked the central government's guarantee to pay the state's $17 million November bill. The state itself subsequently paid up.
But the December payment for $22 million is now more than a month overdue, not to mention the January bill. The state electricity board argues that Dabhol owes it more than $85 million as a penalty for taking a couple of hours too long to fire up the plant. Dabhol Power calls this a frivolous excuse to avoid paying its bills and has again invoked the government guarantee. If the dispute cannot be settled, Dabhol will seek international arbitration, Enron says.
The payments crisis has given a lift to the project's opponents. A coalition of leftist parties and other groups held anti-Enron protests across Maharashtra on March 1. They want what they regard as a sweetheart deal to be canceled.
The Enron imbroglio, in turn, has alarmed American diplomats, who have pressed their concerns with officials in what they see as the interest of closer economic ties for the United States and India. Opponents of the project, like Girish Sant of Prayas, a nonprofit energy research group in Pune, say American government lobbying for corporate interests is unseemly.
Richard Celeste, the American ambassador, warned a gathering of political and business leaders in Bombay in late January that the perception that a legal contract like the one for Dabhol was "fair game for renegotiation" would feed uncertainty about investing in India.
Mr. Celeste, a Clinton appointee who will soon be leaving, said he had delivered the same message in a meeting with Mr. Deshmukh.
"I did tell the chief minister of Maharashtra when we sat down that I had no intention of going on the board of Enron," Mr. Celeste said in an interview.
Mr. Celeste's predecessor, Frank Wisner, joined the board of an oil and gas exploration company after he retired as ambasssador in 1997 that was then majority-owned by Enron; he has been criticized here for the move. But Mr. Wisner, now vice chairman of the American International Group, an insurance company, said that though Enron then owned a majority of the exploration company, their boards were separate.
He labeled as "foolishness" the argument that his membership on the board was a reward for the help he gave Enron in his three years as ambassador.
Earlier this month, Mr. Wisner and a group of corporate representatives from a United States-Indian business group met with N. K. Singh, one of Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee's most influential advisers, to discuss a number of issues, including Dabhol. Among those present were a representative from Enron and Enron's former top executive here.
"Dabhol sends a signal to investors in general and power investors notably that there's trouble ahead for investors in India," Mr. Wisner said. "It's in everyone's interest to see this settled quickly."
If anything, American lobbying on behalf of Enron may become more aggressive under President Bush. Kenneth L. Lay, chairman of Enron, has for years been an informal adviser and close friend to Mr. Bush and an important campaign fund-raiser.
Mr. Cline, Enron India's managing director, said Enron itself had no plans to invest in any more power projects in India for now and that companies in the sector were thinking hard before choosing India.
"When the markets of the world beckon with quicker returns," he said, "most companies are choosing to go elsewhere."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Interpublic Agrees to Buy True North

BYLINE:  By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
There's a new No. 1 on Madison Avenue -- again.
 Only five months after the WPP Group in London became the world's largest marketing communications company in revenue and billings by acquiring Young & Rubicam Inc., the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York, whose agencies work for clients like Coca-Cola, General Motors and Nestle, has leap-frogged into the lead. 
 Interpublic will go to the head of the class after the completion of an acquisition announced yesterday, after weeks of speculation, to buy True North Communications in Chicago, whose agencies work for clients like AT&T, Compaq Computer and PepsiCo. The stock deal, subject to the usual conditions, is valued at almost $2.1 billion.
The acquisition is the first big takeover of an agency company so far this year and the largest ever by far for the continually acquisitive Interpublic, which had been third in revenue behind WPP and the Omnicom Group in New York and second in billings behind WPP. True North, which had been shopping itself around to potential buyers since November, after losing its most important client, the Chrysler Group, had been ninth in revenue and eighth in billings. 
The acquisition represents a major gamble by Interpublic executives that a takeover of this size, one of the largest ever in advertising, makes sense strategically at a time when the slowdown of the American economy threatens to abruptly end the long-running boom on Madison Avenue.
"The question is, how smart will they look a year from now?" said Lauren Rich Fine, an analyst who follows the advertising industry for Merrill Lynch & Company. "I'd like to be able to look back and say, 'This is a great management that took the risk to buy True North today.' "
The deal, expected to be completed by early July, could be seen as emblematic of the types of transactions that take place in hard times: opportunistic acquisitions by the biggest agency companies seeking to grow ever bigger as they strive to stay apace with the huge consolidations among global marketers.
"How many advertising agencies are needed in the world?" Michael J. Russell Jr., an analyst who follows the industry for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, asked rhetorically. "The answer starts to drop as clients consolidate."
True North had been in on-again, off-again talks with Interpublic for more than three months, as negotiations also started and stopped with WPP and another giant marketing communications company, Havas Advertising in Paris. After the loss of the Chrysler Group creative and media assignments, with combined billings estimated at $2.4 billion, David Bell, chairman and chief executive at True North, had indicated he was amenable to outside offers.
"One of the jobs of a C.E.O. in a consolidating industry is to make certain our clients, our people and our shareholders are in an endgame environment," Mr. Bell said in a telephone interview.
"We have done the right thing not only to accelerate our growth," he added, "but also our ability to deliver a broad range of services seamlessly and smoothly by making available new services in the Interpublic family."
The deal, which lifts Interpublic to an estimated $6.7 billion in revenue from $5.2 billion and an estimated $62.5 billion in billings from $48.2 billion, brings under one ownership True North agencies like FCB Worldwide, the Bozell Group, BSMG Worldwide and TN Media along with Interpublic operations like McCann-Erickson, the Lowe Group, Weber Shandwick and Initiative Media Worldwide.
"It adds to the management depth of Interpublic to address issues going forward" raised by the uncertain economic outlook, said John J. Dooner Jr., chairman and chief executive at Interpublic, who joined Mr. Bell for the telephone interview.
"People who've gone through good times and bad times know how to get things done," he added, "and also know how to ride out of bad times in a strong way."
This is the first acquisition for Interpublic since Mr. Dooner added the duties of chairman in early January to his responsibilities as chief executive. Ms. Fine said she hoped Interpublic could successfully integrate the True North operations as it dealt with existing issues like improving results at the Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide unit of Lowe.
Some combinations of True North and Interpublic agencies are likely as Interpublic looks for annual cost savings in the $25 million range as a result of the deal. But the largest agency owned by True North, FCB, is to operate as an autonomous worldwide agency network to avoid client conflicts, becoming the third worldwide general advertising agency for Interpublic alongside McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising and Lowe Lintas.
"This is terrific," Brendan Ryan, chief executive at FCB in New York, said during a conference call with analysts to discuss the deal. "We become part of the No. 1 company in our industry.
"No. 1 is good," he added. "Big is good."
Mr. Ryan, Mr. Dooner and Mr. Bell said they believed the autonomous structure would prevent conflict-sensitive clients from leaving FCB, most particularly PepsiCo, which has Tropicana Pure Premium juices at the FCB New York office; additionally, the FCB Chicago office handles the Gatorade brand of energy beverage sold by Quaker Oats, which PepsiCo is in the process of acquiring.
That situation is complicated, however, by the fact that Interpublic itself, rather than an Interpublic agency, was named last year by Coca-Cola to serve as the "brand steward" for the flagship Coca-Cola soft drink. And in 1995, PepsiCo expressed its anxiety when Chiat/Day, which handled the Fruitopia line of beverages for Coca-Cola, was acquired by Omnicom, whose BBDO Worldwide and DDB Worldwide agencies handle PepsiCo brands like Frito-Lay and Pepsi-Cola. That anxiety was conveyed by Omnicom to Coca-Cola, which shifted Fruitopa's account to another agency.
Mr. Ryan, who is to remain chief executive at FCB, recalled that he first met Mr. Dooner three decades ago when Mr. Ryan was the product manager on Minute Rice at General Foods, now part of the Kraft Foods unit of Philip Morris, and Mr. Dooner was the junior media executive on his account at Grey Advertising, now the Grey Worldwide unit of the Grey Global Group.
Mr. Dooner chimed in that Interpublic wanted to acquire True North because "I've got to make sure Brendan Ryan buys that media plan I tried to sell him 30 years ago."
Mr. Bell will become vice chairman at Interpublic after the deal is completed. Until then, he will head a transition team, working with Barry Linsky, executive vice president for planning and business development at Interpublic; Bruce Nelson, executive vice president and chief marketing officer at Interpublic; and Kevin Smith, executive vice president and chief financial officer at True North.
Interpublic will exchange 1.14 shares of its stock for each of the 51 million outstanding shares of True North, which enjoyed a recent runup in its stock price despite the carnage on Wall Street because of speculation that Interpublic, WPP or Havas would make a a takeover bid.
In trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, True North shares closed at $38.12, down $1.19 or 3 percent, and Interpublic shares closed at $34.12, down $1.13 or 3.2 percent.
True North's largest shareholder, the Publicis Groupe in Paris, which owns 9 percent of True North stock, said it would seek more information about the deal before tendering its shares to Interpublic. Publicis, which lost a hostile takeover bid for True North in 1997, described the price Interpublic is paying as at the bottom end of expectations.
That may be true, but True North was not expected to fetch a price well above its current trading price because of the uncertainties caused by the loss to units of Omnicom of all its Chrysler Group assignments. They accounted for 9 percent of True North's revenue and up to 25 percent of its profits.
"I'm very comfortable with the price Interpublic is paying," said Ms. Fine, the Merrill Lynch analyst. "From the True North perspective, shareholders have to be a little disappointed."
Paradoxically, while the loss weakened True North and undoubtedly accelerated its end as an independent agency company, it also made True North more appealing to would-be acquirers like Interpublic that work for other automakers and would have faced conflict problems had a bid for True North proceeded earlier.

HEADLINE: Pilots at Comair Vote to Reject 5-Year Contract 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: HEBRON, Ky., March 19 

 BODY:
The pilots of Comair, the nation's second-largest regional airline, today rejected a proposed five-year contract.
 More contract talks are scheduled on Friday to try and resolve salary, scheduling and other disputes. 
The rejected contract could lead to a strike as early as next week. 
 President Bush, who has said he was inclined to block airline strikes that could hurt the economy, may also intervene.
Only six of the 1,096 pilots who voted supported the contract offer, said J. C. Lawson, chairman of negotiators for Comair's chapter of the Air Line Pilots Association.
A walkout could idle the airline, the most active carrier at Cincinnati-Northern Kentucky International Airport. Comair has flights to 95 cities in the United States, Canada, Mexico and the Bahamas and serves more than eight million passengers annually.
The president of Comair, Randy Rademacher, said the airline hoped to reach an agreement when the negotiators and a federal mediator meet on Friday in Washington.
"In our industry, it seems that first contracts are often rejected," he said. "A strike is not imminent."
Comair said it would shut down flight operations if the pilots walk out but would keep about 4,000 other employees on the job.
A White House spokesman, Scott Stanzel, said the National Mediation Board had not found that a Comair strike could hurt the region economically, which would allow the president to intervene.
The rejected five-year contract would have given Comair pilots a company-financed retirement program, and increased pay of top-scale pilots to $96,000 from $66,000.
Union leaders said the contract did not offer large enough increases to first-year pilots, who make $17,000 and $29,000 in the second year.
