HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
Two drug wholesalers plan to merge in a $2.4 billion stock deal.

BYLINE:  By Kenneth N. Gilpin 

 BODY:
IN a deal that will probably attract regulatory scrutiny, the AmeriSource Health Corporation and the Bergen Brunswig Corporation, the nation's third-and fourth-largest drug wholesalers, said yesterday that they had agreed to merge in a $2.4 billion stock deal. 
 The combined company will have about $35 billion in annual sales and 13,000 to 14,000 employees. It would compete with Cardinal Health Inc. as the nation's biggest drug wholesaler. 
 Under the terms of the agreement, which was approved by the boards of both companies over the weekend, Bergen shareholders will receive 0.37 share of the combined company for each of their shares. The new company will be called AmeriSource-Bergen and will be based in Valley Forge, Pa. 
The deal is termed a merger of equals, but AmeriSource shareholders will own about 51 percent of the company.
The proposed transaction comes on the heels of Cardinal Health's $1.94 billion acquisition of Bindley Western Industries. At the time that acquisition was announced, Bindley was the nation's fifth-largest drug wholesaler. 
Cardinal Health's acquisition was quickly approved by federal regulators. But analysts said the Federal Trade Commission would most likely take a very close look at the proposed combination of AmeriSource and Bergen. 
In 1998, the F.T.C. blocked the $4.5 billion purchase of Bergen by Cardinal Health as well as a proposed $3.2 billion takeover of AmeriSource by McKesson HBOC. The agency argued the deals would put too much power in the hands of McKesson and Cardinal. 
Robert E. Martini, the chairman and chief executive of Bergen, said in a telephone interview yesterday that "we spent a great deal of time" on the question of whether the deal would pass muster with the F.T.C. "We feel a lot more comfortable because the Cardinal Health deal got through very quickly and very easily."
Some analysts offered a more cautious assessment. 
"I think the odds are 60-40 in favor of this deal happening," said Lawrence C. Marsh, an analyst at Lehman Brothers. "The combined national market share would be less than 30 percent, or about the same size as Cardinal-Bindley. It could be hard for the F.T.C. not to scrutinize one deal and then turn around and look hard at the next one."
Leonard Yaffe, an analyst at Banc of America Securities, said the "dynamics of this merger are much more similar to the Cardinal-Bindley merger than they would be to the two mergers that were attempted in 1998."
He continued: "Then, four companies were trying to merge to create two companies. This would leave three big competitors." 
While Bergen is nearly twice as large as AmeriSource in terms of revenue, its market value is smaller. 
Investors have penalized Bergen for problems it faced in 1999 and early last year, when two acquisitions Bergen made stretched its capital and left it with a big debt load. 
Last year, Bergen sold one of those companies, the unprofitable Stadtlander Pharmacy. Bergen, which paid $428 million for the business, sold it to the CVS Corporation, the pharmacy chain, for $124 million. 
Bergen also acquired PharMerica Inc., one of its biggest customers, for $1.1 billion. But changes in Medicare cut into the unit's sales. 
In November 1999, the company fired Donald Roden, who engineered the deals, as president and chief executive. 
Mr. Martini, who served as chief executive until 1997, took the job back and has served as interim chief executive ever since. 
Given the slim operating profit margins in the industry, analysts said combining the two companies made a great deal of sense. But the reaction on Wall Street was less upbeat. 
Shares of Bergen closed at $15.87, down 7 cents, while AmeriSource fell $3.28, to $45.20.
"You need economies of scale," to offset narrow profit margins," said Howard Capek, an analyst at UBS Warburg. "The margins in this business are very thin, and they are not getting any fatter."
Combining the companies will "eliminate an entire corporate overhead structure," he added 
AmeriSource and Bergen said they expected that three years after the deal was completed that they would generate more than $125 million in annual operating savings. 
Executives from the two companies will divide management responsibilities. 
Mr. Martini will become chairman of the combined company. R. David Yost, chief executive of AmeriSource, will be chief executive. 
Mr. Martini said yesterday that he expected the transaction to be completed by late summer.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert E. Martini, left, the chairman and chief executive of Bergen Brunswig, and R. David Yost, the chief executive of AmeriSource. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Senate Debates McCain's Bill On Campaigns 

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19 

 BODY:
With Senator John McCain urging his colleagues to "take a risk for our country," the Senate opened debate today on legislation to overhaul the nation's campaign finance law and handed Mr. McCain a narrow victory on an early test vote.
 Sharp differences of opinion quickly emerged on the bill, sponsored by Mr. McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Senator Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, that would affect lawmakers quite personally by changing the way the political parties operate. Senators were already reprimanding one another this evening just after the first vote took place. 
 Mr. McCain, who put his effort to limit money in politics at the center of his presidential campaign last year, said that six-figure donations to the political parties were sullying politics. "Any voter," he said, "with a healthy understanding of the flaws of human nature and who notices the vast amounts of money solicited and received by politicians cannot help but believe that we are unduly influenced by our benefactors' generosity." Excerpts, Page A22. 
Senator Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican who has long battled against the bill, soon replied that the effort to end the unregulated, unlimited donations to the parties and to impose new restrictions on issue advertisements, violated the Constitution and would weaken the parties.
"The only way to really get at the core of this problem, if senators believe that the influence of money in politics is so pernicious, is to change the First Amendment," Mr. McConnell said. "The nub of the problem is you can't do most of these things as long as the First Amendment remains as it is."
In a sign of just how byzantine the maneuvering is likely to become as the Senate goes through two weeks of debate on the issue and free-flowing amendments, Mr. McCain and Mr. Feingold almost lost their first, symbolic test of strength in the 50-50 Senate over an amendment designed to assist candidates who run against millionaires.
While such an idea has support in both parties, Mr. McCain sought to defeat an amendment by Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, because it would allow political parties to pour in money to assist a candidate whose opponent had put more than $1 million of his own money into a campaign. Mr. McCain said a different way could be found to approach the problem.
But the provision initially appeared to be passing -- which would have been a blow to the coalition supporting the McCain-Feingold bill. It was defeated 51 to 48 after Democrats huddled and lobbied on the Senate floor and persuaded the Democrats Robert G. Torricelli and Jon Corzine of New Jersey and Herb Kohl of Wisconsin to change their votes. 
Mr. Kohl and Mr. Corzine are both millionaires who were initially trying to vote to aid candidates who face wealthy opponents like themselves.
Seven Republicans voted with the McCain-Feingold coalition, while five Democrats broke with their party to support the amendment. But it was not at all clear where these senators will stand on coming amendments. Senators planned to work over the evening to draft a compromise approach to wealthy candidates.
The day's proceedings were the first time since Republicans took control of Congress in 1995 that Republican leaders agreed to full debate on the McCain-Feingold bill and not kill it off in a filibuster. And few knew what would finally emerge from the Senate, and from an expected free-wheeling amendment process.
Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader from Mississippi, said, "I don't think the chances of McCain-Feingold passing as is are really good." Mr. McConnell said, "I think it would be easier to predict who's going to win the N.C.A.A. tournament." And Mr. McCain said he thought he had more than an even chance of finally pushing his legislation through the Senate on his sixth try after years of being blocked. 
But Mr. McCain said that success would depend on the amendment process and expressed fears that his coalition could be broken up by amendments that "look pretty good and yet are sort of like poison pills." 
The McCain-Feingold bill would ban the unlimited, unregulated donations to the political parties known as "soft money." It would also restrict issue advertisements by labor and corporations that are often thinly disguised advertisements for or against specific candidates within 60 days of a general election and 30 days of a primary and require more disclosure by other outside groups.
A rival bill, sponsored by Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, and encouraged behind the scenes by the White House, would limit the amount of soft money donations that individuals, corporations, committees and labor unions could make to national political parties to $60,000 a year or $120,000 per election cycle. It would also triple the current limits on regulated contributions to candidates. 
Mr. Hagel, who today drew the support of Senator Lott, argued that his approach would keep the political parties strong. "The parties are a vital component of our system," he said, "especially for a challenger to take on a well-financed entrenched incumbent. Who else is there to support that challenger, be they Democrat or Republican unless the challenge is self-financed?" Mr. Hagel's opponents say his measure would do little to stem the flow of money into campaigns.
President Bush has stopped short of endorsing Mr. Hagel's bill, but a set of principles the president released last week were much closer to Mr. Hagel's approach than Mr. McCain's. Mr. Bush called for a ban on soft money contributions by unions and corporations but not by individuals.
Debate was intense throughout the day with an unusual number of senators in the chamber listening to one another. Some senators used charts and pointers to underscore their arguments. Others told tales of how burdensome fund-raising had become. "I've now been through two re-election cycles and it's gotten worse," said Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, telling how he and his 1998 opponent spent more than $20 million in their campaigns in a small state with fewer than 1.5 million people.
Even before the debate opened this afternoon, Mr. McCain showed some of the flare for publicity that marked his presidential run. He and Mr. Feingold led scores of reporters and television cameramen in an antic march through the streets near the Capitol to watch the senators proclaim their opposition to big money fund-raising first in front of the nearby Republican national headquarters and then the Democratic headquarters. Many of Mr. McCain's former campaign aides were on hand, trying to keep the hordes of photographers from banging into road signs and falling over stoops.
As the duo spoke in front of the Republican National Committee, no one emerged. But when they hit Democratic Party headquarters, several staff members came out to watch. Saying that the "party of the people" was now raising $1 million checks, Mr. Feingold declared, "This is not why I became a Democrat and it is not the future of the Democratic Party."
As he spoke, some Democrats unfurled a banner from a top floor window, hastily made with red spray paint, saying: "Democrats support McCain-Feingold. Pass now." Mr. McCain shouted up to them: "Great Americans, up there. God bless you. Send back the checks, guys."

UNIONS AND CORPORATIONSWould require labor unions to notify nonunion employees that they may request a refund of the portion of their union fees used for political purposes. ISSUE ADVERTISINGWould seek to restrict "issue advocacy" advertisements by prohibiting labor unions and for-profit corporations from paying for radio or television advertising that clearly refers to a specific candidate within 30 days of a primary or 60 days of a general election. INDEPENDENT EXPENDITURESRequires timely reporting of independent expenditures on behalf of a candidate to the Federal Election Commission and specifies circumstances in which political activities will be considered "coordinated" with candidates. HAGEL BILL SOFT MONEYWould impose a limit of $60,000 per year, indexed for inflation, on soft money contributions to national party committees by individuals, PAC's, organizations, labor unions and corporations. Would not restrict soft money spending by state parties. INDIVIDUAL CONTRIBUTIONSWould increase the limit on individual contributions to $3,000 from $1,000. Would increase limit on individual contributions to national party committees to $75,000 per year from $25,000. Would increase limit on PAC contributions to candidates to $7,500 per election from $5,000. UNIONS AND CORPORATIONSNo provisions. ISSUE ADVERTISINGDoes not have any provisions for regulating issue advertisements, but would require all television and radio stations to make public all purchases of political advertising. INDEPENDENT EXPENDITURESNo provisions. BUSH'S POSITION SOFT MONEYWould prohibit soft money contributions from corporations and labor unions, but not from individuals. INDIVIDUAL CONTRIBUTIONSWould increase the current limit of $1,000 on individual contributions, which was set in 1974. Mr. Bush's campaign documents estimated that if adjusted for inflation, the limit would increase to about $3,400. UNIONS AND CORPORATIONSSupports prohibiting corporations and unions from political spending without permission from shareholders or members. ISSUE ADVERTISINGCalls for "protecting the rights of citizen groups to engage in issue advocacy." INDEPENDENT EXPENDITURESNo explicitly stated position, but Mr. Bush does call in general for the need to protect the "rights of individuals to express their views."(Sources: Offices of Senators John McCain and Chuck Hagel; White House; Congressional Quarterly; Democracy 21)(pg. HEADLINE: METRO BRIEFING 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
 NEW YORK

MANHATTAN: HOUSING CHIEF QUITS
The chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, John G. Martinez, yesterday announced his resignation, effective April 1. A former senior executive at PaineWebber, he said that he planned to return to the financial industry. A Giuliani administration official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, denied a report in Newsday that Mr. Martinez was forced out of his post because of clashes with mayoral aides. The official added that the front-runner to fill the housing post was the city's Juvenile Justice commissioner, Tino Hernandez. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

MANHATTAN: MAYOR BACKS ELECTION BILL
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday endorsed federal legislation that would provide $2.5 billion over five years for cities and states to modernize voting systems. A national study would examine new methods of voting to determine which are the most accurate, fastest to tally and easiest for voters. If the legislation, sponsored by Senator Charles E. Schumer, were approved, New York City could get as much as $45 million to help it replace its voting machines, perhaps as soon as November 2002. Eric Lipton (NYT)

MANHATTAN: COLUMBUS CIRCLE PLANS
An advisory panel that helped select the developer for the former New York Coliseum site in Columbus Circle has been reconvened and will examine how to renovate the circle itself and the city-owned building on the south side of the plaza, 2 Columbus Circle. "We are not moving Columbus, he is staying in Columbus Circle," Mayor Giuliani said yesterday. But he said he would welcome changes making the circle more of a gateway to the Upper West Side and Lincoln Center. A new headquarters for AOL Time Warner is scheduled to open in Columbus Circle in late 2003. Eric Lipton (NYT)

A detective has been transferred in connection with the January arrest of a man who had written a letter critical of Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island borough president, police officials said yesterday. The letter sent by the arrested man, Terence Hunter, to Mr. Molinari described Mr. Molinari's decision to close a Staten Island community center as a "high-tech lynching." Kevin Flynn (NYT)

Nine hundred and fifty workers at Community General Hospital have decided to join Local 1199Upstate of the Service Employees International Union. Prosecutors investigating pardons by former President Clinton want to interview Sheldon Silver, speaker of the State Assembly, officials said yesterday. A spokesman for Mr. Silver said he had agreed to the request, which came last week from United States Attorney Mary Jo White. Mr. Silver had accompanied Hillary Rodham Clinton, then a Senate candidate, to New Square in Rockland County last August. Mrs. Clinton won the town in the election, and President Clinton later commuted the sentences of four men from New Square. Mr. Silver said he planned to tell the investigators that "no discussion took place as to a pardon." (AP)

MANHATTAN: CHARAS CENTER FACES EVICTION
An East Village community center faces eviction once again following a decision Friday by a three-judge appeals panel. In February, a jury found that the landlord for the Charas/El Bohio Cultural and Community Center could not evict the center because the landlord did not plan to comply with the deed's requirement that the building be used for community facilities. But lawyers for the landlord, Gregg Singer, appealed an earlier judge's decision that required him to prove that he intended to comply. The appeals panel overturned that judge's decision last week and cleared the way for eviction. Alan Levine, a lawyer for Charas, said that he planned to ask the panel to stop eviction and that the decision favoring Charas still stands. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

Assemblyman Thomas P. DiNapoli won the support of the Long Beach Democratic County Committee yesterday in his bid to become Nassau County executive. Mr. DiNapoli is competing with Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi of Glen Cove for the Democratic nomination. The Long Beach party is considered one of the most powerful Democratic organizations in the county. The incumbent county executive, Thomas S. HEADLINE: With Glare Hitting Clinton, Limelight Eludes Schumer 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19 

 BODY:
The senior senator from New York charged out of a subcommittee hearing room the other day and headed for an adjoining hallway, eager to hear how his performance inside went over with the audience.
 "Hey, did you see that?" the senator, Charles E. Schumer, exclaimed to the first aide he spotted, bouncing like a boy who had brought a glowing report card home to his parents. "It was really great. I really nailed them." 
 Even in Washington, Mr. Schumer's efforts to be the center of attention are the stuff of playful humor, if not legend. This is, after all, the man who once showed up at an outdoor festival in New York City with a campaign aide hoisting a sign above the crowd that read, "Come Meet Chuck Schumer." 
But these days, Mr. Schumer is facing intense competition for the spotlight from Hillary Rodham Clinton, New York's newest senator and someone who does not have to lift a finger to get the kind of attention that Mr. Schumer works around the clock to attract.
Mr. Schumer's friends were so concerned that he might shrivel in the limelight of his new colleague, in fact, that they briefly considered having a celebrity-filled party for his 50th birthday on a scale that the Clintons themselves might have staged.
But something strange has happened since Mrs. Clinton took office more than 70 days ago. The junior senator has indeed eclipsed her higher-ranking colleague, but in the same way that a star athlete might overshadow his teammates' on-field heroics with his off-field missteps.
In New York City's relentless media culture, that has meant that just about every aspect of Mrs. Clinton's public and private life has come under almost daily scrutiny. It is not just the swirl of interest over the pardons granted by former President Bill Clinton, including those handed to members of a tight-knit Hasidic enclave in New Square, N.Y., that voted heavily for her. It is also about her hairstyle, her wealthy friends, her marriage and so on.
As a freshman senator, Mrs. Clinton has diligently offered ideas for improving education, reviving the upstate economy of New York and reducing air pollution, among other pressing issues. But the scrutiny will not die down.
The latest round occurred today with a disclosure in The New York Post that Mrs. Clinton's new Senate office, at 780 Third Avenue in Manhattan, costs more than any other office occupied by a United States senator, at an annual rent of $514,149. Her spokesman described the rent as reasonable given Manhattan's real estate market and said more expensive sites had been rejected. Still, her space is more than twice as expensive as Mr. Schumer's Manhattan office.
Some of these comparisons are inevitable. But the publicity focused on Mrs. Clinton leaves Mr. Schumer free to be the club's Cal Ripken, a star in his own right but also a hard-working Joe who shows up every day to do his job. That, at least, is the image his aides have worked diligently to reinforce.
At the same time, Mr. Schumer appears to be trying to escape the long shadow of his new colleague. He recently angered people close to Mrs. Clinton, for instance, by not only refusing to sidestep questions about her husband's controversial pardons but also repeatedly denouncing some of them, especially the pardon of a fugitive financier, Marc Rich, as a miscarriage of justice. 
His aides say he meant no harm by his remarks and was just speaking his mind. But others viewed his public disapproval as an effort to distance himself from Mrs. Clinton, lest he become tarnished by the association. Still, people close to Mr. Schumer say that the more Mrs. Clinton is defined as New York's celebrity senator, the better foil she provides for the Senator Everyman image: the dad with a happy life outside of politics, the guy who still drives a 1991 Ford Taurus.
"They're both brilliant but very different," said Ken Sunshine, a Democratic strategist in New York. "Chuck has no pretensions of being a star, and circumstances have made her the biggest star in Washington."
In other ways, little has changed. Mr. Schumer is the same unabashed self-promoter that he has always been. He holds a news conference somewhere in New York just about every other Sunday, a notoriously slow news day for reporters, to maximize the coverage. He as well as any other politician knows that many pet causes would be squeezed out of the news on weekdays by other, more urgent, items. 
Recently, Mr. Schumer dropped any pretense of modesty when a few constituents showed up at his office here in Washington to discuss some of their concerns. No sooner had the two visitors mentioned a new program that the governor back in New York had created than the senator interrupted. "Did you know that was our idea?" he said. "They took that from us."
He and Mrs. Clinton have yet to compete directly for credit on any legislation, or other matters. He says New York is a big state, with more than enough people and problems to keep two senators busy. "There's so much work to do," he said the other day as he left a news conference where he and Mrs. Clinton announced their support for environmental initiatives. "So we're helping each other, working together."
Mr. Schumer and Mrs. Clinton are as different in their styles as New York's two previous senators were: Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the self-styled intellectual, and Alfonse M. D'Amato, a man known less for his soaring oratory than for his meticulous care of constituent complaints.
Mr. Schumer has a hurried manner and mercurial disposition. He can be thoroughly engaging and funny, like when he mockingly referred to himself as Senator Scuffed Shoe. Or he can be overbearing, elbowing his way into some of the most high-profile debates on Capitol Hill.
Mrs. Clinton, on the other hand, is reserved and sometimes aloof. Even when facing tough and embarrassing questions from reporters, Mrs. Clinton is unflappable, rarely betraying even a hint of anger or combativeness in her tone or gestures.
For all their differences, Mr. Schumer and Mrs. Clinton have tried to get off to a good start. The two have had dinner twice over the last few weeks to discuss issues, and their staffs consult almost daily to keep each other posted on what they are doing.
In the end, though, Mr. Schumer is a one-man show. In news releases and phone calls, he trumpets his success in bringing home money for hospitals, schools and mass-transit projects to a state whose influence has waned in recent years within the nation's capital.
But Mr. Schumer does not want to simply be remembered as a Mr. Fix-it, in the D'Amato tradition. Elected to the Senate in 1998 after 18 years in the House, Mr. Schumer has built on his experience to champion issues like anticrime legislation while serving on the Senate Judiciary Committee. This session, Mr. Schumer is pushing to make college tuition tax-deductible, modernize the nation's aging voting system and bring down the price of prescription drugs by speeding up the process by which they become available to consumers as lower-cost generic drugs.
He has also been an outspoken critic of the new Bush administration, using his position on the Judiciary Committee to try to derail the nomination of John Ashcroft as attorney general and publicize the Bush administration's quiet effort to remove the American Bar Association from the judicial selection process. Mr. Schumer has also worked to shed the image he developed as a fierce partisan during his years in the House. He has reached out to Republicans, most notably Gov. George E. Pataki and Senator John McCain of Arizona. In New York City, he and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani seem to have a warm relationship, and Mr. Schumer's wife, Iris Weinshall, is the mayor's commissioner of transportation.
In the last six months, Mr. Schumer has been at the governor's side several times, much to the chagrin of Democrats who are gearing up to try to unseat Mr. Pataki in 2002.
Ever a pragmatist, Mr. Schumer offers no apologies. "Our job is to work together to get things done," he said.

A1); Senator Charles E. Schumer greeted constituents yesterday near Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. (Vincent Laforet/The New York Times)(pg. B4)

HEADLINE: Bush and Japanese Leader Talk, but Officials Then Disagree on What Was Said 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19 

 BODY:
President Bush and Japan's prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, met today to discuss joint strategies for restoring growth to the world's two largest economies but ended the session with only a vague commitment by Japan to confront its problems.
 "The interrelationship between our two economies is important," Mr. Bush said at a brief photo opportunity with Mr. Mori, noting that the two countries account for roughly 40 percent of the world economy. "The stronger we are, the more likely it is there will be prosperity in other parts of the world." 
 No one expected real agreements from this first meeting between Mr. Mori, a powerless figure in his own party who has hinted that he will resign next month, and Mr. Bush, who is new to many of the complexities of international economic management.
Yet when the two-hour meeting and luncheon at the White House concluded, American and Japanese aides initially gave somewhat differing accounts about a crucial issue in the leaders' conversation: Whether Japan would seek to revive its badly ailing economy by promoting demand at home or by seeking to take advantage of a weakening yen and exporting more cars, steel and other goods to the United States.
The issue is potentially critical for Mr. Bush, as his father can attest from bitter experience in the late 1980's and early 90's. If Japanese goods become cheaper at a time of weak consumer demand in the United States, the result could be accelerated layoffs in American factories. 
"The president did note that some in Japan felt that the best solution was to export their way out of the problem," a senior administration official said in a briefing at the White House. "But he emphasized, and the two leaders agreed, that the answer is strong domestic growth brought about by deep, structural reform."
Two hours later, a Japanese official said Mr. Mori had made no such agreement. But tonight, after additional inquiries, Ichiro Fujisaki, a senior diplomat who sat in on the meetings, said that while Mr. Mori made no explicit mention of Japan's export strategy, "we are not aiming at export-led growth." Mr. Fujisaki said that actions today by the Bank of Japan should strengthen consumer purchasing in Japan.
Condoleezza Rice, President Bush's national security adviser, added this evening, "They were very clear on the steps that need to be taken to make Japan's economy grow" at home.
Today's meeting was intended primarily to signal to Japan that the new administration is ready to revitalize relations with Tokyo, after four years of trade disputes during the Clinton administration and another four of disputes over Japan's unwillingness to reform its stricken banking system.
Clearly neither the White House nor the Japanese government were in a mood to expose either leader to intense questioning on those subjects. While President Bill Clinton had used the first visit here by a Japanese prime minister as a moment to hold a joint news conference and a public debate with his counterpart about economic reform, Mr. Bush and Mr. Mori took only one question, during a brief photo opportunity in the Oval Office. 
Mr. Bush provided the answer, a relief to Japanese officials, who are all too aware that Mr. Mori's misstatements have contributed to the calls for him to resign. 
Listening to the American and Japanese officials describe the meeting later, it was difficult at times to believe that they had been in the same room.
The Japanese dwelled on the talks about China, Russia and North Korea, discussing the issues surrounding North Korea's continued development of the Nodong missile. They skimmed over Mr. Mori's economic discussions, saying he had spent much of the time giving Mr. Bush a seminar on the last 10 years of Japanese economic management, little of it a pretty story.
The White House, eager to show that Mr. Bush was engaging the world's second-largest economy on questions of economic reform, dwelled on a joint statement issued by Mr. Bush and Mr. Mori, noting that Japan had committed itself to "effectively addressing the issues of corporate debt and nonperforming loans."
"We were heartened by the unusually explicit acknowledgment of the nonperforming loan problem," said the senior Bush administration official, who under rules set by the White House could not be named.
But this was hardly the first time the Japanese government has acknowledged the issue, which dates to the early 1990's: It has spent hundreds of billions of dollars bailing out banks, though it has stopped short of closing insolvent banks and selling the real estate they hold.
At the Treasury Department and the White House, officials were relieved by the Bank of Japan's decision, just hours before the meeting, to effectively begin printing money and keep doing so until it brought Japan's increasingly dangerous deflation to an end. The strategy brings Japan's already rock-bottom interest rates to zero, and increases the liquidity of Japan's struggling banks.
But the liquidity is aimed at "overnight money," the money banks keep in their short-term reserves. And that means, many analysts said, that much of it may go to the purchase of dollars, so that the banks (or their borrowers) can earn a higher rate of return.
"No one buys a house or builds a factory with overnight money," said Kenneth Courtis, vice chairman for Asia at Goldman, Sachs. "The banks, the hedge funds, you name it are going to go to U.S. currency."
The result could be a weaker yen, and that could pose the next major Japan challenge for Mr. Bush. A weak yen could increase America's trade deficit, an issue that was dormant in Congress as long as the economy was growing, but is already becoming a point of contention. That issue plagued Mr. Bush's father in 1991 and 1992, and contributed to his defeat, a point the current president understands well.
Mr. Bush's second challenge is to find ways to persuade Japan to move ahead quickly with the commitments in today's statement, "deregulation, restructuring, and foreign direct investment." 
His father started on that path, and Mr. Clinton continued along it. But it became clear to both presidents that the United States has little leverage when it comes to changing Japan faster than the government, the bureaucracy and the Japanese corporate leaders want to change.

HEADLINE: Powell Shifts Emphasis of Mideast Policy 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19 

 BODY:
In the Bush administration's first major description of its Middle East policy, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell drew a sharp distinction today from the Clinton administration's strategy of engagement in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, saying, "The United States stands ready to assist, not insist."
 General Powell, speaking on the first day of a visit here by the new Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, said that this did not mean that the status quo should be allowed to stand, but that it was the parties themselves who needed to start a dialogue. 
 In an address to a conference of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, General Powell passionately echoed Mr. Sharon's phrase that the violence between the Israelis and Palestinians "must stop." 
Later, at the same conference, Mr. Sharon focused on terrorism as the scourge of the region and said the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, was returning to the belief that Palestinians "can defeat Israel by means of armed struggle." 
"Arafat is willing to destabilize the entire Middle East, including moderate Arab regimes, in order to achieve his goals," Mr. Sharon said. 
The new prime minister, who is being welcomed here with respect but caution, is remembered as the Israeli housing minister who was responsible for the aggressive expansion of settlements a decade ago during former President Bush's administration. James A. Baker III, who was secretary of state at the time, wrote in his memoirs that Mr. Sharon was an "obstacle to peace." 
Mr. Sharon is trying to paint a different picture now, and after six months of violence between the Israelis and Palestinians, the Israeli Foreign ministry has hired two New York City public relations firms -- Rubenstein Associates Inc., and Morris, Carrick and Guma -- to burnish Israel's image in the United States. 
For its part, the Bush administration has helped Mr. Sharon with some recent diplomatic moves. The Bush White House has not invited Mr. Arafat to Washington, although it has invited the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, and King Abdullah of Jordan. Mr. Arafat was a frequent visitor to the Clinton White House. 
Further, Mr. Bush called America's Arab allies soon after the election of Mr. Sharon and asked them to give him "a chance," administration officials said. 
As Mr. Sharon began his visit, violence continued at home. Palestinian gunmen killed a 58-year-old settler, Baruch Cohen of Efrat, in a drive-by shooting on the West Bank today.
Brig. Gen. Benny Gantz, the Israeli commander for the West Bank, charged that the gunmen had taken advantage of what he said were Israel's loosened restrictions on Palestinian movement. After reports that the gunmen had fled past Palestinian checkpoints into the Bethlehem area, Israel sealed the city. Settlers called for the Israeli Army to reinstate a blockade of all major Palestinian cities and to keep Palestinian cars off the highways.
The shooting followed what the Israeli Army said was the first Palestinian mortar attack on southern Israel from Gaza since 1967. It wounded an Israeli soldier.
Foreign Minister Shimon Peres, referring to the shooting and the shelling, said, "This is something that cannot be carried out with the authoritative body, Palestinian officialdom, being aware of it."
During a women's protest march north of Jerusalem, Hanan Ashrawi, a prominent Palestinian lawmaker, was slightly wounded in a leg when Israeli soldiers lobbed a stun grenade at the demonstration. Palestinian officials said several other women had also been wounded slightly. 
The tone of General Powell's speech -- called by State department officials a "minimalist" approach to peace talks in contrast to the "maximum" approach of the Clinton administration -- appeared to appeal to the audience. General Powell was warmly received, and there was boisterous applause for some lines in his speech, especially those referring to the United States strengthening its "strategic cooperation" with Israel. 
There was no mention in the speech of a "peace process" -- a favorite phrase of the Clinton administration. General Powell has abolished the office of the special Middle East coordinator, a title held in the by Dennis B. Ross. 
The secretary moved beyond the specifics of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and addressed its regional context, urging Arab nations to be "voices of moderation." It is most "unfortunate" that no Arab nation maintains a resident ambassador in Israel, he said.
Soon after the violence between the Israelis and Palestinians began last fall, Egypt and Jordan, which have peace treaties with Israel, withdrew their ambassadors. 
General Powell touched on Iran and Iraq, apparently giving a nod to the Clinton administration's efforts to find some common ground with moderates in Iran. "We are aware of the intellectual and political foment taking place within Iran, and we will continue to watch developments there closely and hopefully," he said. 
On Iraq, he said he would have more to say "after the completion of our policy review" but repeated his theme that the United States is trying to strengthen the international coalition forged 10 years ago during the Persian Gulf war. 
At Blair House, Mr. Sharon met with General Powell; the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice; the director of central intelligence, George J. Tenet; and Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld. 
Afterward, a senior State department official said General Powell had urged Mr. Sharon to take steps to ease the economic pressures on the Palestinians caused by the Israeli blockade on goods and people moving in and out of the Palestinian territories. 
In response, the official said, Mr. Sharon said that he was taking some steps -- like easing the movement of goods -- but that he was finding it difficult to move forward because he had seen little reciprocity from the Palestinian authorities. 
"We understand that it is difficult to take steps with the violence going on, but we also believe that it's important to give people a sense of confidence," the official said of the call for Israel to ease the economic hardship on ordinary Palestinians. 
Before his meetings, the Israeli newspaper Haaretz reported that Mr. Sharon was prepared to tell the administration that he would evacuate a number of Israel settlements in Gaza if Mr. Arafat was ready to agree to "interim agreements" toward peace.
But the State Department official said Mr. Sharon had not raised the question of settlements in his discussion with General Powell. 

CORRECTION-DATE: March 28, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on March 20 about the Bush administration's Middle East policy misstated a word in a comment from Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel, on the fatal shooting of an Israeli and on a mortar attack on southern Israel. He said such attacks "cannot be carried out without the authoritative body, Palestinian officialdom, being aware of it." He did not say "with the authoritative body."

HEADLINE: Energy Chief Sketches Plans To Curb Rules Limiting Supply 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19 

 BODY:
Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham said today that the nation faced a "major energy supply crisis" akin to the oil embargoes of the 1970's and indicated that the Bush administration intended to overhaul regulations to ease fuel exploration and help energy production and distribution.
 Mr. Abraham, outlining the agenda for President Bush's energy task force, said rising electricity and natural gas prices were serious enough to tip the nation into recession. Only a major push to eliminate environmental and other regulatory obstacles to increased supplies will alleviate shortages, he said. 
 "The bad news is that the situation in California is not isolated, it is not temporary, and it won't fix itself," Mr. Abraham said.
But like several other Bush administration officials who have warned of an energy crisis in recent weeks, Mr. Abraham did not mention any policy initiatives that would help California or other states to limit price spikes or increase supplies. He said detailed initiatives would come in several weeks, when Mr. Bush's task force submits recommendations for legislation and rule changes to promote energy production.
President Bush, speaking as he met with his energy team at the White House this afternoon, said the focus was long term. "One thing is for certain: there are no short-term fixes," he said. 
The administration has sought to use California's problems to promote the opening of more federal land, including 1.5 million acres on the coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, for oil and natural gas drilling and coal mining. The opening of the Alaskan wilderness was the only specific policy change that Mr. Abraham endorsed today in a lengthy address on energy problems to industry executives gathered for an energy conference here.
"While the resources of A.N.W.R. won't make us energy independent, they will help increase America's energy security by ensuring a more diverse supply of oil," he said, adding that oil and gas exploration would proceed on only a small percentage of the wilderness.
But that aspect of the Bush energy plan seems likely to face stiff resistance in Congress, where many Democrats oppose the drilling in the wilderness for environmental reasons. 
A group of 500 scientists, organized by leading environmental groups, plans to present a letter to Mr. Bush on Tuesday urging him to reconsider making drilling in the Alaskan refuge a centerpiece of his energy strategy.
Environmental leaders also criticized Mr. Abraham's comments about California, arguing that the administration was using the crisis there as a cover to advance the energy industry's agenda. "It's distressing that California's crisis is being used as a pretext for outmoded and misguided national energy policies," said Hal Harvey, president of the Energy Foundation, a partnership of foundations that promote energy efficiency and renewable energy.
The renewed focus on energy policy also came just after the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries decided to lower oil production, a move that threatens to increase gasoline prices as the summer driving season approaches.
Mr. Bush often said during the campaign that he would work to increase foreign oil supplies through quiet diplomacy with Arab producers. Administration officials acknowledged today that Mr. Abraham had sought to persuade OPEC leaders to maintain or increase production levels.
"The actions taken this weekend were disappointing," said Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, "but that won't stop the president from continuing the outreach to talk to our allies, to talk to our friends, and working toward a long-term approach so that the supplies are stable."
Mr. Abraham told the energy conference, held at the United States Chamber of Commerce, that energy problems were already having a profound effect on the economy. He cited an estimate from the National Association of Manufacturers that rising fuel prices from 1999 to 2000 cost American business and consumers more than $115 billion, knocking roughly a full percentage point off overall economic growth.
While he declined to discuss detailed policy proposals to address the energy crisis, Mr. Abraham indicated that environmental protections would be a target. He said the administration wanted to find a middle ground between environmental concerns and the need for new energy supplies, but criticized the Clinton administration on the ground that it had leaned too far in the direction of protecting the environment.
He said oil companies were unwilling to build refineries in this country, at least in part because the government required them to provide some 15 types of gasoline to meet various regional antipollution standards.
The nation has rapidly become more dependent on natural gas, Mr. Abraham said. But he added that 40 percent of potential gas reserves in this country were on federal lands that were closed to exploration, suggesting that some of those reserves needed to be opened to help bring down soaring natural gas prices.
He also cited estimates that electricity demand would grow by 45 percent over the next 20 years and that the nation needed to add 90 power plants a year to keep up with that demand. That will happen only if power companies break through the logjams that have made it difficult to build such plants, he said.

HEADLINE: THE POLITICS OF AGING; 
Of Social Security and Saving

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
CONGRESS has embarked on a great debate over the future of Social Security and Medicare. In the next few years, politicians, health policy experts, actuaries and lobbyists will dissect scores of proposals of mind-numbing complexity.
 How should people prepare for the looming changes? The answer, said Marilyn Moon, an economist at the Urban Institute, can be summarized in three words: "Save like crazy." 
 "Even under the promises of current law, Social Security and Medicare need to be supplemented by other income," said Ms. Moon, who was also a public trustee for the two programs. 
Dallas L. Salisbury, the president of the Employee Benefit Research Institute, a private nonpartisan group, agrees. "On average, Medicare covers 54 percent of annual medical costs for retirees," Mr. Salisbury said. "No matter how Medicare is reformed, and even if it helps pay for prescription drugs, individuals will need to have more money available to pay medical expenses or to buy health insurance."
A new poll by The New York Times suggests that more people are saving for retirement front page, this section . Mr. Salisbury said the findings were consistent with surveys by his organization, but he added, "Most people still are not saving enough."
The proposals for revamping Social Security and Medicare are inspired, in part, by a judgment that the programs will be financially unsustainable in the long run, as millions of baby boomers retire. Members of Congress know the costs will rise rapidly and would like to make them more predictable. 
The politics of the issues are so volatile that lawmakers may forgo a major overhaul of either program, at least for the next 5 to 10 years, settling for piecemeal changes instead. But the direction of the changes is clear: they are likely to shift more of the cost -- or at least more of the financial risk -- to beneficiaries.
The prospect of such changes injects an element of uncertainty into the retirement plans of aging baby boomers; that, in turn, strengthens the case for them to save more.
Mr. Salisbury recommends that workers save 16 percent to 20 percent of their take-home pay. Then, he said, they have a reasonable prospect that their retirement savings and Social Security will fully replace the income they earned when they were working.
"One thing workers should not do in anticipation of Social Security reform is to reduce other savings, or contributions to 401(k) plans or individual retirement accounts," he said. "Personal Social Security accounts would be a substitute for part of your current Social Security benefit, not for private savings."
One of the more popular proposals would allocate 2 percentage points of the current 12.4 percent payroll tax to personal savings accounts. For many people, Mr. Salisbury said, such savings are unlikely to amount to very much, even if the money is allowed to accumulate for 30 or 40 years. "You would not want to change your behavior in anticipation of the income from such an account," he said. 
Reducing poverty among the elderly has been one of the great achievements of Social Security, and despite the recent gains in the stock market and the overall economy, many older people depend heavily on their monthly checks. For 63 percent of beneficiaries, Social Security provides at least half of their total income, according to government data; 18 percent of recipients have no other source of income.
People worried about changes in Medicare should check with their employers to see if they can qualify for health benefits after retirement, experts say. Such employer-sponsored benefits typically supplement Medicare, which is much less comprehensive than the health insurance that many workers now receive from their employers. Medicare, for example, does not generally cover prescription drugs outside the hospital. President Bush and Congressional leaders have promised to fill this gap, but Congress may begin with a limited program because lawmakers fear that the costs may become enormous. 
Some employers that provide health benefits to workers do not offer coverage to retirees. And some employers that offer retiree health benefits stipulate that workers must have been employed for a certain number of years before they can qualify. The rules for a worker's spouse may be stricter still.
Proposals to revamp Medicare generally encourage employers to continue providing health benefits to retirees, and several major proposals in Congress offer subsidies to employers. So experts say workers would be well advised to check on the health benefits they will receive after retirement.
A common theme running through the proposals to redesign Social Security and Medicare is that workers and retirees should take more responsibility for planning, arranging and financing the benefits they receive in retirement. It is, experts say, never too early to start preparing for such awesome tasks. 

Big Programs And Big Questions
WASHINGTON
During his campaign for president, George W. Bush proposed major changes in Social Security and Medicare, embracing ideas that had already begun to gain support in Congress. He said workers should be able to divert part of their Social Security payroll taxes into private savings accounts. A person earning $30,000 a year might, for example, be allowed to put $600 a year into a private account. 
Advocates for such a change say, in the words of the Cato Institute, a research center here, that Social Security is a "bad investment." They point out that money in the Social Security trust fund is invested in special government securities, which, over the long term, have produced a lower return than the stock market.
Critics of such proposals reply that the markets can be risky, and that the amount of money in an individual account at the time of retirement would depend, in part, on how wisely a person had invested. They add that diverting money from payroll taxes would have the effect of drawing down the trust fund, which is expected to begin running short of cash in the 2030's.
Many of the proposals for changes in Medicare assume that beneficiaries want more choice in the type of health insurance they receive after reaching the eligibility age, now 65.
Congress is seriously exploring proposals that would give beneficiaries financial incentives to enroll in private health plans. The traditional fee-for-service program would still be run by the government, but would compete for enrollment with approved private plans. The government would pay part of the cost, or the premium, in either case.
Supporters of this approach say it would encourage beneficiaries to select the plan offering the best coverage for the lowest cost. Critics say this is a recipe for cutting the benefits of people with chronic illnesses and disabilities. Many of them would end up in the traditional fee-for-service program, critics say, and the federal payment on their behalf would be inadequate to cover the costs.
 ROBERT PEAR

HEADLINE: SECOND STARTS; 
In This Career, The Investment Is in Young Minds

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY 

 BODY:
"HOW'D we do last night?" Richard S. Pechter, veteran investment banker, asked Carlos Mora, his eager protege.
 Lucent is down, the earnest young man said sheepishly. Microsoft, too. "I want to buy I.B.M.," he suggested. 
 "Do it," Mr. Pechter said. "I think that's a good buy. What do you want to sell?" 
Mr. Pechter, 55, retired in January 2000 as the chairman of the financial services group at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, where he oversaw 6,000 employees and $2 billion in annual revenue. Now his main client is 16-year-old Carlos, who plays an Internet stock market game with fake money as a charter member of the Wall Street Club here at Liberty High School, where Mr. Pechter is drawing a $37,000 salary as a first-year algebra teacher.
"I was at the very top of Wall Street, the very top firm, the very top guy," mused Mr. Pechter, whose dwindling hair is gray and white. "Now I'm at the very bottom. You can't be any lower in the system than I am.
"The irony of it is, it's pretty satisfying to impact one kid," he added. "I'm glad now that I will not reach the age of 80 and only have looked at one world."
Mr. Pechter, a graduate of Yale and of Harvard Business School, is part of a small but growing cohort of retirees returning to the classroom, not as volunteer mentors or as tutors but as full-time teachers, often in the nation's most impoverished schools. (Liberty, for example, is a small alternative high school for students who struggled in traditional classrooms.) With states and school districts scrambling to find 2.5 million new teachers over the next decade, many are seeking unconventional candidates, including those who are closing out one career but who have time and energy for another. As people live longer yet retire earlier, or string together multiple careers, many see teaching as a way to get involved in their communities and work on one of society's most vexing problems.
"This is largely an untapped pool," said Mildred Hudson, the chief executive of Recruiting New Teachers, a nonprofit organization in Belmont, Mass. "It's an important missing link in the recruitment efforts around the country."
In recent years, 40 states have adopted programs that allow non education majors to be certified as teachers after a few weeks or months of training. Most focus on recent graduates or midlife career changers; of the 4,100 people enrolled in California's 75 alternative certification programs, just 7 percent are 50 or older. But experts say retirees often make the best recruits.
Troops to Teachers, established by Congress in 1994, has sent nearly 4,000 retired soldiers and sailors into classrooms across the country. California State University at Dominguez Hills set up a similar program for retired aerospace engineers during the recession in the early 1990's, and Drexel University in Philadelphia joined with General Electric to help about 75 retirees become math and science teachers in local high schools.
"It's not just who you look for, but how you help them learn to teach," said Linda Darling-Hammond, a professor of education at Stanford University, where two dot-com millionaires who retired early are studying to become teachers. "We make a mistake in education thinking about who to recruit without thinking about how they should be trained."
Principals and people who operate certification programs say that compared with other new teachers, retirees bring experiences that help children see practical applications for what they are learning. Their maturity and patience often lead to better classroom management and relationships with students' parents. With their own children grown and gone and pensions kicking in, many have fewer financial worries.
And while retirees may be a shorter-term investment for schools than career switchers -- "I don't think I can live long enough to be a master teacher," Mr. Pechter said with a laugh -- they come to the classroom out of a desire to teach, rather than out of frustration with a previous job.
"That's what I always wanted to do since I was in grade school," said Thomas McGurk, 61, a retired psychiatrist who is applying for a teaching job in Kansas City, Mo. "I can do what I want to do now."
Besides Mr. McGurk, the Kansas City Teaching Fellows program -- similar to a current New York campaign to bring new people into the city's weakest schools -- attracted a 68-year-old man who was a missionary minister in Africa and Germany, among other places; a 57-year-old woman who worked in banking and real estate for 28 years; and a 53-year-old man who has read 78 books in the four months since selling his transportation business. In St. Petersburg, Fla., Eckerd College's new alternative certification program includes a former government worker, a vacuum cleaner salesman and a supervisor of a paper company.
A recent television commercial for Fidelity Investments depicts a retired chemical engineer mangling names during attendance in his first day as a chemistry teacher. "I'm very excited and a little bit nervous," says the character, a Mr. Foley. "I'm a lot nervous."
Mr. Pechter, who produced the 1997 Tony award-winning musical "Titanic," slept late and took piano lessons for the first six months of his retirement. Then, last summer, he went to Houston for six weeks of boot-camp training as part of Teach for America, the decade-old program that has placed more than 5,000 recent college graduates in urban and rural schools. (Mr. Pechter was twice the age of his fellow corps members, some of whom are friends of his youngest daughter, a student at Sarah Lawrence College.)
The learning curve has sometimes been as steep as the quadratic equations Mr. Pechter was reviewing with his students the other day. 
First, after relying on a secretary for decades, he had to figure out how to work a photocopy machine. More slowly, he has discovered that "it doesn't matter what I teach, it matters what you learn," and rejiggered his lesson plans to be less teacher-centered. (Instead of lecturing, he now reviews for exams by playing bingo, the students solving problems and circling answers on game cards.) After a student asked, "Why do you have to make this so complicated?" Mr. Pechter redefined his goals: "I'm not trying to get them to be sophisticated users of the quadratic formula, I'm trying to get them to know that there is a formula."
For Liberty students, the lessons of hard work, responsibility and setting achievable goals, Mr. Pechter says, are as important as those in his math textbook. "I want them to win," he said, seated at his desk beneath his framed degrees and a stock certificate from his company's going public. "I want them to see what it feels like to win."
Wealthy retirees like Mr. Pechter could help students in other ways, of course -- by paying for their college education, for example. But teaching has had a deeper effect on him. 
He says he listens better now. He has a more nuanced understanding of President Bush's education proposals. He has even reignited a relationship with his former wife, Kayla, a nurse practitioner at a Jersey City emergency room, who said: "I wanted him to have that experience where you touch one person's life. What it means to have one kid smile at you, one kid learn the equation."
As an executive, Mr. Pechter spent most of the day sitting; now he stands a lot more. He has traded in his briefcase for a backpack, swapped a spacious 49th-floor office in New York's financial district for a sweaty, windowless basement classroom tucked under a 99-cent store. He gave all his suits to his son.
But each morning as he drives to work from his home in Summit, N.J., Mr. Pechter still sees the sun rise over the Manhattan skyline. And since Carlos Mora has a portfolio to maintain, Mr. Pechter still keeps one eye on the stock market.

SECTION: Section H; Column 1; Retirement; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 1730 words

HEADLINE: SECOND STARTS; 
These Retirees Are Not In Kansas Anymore

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: SAN MIGUEL DE ALLENDE, Mexico 

 BODY:
WHEN Gene Maxon, an Oklahoma oilman then pushing 70, first vacationed in this small colonial city eight years ago, he ran into Philip J. Maher, the American consul here.
 "You know, Gene," Mr. Maher said, "if you live here more than half the time, you stop aging -- and I suggest you start now." 
 That was no joke, said Mr. Maher, a retired Air Force colonel who has been the consul since 1983. "People come here to live," he said. "They go to Florida to die." 
There is no fountain of youth in San Miguel de Allende. But there is an American circle of nearly 4,000 retirees who have brewed their own rejuvenating mix of congeniality, community service and cocktails under a constant sunshine. They are among an uncounted number of Americans 50 and older -- the estimates run well over 100,000 -- who call themselves retired and have made Mexico their home, settling in places like San Miguel de Allende in the state of Guanajuato and Ajijic in the state of Guadalajara, transforming them into bilingual and bicultural communities that bear little resemblance to the exclusive gated and guarded enclaves found in the swath from Florida to Southern California.
Mr. Maxon and his wife, Sandra, sold their business, said goodbye to Tulsa, Okla., and moved to San Miguel with no regrets. "People back home ask why we are here," Mr. Maxon said. "It's peaceful, it's quiet, there's no violence. This is a cosmopolitan place, full of well-educated, interesting people -- they entertain us. There is something to see or do here every day of the week. And it's springtime year round.
"I grew up in Clyde, Kan., population 1,500," he said. "And San Miguel reminds me of that small Midwest town in the 1950's where everybody knew everybody. San Miguel, though it's much larger, has that same air of peacefulness."
It may sound like paradise, but it is not -- not exactly. The American influx has swelled San Miguel de Allende from a quiet town of 25,000 three decades ago to a small city of roughly 100,000 today.
The American arrival began more than 50 years ago with a trickle of artsy adventurers and bohemian-minded World War II veterans financed by the G.I. Bill. The trickle became a stream in the 70's and a bona fide phenomenon in the 90's. Now the cobblestone streets are jammed with cars on weekends, and the gorgeous colonial buildings, which lend the city its lost-in-time feeling, are harder for locals to afford. Most of the Americans are much richer than most of the Mexicans in San Miguel, many of whom make their living farming and tending shops, not living off stock dividends. 
This creates some resentment, though it tends to stay under the surface, with natives praising the Americans for their wealth and good deeds, and on rare occasions quietly cursing the changes they have wrought. It also creates a small but significant theft problem, though there is very little violent crime. Still, some Americans "can't cope with the contrast between the slums and the million-dollar houses," said Marjorie Zap, a 76-year-old retired economist who has lived here for five years.
If anyone has ideas about hopping in a recreational vehicle and moving here to live like royalty off of Social Security, forget about it. The cost of living has probably gone up tenfold since 1970, and it cannot be done on much less than $1,500 a month. And those who have never experienced life outside the United States are unlikely to make a go of it in Mexico.
But pleasures abound for people who are intrepid, slightly offbeat, willing to live life in a different cultural rhythm and able to give something back.
Many of the retirees living here came on vacation and had a eureka experience: the flash of knowing that This Is the Place. Tony and Shirley Adlerbert were among them. They had a nice life in the States -- a good home in Vermont, plenty of money, few worries, childless by choice and contentedly so. They came down to San Miguel for a vacation in 1991.
"I sat in the Jardin" -- the leafy town square -- "and I felt all the stress melt away," said Ms. Adlerbert, a human-resources manager for 35 years. "The tranquillity -- people want to have it, to take it home with them."
Instead of leaving that feeling behind, the Adlerberts spent their second week of vacation buying a home. They have lived here full time for six years. He is the executive director and she is the treasurer of Feed the Hungry, which runs 12 kitchens feeding 1,500 of San Miguel's poorest children. He plowed his experience as the chief executive of an investment firm in Vermont into running the charity, and while that involves lots of work, he looks like a happy man.
"We came here to recapture a life that just doesn't exist anymore in the United States," he said. "It's like a little village."
Yes, but a bustling one. "I was always in a corporate environment, and I never had any free time," Mrs. Adlerbert said. "Here you can be as busy as you want to be -- and I am busy. Sometimes I say to Tony, 'What happened to retirement?' "
That is an interesting question. Carl Franz, a co-author of "The People's Guide to Mexico," recalls that a tourist once asked, "What do you people actually do here in San Miguel de Allende?"
The answer was, "Well, you either do good or play golf," Mr. Franz said. 
San Miguel has become too cosmopolitan for his taste. Mr. Franz lived there for nearly 30 years, moving to Ajijic (pronounced ah-hee-HEEK) two years ago. There is a friendly war, sometimes not that friendly, between the two communities, the San Miguel crowd looking down their noses somewhat at Ajijic, whose partisans sneer at the perceived snobbery of San Miguel, and both accusing the other of being too fond of cocktails.
Ajijic, on the banks of Lake Chapala, is more low-key, though it boasts its own film festival and other artistic attributes. Robert and Bonnie Kleffel moved there from San Diego last year, buying and remodeling a house. Housing costs are a third to half of what they would be in California, Mr. Kleffel said, and "everything we need -- food, clothing, medical, entertainment and interesting friends -- is within walking distance." The advent of free trade means there are few consumer goods that Americans cannot find in Mexico.
Mr. Kleffel said there is "some division in the expatriate community." On the other side are people who isolate themselves from Mexico, living behind gates, watching only American television shows, eating only American food, speaking only English and just to fellow Americans. 
Mr. Franz, who has traveled to almost every corner of Mexico, said the American communities in this country have become "another form of the American melting pot, breaking down some of the economic and class differences we have in the U.S. and like to think we don't." 
"In San Miguel, in particular, you have that mix: starving artists, single or divorced or widowed women without much money who tend to be more adventurous than single men, writers and poets -- probably an unhealthy number of poets -- artists, sculptors, people with real reputations in these fields, and then a huge moneyed cocktail circuit," he said.
He also identified a species of Americans here "who come down thinking it's going to be paradise for peanuts, people who don't have a clue about the culture, complaining about the servants, complaining about people not being on time, not being able to get a phone installed in two days, people who don't understand the difference between a truly wealthy country and one that is struggling," he said. "But there are those people who are really doing good works -- on the environment, working with orphans, helping with the library, which is a wonder."
An unscientific sample of the American community in San Miguel suggests that the good-works crowd is doing much better than the martinis-for-lunch bunch -- although some people doubtless engage in both. They have built a new hospital, helped fix up San Miguel's fountains, set up two major music festivals and started most of San Miguel's 100 or so charities. Dr. William T. Harrison, who is 80 and lives here with his wife of 10 years, June S. Holly, a doctor of education and social activist, makes "a lot more house calls than I did in Houston, and here I can be of service without H.M.O.'s and Blue Cross."
Medicine costs about a third of what it does in the States, which helps because coverage under Blue Cross and Blue Shield expires after 60 days in Mexico, Dr. Harrison said. (Medicare does not provide coverage outside the United States.) Colonel Maher had a knee replaced in the new hospital; the surgery cost $4,000, about a tenth of what it would in the States, he said. An X-ray costs $6, a visit to the dentist, $40. San Miguel's steep, stony streets are challenging for people with bad joints. Still, Ms. Zap said, "If you are infirm, there are people in the community who can take care of you." Like the Community of Hope, an ecumenical group in which Ms. Holly is active. Ms. Zap added, "I plan to stay here till I die." Most Americans here choose to have life-or-death surgery in the United States, and new commercial flights from the city of Leon nearby means they can wake up in San Miguel and be in a hospital in Houston or Los Angeles by afternoon.
The nearness of the United States also means that children can visit with ease. "One difficulty in making the move is leaving the kids behind," said Russ Archibold, 77, a semiretired management consultant. Most of San Miguel's retirees live in fairly spacious homes with room for guests -- remodeled colonial houses or fancy new ones that in the United States would cost two to three times San Miguel's going rate of about $250,000. Of course, people don't want to feel as if they are running a hotel, Mr. Archibold said -- "so we built a house with only one extra bedroom."
Mexico requires retirees from abroad to obtain a resident visa, which can take months, and to prove they have an income of roughly $18,000 or more a year. Sorting out visas, building permits and car registrations may require a lawyer -- Mexico's bureaucracy can be byzantine, but even Eden had its snake. 
Of course, Americans always like to improve on paradise. But as Mr. Archibold said over a $2 breakfast the other day, San Miguel may be as close as one can get, given the human condition.
"Nobody cares what you do in this town," he said, "as long as they know all about it."
