HEADLINE: The World According to AARP 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
EVERY day, across the country, the letters arrive with the inevitability of taxes and death -- which is just what some recipients think of when they open them. 
 "Dear friend," comes the greeting. "The enclosed AARP card has never been more valuable to you than it is today." Some who get the letter view it with dread or with humor, but since all recipients have just turned 50, they cannot help but see it as a symbol: they have just crossed a Rubicon. 
 The humorist Bill Geist once wrote that with the end of the draft and the arrest of the Unabomber, the AARP letter is the most feared piece of mail a person can get. 
Yet the organization that mails nine million of these letters each month -- and last year sent one to Mark Spitz, Stevie Wonder, Morgan Fairchild and David Cassidy, among others -- is famous for more than just reminding people of something they would rather forget. Over the years, AARP -- formerly known as the American Association of Retired Persons -- has become the older American's 800-pound gorilla, known for its sheer size and political muscle. Its membership, 33.4 million, is bigger than the population of Canada, and represents 45 percent of Americans 50 and older. Those letters may cause some resentment, but they are effective.
AARP's annual budget of $435 million is about three times the size of the National Rifle Association's. For the last three years it has topped Fortune magazine's survey as the most effective lobbying organization in Washington. 
And this behemoth may be about to grow bigger. The huge post-World War II cohort of baby boomers is starting to swell AARP's ranks. Americans are turning 50 at the rate of 1 every 7.6 seconds; in the next 30 years, the number of people aged 65 or older will double, to 20 percent of the population. 
"The demographics are on our side," Horace B. Deets, the group's executive director, once told an interviewer. 
But even as Mr. Deets, 62, prepares to step down later this year, there are signs that all has not been well with the organization he has headed since 1988. Membership grew at 20 percent a year in the 12 years before Mr. Deets took over, powered partly by AARP's lowering the eligibility age to 50 from 55 in 1984. Membership growth slowed to 1 percent a year during his tenure. From 1996 to 1999, the last year for which complete financial data are available, revenue from dues, which makes up 32 percent of AARP's income, was relatively flat. 
And there has been a series of embarrassments. In 1994, AARP, a nonprofit group, agreed to pay the Internal Revenue Service $135 million to resolve a dispute over its business income from 1985 through 1993. The group paid $15 million in lieu of back taxes in 1994 and 1995, and another $52 million two years ago. And it had to spin off a commercial subsidiary that sold insurance and other services to its members. Two years ago, the Postal Service fined AARP $5.6 million, citing it for illegally mailing millions of solicitations for commercial insurance. The Postal Service said that AARP should have been paying a commercial rate for postage rather than the cheaper rate charged to nonprofit agencies.
This is not the worst of it. Notwithstanding the Fortune designation, some Congressional staff members and dispassionate observers say AARP, once in the forefront of legislative battles like the fight over cutting Social Security cost-of-living increases, has lost its lobbying edge, adopting a more cautious approach out of fear that a strident tone might alienate some of its members, once largely Democratic but now roughly divided between Democrats and Republicans. 
"I've almost stopped thinking of them as a lobby," said a House Democratic staff member familiar with the group's work on Capitol Hill. "They have all kinds of valuable member services and do really good research work. But in terms of being a tough lobby, they're not what they used to be."
Yet of all the challenges that AARP faces, perhaps the greatest is keeping a cohesive purpose and sense of direction with a membership that is split by an age gap and a sense of identity. The organization may be poised to achieve explosive growth, but it also has to figure out how to appeal to people who are 50 to 65 and still working, while remaining relevant to older retirees. How, for example, will AARP ultimately come down on the issue of privatizing Social Security, which many younger members might favor, when retirees fear such a move might lead to a cut in their benefits?
John Rother, AARP's chief lobbyist in Washington, responded to these concerns. "Part of the Social Security debate that everyone would expect us to be prominent in would be to protect current beneficiaries," he said. "And if we were just a membership organization for people 65 and above, maybe that's where we would spend most of our energy.
"But because we're putting so much focus now on the younger group, it pushes us to think much longer-term," Mr. Rother continued. "So we're putting just as much emphasis on pensions and savings that people can do in their working years as we are on the traditional Social Security system itself."
Those intellectual, marketing and lobbying strains will only intensify in the future. Sixty percent of AARP's membership is currently 65 and over; 40 percent is between 50 and 65. With the baby boomers, those proportions may change. And if the differences between the two groups sunder AARP's mission and outlook -- there is no guarantee that it will -- then its size could turn from an asset to a liability. 
The challenges of bigness are nothing new for AARP. The group was founded in 1958 by Dr. Ethel Andrus, a retired educator who as head of the National Retired Teachers Association was concerned that many of her members could not obtain health insurance. Dr. Andrus struck up a partnership with Colonial Penn Life Insurance, whose marketing of insurance through the association helped increase the group's appeal.
The association's explosive growth came under Cyril F. Brickfield, a back-slapping hail fellow who took over in 1967 when the group had about one million members. By the time Mr. Brickfield stepped down in 1987, membership was 28 million. 
He was followed by Jack Carlson, a former chief economist at the Office of Management and Budget in the Nixon administration. Mr. Carlson lasted only 15 weeks before being forced out. Association officials said he and the group's directors did not agree on his desire to restructure the group's businesses to make each operation pay for itself. Mr. Carlson accused the group of slovenly management. 
If Mr. Brickfield, the group's most famous leader, was a man about Washington, Mr. Deets, who became executive director in 1988, is about as low-key as they come. At a time when the heads of interest groups are media stars, Mr. Deets prefers to work in the background. To many in Washington his name seems to be Horace Who? 
Though his penchant is for strategic thinking and management reforms, Mr. Deets has spent much of his time putting out brush fires. Not long after he took over, the association was criticized for supporting legislation that set up a catastrophic health insurance plan in Medicare. 
The measure, the biggest expansion of Medicare since its inception in 1965, provided insurance for elderly people beset by huge medical bills for major illnesses. But some seniors with higher incomes objected to the plan's $60-a-year increase in Medicare premiums and its annual surtax that ran as high as $800.
Howls from a group of higher-income older people prompted Congress to repeal the program in 1989. But some turned their scorn on the AARP. Mr. Deets, who still defends the group's support for catastrophic care, estimated that 12,000 to 14,000 members resigned in protest. For a group with nearly 30 million members, the loss was minuscule. But the experience was searing.
"We learned some tough lessons out of that repeal," Mr. Rother said. "One thing we learned was that it wasn't sufficient to just do the policy analysis here in Washington. You really had to lay the groundwork all across the country."
The setback helped spur AARP to open more state offices, an idea that had been resisted by AARP leadership, which feared it would lead to fragmentation. But with so many government functions devolving to the states, establishing a stronger grass-roots network has taken on an importance beyond setting up structures that communicate what the group is doing in Washington. 
"So much of what is done that affects the audience we serve is either funded, regulated or delivered at the state level," Mr. Deets said. "If you're going to be effective in serving your members' needs, you have to be a player at the state level." 
In 1988, the group had 10 regional offices and one state office. By the end of this year, it will have 53 offices, one in every state and major territory. AARP employs about 1,900 people and enlists about 3.4 million volunteers. 
AARP may have learned something else from the travails of catastrophic health insurance -- political caution. "This was considered a major blunder by the Washington operation in that they got out ahead of their members," said a Democratic Congressional staff member. "They haven't gotten over it yet."
Since then, the knock on AARP has been that it has tried to maintain a middle ground so it would not be closely identified with either party. This was further sharpened by the Republicans' capture of Congress in 1994, and the wafer-thin margins that now divide the House and the Senate. With AARP's membership evenly divided politically, the leadership has felt the need to cling to the middle so as not to jeopardize either the $141 million it gets from dues or the $161 million in royalties from the sale of goods and services like insurance and prescription drugs that carry the AARP imprimatur. Or so the argument goes.
In addition to lobbying, AARP researches issues important to older people and organizes volunteers for community projects. For $12 a year, members receive discounts on prescription drugs, travel, car rentals and other services, including advice on financial planning and health.
"They don't want to lose membership, because membership feeds into all their products," said Robert Binstock, a professor of aging, health and society at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland. "I think that's what they are trying to do -- do enough advocacy for the aging so it seems like they're doing the right thing, but not enough to seem radical."
Curiously, AARP officials do not disagree with this assessment, though they say the part about being primarily motivated by money is overstated. 
"AARP has developed a certain lobbying position," said William Novelli, an associate executive director of the organization and a possible successor to Mr. Deets. "What it boils down to is, don't get way out in front of your membership. We're not Planned Parenthood. Try to work with both sides, bring them together, keep raising the bar in terms of what you want. When you represent 34 1/2 million people, the majority of whom vote, you don't have to smack people in the head with a stick."
Mr. Novelli promised that in the future, AARP would take more of a leadership role in lobbying efforts, would build its grass roots into a more potent force and would become more forceful on issues like pensions. But do not expect it to become a strident voice identifying strongly with one side or the other on Capitol Hill. 
"If you come down hard on somebody, you're going to rile up a certain percent of your own members," Mr. Novelli said. "Of course, then they'll go to your membership and try to turn them against you."
These days AARP is trying not only to make sure no one turns its members against it but also to enroll more baby boomers.
The organization is in the middle of a five-year effort to figure how to attract younger members. It has started a $100 million campaign to erase its image as an organization for old people. In 1998, it changed its name, dropping the periods in its acronym, along with its dowdy title. 
Earlier this year AARP started a magazine, My Generation, which is offered to younger members instead of Modern Maturity, which will continue to go to older members. "We've known for several years that we had to start reaching out for a younger audience," said Martha Ramsey, the director of publications. The premier issue, with the actor Ed Harris on the cover, featured articles on subjects like technology and gadgets, financial planning and camps offering trapeze lessons. 
Whether all this will attract the baby boomers, and whether these new members can keep the organization together, Mr. Deets and the AARP leaders are determined that if the organization goes the way of the dinosaur, it will not be out of complacency.
Recently Mr. Deets read a book by Peter Drucker that contained these words, " 'Those whom the gods would destroy are first granted 40 years of business success.' "
AARP is 43 years old.

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article in the special Retirement section on March 21 about the influence of AARP, formerly the American Association of Retired Persons, misstated its membership and its annual dues. In 2000, according to the organization, it had 34.3 million members, not 33.4 million. The fee is $10, not $12.

HEADLINE: SECOND STARTS; 
When Do You Retire? Here Are 6 Answers

BYLINE:  By LESLIE BERGER 

 BODY:
ANDREW DONG retired three years ago with health, wealth and youth to spare. He was 36, the vice president of a Canadian software company about to go public, when he made up his mind to cash in, buy a motorcycle and travel as much as he could.
 But even for Mr. Dong, a mathematician turned millionaire, the decision was not easy. What quietly guided him was the death of a close colleague, from melanoma, at the age of 40. "He was diagnosed too late," Mr. Dong said. "It made me realize that you can go at any time." 
 Rarely simple, the decision to retire is often a tangle of conflicting emotion infused with urgency. Money, obviously, is a big concern. But so are intangibles like geography -- do you want to move closer to your children and grandchildren? -- and time. 
Many people who choose to retire experience a "giddiness of opportunity" and yearn to do something meaningful, said Marc Freedman, the president of Civic Ventures, a public policy group in San Francisco.
Yet at the same time, he went on, there is the sobering realization that "time means more than at any other period of life because the hourglass has started to run."
Joseph F. Quinn, an economist at Boston College's Center for Retirement Research, agrees. "More and more people," he said, "are thinking about what they're going to do all day long and how long they're going to live" -- one reason so many older workers are taking part-time "bridge" jobs instead of simply retiring from the work force.
Findings like these are borne out by the experiences of Mr. Dong and five others who agreed to talk about their decision to retire. For all of them, the constant was that money was only part of the equation. Or as Clare Hushbeck, an economist with AARP, put it: "The no-brainer is finances. The kinds of things where people really don't put enough thought into, and are surprised by later, are much more personal things."

Eager to Move On
Barbara Rubin, professor
Like Mr. Dong, Barbara Rubin was influenced by an early death -- that of her mother at 56, from ovarian cancer. Dr. Rubin, an ardent feminist who never married, was 63 when she retired last June from New Jersey City University in Jersey City, where she co-founded the women's studies program and Women's Center.
"I had other artistic urges," she said. "I no longer wanted to be an administrator, and I was concerned that the administrative part of me would kill the artistic part of me." And, she added, "I didn't want to postpone any longer the next phase of my life."
Dr. Rubin now relishes the chance to write nonfiction and poetry, study French and possibly live overseas. But retiring has been scarier than she thought because a portion of her savings is tied up in the stock market. A native New Yorker, she also continues to rent in a Gramercy Park building. Social Security should cover her housing costs, provided that rent stabilization holds.
For the first time, she has hired a financial adviser and is trying to live on a budget. She is eating out less, choosing trips more carefully, worrying about isolation. Deciding to retire inevitably meant taking stock, she said, adding, "I had to deal with choices I'd made many, many years ago."

Prepared for a Smooth Landing
Charles Griffith, pilot
Charles Simmons Griffith approached retirement with the crisp efficiency of his 22-year career as a pilot for Southwest Airlines and his service in the Air Force before that. He stopped flying in November 1999, at age 55 -- five years before the federal mandatory retirement age for commercial pilots.
"I had it in my head that an adjustment of this magnitude was easier made at a younger age," he explained. "Fifty was too young. Sixty was too far down the road. Fifty-five to me seemed to be just right. I wanted to still have some sense of youth about me when I did the things that I wanted to do."
Money is not an issue for Mr. Griffith, who benefited from Southwest's profit-sharing program and a lifetime of careful saving and investing. Nor is boredom: a decorated Vietnam veteran, he is turning his war experience into a novel. He is also restoring the 1885 brownstone in downtown Chicago that he and his wife, Sarah, bought after raising their family in Texas. Fulfilling an urge for community involvement, he takes children flying in his Tobago TB10 two weekends a month.
"For me to go from being a captain from a big airliner and managing a crew to just being a U.S. citizen was not a big deal," Mr. Griffith said.

Certain the Time Was Right
Charles Littel, maintenance chief
Charles Littel's knees told him when it was time to stop working.
"I was having trouble getting up and down ladders and helping out with moving furniture and that," said Mr. Littel, 64, who retired in January 2000 as the maintenance supervisor of an office building in Philadelphia. "And the building I'd been in was sold and new owners were coming in and I just thought it was a good time to leave."
He talked it over a lot with his wife, Kathleen, who still works as the manager of a hospital ward. Between his pensions and Social Security and her salary and health insurance, they figured they could meet their monthly expenses and still be able to travel -- including more frequent visits with their children and grandchildren. They also wanted to spend more time with each other after years of conflicting schedules.
Mr. Littel said the hardest part of retiring was his last month on the job, when he could not stop himself from thinking, "Hey, you're not coming back to this place anymore."
"You start to second-guess yourself a little bit," he admitted. "Do I really want to? Is this right for me? Now that I have been off for a year, I can honestly say no, I did not make the wrong decision."
Much of Mr. Littel's life revolves around the Schuylkill River, where he rows three or four mornings a week in good weather. There, he has friends of all ages and occupations to work out with -- though it's the serenity of the sport he loves best.

Coming Full Circle
Betty-Bruce H. Hoover, principal
As a principal of a private high school for 16 years, Betty-Bruce H. Hoover had greeted and graduated four generations of teenagers and counseled their parents about letting go.
Suffice it to say she had no trouble recognizing when it was time to let go herself. It happened in the summer of 1999 when she was preparing for the coming year.
"Lots of things had come full circle, several times," said Mrs. Hoover, 62, who stepped down last June as the upper division director of Berkeley Preparatory School in Tampa, Fla.
There was also the issue of staying in tune with students' interests, which got harder once her own children grew and her administrative duties increased. Even her herb garden at home seemed to be sending a message: "The only one I couldn't get to grow was thyme."
She is traveling more with her husband, a tax lawyer, and awaiting the birth of a second grandchild. There are photo albums to finally organize and the classics she wants to reread without pressure.
On the laptop she received as her retirement gift, Mrs. Hoover is writing a history of the school. It is a contract job that gives her an excuse to visit the campus a couple days a week, chat with friends and check the bulletin board for inspirational sayings.
"Your best work is accomplished by always being where you are when you're there," was a favorite, Mrs. Hoover said. "I particularly used that with seniors who were always looking so far ahead."

Looking Homeward
Harold Goodis, endodontist
For Harold E. Goodis, planning his retirement has been a cakewalk compared with the career change he made 15 years ago when he left his dental practice in Orlando and went to San Francisco, to become a dental professor at the University of California. If financially unsettling -- he and his wife, Joan, became renters -- the move was intellectually gratifying.
Now 65, Dr. Goodis still thrives on his teaching and research but is savoring the prospect of retiring. He will do it in about four years, when fully pensioned. He will continue his research, but on an emeritus basis. He will finally write up the stories he has been telling his grandchildren. "I've always worked and it's going to be strange not to have a regular working schedule," he said. "But there are several other things I want to do that negate having a schedule."
The biggest dilemma has been where to finally buy a home to retire to -- and whether to return to the East Coast. At first, Mrs. Goodis lobbied heavily to be closer to their children. But the couple reluctantly concluded that "we did not want to live next door to our own children," Dr. Goodis said, adding, "They have their own lives."
They began looking for golfing developments as close to San Francisco as they could afford and found the town of Fulsom, about two hours north. Their new home is under construction and should be ready to use on weekends long before they move in full time. Now the only unresolved issue is where to buy cemetery plots, Dr. Goodis said, without a trace of gloom.
"I'm not going out of this life alive, and that's all right," he said. "I will have hoped to have lived a full, fruitful life and can't ask for anything more than that."

HEADLINE: DANCE REVIEW; 
A Monty Python Tone In a Japanese Troupe

BYLINE:  By ANNA KISSELGOFF 

 BODY:
Experimental dance in Japan today is hot. New ideas about ideas, not just movement, have spewed forth from visiting troupes in recent years.
 Condors, a zany all-male group founded and directed by the choreographer and dancer Ryohei Kondo, spices its rebellion against serious concert dance and high-tech society with clever irreverence. 
 Appearing at Japan Society on Saturday night, Condors came across as a Japanese Monty Python with a Beatles-like spirit in its videos.
Using pop culture to critique pop culture and just plain culture, Condors has a pop-group appeal of its own. Squeals and laughter came from the younger Japanese viewers at Japan Society's theater, where the Condors program was presented with Dance Theater Workshop before an appearance in Los Angeles at Japan America Theater on Friday.
Many of the spoken punch lines were translated by the cast or their puppet surrogates. Mr. Kondo knows how to mix his media. Dance deliberately channeled into an athletic tumbleweed style is only one component in the current performance, titled "Conquest of the Galaxy: Jupiter -- Love You Live." The program consists of sketches, but the bits and pieces are assembled so quickly that the impression of collage and montage runs through the show.
That there is method in the madness is obvious. In the Japanese tradition, Mr. Kondo is the leader or teacher, and the others are disciples. A rangy and brilliant virtuoso, he reserves the bravura for himself, sometimes in the image of a pop star in sunglasses and curly wig. The 11 other men come in all shapes and sizes. Some are trained dancers and some are not, although they may be born comedians.
The sketches are uneven but the spirit of uninhibited physical theater is present. There are some pure movement passages, usually focused on a variety of leaps. More often Muzak and American and Japanese pop recordings set the tone for a parody. There is a hilarious spoof of a Hollywood western with the hero pushing past the shoulders of two men, who serve as a saloon's swinging doors.
A cloth doubles as a screen or a puppet-stage horizon. On film, the cast cavorts everywhere from the Great Wall of China to East 47th Street in Manhattan. The skits take aim at the new economy, with performers personifying banks and skyscrapers; ballet, with dancers in long johns; a dictator spinning a globe; and Japanese travel posters. The loopier Condors is, the better.

HEADLINE: Retirement Savvy 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Contrary to your suggestion, your March 16 front-page article profiling blue-collar workers with 401(k)'s did not show why the stock market decline should produce a decline in support for President Bush's proposal to allow Americans to invest a portion of their Social Security payroll taxes in the stock market. 
 Among those you interviewed were men and women who had suffered losses but who also revealed considerable market sophistication. 
They talked about the need to stay in for the long haul and to shift to low-risk investments closer to retirement age as well as the desirability of beginning to invest early in life.
A woman who was asked about investing her own money after the fall of her 401(k) doubted that she could make any better informed investments than government economic institutions. "I'm not smarter than Greenspan," she said. She's too modest. She's doing better than any government institution I know.

BOB KERREY
New York, March 19, 2001

The writer, the former United States senator from Nebraska, is president of New School University.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Argentina Calls on Ex-Economics Chief to Halt Slide 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, March 20 

 BODY:
Scrambling to keep Argentina from plunging further into recession and political disarray, President Fernando de la Rua cast aside more than a year of austerity policies and called on Domingo Cavallo, the country's economic hero of the early 1990's, to come to the rescue.
 Mr. Cavallo, a supply-side economist well regarded on Wall Street, was named economy minister in a reshuffled cabinet, the same post he was given almost exactly a decade ago by Carlos Saul Menem. He is replacing Ricardo Lopez Murphy, who resigned on Monday after only two weeks in the post when his proposals drew a storm of opposition. 
 Mr. Cavallo's appointment represents a sweeping departure from Mr. de la Rua's failed efforts to raise taxes and cut spending in hopes of reducing budget deficits and lowering interest rates. Instead, Mr. Cavallo is expected to push tax cuts and deregulation to jump-start an economy -- South America's second largest after Brazil -- that has contracted for two years.
Choosing Mr. Cavallo was a matter of politics as much as economics, as Mr. de la Rua tried to combat a growing sense that his fractious ruling coalition was incapable of governing after 16 months of scandals and policy shifts. Mr. de la Rua said Mr. Cavallo "will be in charge of directing the country's economy."
Speaking to reporters today, Mr. Cavallo said, "All of the attention of my ministry will be directed at rapid reactivation and vigorous economic growth, to increase employment and increase family income, so people will consume more, and we will exit this recession that has gone on for three years." 
In 1991, the demons plaguing Argentina were hyperinflation and a plunging currency. Mr. Cavallo tamed them by pegging the Argentine peso firmly to the dollar through an arrangement called a currency board, which backs all the pesos in circulation with hard-currency reserves. Inflation fell to single digits, investor confidence blossomed and Mr. Cavallo's reputation was made.
In those days, the United States was emerging from its own recession and international investors were intrigued by Mr. Menem's wave of privatizations. Now, Mr. Cavallo comes back to power as the United States and Latin American economies are slowing down, which could make his job more difficult. International investors are also much more skeptical about Argentina after several years of disappointing economic performance.
Mr. Cavallo has long argued that Argentina needs a supply-side injection of capital to restore consumer confidence because the country's economy is primarily driven by demand from its own consumers and businesses, not by exports. If his expected tax cuts fail to reignite growth quickly, though, the country's fiscal plight may worsen. The federal deficit in January reached $985 million, up sharply from the $590 million shortfall in January 2000.
"Cavallo's appointment is good news but doesn't solve Argentina's longer-term problems," David Malpass, chief international economist at Bear, Stearns, wrote in a report today. Mr. Malpass praised Mr. Cavallo's first policy statements, saying they "shifted the budget focus from arbitrary I.M.F. fiscal targets to a concerted attack on government bureaucracy, corruption and wasteful spending." 
Today, Mr. Cavallo tried to tamp down rumors that Argentina would retreat from the currency peg, known here as convertibility, and devalue the peso in an attempt to bolster exports. Critics say the peg has outlived its usefulness and made Argentine exports uncompetitive. But "convertibility is here to stay and will never be abandoned," Mr. Cavallo said. Many Argentines have been converting peso bank deposits into dollars in fear of a devaluation. 
Mr. Cavallo, who in recent years has led a small conservative party and held a seat in Congress, is bound to become the most powerful aide to Mr. de la Rua at a time of growing labor and student protests, including road blockades and sit-ins around Buenos Aires. A small bomb exploded on Monday outside the offices of a research center associated with Mr. Lopez Murphy; no one was injured. 
Mr. Lopez Murphy had proposed a plan to save the government $4.45 billion over two years, mostly by cutting aid to higher education, fuel and tobacco subsidies and tax exemptions, and cracking down on tax evasion. The plan caused protests and a near-rebellion by governors belonging to Mr. de la Rua's Radical Party, and several cabinet ministers resigned.
Mr. de la Rua also named new ministers of the interior, education and infrastructure and housing and filled several other key posts; several of the new appointees are allies of Mr. Cavallo, who is 54 and a Harvard graduate.
Mr. Cavallo asked Congress today for a free hand to cut regulation, simplify labor laws and fight corruption -- the issue that led to his eventual break with the Menem government.
But with congressional elections scheduled for October, opposition leaders responded guardedly. "We cannot say 'we are going to delegate everything,' " said Senator Eduardo Menem, a leader of the opposition Justicialist Party and brother of the former president. "Otherwise, we might as well close Congress." 
Investors also reacted cautiously. The benchmark Merval stock index rallied early in the day and then settled back to close off 0.6 percent.

HEADLINE: Business Travel; 
Midsize and smaller airlines tend to get the best ratings in the latest customer survey by Zagat.

BYLINE:  By Joe Sharkey; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. E-mail: jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
MOST airline performances declined over the last few years, with long lines, unpredictable delays, crowding and disorganization over all making air travel less appealing -- except for those people who were in first class or business class," Tim Zagat said yesterday. "And even they noted that the level of service was not always what they would have liked."
 Now before some wiseacre hollers "Whoa, stop the presses!" let us note that Mr. Zagat is not just another voice grumbling from the dim recesses of the departure lounge when he talks about airline performance. Rather, he is an impresario of qualitative and quantitative consumer ratings: the co-founder, with his wife, Nina, of Zagat Survey, which publishes those pithy, opinionated guides to restaurants, hotels and other travel and leisure services. 
 Yesterday, the Zagats released their 2001 Airline Survey, which rates the performances of 70 domestic and foreign airlines. The survey -- the first conducted by the company since 1998 -- is based on evaluations by more than 31,000 airline customers, including nearly 1,000 travel agents. On average, the respondents took 15.7 domestic and 3.9 international flights last year, according to Mr. Zagat. Airlines are rated numerically, with grades for comfort, service, food and cost, and also awarded an overall numerical score -- "30 being perfection; zero being terrible," Mr. Zagat said. 
You can find the survey on the Zagat Web site, www.zagat.com. Following are some highlights, starting with the airlines that customers decided performed best.
In general, midsize and smaller carriers were the highest rated. The top-rated domestic airline for economy-class travel was Midwest Express Airlines, a Milwaukee-based carrier that promotes business-class-style seating and service at coach prices. Customers raved about its leather seats, free Champagne, real china and friendly crews -- all "reminders of what's possible" in air travel, as one passenger put it.
Finishing behind Midwest in the top five over all were JetBlue Airways, a "role model" for discount carriers, Mr. Zagat said in summarizing customers' ratings; Alaska Airlines; Midway Airlines; and National Airlines.
For premium-service seats, the top five domestic carriers were Hawaiian Airlines, Alaska Airlines, Continental Airlines, American Airlines and United Airlines. Of the major airlines in this group, Continental got high marks for its new fleet, its extensive schedule of nonstop cross-country flights and its highly regarded frequent-flier program. Customers liked American's new roomier coach seats but didn't much care for the self-serve bags the airline passes out for breakfast and lunch, which one customer called "a joke."
Interestingly, United made the top five in premium class despite a sorry record of delays and cancellations last year. Some customers suggested that was because the airline had been making real efforts to win back customer good will with improved food and frequent-flier program bonuses. 
Since the previous survey in 1998, "Continental clearly made the greatest improvements" domestically, Mr. Zagat said. Internationally, Continental performed even better, according to the survey. "It jumped 3 points over all in our ratings, which is the most of any of the 70 airlines that were surveyed," Mr. Zagat said. "It's a major turnaround for an airline of that scale."
For international flights, Singapore Airlines was top-ranked in both premium and economy classes. Readers called it "the standard for quality" and the best of the Star Alliance partners. Virgin Atlantic also scored well among foreign carriers, especially in premium class, where it was rated second behind Singapore by customers who praised Virgin's "hip" environment, personal amenity kits, extensive in-seat entertainment choices, and on-board "massages and manicures at 2 a.m."
Following among the top 10 premium rankings were Cathay Pacific, Thai Airways, Air New Zealand, Swissair, Qantas, Japan Airlines, British Airways and South African Airways.
In economy, after Singapore, eight of the same airlines turned up, in slightly different order and with the exception of Scandinavian Airlines System, which displaced British Air in the list.
Zagat surveys are best known for customer comments, which range from effusive and admiring to qualified and diffident to downright derisive. Dissatisfied Zagat raters are notoriously brutal, as suggested by unpublished comments from restaurant reviewers listed on the Web site: "Dishes taste like road kill," one diner wrote of a restaurant. "Food tastes like socks," said another, of a separate establishment. "Be sure to sit in the no-shooting section," someone else warned. And readers of the airline survey looking for the zingers won't be disappointed.
"Should be on Antiques Roadshow," one customer said of the Northwest Airlines fleet.
"Then there are the ones where you kind of wonder why they bother," Mr. Zagat said of some foreign airlines' ratings. "Like Egypt Air, where one of the quotes was 'the words on-time don't exist.' Of Olympic Airlines, another flier asked, 'How about cleaning the jets once in a while?' " he said.
And how about that Aeroflot? You want to talk bum trip? "Aeroflot got an overall score of only 4.9, which is about 4 to 5 points below anyone else," Mr. Zagat said. "Not for the faint of heart," one reviewer said of the Russian carrier.
Other international airlines got qualified praise, like Aeromexico, lauded for its "free beer" and "nice selection of tequila" -- all the better to ward off the "biting bugs" that one dissatisfied customer said came along for the ride.

HEADLINE: Management -- Border Crossing: Where Language Isn't a Barrier; 
2 Schools, 2 Nations, One Future Envisioning Free Trade

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MONTERREY, Mexico 

 BODY:
At the Duxx Graduate School of Business Leadership here, everybody speaks English. At the Latin American program of the University of Miami School of Business Administration more than a thousand miles to the east, everyone speaks Spanish.
 It might seem that the mostly Latin American natives at the two schools have things backward, but they would argue that they are looking forward -- into the free-trade future. As Latin America struggles to overcome its protectionist past and join the global economy, its business leaders realize the next generation of executives needs a crash course in American management to have a chance of closing the gap with the United States. And that is what the students here say they are getting. 
 They come from varied backgrounds and have their own business goals. But whatever language they use in the classroom, they know they have to master American business concepts if they are going to help their countries cope with tumbling trade barriers. With President Bush promising to lobby at the Summit of the Americas in Quebec in April for his goal of a common market for the entire hemisphere by 2005, the challenge has become all the more urgent. 
At Duxx, in a suburb of this most business-oriented of Mexican cities, 20 young men and women, nearly all of them Mexican, are learning the latest American techniques and theories of finance, marketing and leadership skills. The master's program is taught in English, which is rapidly solidifying its position as the hemisphere's preferred language of business.
At the same time, around 50 business people from all over Latin America are attending Miami's program, which focuses on American corporate finance and international marketing. Its classes are taught in Spanish.
But the mind-set at both places is international. "I can't imagine working in a company that is not globally focused," said Carlos Garcia Zendejas, 28, who is studying for a master's in business leadership at Duxx. A native of northern Mexico, he said the program's multinational nature and international faculty worked well with his experience at John Deere and other manufacturers.
"Working and studying this way," Mr. Garcia Zendejas said, "has opened up a lot of horizons for me."
For many of these students, the horizon already stretches to a world where crossing borders is hardly more meaningful than crossing highway traffic lines. Eugenio J. Cisneros, 38, was born in Miami of Cuban parents. A few years later, the family moved to Venezuela. There, Mr. Cisneros entered his father's gasoline retailing business, operating one of the busiest truck stops in the country. Mr. Cisneros has taken the family business international by buying six stations in Puerto Rico.
"There are no boundaries anymore," Mr. Cisneros said during a break from his classes at the University of Miami. Like most of the M.B.A. students, he keeps in touch with his business, which usually means that as soon as a break begins, he is on his cell phone calling Puerto Rico or Venezuela. "With globalization," he said, "things get tougher and tougher every day."
Preparing for business in that world is changing, too. "Back in the 1970's and 1980's, you really didn't have to open the catalog at most business schools because the content and format of the courses were the same everywhere," said Larry E. Penley, dean of the Arizona State University College of Business and chairman of the International Association for Management Education, which accredits business schools. Telecommunications and globalization have overhauled the way business is done, he said, which means the schools had to change what they taught and how they taught it.
"What we've seen is a transformation of the whole business curriculum," he said, "and the internationalization of business schools."
Competition among business schools has grown vicious in recent years, especially in the crowded ranks below the top tier of schools. Harold W. Berkman, vice dean of the University of Miami School of Business Administration, said he had been looking for ways to distinguish Miami's business program from that of hundreds of similar schools.
"I was up one morning at 4:30 asking myself what we can do that no one else can do," he said. He knew that Miami had become a financial capital for Latin America, the place where bankers, executives and entrepreneurs from the region congregated to dip their toes into America's capitalist waters.
Professor Berkman imagined a course taught entirely in Spanish that would attract active business leaders who had a basic understanding of English but felt more comfortable in their own language and who were eager to pick up American business secrets.
There is an awareness, Professor Berkman said, of the Free Trade Area of the Americas coming. He was referring to the free-trade bloc championed by President Bush. "But there's also an awareness that Latin America is behind the curve."
The first class, in 1997, was canceled when not enough students enrolled. The university tried again the following year, changing the approach of the advertising slightly to reflect cultural differences among the nations. It took out ads in magazines and newspapers. A recruiter was sent to the region. "There, people don't believe you until they see you," Professor Berkman said.
On the second try, 22 students signed up for a master's program in professional management. Students were required to come to Miami for five intensive two-week periods from fall to the early summer, supplemented by reading and study. After the first two classes graduated, in 1998 and 1999, the university added a Master of Business Administration.
Although classes are conducted in Spanish, all the readings and case studies are in English. Most students speak it, too, but sometimes with gaps, just as their English-speaking professors have gaps in their conversational Spanish.
"No tenemos loyalty," said Anthony Miyazaki, an assistant professor of marketing, as he mixed idioms in addressing the M.B.A. class. His students later said Mr. Miyazaki sometimes needed to switch to English to get across a concept, but they usually knew what he meant. Mr. Miyazaki, who learned Spanish in college, said the students often adopted American lingo in their eagerness to learn.
"We're supposed to use the term porcion de mercado," he said, "but everybody here just prefers to say 'market share.' "
The students at Duxx are younger and less experienced than those in Miami, but just as aware of the multinational demands of contemporary business. "The international aspect of business is crucial, especially here in Monterrey where people are expected to know about international business," said Antonio Garza Torres, 36, of Garza Garcia, the suburb of Monterrey where Duxx is situated.
Duxx was begun in 1993 by Alfonso Romo Garza, scion of one of Monterrey's thoroughbred corporate and political families. He hired Carlo Brumat as dean, a polyglot Italian academician with extensive experience teaching business management in English at Insead, France's leading international business school.
At Duxx, students enroll full time and study one or two courses at a time. Teachers fly in from the United States, Britain and elsewhere for two-week periods. The instruction and all the reading are in English.
Duxx students must pass standardized admissions tests and demonstrate their command of basic English. Inevitably, though, some things get by them.
"What's a life raft?" asked a number of students in the interpersonal relations class taught by William O. Roberts and Karl E. Scheibe. One student responded in Spanish that it was a life preserver, another that it was a wet suit. A third called it a small boat. The word brigand in another class left nearly all the students clueless about its meaning.
But for the most part, English is not a major impediment, and here, at least, the old Mexican distrust of English as an artifact of cultural imperialism is dead. "English is the lingua franca of business," Dr. Brumat said. "Not recognizing that is like shooting yourself in the foot."
Despite President Bush's embrace of free trade, opposition is growing among environmentalists, anti-trade activists and citizens groups worried that too many people are being left behind by globalization. Also, diplomatic and commercial quarrels among the 34 nations that would make up the free-trade area make the 2005 goal a moving target.
That does not stand in the way of those enrolled, however. If the pact happens, said Pamela Camus, 45, country director in Chile for American Airlines and a student in the Miami program, "it may be in many more years to come." Mrs. Camus, who is Chilean, noted that it has taken the United States more than seven years to start negotiations for a free-trade agreement with her country.
Mrs. Camus is certain a hemispheric agreement will help Chile and other Latin American countries, but she is not willing to just sit and wait for it to happen. "Whatever the United States does has an impact on our economy," she said. "I'm preparing myself to handle my company and my dreams in every area and every situation that comes."

HEADLINE: NATO Leader Asks for More Kosovo Troops 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20 

 BODY:
The secretary general of NATO, Lord Robertson, has asked NATO members to send about 1,400 more troops to Kosovo so that the alliance can better cope with the crisis in neighboring Macedonia by stepping up border patrols.
 In his request for more soldiers, Lord Robertson stressed that there were no plans to extend the Kosovo peacekeeping operation into Macedonia itself, diplomats said. 
 But the appeal for reinforcements showed that NATO was stretched thin as it tried to control Kosovo and prevent Kosovo Albanians from moving across the border into Macedonia to join the insurgency.
As President Bush emerged tonight from a tour of the Central Intelligence Agency's headquarters in suburban Virginia where he gave a short speech, he was asked about the possibility of direct United States military assistance to Macedonia. "We'll work with NATO to develop a strategy that will help Macedonia protect herself," Mr. Bush said. 
The Pentagon was not expected to agree to sending more troops to supplement the roughly 5,000 American soldiers in Kosovo, officials said.
A much more likely possibility was for the United States to provide some unmanned reconnaissance aircraft for use over Macedonia, where a small group of ethnic Albanians are fighting the Macedonian Army near the city of Tetovo. 
At a Pentagon briefing today, a spokesman, Rear Adm. Craig R. Quigley, said that the United States had not yet received a formal request for more troops. President Bush, who campaigned last year on drawing down American troops in Kosovo, has tried to keep his administration at a distance from the intensifying fighting in Macedonia.
From the European perspective, Washington appeared to be looking at the Macedonia crisis as "an irritating little problem they hope will go away," one NATO diplomat said. In Europe, there was increasing concern that the Macedonia fighting could descend into the fifth Balkan war since the collapse of Yugoslavia in the early 1990's. 
Officials in several American allies in Europe are said to have increasing concern that NATO would begin to look impotent if Macedonia were allowed to descend into fierce ethnic conflict while more than 35,000 NATO-led soldiers remained next door in Kosovo. 
The Pentagon has made abundantly clear, NATO diplomats said, that it does not want American troops in Kosovo to be involved in missions that go beyond its borders.
At NATO headquarters in Brussels, where Lord Robertson made the request Monday night and where it was further discussed today among NATO ambassadors, there was a understanding that the Europeans would have to meet the new request, diplomats said. So far, only Spain has come forward, pledging about 150 new troops, a NATO official said. 
New troops would allow the commander of the NATO-led forces in Kosovo to fill out a reserve force depleted in recent weeks as troops from it have been posted to active duty, a senior NATO official said.
The NATO forces in Kosovo have come under strain as they try to quell two hot spots -- the ethnically divided city of Mitrovica and the border area near the opening to the Presevo Valley, where Kosovo Albanian guerrillas have been fighting Serbs.
In addition, NATO-led forces have suddenly had to concentrate on the border of Kosovo and Macedonia. Patrols were reinforced starting in late February, but there is now a need for further reinforcements, NATO officials said. 
At the Pentagon briefing, Admiral Quigley said about 150 American troops were moved on to the border in February to halt the flow of fighters and arms into Macedonia. A total of about 300 American soldiers were now patrolling that border, he said.
In Washington today, the discussion of Macedonia focused on supplying money to the Macedonian government and on giving it the mettle to hold back the guerrillas.
Robert Frowick, an experienced American diplomat who knows Macedonia well, will go to the capital, Skopje, as the head of the mission of the Organization of Security and Cooperation in Europe there.
At the State Department, the spokesman, Richard Boucher, said the administration was examining ways it might increase its funding to the Macedonian government, which the ethnic Albanian population criticizes for not sufficient attention to it. About 30 percent of the people of Macedonia are ethnic Albanian; Slavs are in the majority. 
The United States was providing $33 million for economic and civic society programs this year, including an Albanian-language university, Mr. Boucher said. Also, $13.5 million was going to Macedonia in military assistance, a small amount of it for training, he said. 
One immediate concern is the Macedonian military's use of tanks around Tetovo, which is predominantly Albanian. American and NATO officials fear that is heavy-handed and risks alienating the population.

HEADLINE: Text of Statement by the Federal Reserve 

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy panel, decided to lower interest rates 50 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point:
 The Federal Open Market Committee at its meeting today decided to lower its target for the federal funds rate by 50 basis points, to 5 percent. 
In a related action, the board of governors approved a 50- basis-point reduction in the discount rate, to 4 1/2 percent. 
 Persistent pressures on profit margins are restraining investment spending and, through declines in equity wealth, consumption. The associated backup in inventories has induced a rapid response in manufacturing output and, with spending having firmed a bit since last year, inventory adjustment appears to be well under way. 
Although current developments do not appear to have materially diminished the prospects for long-term growth in productivity, excess productive capacity has emerged recently. The possibility that this excess could continue for some time and the potential for weakness in global economic conditions suggest substantial risks that demand and production could remain soft. In these circumstances, when the economic situation could be evolving rapidly, the Federal Reserve will need to monitor developments closely. 
The committee continues to believe that against the background of its long-run goals of price stability and sustainable economic growth and of the information currently available, the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future. 
In taking the discount rate action, the Federal Reserve Board approved requests submitted by the boards of directors of all 12 reserve banks.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Fall Hard as Fed Rate Cut Disappoints Investors

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
After weeks of anticipation, investors were disappointed yesterday after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates less than they had wanted.
 Stocks fell sharply, with technology issues suffering big losses. The afternoon selloff partly reflected the misplaced bets of investors who had hoped the Fed would reduce short-term interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point. Instead, the central bank cut its target for the federal funds rate by a widely anticipated half a point, to 5 percent. 
 The Nasdaq composite index fell 93.74 points, or 4.8 percent, to 1,857.44. The Nasdaq is down 24.8 percent so far this year. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 238.35 points, or 2.4 percent, to 9,720.76. It fell below 10,000 last week as investors' fears spread beyond the technology sector, and it has now declined 9.9 percent this year.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 28.19 points, or 2.4 percent, to 1,142.62. It has declined 13.5 percent this year.
The Fed made its announcement around 2:15 p.m. Eastern time. Until then, the stock market was sluggish, showing modest gains. Immediately afterward, the Nasdaq dropped about seven-tenths of a percent, then jumped back up about 2 percent.
"The indecision is rampant," said Jeffrey D. Saut, chief investment strategist for Raymond James & Associates. "It's up, it's down, it's down, it's up."
After that, though, stocks began a rapid and steady descent. The losses carved deeply into technology stocks, which some investors had hoped would surge, at least temporarily, after the move by the Fed.
"Investors just don't know how they want to be positioned," said Brett Gallagher, a vice president of Julius Baer Investment Management, who manages $400 million in equity holdings for foundations and wealthy individuals. After some hasty adjustments, they seemed struck by a realization that "the next scheduled releases we're going to see are going to be first-quarter earnings and we don't expect those to be brilliant."
Intel fell $2.44, to $24.63; Cisco fell $1.75, to $19.06; and JDS Uniphase fell $3.13, to $21.50. 
Oracle, which said it would cut up to 2 percent of its work force, fell $1.06, to $14.38. Solectron, which said late Monday that it would cut jobs and might miss sales targets, fell $2.40, to $19.09.
Financial stocks also fell sharply, contributing to the drops in the S.& P. 500 and in the Dow. Citigroup dropped $2, to $44.30; J. P. Morgan Chase fell $2.56, to $42.59; and American Express lost $1.49, to $37.27.
The losses in the financial sector, usually a beneficiary of interest rate cuts, partly reflected concerns about debt loads, a global economic slowdown and the banking crisis in Japan. Investors basing their picks on the hope that the rate cut will cause stock prices to rise quickly made their purchases in the energy sector and in the stocks of intrinsically cyclical companies, said Jon Brorson, director of equities for Northern Trust, the money management unit of the Northern Trust Company.
Alcoa rose 35 cents, to $36.28, and International Paper gained $1.10, to $37.36.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices rose yesterday after the Federal Reserve lowered interest rates to 5 percent and signaled another rate cut could come as early as next month -- before the central bank is scheduled to meet on May 15.
"The Fed looks as though it's ready to do another intermeeting move," said Michael Materasso, who oversees $7.5 billion at Fiduciary Trust Company International. "It's going to take longer for the economy to turn around, and the Fed is going to have to keep cutting rates, which is positive for bonds." 
The 10-year Treasury note rose 16/32, to a price of 101 31/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 4.75 percent from 4.81 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 13/32, to 101 22/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.26 percent from 5.29 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD 

BYLINE:  By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS, LYNETTE HOLLOWAY, KAREN W. ARENSON, MICHAEL POLLAK, EDWARD WYATT and ALLISON FASS 

 BODY:
Talmud and Transit
 Jewish high school students have been stranded without free public transportation one to four times a week after they have spent long hours in school studying the Talmud, ASSEMBLYMAN DOV HIKIND is complaining. Mr. Hikind has been lobbying Marc V. Shaw, executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and Lawrence G. Reuter, president of New York City Transit, to extend free student MetroCard hours beyond 8:30 p.m., to accommodate yeshiva students who stay as late as 10 p.m. So far, the transit officials have declined, despite a letter of support from New York's Catholic schools. 

Bank's Bilingual Aid
Fleet Bank has provided $760,000 in grant money to the Board of Education to help pay for the recruitment, selection and training of 125 educators who will work with non-English-speaking children. The grant comes just weeks after the board voted to overhaul its bilingual-education programs.

Moving to Barnard
CAMERAN MASON has become vice president for development and alumnae affairs at Barnard College. Although not a Barnard graduate, she attended a women's college -- Wellesley -- where she studied economics and history and was in Phi Beta Kappa. Before moving to Barnard last month, Ms. Mason worked at Fordham University for 10 years.

Takes Pawn and Draws the Foul
The Ravens of St. Raymond High School for Boys are enjoying a rare double victory this month. On March 10, the Bronx school's chess team beat eight other schools to win the city's Catholic High School Chess League title. And last Wednesday, the basketball Ravens won the city's Catholic High School Class A championships over 11 other teams.
"We've been a basketball power for quite some time, but there's a lot going on at the school," said JOHN C. CUMMINGS, development director. St. Raymond, in the Soundview section, has 800 students. GARY DECESARE coaches the basketball team, and BROTHER JOHN McMANUS coaches the chess team.
By coincidence, Archbishop Molloy High School in Queens lost to St. Raymond in the finals of both events.

Fields, Not Dreams
Take the Field, a public-private partnership created last year to rebuild some of the dilapidated playing fields at New York City public schools, broke ground this week on its third project, at William C. Bryant High School in Queens.
The organization, founded by RICHARD A. KAHAN, the former chief executive of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, PRESTON ROBERT TISCH, the co-chairman of the Loews Corporation, and TONY KISER, president of the William and Mary Greve Foundation, has rebuilt the athletic facilities at George Washington High School in Manhattan, and is nearing completion on a project at Seward Park High School, also in Manhattan. The effort's next stage will include four more projects, at South Bronx, Port Richmond, Far Rockaway and Brooklyn Technical High Schools.

Mount Sinai All the Way
HECTOR VAZQUEZ was born at Mount Sinai Hospital 25 years ago, and in May he will be graduating from the Mount Sinai School of Medicine. What he credits for this circular journey of sorts is a program at the Manhattan Center for Mathematics and Science High School in East Harlem that has helped prepare 300 students for careers in medicine, science and mathematics. Mr. Vazquez is the first participant in the Mount Sinai Scholars program to graduate from medical school. "I feel lucky to have been in the program and if it wasn't for that, I wouldn't be in medical school today," said Mr. Vazquez, who wants to be a pediatrician. "No one in my family is a doctor or a nurse." The program provides after-school science enrichment, entrance exam preparation and summer internships in Mount Sinai labs. HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES; 
Dollar Follows Downward Spiral of Stocks

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar followed battered stocks down, hitting its lowest level in nearly a week against the euro yesterday in the wake of the Federal Reserve's half percentage point cut in interest rates.
 Analysts said many market participants had pinned their hopes on a more aggressive easing and sold off in disappointment -- even though the Fed has cut short-term lending rates by 1.50 percentage points this year. 
 The dollar initially held steady as dealers plumbed the meaning of the Fed's decision. But it ultimately fell.
"It's clear that the stock market had too much of a rate cut priced in, so the knee-jerk is clearly a negative," said Eric Nickerson, chief currency strategist at Bank of America in New York. 
"But the Fed seems to think the adjustment process is under way, so maybe this is a reality check," he said, adding that the dollar's fortunes in the near term would largely hinge on the performance of the American equity markets.

HEADLINE: Even Poor Say Life Improved In Last Decade, Survey Finds 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
Even New Yorkers who did not benefit financially from the city's surging economy in the late 1990's became more satisfied with their neighborhoods, according to a survey to be released today by the Columbia University School of Social Work.
 But there was a surprising number of such people; the random telephone survey of 1,500 people over several months in 1999 found that a stubborn 39 percent of families in the city lived in what the researchers defined as poverty -- 150 percent of the federal poverty level, which works out to $25,000 a year for a family of four. The proportion scarcely changed between 1999 and 1997, the first time Columbia did such a survey. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus 2.5 percentage points. 
 "In their assessments of neighborhoods, there's a shared sense that things are going well," said Marcia K. Meyers, associate director of the university's Social Indicators Survey Center. But, she said, "we see signs of growing inequality."
The survey may add more fuel to the debate among politicians and economists over whether the boom of the 1990's has helped people all over the city, or if the gains have been limited to those who were already wealthy, which was the pattern set in the 1980's. The Census Bureau is not scheduled to release data that may help resolve that question until the end of this year.
The survey found plenty of evidence that city residents profited during the economic boom times of 1997 through 1999. More families had at least one member working full time (48 percent versus 41 percent in 1997), more were making at least $66,640, which is four times the poverty level (34 percent versus 28 percent), and many more had money in the bank or could borrow it easily from friends and family.
But some things have not changed, including the proportion of families who say they are living in housing with major structural, heating or plumbing problems (23 percent), those who have no real assets (28 percent) and those with low incomes.
What is less clear is whether poor people's economic situations have stagnated, or if, as New Yorkers find their economic lives improved, they have been replaced at the bottom by poor immigrants.
An increased number of people in the city were born overseas; 35 percent of the survey respondents were immigrants, versus 30 percent in 1997. But the survey was conducted in English and Spanish only, Ms. Meyers said, so it did not reach many other immigrant groups.
Even if they did not prosper economically, poor residents increasingly rated their neighborhoods as good places to live; the percentage rose to 60 percent, from 54 percent. The attitudes of more affluent people did not change nearly as much, although they are far more satisfied with their neighborhoods.
The drop in crime may go a long way toward explaining this finding. The percentage of poor families that had been victimized by crime fell by about 5 percentage points between 1997 and 1999, to 6 percent -- almost equal to the 5 percent reported by wealthier people (an improvement of 2 points). The percentage of poor families who said their neighborhoods were safe rose to 70 percent, from 65 percent; for wealthier families, the proportion was 89 percent, up from 86 percent.
Despite the drop in crime, poor residents said they were sharply less satisfied with police protection in 1999 than they were in 1997; the proportion of people who called it good or very good plunged by 10 percentage points, to 53 percent. Among wealthier respondents, the level of satisfaction was unchanged at 72 percent.

HEADLINE: Assembly Plan Draws Lines For an Albany Budget Fight 

BYLINE:  By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 20 

 BODY:
State lawmakers outlined the battle lines of their budget wars today, with Assembly Democrats proposing to spend generously on schools and health care and Senate Republicans seeking to spend just as generously on tax cuts. Both houses appear more optimistic than the governor about how much revenue the state will bring in over the next year.
 Released this morning, the Assembly's spending plan would cost $2.29 billion more than Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget of $83.68 billion. Senate Republicans, who released their plan on Monday, are slightly closer to the governor, with a budget package that would cost about $84.1 billion. 
 At a news conference, Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker, maintained that his budget was based on realistic revenue projections. The governor's budget, released in January, projected revenues of nearly $43 billion. The Senate expects the state to bring in about $1.2 billion more, while the Assembly expects $2.1 billion over the governor's projections.
Mr. Silver pointedly reminded reporters that his revenue projections have proved to be more accurate in past years than the governor's, which have been much lower, and more conservative, than actual revenues.
Budget negotiations are usually much harder when the economy is in dire straits and spending cuts are proposed. This year, Republicans and Democrats propose spending more money, but the contest is over prudence; there is little agreement on where the economy is headed. Perhaps even more important, in a nonelection year, there is no rush for legislators to leave Albany, so negotiations could be long and arduous.
"Even in what are pretty good times, both this year and last year, they find things to fight about," said Charles Brecher, research director of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonpartisan city and state government watchdog group. "They're going to manage to fight and stretch this out, despite what many outsiders would say -- that this is a budget year that's pretty conducive to easier compromise. You're fighting about how much more to give people, not how much to cut."
The Senate and Assembly differ sharply over education. The Assembly budget includes an increase of $1.7 billion a year for school aid, while the Senate's includes an increase of $925 million. The governor has said he would pour an additional $382 million into school aid this year.
What the Assembly would seek to spend on increased school aid, the Senate seeks in the form of tax cuts. Earlier this week, Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, proposed $1.8 billion in tax cuts over five years, much of it for companies that do business in areas designated as economic development zones. The Assembly's proposed tax cuts are substantially less: $519 million. The governor's proposed tax cuts are much closer to the Assembly Democrats', about $530 million.
To guard against a souring of the economy, the Senate proposes to tuck away $4 billion in reserves. The Assembly would set aside $2.17 billion. The governor's proposal is far more modest, at about $1.4 billion.
The Assembly budget also provides $470 million toward investment in high technology projects and $327 million in Medicaid funds for nursing homes and home health aides. It increases spending for higher education and seeks to spend $184 million out of the welfare surplus fund to train child care workers.
The Citizens Budget Commission applauded the governor's spending proposal last week as "the most responsible and prudent" budget in 16 years, singling out his proposed reserves and his plan to phase in tax cuts that have already been enacted. It did, however, find his school financing proposal to be inadequate.

HEADLINE: The Fed and the Stock Market 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve cut its key short-term interest rate by half a percentage point yesterday for the third time this year, hopeful that lower borrowing costs will help avert a recession by encouraging businesses to invest more and consumers to spend more. Wall Street was disappointed that the Fed did not cut the rate more aggressively, and traders unloaded stocks late in the day, driving the market averages down. The Fed's refusal to cut rates further was widely interpreted as a reluctance to use its monetary powers to prop up faltering stock prices. But the central bank also sent a signal that it was willing to step in with further rate cuts soon, if needed, and that it was cognizant of the emerging interdependence between moves in stock prices and the "real" economy. 
 The Fed lowered the federal funds rate, which financial institutions charge each other for overnight deposits, from 5.5. to 5 percent. Recent reports showing persistent strength in the labor market, real estate and some retail sectors of the economy may have dissuaded the Fed from cutting the rate three-quarters of a point simply to please Wall Street. But in its statement explaining the move, the Fed made clear that it may not wait until its next Open Market Committee meeting in May to cut rates again. Its statement that "when the economic situation could be evolving rapidly, the Federal Reserve will need to monitor developments closely" provides reassurance that the Fed will remain vigilant. Indeed, some analysts believe that the federal funds rate could be cut as low as 4 percent by the summer. 
 The Fed's action may have disappointed Wall Street, but it illustrated once again how much faster the Fed can bring its monetary policy to bear than Congress and the Bush administration can fashion a tax-cut stimulus. It will take some months for the impact of the latest rate cut to be measured. But by the time Congress gets around to passing a tax cut and that cut is put into effect, the Fed will have had several more shots at stimulating the economy through rate cuts. Yesterday President Bush called once again for Congressional passage of a tax-cut stimulus, but unless his proposal is drastically reshaped to take effect quickly and put money into the hands of low- and middle-income consumers, it will provide very little stimulus at all.
Although the Fed usually resists the impression that it acts in response to the stock market, it acknowledged in its statement yesterday that declines in "equity wealth" had restrained consumption. With more than half of all Americans now invested in stocks, in other words, it is no longer possible to argue that the Nasdaq's dramatic 60 percent plunge over the past year does not have a spillover effect on the real economy. Conversely, when markets were soaring, consumers spent more than they earned, buoyed by the rising value of their assets. Just how the Fed will incorporate such factors into its policy making remains uncertain.
The Fed suggested yesterday that it is still not clear whether the 10-year-old expansion, the longest ever, is about to come to an end. It cited global economic weakness and the slowdown in manufacturing caused by excess inventories held by businesses as particularly worrisome. The country may yet avoid a recession, and is unlikely to face prolonged and paralyzing deflation on the Japanese model, but we are clearly going through what could best be described as a bitter financial hangover. Consumers stopped saving during the boom of recent years and are deeply indebted, and the availability of easy money on Wall Street led corporations -- especially technology firms -- to invest in excess capacity, driven by a "build it and they will come" mentality. The Fed has been moving aggressively to stimulate spending, but more aggressive moves may yet be required.

HEADLINE: Facing a Deficit, Suffolk's Chief Urges an Increase in the Sales Tax 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, N.Y., March 20 

 BODY:
Facing a year-end budget deficit of $35 million caused by lower-than-expected sales tax revenues for the last quarter of 2000, the Suffolk County executive today called for the county to raise its sales tax by a quarter of a percentage point. 
 The increase, which would require approval from the county and state Legislatures, would reverse a 1995 sales tax cut of the same size and bring the combined state and county sales tax back to 8.5 percent in Suffolk, the same as in Nassau County and the highest in the state. 
 In an annual address to the Suffolk Legislature, County Executive Robert J. Gaffney said that unless the county acted soon to control costs and find new revenue, the deficit could hit $140 million by the end of 2002. "Adjusting our sales tax rate is the only realistic option available to raise revenues to help bridge the budget gap over the short term," he said. Mr. Gaffney also announced a hiring freeze and asked for changes in the county charter that would allow it to set aside up to two-thirds of budget surpluses in good years to protect against property tax increases during economic slowdowns. 
Current county law requires that budget surpluses be used to reduce property taxes. Mr. Gaffney said that more than $300 million in surpluses resulting from sales tax revenues had reduced general fund property taxes by 70 percent over the last eight years, to $49 million from $161 million. Those taxes are about 1 percent of the property taxes on an average resident's bill. Most of the property taxes residents pay go toward schools, sewer districts, towns and villages.
Mr. Gaffney said the county's heavy reliance on the sales tax, a less stable source of revenue than the property tax, made the county vulnerable when the economy slowed and sales tax revenues fell. While saying that the county had cut property taxes "maybe too much," Mr. Gaffney made no mention of raising that tax. He also said a sales tax exemption for clothing costing less than $110 should continue. 
The county collected $761.7 million in sales tax revenues last year, or almost $28 million less than the $789.6 million in revenues Mr. Gaffney's office had projected. Those revenues pay for more than half of general fund expenses, and pay a smaller part of expenses for the police district, which covers the county's five western towns. The county share of the current 8.25 percent sales tax is 4 percent.
