HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Stock Investors Fighting the Fed In Second Round

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
For the second time in two years, Wall Street is ignoring its own advice.
 One of the stock market's oldest maxims is that investors should buy stocks aggressively when the Federal Reserve is lowering short-term interest rates and be much more careful when rates are rising. The logic is simple: falling interest rates put more money in consumers' pockets and lower corporate borrowing costs, helping corporate profits. Rising rates force consumers and companies to spend more money on interest payments, hurting the economy and corporate earnings. 
 In other words, don't fight the Fed.
But in late 1999 and early 2000, that is exactly what investors did, bidding technology stocks to extraordinarily expensive levels even as the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates six times to slow the economy and the stock market.
By the end of 2000, that arrogance had proved remarkably foolish, as the Fed's rate increases succeeded in slowing economic growth and cutting corporate spending on capital equipment. Information technology companies, which some analysts had predicted would be immune to slowing economic growth, turned out to be especially hard hit by the rate jumps.
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index has now fallen more than 63 percent from its highs a year ago, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has plunged more than 25 percent since last March.
Now, with investors $4 trillion poorer and economic growth slowing sharply, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, is cutting short-term interest rates to get the economy moving again. Yesterday, he reduced rates for the third time in three months, setting short-term rates at 5 percent. Since early January, Mr. Greenspan has lowered rates by 1.5 percentage points, the fastest he has ever cut rates.
Yet the same investors who insisted that the Fed's rate increases would never slow the economy last year are again fighting the Fed, this time by selling stocks as Mr. Greenspan cuts rates.
Stocks plunged yesterday after the Federal Reserve announced its rate cut, mainly because investors hoped Mr. Greenspan would reduce rates even more than he did. The Nasdaq skidded 4.8 percent yesterday, while the S.& P. 500 and Dow Jones industrial average each dropped 2.4 percent.
Mr. Greenspan, who could do no wrong in Wall Street's eyes for the first 13 years of his tenure, is now viewed as out of touch with the economy and the market by some investors who think he should cut rates even faster.
Christopher Wolfe, equity strategist for J. P. Morgan Chase's private bank, which manages $330 billion, said Mr. Greenspan should have cut interest rates more steeply to prop up corporate earnings, which are likely to be dismal for the first quarter.
"We needed 75 basis points," Mr. Wolfe said. (One basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point, so 75 basis points is three-quarters of a percentage point.)
William Rutherford of Rutherford Investment Management in Portland, Ore., which manages less than $100 million, complained that "Greenspan is looking at historical data." He continued: "He's not looking forward into the future, whereas investors look forward. Consumer confidence, business confidence has been shattered, and he's not taking that into account."
But despite Wall Street's cries, the economy is hardly in free fall.
The unemployment rate remains at just 4.2 percent, near its lowest levels in 30 years, and many indicators of economic growth remain strong. Consumer borrowing continues to rise, and sales of existing homes rose more than 6 percent in January.
To be sure, the information technology sector has been extremely weak since the fall. Big technology companies like Nortel Networks and Dell Computer have laid off workers and told investors to expect lower earnings for much of this year. Smaller Internet companies are shutting down in droves.
But many companies outside the technology sector appear to be weathering the storm quite nicely. Analysts expect Wal-Mart Stores, the nation's largest employer, to post sales of almost $220 billion and profits of almost $7 billion this year, compared with sales of about $190 billion and profits of $6 billion in 2000. Profits at Citigroup, the nation's largest financial services company, are predicted to rise better than 10 percent this year.
"The economy is not doing badly," said David Wyss, chief economist at Standard & Poor's. "Employment growth for the first two months looks pretty strong, consumer confidence may be bottoming out. The only thing that looks bad is the stock market."
Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said he was concerned that high energy costs and the weak euro are hurting the United States economy, especially manufacturing, and he would like to see the Fed eventually cut another half of a point from short-term rates. But Wall Street's reaction to yesterday's rate cut puzzled him.
"I think it was fine; I never got into the hype of 0.75," Mr. Jasinowski said. "I think some of the traders have just gotten anxious for immediate gratification because the market's down so low that there's nothing else they can think of."
Rod Smyth, chief investment strategist at First Union Securities, said he expected the Dow to gain more than 20 percent over the next year and be at 12,000 by March 2002.
"The market has no patience, because people are very psychologically damaged as a result of what's going on," Mr. Smyth said. "It has no patience because people are on margin. But with 100 years of experience of interest rates, the one thing you know is they take time."

 INTERNATIONAL A3-10

Macedonia Ultimatum To Ethnic Albanian Rebels
The government ordered ethnic Albanian rebels occupying the hills above Tetovo to surrender or withdraw within 24 hours or it would move to wipe them out. A guerrilla commander reached by Reuters said the rebels would ignore the deadline. The ultimatum came hours after Macedonian forces launched an offensive. A10

Bush and Sharon Meet
President Bush and Prime Minister Ariel Sharon met in Washington, the first such meeting since they took their offices. They focused as much on the Israel-United States security relationship as on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and expressed desire not to push the possibility of peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians while violence continued. HEADLINE: METRO BRIEFING 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
 NEW YORK

QUEENS: MASSACRE SITE TO BE MALL
The owners of a former Wendy's restaurant in Flushing where five workers were killed during a robbery last May have decided to convert the building into a minimall. Glenn Lau-Kee, a lawyer for the owners, said yesterday that the building, at 40-12 Main Street, was rented two weeks ago to a group that intends to divide it into small stalls for vendors. He said the minimall was expected to open in late spring. Mr. Lau-Kee said the owners, who bought the building last month, included a provision in the lease prohibiting cooking on the property, as has been requested by relatives of the slain workers. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

ALBANY: CHANCELLOR RE-ELECTED
The state Board of Regents re-elected Carl T. Hayden, left, to a third three-year term as chancellor yesterday. Mr. Hayden, a member of the board since 1990, was first elected chancellor in 1995. He has since joined with the state education commissioner to institute stricter testing standards for schoolchildren. Mr. Hayden was unopposed for another term. Adelaide L. Sanford, a board member and a former New York City teacher, was designated vice chancellor. (AP)

ALBANY: WAGE BILL ADVANCES
The state's minimum wage will rise to $6.75 an hour from $5.15 if a proposal approved by the Assembly on Monday is approved by the State Senate and signed by Gov. George E. Pataki. Assemblyman Eric N. Vitaliano, a Democrat from Staten Island who supported the bill, said that if the minimum wage had kept pace with the inflation since the early 1960's, it would now be close to $7.30. Hope Reeves (NYT)

PLAINVIEW: STUDENT ARRESTED IN BOMB THREAT
A 13-year-old boy was arrested yesterday at his home here after he posted a threat on his Web site to blow up his school, the Nassau police said. The boy, a student at John F. Kennedy Middle School in Bethpage whose name was not released, was charged with menacing. He was suspended from the school last month after he posted the names and photographs of 36 students whom he threatened to assault, according to The Associated Press. The threat posted on Friday warned that everyone in school, including him, would be killed when a bomb went off on May 16, the A.P. reported. Andy Newman (NYT)

SYRACUSE: U.S. ATTORNEY TO RESIGN
United States Attorney Daniel French announced yesterday that he would resign his post in the Northern District of New York, effective at the end of May. Mr. French's announcement came just days after the Bush administration asked for his resignation. Mr. French indicated in a letter to the president that he might ask to stay on the job for a few extra weeks if several complicated cases, involving charges of corruption in the Schenectady Police Department, had not been resolved. (AP)

MANHATTAN: DISPUTE LEADS TO SHOOTING
One girl was shot in the leg and another pushed into a moving city bus yesterday afternoon during a dispute between two groups on the corner of 65th Street and Broadway, the police said. Neither of the injured girls was identified. One, 14, suffered minor injuries after being pushed into the bus and was taken to St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, where she was in stable condition last night. The girl who was shot in the leg, a 15-year-old, was in stable condition last night at Union Hospital of the Bronx, the police said. The police arrested a suspect in the shooting, a 22-year-old man, at 79th Street and Fifth Avenue. Charges were pending last night, Officer Gary Cillo said. Susan Saulny (NYT)

ALBANY: PATAKI PROPOSES PAROLE BAN
Gov. George E. Pataki renewed his proposal yesterday to end parole for nonviolent felons, a plan rejected for the last two years by the Assembly's Democratic majority. Under Mr. Pataki's plan, nonviolent felons would be required to serve at least six-sevenths of their sentences before being released. Under the sentencing now used for nonviolent felons, an inmate often becomes eligible for parole after serving a third of the maximum sentence imposed. (AP)

STATEN ISLAND: UNION GETS NEW CONTRACT
The union representing 600 Metropolitan Transportation Authority bridge and tunnel workers has reached a tentative settlement that provides for a 15.75 percent raise over the contract's 64 months. The union, the Bridge and Tunnel Officers Benevolent Association, represents workers at the Brooklyn-Battery and Queens-Midtown Tunnels and most of the city's toll bridges, including the Throgs Neck, Whitestone, Triborough and Verrazano-Narrows. The agreement, retroactive to Oct. 1, 1997, runs through Feb. 14, 2003, and provides most workers with more than $6,000 in retroactive pay. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

MANHATTAN: MAN CHARGED IN CELLMATE'S DEATH
The police yesterday charged an emotionally disturbed man in the stomping death of his cellmate at Rikers Island. The man, Derrick Smart, 19, of East 229th Street in the Bronx, had been arrested on charges of bludgeoning his grandmother to death. He was placed in a cell with Robert Konopka, 45, of Staten Island, who was being held on charges of violating a court order to stay away from a neighbor. Mr. Konopka's death on Jan. 9 prompted a review of the city's policy of placing inmates with histories of psychiatric problems in cells with other inmates. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

NEW JERSEY

NEWARK: NATURAL GAS CONTRACTS
The state ratepayer advocate wants to stop Public Service Electric and Gas from transferring its contracts with natural gas suppliers to an unregulated affiliate because, she said, the utility is trying to circumvent state scrutiny of its rates. The advocate, Blossom A. Peretz, has asked a court to block the transfer. John Scarlata, the utility's general manager for gas supply operations, said the company wants more flexibility in negotiating contracts. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

CONNECTICUT

NEW HAVEN: NEW LEADER AT YALE DIVINITY
The Yale Divinity School yesterday announced the appointment of Rebecca S. Chopp, an ordained Methodist minister, as dean. She will be the first woman to hold that post. A provost and executive vice president for academic affairs at Emory University in Atlanta, she will start at Yale's graduate Divinity School on July 1. She earned a Ph.D. from the University of Chicago's Divinity School and taught at the University of Chicago before moving to Emory in 1986. At Yale, she succeeds Richard Wood, who left in December to become president of the United Fund for Christian Education in Asia. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

HEADLINE: 2 Quandaries Facing Bush 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20 

 BODY:
Hardly a day goes by at the White House without President Bush warning of the two urgent national afflictions that have defined his first two months in office: a "sputtering" economy whose growth has "stalled" and an "energy crisis" that threatens to spread beyond California.
 Mr. Bush is pushing prescriptions for both: what he calls a $1.6 trillion tax cut plan that he argues goes hand-in-hand with the interest rate cuts that the Federal Reserve continued today, and a long-term energy policy due out in the next month or two. 
 But Mr. Bush is facing critics on the left and the right who say that his proposals reflect long-range policy goals that he is trying to sell by claiming they will address short-term problems, and politically, his strategy already appears vulnerable. 
A few of Mr. Bush's advisers acknowledge the inconsistency. And they say that, ever so gradually, the White House is now exploring its options in the face of an apparent disconnect between the immediate challenges the President is citing and the longer-run solutions he is offering.
The behind-the-scenes maneuvering over Mr. Bush's tax proposals are the clearest evidence of the problem. Under the proposal he sent to Congress just a few weeks ago, there was no tax cut for the current year at all, a fact that seemed to undercut the president's repeated claim that the combination of the Fed's rate cuts and his own tax plan would pull the country out of what appears to be a cyclical downturn.
Even the cut passed by the House earlier this month -- and heartily endorsed by the White House -- provides only $5.6 billion in tax relief this year. In a $10 trillion economy, that is, in the words of Robert Litan, an economist at the Brookings Institution, "something so tiny that you won't even notice it." 
On that point, Democrats and Republicans seem to agree. But each side is using that fact to bolster the case for substantial change in Mr. Bush's plan.
The Democrats -- led by the Senate minority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, who has emerged as his party's most effective voice on the issue -- wrote Mr. Bush a letter on Monday offering to put a tax cut bill on his desk by May 1. Mr. Daschle's plan would be a far more limited version of Mr. Bush's, cutting taxes for those in the bottom tax bracket by more than Mr. Bush would, but providing no relief for wealthier taxpayers.
Other Democrats have chimed in with similar proposals, noting that the taxpayers with the lowest incomes are far more likely to spend their rebates and provide an immediate stimulus for the economy. What the Democratic proposals all leave out, of course, are tax cuts for wealthier taxpayers.
"We're open to discussing all of it," Dan Bartlett, a deputy assistant to the president, said today. "We're willing to change the president's plan to get it in the hands of taxpayers quicker."
Mr. Bush himself has yet to endorse a specific proposal, and finds himself, one White House aide noted, a bit trapped between those on his left who would use a quick cut to undermine a far bigger one, and those Republicans who are determined to use the moment to pass a tax cut far larger than Mr. Bush's $1.6 trillion package.
And even while Mr. Bush contends with Senator Daschle on the left, he and his aides find themselves quietly trying to contain the enthusiasm of people like Representative Patrick J. Toomey, Republican of Pennsylvania. Mr. Toomey marshals the same facts that Mr. Bush does -- a slowing economy accompanied by record tax collections by the Treasury (though the effects of the downturn, economists say, may not show up at the Treasury for months to come). 
But Mr. Toomey and others committed to shrinking the size of government see the downturn as an opportunity to pack far more tax reductions into the current year, including increasing the contributions that taxpayers can make to Individual Retirement Accounts and 401(k) programs at work, repealing Social Security tax increases that were passed in the first year of the Clinton administration, and cutting capital gains taxes by 25 percent.
Aren't these merely gifts to the rich? "It's hard to cut taxes for people who don't pay taxes," Mr. Toomey responded at a forum at the Heritage Foundation last week, "although Democrats are determined to find a way."
For now, Mr. Bush continues to insist that he has come up with "the right number," and that he has no plans to expand his package. 
Unfortunately for Mr. Bush, it is proving a lot harder to move barrels of oil than to shift the terms of the tax debate.
When Vice President Dick Cheney submits his long-term energy plan in a month or so, few doubt it will be full of plans for more oil drilling, from the Alaskan wilderness to the West Coast. Almost daily, the White House is using the blackouts in California to build support for what it calls a "long-term energy plan," and while Mr. Bush has been careful not to criticize his predecessor by name, Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham shows no such compunctions.
In a speech at the United States Chamber of Commerce on Monday, Mr. Abraham said Mr. Clinton's energy policy amounted to taxing the use of energy and neglecting to create more supply.
"Our last recessions were all tied to energy crises," Mr. Abraham said, suggesting that if the energy shortfalls worsened, the United States' economic downturn could become deeper and more prolonged.
He argues that the United States will have to build at least 65 power plants a year, construct new pipelines and transmission lines across the country and promote the use of coal -- one of the reasons, he said, that Mr. Bush had to back off a campaign promise to regulate the emission of carbon dioxide from power plants. 
But Californians will find little in Mr. Abraham's plans to end the kind of blackouts they were experiencing as he spoke. 
"Is this an 'energy crisis?' " asked Daniel Yergin, who heads Cambridge Energy Associates and has chronicled the ebbs and flows of the energy markets. "We came perilously close to a natural gas crisis this winter, and unless there is a cool economy and a cool summer in New York, we will have similar electricity issues there."
Mr. Yergin traces the immediate problem to 1997 and 1998, when an economic downturn in Asia dampened demand and softened prices, discouraging the industry from drilling for oil or building refineries. Now those economies are back, and world oil production is at a bit more than 81 million barrels a day, well short of what it would have been if the investment levels had stayed up.
Mr. Bush was in the oil business and understands this well. "One thing is for certain," he said Monday. "There are no short-term fixes." 
He said he wanted to loosen regulatory hurdles -- often a euphemism for environmental restrictions -- and reach a deal with Mexico to allow American companies to explore for natural gas. 
He might have mentioned getting OPEC to pump more, a diplomatic failure for which he criticized the Clinton administration during the campaign, but has said little about it since OPEC became his own problem. All this, of course, takes time. 
And that is what worries Mr. Bush's aides, who know it is only a matter of time before Mr. Clinton's days are forgotten, and Mr. Bush will begin to take the heat for the immediate problems.

HEADLINE: FED LOWERS RATES BY 0.5% AND HINTS OF FURTHER CUTS 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve cut interest rates a half percentage point today, continuing its effort to resuscitate the faltering economy but disappointing investors who hoped for more.
 In explaining its decision, the Fed said it saw "substantial risks" that the economy could remain weak for an extended period, cited strains on businesses and consumers alike and noted that the international economic outlook was worsening. 
 It also made clear that it remained open to further rate cuts before its next scheduled meeting on May 15 if signs of economic deterioration continued.
But by holding its rate reduction today to half a percentage point rather than the three-quarters of a point many on Wall Street had been seeking, the central bank seemed to signal that it would not dispense rate reductions simply as first aid for investors wounded by tumbling stock prices. Page C1. 
Investors, who in less stressful times might have seen a half-point rate cut as a powerful antidote to what ails them, took the news hard, sending financial markets down sharply. After gyrating in the minutes immediately after the Fed's announcement at 2:15 p.m., stocks tumbled, with both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq composite index finishing the day well below recent lows.
The Dow closed at 9,720.76, down 238.35 points, or 2.4 percent. The Nasdaq lost 93.74 points, or 4.8 percent, to finish at 1,857.44.
The Fed's move came against a backdrop of not just the bear market, but also worries about mounting financial problems in Japan and increasing uncertainty about whether the decade-long expansion in the United States was coming to an end.
The Fed's move was intended to put downward pressure on the interest rates paid by businesses and consumers, giving the economy a boost by stimulating more borrowing and spending. 
Most big banks immediately reduced their prime lending rates for business customers to 8 percent from 8.5 percent. But mortgage rates have been falling for some time in the expectation of action by the Fed, and it is unclear whether they will decline further. 
The sharp cut reflected the belief of Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, that in a fast-changing economy he no longer has the luxury of adjusting interest rates in small quarter-point steps over a long period, the approach he took through most of this business cycle.
It was the third half-point reduction in the central bank's benchmark federal funds target rate on overnight loans between banks since the beginning of the year, making this the most concentrated dose of rate reductions since Mr. Greenspan took office in 1987.
It left the federal funds rate at 5 percent, where it last stood in the summer of 1999, when the Fed was beginning to raise rates to cool off what it then judged to be an overheating economy.
The Fed also reduced its less frequently used discount rate on loans to banks from the Federal Reserve system to 4.5 percent from 5 percent.
The White House spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said President Bush would have no comment on the Fed's action. He said the administration was concerned about the economy at home and in Japan and reiterated the White House's assertion that the president's proposed tax cut would help the economy bounce back.
In its statement explaining its decision, the Fed cited threats to the economy from declining corporate profits, cutbacks in capital spending by companies and the likelihood that consumers would spend less because of the steep drops in stock prices. 
Still, the central bank suggested that in some ways the worst may already be past. It said in particular that companies had gone a long way toward reducing their inventories of unsold goods and unneeded supplies, a necessary step before companies increase production again.
But it noted that companies could continue to be plagued by overcapacity for some time -- especially with Japan's economy in deep trouble and other big industrial nations slowing, too.
And it suggested that it was increasingly open to the argument that the economy's difficulties could stem largely from a boom-bust cycle in capital spending and investment by companies -- a problem that can take considerable time to put right -- rather than a simple imbalance between supply and demand.
Using language that was easily decipherable code for a willingness to cut rates again soon, perhaps before its next meeting, the Fed said that under "these circumstances, when the economic situation could be evolving rapidly, the Federal Reserve will need to monitor developments closely."
The message that the Fed sees a clear path for further rate cuts was underlined by the absence of any reference to inflation, high energy prices or low unemployment -- all concerns that gave the Fed pause about easing monetary policy through the end of last year and even into this year.
"Persistent pressures on profit margins are restraining investment spending and, through declines in equity wealth, consumption," the Fed's statement said. "The associated backup in inventories has induced a rapid response in manufacturing output and, with spending having firmed a bit since last year, inventory adjustment appears to be well under way."
Still, it went on, the possibility that companies could suffer for "some time" from excess capacity and the "potential for weakness in global economic conditions suggest substantial risks that demand and production could remain soft."
Although it has been clear almost since the last policy meeting on Jan. 31 that the central bank would cut rates again today, the meeting was clearly among the most pivotal in the Fed's recent history, with the expansion at risk and the stock market in full-scale retreat.
At stake is not only the continuance of the long period of prosperity and the health of Wall Street, but Mr. Greenspan's own reputation as the master of the economy and the role of the United States as the world's most reliable engine of growth.
Some economists said Mr. Greenspan was partly responsible for the economy's condition now because he pushed rates up through last spring in what he characterized then as a pre-emptive strike against inflationary forces -- and what some analysts said at the time was a determined effort to prick a stock market bubble.
Today's decision left some analysts concerned that Mr. Greenspan had failed to appreciate how weak the economy had become. 
David Orr, chief economist at First Union, said "softness in business activity warranted a larger cut, in order to move monetary policy into a more stimulative mode." 
Robert V. DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Smith Barney, said "the Fed's actions thus far do not appear to be promoting financial conditions conducive to solid growth."
The central bank's statement today, he said, "appeared to be written by a committee that lacked consensus or conviction or both."
But other economists said the Fed's choice today was the right one, given that the economy may not be nearly as weak as the plunge in stock prices would suggest. 
They said crucial sectors of the economy like consumer spending and housing had held up reasonably well, that the economy had continued to create new jobs and that industry could bounce back quickly after reducing inventories.
In any case, they said, the Fed could hardly be accused of moving timidly to address the situation now. In 1990 and 1991, the last time the economy was in recession, it took six months for the Fed to cut the federal funds rate 1.5 percentage points. It has made the same reduction this year in less than three months.
Moreover, these analysts said, Mr. Greenspan was right to draw a line at tailoring monetary policy to fit Wall Street's needs, despite the critical role that stock market wealth plays in influencing spending and consumer confidence.
"The Fed wisely did not lower the funds rate more to meet the short-run desires of financial market participants," said Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at Bank of America. "Having done so would have risked the Fed's long-term credibility."
Mr. Levy said the Fed was wrestling with problems that were always tricky for central banks to address: an adverse shock from rising energy prices, combined with a sharp decline in the financial markets, which makes it more expensive for companies to raise capital to expand their business or make it more efficient.
"They're adjusting policy in a very difficult, uncertain environment," Mr. Levy said, "and they're trying to do the right thing as far as balancing their long-run objectives versus the market's short-term needs."

A front-page chart yesterday showing the effect of recent interest rate cuts on consumers misstated the average monthly payments on a $250,000 30-year fixed-rate mortgage, using the figures for a $125,000 loan instead. Last summer, when the rate was 8.5 percent, the payment was $1,922 a month, not $961. The payment now, with a rate of 7.02 percent, is $1,667, not $833.

HEADLINE: Our Towns; 
The Market Is Just Sound, Not Fury, Here

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW PURDY 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY 

 BODY:
SUFFICE it to say that unlike the stock markets, the passengers on the dollar-a-ride commuter van creeping along John F. Kennedy Boulevard in Hudson County yesterday morning were not hanging on Alan Greenspan's every word.
 "Sometimes I check how the stocks are doing, how Nasdaq's doing," said Francisco Silva, 29, referring to them as if they were celebrities. But it's really more out of curiosity than concern. Mr. Silva is not an investor. He's a butcher. And while he's read about the anxiety roiling the financial world, he's counting on a simple notion to get his family of five through an economic storm. "People never stop eating," he said. 
 The financial industry, headquartered in gleaming buildings across the Hudson in Manhattan, jumped the river during the latest boom, giving rise to a ribbon of new office space and housing along the bank in Jersey City and other Hudson County towns. But just a few blocks back from the splendid views of New York, the largely immigrant, working-class neighborhoods are much as they were before the boom, hardly affected by the big business being done nearby.
To passengers on the crowded vans that supplement public transportation on Hudson County's choked streets, the nervous market is background noise. But like last month's blizzard hoopla, the drumbeat of dire forecasts from the financial neighborhood nearby -- and the darkening clouds -- are getting difficult to ignore for those who fear real, not paper, losses.
"I don't have enough money to play with the stock market," said Maritza Rivera, who lives in West New York and was taking a van to her job as an office cleaner in Manhattan. But she knows she's not immune. "I've heard on the news that big corporations are going to have layoffs," she said. "It's a concern for everyone."
Particularly if you've seen the ax fall. Edwin Colon, a 21-year-old steamfitter's apprentice, was waiting for a van to take him home to Weehawken on Monday evening. He was holding a newspaper with the big headline "How Low Will He Go?" previewing Mr. Greenspan's interest-rate cut yesterday. He didn't comment on the headline, but the situation at his mechanical company had his attention.
"On Friday they laid off three laborers," Mr. Colon said. "Last week they laid off four fitters. I just try to work harder so the boss knows I shouldn't be laid off."
On the dashboard of one of the vans on Kennedy Boulevard yesterday, a sticker read, "The Road to Success Is Always Under Construction."
Not a bad motto for Ted Cruz. He was working in the shipping and receiving department of a toy company in Jersey City until last year. He noticed they were shipping fewer toys. Then several months ago, he said, the company started letting people go, himself included. "It started in the office and ended up in the warehouse," said Mr. Cruz, 35, who recently began working as a security guard.
While good times may be particularly good for the well-off, when things turn bad "it hurts everyone, one way or another," Mr. Cruz said.
SOME of the vans travel through more well-to-do neighborhoods, picking up commuters to New York, some of whom have a closer view of the prevailing unease. 
"I get to see a lot more stress than I care to," said Recee McCullough, a Weehawken resident who works as an office administrator for a small hedge fund in Manhattan. As for herself, "I just started investing, so I don't have a lot to lose."
Almost everyone has a personal barometer for the economy.
Lamont Farrich, the manager of a Chinese restaurant in Midtown Manhattan, said, "Business has been off 40 percent" in the past few months. The dinner and tourist trade has not been bad, he said, but the number of lunch customers has fallen to around 110 from about 160. "And when people come in," Mr. Farrich said, "they usually sit at the bar and watch the stock market."
But not everyone's barometer is falling. 
The woman sitting next to Mr. Farrich announced blithely, "My business is booming." Asked what she did for a living, her answer was a reminder that whatever the shape of the economy, some things will always pay. In her case, it was crime. "I do DNA analysis for a crime lab," she said, exiting the van, a bounce in her step.

HEADLINE: E.P.A. TO ABANDON NEW ARSENIC LIMITS FOR WATER SUPPLY 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20 

 BODY:
The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it intended to withdraw a new drinking-water regulation approved by the Clinton administration, saying it did not believe that the decision was supported by the best available science.
 The rule, which would have reduced by 80 percent the permissible standard for arsenic in drinking water, had been a priority of environmental groups for more than a decade. It had been vigorously opposed by the mining industry and by some municipalities on grounds that the cost of compliance could reach into the hundreds of millions of dollars. 
 The decision, announced by Christie Whitman, the E.P.A. administrator, leaves in place, at least for now, an arsenic standard established in 1942. It is the Bush administration's most significant departure from the environmental policies of the Clinton administration. 
The withdrawal came just days before the new rules, approved in President Bill Clinton's last week in office, were to become final.
The agency's decision turns on the question of whether there is sufficient evidence to determine the level at which arsenic poses an unacceptable risk to human health when it is in drinking water. Arsenic, a naturally occurring substance, is also a known carcinogen.
A 1999 study by the National Academy of Sciences concluded that the current arsenic standard of 50 parts per billion "could easily" result in a 1-in-100 risk of cancer. The report went on to recommend that the acceptable levels be revised downward "as promptly as possible." The 10 parts per billion standard approved by the Clinton administration is identical to the one adopted several years ago by the European Union and the World Health Organization.
A former E.P.A. official who helped draft the Clinton policy used strong words in condemning today's action.
"I'm stunned," said the ex-official, Chuck Fox, who until January was the agency's assistant administrator for water. "This action will jeopardize the health of millions of Americans, and it compromises literally a decade's worth of work on behalf of developing a public health standard."
The action was the second victory in a week for the mining industry, which was a big contributor to President Bush and the Republican party and which had sued to block the Clinton rules. Last week, coal producers embraced the administration's decision not to regulate carbon dioxide emissions from power plants.
John Grasser, a spokesman for the National Mining Association, called the administration's decision to withdraw the drinking-water rule a source of significant relief. 
"The Clinton administration rushed this out in the midnight hour," Mr. Grasser said. "We felt all along that it was really a political decision unsupported by the science."
Advocates for the mining and chemical industries, along with some people representing cities that would have been affected by the new rule, argued that the new standards were arbitrary and would have exacted a huge financial cost. 
Ms. Whitman cited that argument in explaining today's decision.
"It is clear that arsenic, while naturally occurring, is something that needs to be regulated," Ms. Whitman said in a written statement today. 
But, she continued, "certainly, the standard should be less than 50 p.p.b., but the scientific indicators are unclear as to whether the standard needs to go as low as 10 p.p.b." 
Earlier, in announcing the decision in a speech to the Association of Metropolitan Water Agencies, Ms. Whitman pledged, "When we make a decision on arsenic, it will be based on sound science and solid analysis."
At least 11 million Americans, most of them in small towns and rural areas but some in cities as large as Albuquerque, rely on drinking water that contains more arsenic than the 10 parts per billion that would have been allowed under the Clinton rules, officials of the environmental agency said.
But they would not be immediately affected by the Bush administration's decision to withdraw the Clinton rules, the officials said, because the new standard would not have begun to take effect for three years.
A senior E.P.A. official said the administration hoped to come up with its own recommendation by sometime this summer.
The rules on arsenic in drinking water fall under the Safe Drinking Water Act, and Congress had set a deadline of June 2001 for the E.P.A. to come up with a new standard.
The Associated Press reported tonight that the administration would seek to suspend another environmental action taken under President Clinton. The change would set aside stricter rules on hardrock mining that required compliance with tightened environmental standards. 
On the arsenic rule, among lawmakers who had been most outspoken in urging the Bush administration to withdraw the Clinton rules was Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, whose state has high naturally occurring arsenic levels.
In a letter to Ms. Whitman earlier this year, Senator Domenici said the rules would impose "an excruciating financial burden" on his state, affecting one in four municipal water systems, imposing a price of compliance of $400 million to $500 million.
Congressional Democrats reacted bitterly today to reversal of the Clinton policy.
"This is another example of a special interest payback to industries that gave millions of dollars in campaign contributions," said Representative Henry A. Waxman, the California Democrat who was the author of the safe drinking water legislation. 
Arsenic is a common byproduct of mining operations, so stricter standards for its content in drinking water would translate into stricter standards for many mining sites.
The wood products industry also supports the administration's ruling because arsenic is used to pressure-treat lumber. The industry's trade association, the American Wood Preservers Institute, which had supported the mining industry in a lawsuit welcomed the news today. 
"We're very relieved and delighted about what we hear," said Mel Pine, the organization's spokesman.

HEADLINE: American Is Guiding A Market For China 

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH

DATELINE: SHANGHAI 

 BODY:
James Liu is an American. That is not surprising until you consider what Mr. Liu does: he helps run the Shanghai Stock Exchange. He is the exchange's executive vice president, working to reshape China's state-dominated equity markets into a capitalist tool.
 It has not been easy. Most recently, he backed proposals to open the country's hard-currency share market to local investors, only to have superiors override his advice that it be done gradually. The sudden opening sent prices rocketing more than 50 percent. 
 Now Mr. Liu is pushing Chinese companies that have listed stocks abroad to come home and help raise the quality of the stocks trading on the Shanghai exchange.
That China's secretive government would allow an American citizen to take such a significant position is evidence of the country's commitment to sweeping changes in its financial system. Dozens of high-powered, foreign-trained professionals like Mr. Liu have been recruited to help steer the country toward globally competitive standards.
In February, for example, Beijing hired a senior Hong Kong stock market regulator to join the China Securities Regulatory Commission. And it consults regularly with Western experts, from foreign stock exchange officials to members of the Federal Reserve Board. 
Mr. Liu's roots are in China, where he was born 40 years ago. He left at 21 and was soon living the American dream, working his way from University of Kansas scholarship student to Wall Street hedge fund manager and becoming rich in the 1990's.
"I worked hard in the U.S., and I was successful -- the U.S. made me a millionaire," Mr. Liu said in an interview in Shanghai. He bought a house in New Jersey and began raising his children there, he said, but he found that he wanted to be close to his aging parents and to give something back to his native land.
A 1998 dinner with China's consul general in New York led to conversations with visiting Chinese officials, and his name and word of his interest in returning to China found their way back to Beijing. The next year, he was approached about working for the stock exchange.
Mr. Liu returned to China in December 1999 and found that the exchange was bloated with low-quality state-controlled companies and was prone to manipulation by government policy makers and securities industry insiders. No one appeared to have a clear idea where the decade-old market was headed. But China was drawing closer to membership in the World Trade Organization, which would expose its financial markets to foreign competition; Mr. Liu could see China was not ready.
"With W.T.O., you want to make a plan for what you're going to do five years from now," he said. "No one seemed worried about that, so that's what I'm trying to do."
As an American in a Chinese bureaucracy, he is in a delicate position. Mr. Liu, like all foreigners, is barred from having any direct say over policy decisions. He operates instead as a sort of consultant, reporting directly to the central government. "My real position is chairman of the exchange's strategic planning commission," he said. 
Mr. Liu has some big ideas. He has pushed successfully for an end to the government's quota system for controlling who can sell shares to the public; phasing it out, probably by the end of 2001, will give private companies much greater access to capital, an important step in making China's still cumbersome state-dominated economy a more limber global competitor. 
He has also pushed, unsuccessfully so far, to allow foreign companies to list shares on China's exchanges, and for regulators to permit short sales, derivatives and other sophisticated trading tools that would increase the markets' liquidity. Without them, he said, the Shanghai exchange will not be competitive with the Hong Kong exchange, where many of China's best companies now prefer to list their shares.
The going is slow because the exchange's administration is just as bureaucratic as the rest of the economy. Its executives advance based on seniority, not achievement, and are much more focused on avoiding mistakes than on taking risks.
In that environment, Mr. Liu has had to amend his own working style. "I've realized that if you push too hard, it's no good," he said.
Remaking the economy in China is an exciting business just the same, he said, though he does not plan to stay forever. "I'm a pioneer," he said. "But I still have my house and two cars waiting for me in New Jersey."

GRAPHIC: Photo: James Liu, a hedge fund manager from New Jersey, now heads the Shanghai exchange's strategic planning. (Ritz Sino/R.S. Photos for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: HOME ECONOMICS; 
Renovations Go Ahead, But Hold the Gilt

BYLINE:  By JULIE V. IOVINE 

 BODY:
NORM ABRAM, the tool-belted sage of "This Old House," has decided to hold off on building a new workshop in his own backyard in Carlyle, Mass.
 Last week, Alex Gorlin, an architect, was told by clients in Westchester to paint, not gild, the ceiling of their new vaulted bathroom. 
 In Greenwich, Conn., Jill Kent, who oversees the installation of audio-video systems, sees no drop-off in business, but the high-end buying binge has subsided. "Last year, things were so flagrant, no one even questioned an $800,000 proposal for lighting and audio," she said. "Now, people are going over these proposals carefully." 
A tumbling stock market has a way of dampening grand schemes. But an impromptu poll of two dozen contractors, designers and industry observers suggests that people are reacting to the recent slowdown in the economy by scaling back rather than canceling their renovations and additions.
Mr. Abram calls it a healthy reality check. "A lot of money has been spent on extreme renovations in recent years," he said. "That money is going to dry up. But it's not the worst thing in the world. Builders have been overwhelmed. So let them catch up to a more sane level of demand." Mr. Abram has instructed his own architect to go ahead with the design of his dream workshop. "But I'm not ready to break ground," he said. 
What will follow this first wave of the jitters? Kermit Baker, an economist at the Joint Center for Housing Studies of Harvard University, is anticipating a substantial stall in homeowner remodeling. He said that the center's first quarterly report for 2001, to be released next month, will show that last year's runaway growth, which increased by $2.6 billion (2.8 percent) from 1999, will drop by about 50 percent.
"There's a lot of turmoil out there," Mr. Baker said, noting that a decrease in the prime interest rate -- good news for remodelers looking for loans -- is concurrent with a softening in sales of existing homes, building materials and at home centers, like Home Depot. "It may be a little less expensive to finance a project right now, but people are worried enough that they're likely to slow down."
It is not only the financing that may get easier. Custom materials and fixtures, like walnut wide-plank floors and swan-shaped faucets, will retain their status, and their prices, as luxury items, but consumers can look forward to a drop in the cost of basics like gypsum wallboard and two-by-fours. A series of factors unrelated to the economy, including supply and demand, have combined to push the cost of building materials lower. With the hasty construction of new factories for producing wallboard, the industry has more then made up for 1999's critical shortage, and last month gypsum wallboard prices reached their lowest level since July 1996.
Lumber is also cheaper than it has been in eight years, according to Random Lengths, a reporting service for the lumber industry. "Don't wait for lumber prices to get any lower," said Rick Schumacher, the executive editor of Building Material Dealer magazine. "It's definitely a buyer's market."
For many who have already taken up their sledgehammers, it's too late to stop now anyway. Renovations, the result of advance planning, are slow to respond to market upsets. Ripping out the kitchen sink is not a spontaneous act; the money has already been put aside even if it has not yet been spent. As Bolek Ryzinski, a Manhattan contractor, said: "People who have been planning something for two years, have all their approvals and their permits. They're not as likely to chicken out."
Is it too much to hope that contractors might actually start returning phone calls? Contractor availability, Mr. Baker said, could be one of the brighter byproducts of this market slowdown. "That's the theory at least," he said, "but so far we haven't heard it in the Boston area." Mr. Baker anticipates that it will take about four months for contractors to work off their backlog, especially on the East Coast, where demand was heaviest. "Then they'll start getting panicky for work," he said.
Calls to contractors in New York City, Long Island and upstate New York met a uniform response: still busy, but don't give up. "I blew off so many people for so long, it's going to take me a while to clean up the docket," said Chris Smiley in Manhattan, who was shocked by a recent call from a woman who said she had bids from three different contractors. "That's amazing," he said. "Six months ago she would have been lucky to get even one person on the phone."
Mr. Smiley declined to make a bid himself, though the woman has called him repeatedly. "It's not worth our money," said Mr. Smiley, who dreads the inevitable return to small-scale jobs, those "with the kids underfoot and the parents living in the bathroom while the rest of the place is gutted."
Dennis Wedlick, a New York architect, is advising his clients to lock contractors in to set prices for their work by negotiating a fixed bid. "I'm telling them to wait until summer to do the work and to spend more time comparison shopping and trying to get firmer prices," he said. When there is a glut of work, contractors can demand that clients pay as the project goes along, plus their standard markup of 20 percent of construction costs. "That forces you to carry the risk," Mr. Wedlick said. It also encourages contractors to pad their estimates. 
Experienced contractors, for the last two years as elusive as rare nesting bowerbirds, are worth the wait. They won't cut you any deals, Mr. Wedlick said, but they will do a better job. Contractors are "not panicking," concurred Paul Deffenbaugh, the editor in chief of Remodeling Magazine. "It's just more equitable now. A year ago, they held all the cards; now we're even."
Even the small-scale contractors reported very few canceled projects. Peter Haber, who has a crew of 12 workers, is busy with a half-dozen jobs in Manhattan and is still getting a few calls for new work in the million-dollar range. At the same time, he has noticed that some of his clients are "lowering the scope of the work," he said. Instead of oak flooring, they're asking for carpets; in place of marble and granite, they're settling for ceramic tile.
High-end electronics, from lighting systems that can be adjusted from the road to Spielberg-worthy home theaters, would seem to be expendable, but as with renovations, consumers are merely lowering their sights. Ms. Kent at Audio Video Systems said customers have turned "cautious." 
"They're getting smarter at cutting corners," she said, and are starting to nitpick about prices. One client canceled an order for a $1,700 custom-made brass keypad for controlling his lighting system, but he bought a $30,000 flat-screen, high-resolution television "because that's what he really wanted for his money," Ms. Kent said. 
Professional decorators, who tend to work at the high end of the remodeling market, haven't noticed much panic on the swatch front. Ronald Bricke, a Manhattan decorator, said that younger clients were tightening their budgets and forgoing the Biedermeier chaise for a Crate & Barrel couch. "They'll still do the work," he said, "but they're coasting at a lower level." His older clients are looking to negotiate for special deals with antiques dealers. "But so far I haven't found any yet," Mr. Bricke said.
In some quarters, the bloom is still on the rose. Mariette Himes Gomez, a Manhattan decorator and furniture designer, said she just received a call from a client who wants a private golf course and clubhouse in Bedford. Next month, Ms. Gomez is also opening a 2,500-square-foot showroom on East 74th Street to sell her furniture collection. "I asked all my clients in the financial world, 'Am I being foolish to do this right now?' " She said they all encouraged her. 
Karen Fisher, a Manhattan decorating consultant, said she had never been busier. "People are spending like there's no tomorrow," she said, citing a couple who recently imported a California decorator to Manhattan because they wanted their New York high-rise apartment transformed into an authentic Mexican hacienda. "The new status is to spend on decorating to show that you were smart enough to get the money off the table in time," she said.
From her office on the Upper East Side, Victoria Hagan, a Manhattan decorator, said she couldn't help but notice that Park Avenue was still lined bumper to bumper with delivery trucks. "I guess no one wants to commit to its being bad yet," she said. 
Regardless what lies down the road, people are still stocking up on the finer things in life, including denial.

An article last Thursday about the impact of the economy on home remodeling projects misspelled the name of the Pennsylvania hometown of Norm Abram, the master carpenter on the television program "This Old House." It is Carlisle, not Carlyle.

HEADLINE: THE INDIE SPIRIT; 
Far From Tigers and Dragons

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
THIS is the kind of thing that bores all my guests," James Schamus said, leaping from his seat.
 Were he a figure in Chinese folklore, Mr. Schamus might be described as looking like a cross between an owl and a young bear. 
 "See this," he said. He was pointing at a thermostat on the wall. "The heat is set at 50 degrees, and the temperature in this room is 69. And it's what -- about 49 degrees outside?" Snow glistened through a window. 
Mr. Schamus, 41, smiled as though he had a frog in one pocket, a spectacular marble in the other.
The house, like its owner, a film producer and screenwriter, gets things done on time and on the dime.
While Mr. Schamus was producing Ang Lee's "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon," nominated for 10 Academy Awards -- including best picture, director and adapted screenplay by Mr. Schamus, Wang Hui Ling and Tsai Kuo Jung -- he was also producing another project in upstate New York. It was a new house for his family, their first.
But Mr. Schamus, who lives on the Upper West Side with his wife, Nancy Kricorian, also a writer, and their children, Nona and Djuna, had a vision beyond weekend retreat.
It was to build a modest house with standard materials that would put on display unstandard thinking about energy efficiency and comfortable design -- on a budget as strict as an independent film's.
What the architects ultimately proposed broke the house apart and sent it flying -- like a building cut in half and given a spin.
"We weren't trying to start a revolution," Mr. Schamus said last week, of his work with two New York architects, Louise Harpman and Scott Specht. "We were trying to show, very simply, with a few thoughts and a couple of changes in terms of material use, that you could create a house that anyone could build, that was fundamentally different."
Not that Mr. Schamus is new to alternative thinking. He graduated from Berkeley twice -- with both undergraduate and graduate degrees. He speaks Danish. His screenplay for Mr. Lee's "The Ice Storm," which won the prize in that category at Cannes in 1997, is an antiheroic ode to the anti-Nixonian 70's. The two men have collaborated on seven films.
"The house is like James," Mr. Lee, a frequent guest, said with affection last week by telephone. "Amiable and intellectual. Kid-friendly, friend-friendly, and politically, environmentally correct."
The small house -- 2,500 square feet that Mr. Schamus budgeted at $200 a square foot -- had a big social agenda. It would accommodate the occasional crowd of 16 or so: part commune, part summer camp.
And he was not without his stylistic preferences either. The house would look like a house in a Shaker village, with the kind of authentic simplicity Mr. Schamus admired in nearby communities like Hancock.
But he liked modernism. And it had to be cozy.
"Did you say 'cozy?' " Mr. Schamus recalled Ms. Harpman asking.
He was sitting in the loft above the living room. Tucked beneath the sloping roof, it helps warm the house in the winter by encouraging the convection of heat. In the summer, it helps cool the house by inducing a strong breeze.
It is also a quiet spot for escape, with beautiful views. The workmen building the house ate lunch there.
"I used to go away to write screenplays -- inns without telephones -- and stumbled across Columbia County," Mr. Schamus said, speaking of how he discovered what is now his part of the world. He visited his 100 acres for several years, walking the property, sitting and "sticking my finger in the air," he said, before he and Ms. Kricorian broke ground in 1998.
"He absolutely knew he wanted a Shaker house," Mr. Specht recalled. "He loved the cleanness of it." Ms. Kricorian also liked its traditional profile.
But Mr. Schamus also wanted to experiment. He sent Ms. Harpman and Mr. Specht to "Energy Crafted Home," a two-day workshop led by Marc Rosenbaum and Bill Rock Smith, leading residential energy efficiency experts. The architects learned of the seminar through the Environmental Building News(on the Web at www.buildinggreen.com).
Ms. Harpman and Mr. Specht, who designed the offices for Good Machine, Mr. Schamus's production company, and renovated a house for Mr. Lee, were the only architects present.
"You find this bifurcation between 'design' architects and 'environmental' architects, who only care about the performance of the house," said Mr. Specht, who with Ms. Harpman studied at Yale.
Mr. Schamus viewed the trip as research, financed with the hope that the knowledge would be shared. Ms. Harpman, who now teaches at Yale, has already introduced its lessons into her classes.
"You can do everything environmentally consciously," she said. "But if there are budget constraints, as there were on James's house, you have to weigh cost against any increase in performance." 
Ms. Harpman mentioned photovoltaic panels as an example. "Photovoltaics are an incredible bell-and-whistle right now," she said. "Beautiful blue panels. I mean, they're on the Conde Nast building, right?" Ms. Harpman explained that "they wouldn't have produced as much savings in energy as putting two extra inches of insulation in the walls. So, you understand instead how to align the studs in the framing to get that in."
What started as a straightforward peaked-roof house shifted direction -- literally. The butterfly shape that Ms. Harpman and Mr. Specht proposed, with two wings rising from a low waist, now leapt into the landscape, providing twin panoramas of the hilly countryside and two nicely separate quarters, for bedrooms and living.
"It became a function issue," Mr. Specht said. "The form worked better than a Shaker house." 
The gentle pitch of the two shed roofs hold snow snugly, in a blanket that insulates the house. Inside, air circulates easily because the ceilings, rising to windows, vent it at both ends rather than trapping it in the center -- producing warmth or coolness.
And the light is brilliant. 
"It's very bright," Mr. Specht said, "even on gray days, because light is coming from very high in the space and it's reflecting down from the angled roofs."
Eleven local contractors bid on the project, at $200 to $600 a square foot.
Mr. Schamus's budget loaded the dice. "It was a reality check," he said. "Money dictated the radical design."
Mr. Schamus let his architects' solutions shave costs. The house was built for $500,000. Construction took 18 months; the family moved in last May.
Ms. Harpman and Mr. Specht specified second-grade maple wood for the flooring. Bead board on the ceilings articulated the rooms without the expense or clutter of wall moldings. Built-in seating in the kitchen, where Mr. Schamus and Mr. Lee, both amateur chefs, spend much of their time when not working, economized handsomely: it cut 22 square feet out of the kitchen and 126 square feet out of the house overall -- which carved more than $25,000 out of the budget.
"It's one of my dream features," Mr. Lee said, with envy, of the banquettes. "It just feels good, like you're sitting in a diner."
The house's big ticket was a $14,000 Tulikivi -- a Finnish wood-burning stove in the living room. This massive soapstone furnace is the house's primary source of heat. There are no fireplaces; a built-in propane-burning system is rarely used.
"Oh well," Mr. Schamus said, his voice dropping, when the stove was mentioned. "Now we're getting religious. One load of wood in the morning, and one in the evening, and the heat absorbed in the soapstone will radiate for hours."
"That thing hovers around 140 degrees," he explained, standing to look down at it fondly from the loft. "Unlike cast-iron stoves, which get to be about 600 degrees. You can give this a nice big hug."
Mr. Schamus's experience as a film producer stood him in excellent stead.
"Crouching Tiger," filmed in rural Anhui Province in China and produced for $12 million, involved a crew of 500. The house required a crew of 10.
"It's the advantage of having worked on 40 films," Mr. Schamus said. "As a middle-class homeowner, you understand crews."
Mr. Schamus had sound advice for anyone designing a house.
"Start with the bathrooms," he said. "Weirdly enough, the minute your bathroom grows, your house grows. This ideology that bathrooms have to be shrines to conspicuous wealth -- how much time do these rich people spend in the bathroom?"
He also cautioned against making changes during production -- fatal in filmmaking.
"You set up the program, you lay down shared principles and visions, and you pass over in early stages, in incredible detail, budget, schedule and planning," Mr. Schamus said. "Then you step back and let people do their best work."
Speaking as a critic, Mr. Schamus gave Ms. Harpman and Mr. Specht high marks. "We just wanted a house," he said. "But design gives you more houseness than you thought."
It might be compared to reaching an audience. "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" has earned $170 million worldwide, a reception that has taken Mr. Schamus and Mr. Lee by surprise. But at the heart of its wizardry is a love story, or a fairy tale -- concepts that anyone can grasp.
Mr. Schamus said of his house, "I really didn't expect to be so pleased with just simple ideas." It was as though the lights in the theater were just coming up.

HEADLINE: HOME ECONOMICS; 
Mysteriously, Real Estate Rolls On

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
AS the Nasdaq and the bonus babies take their hits, and the Fed juggles interest rates, the country's real estate market just keeps rolling along, leaving statisticians, real estate brokers, buyers and sellers scratching their heads.
 "The real estate markets are really the only sector of the economy that is standing tall -- it's healthy," said David Lereah, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors in Washington. "It's a puzzle. Usually, real estate leads the other indicators on down." 
 Robert J. Shiller, a partner in Case Shiller Weiss in Cambridge, Mass., the country's leading residential real estate analysts, agreed. "Our model is still going up," he said, alluding to his company's forecast for the price of houses. He paused. "But we don't believe it." 
If they're confused, think of the rest of us.
In major real estate markets from Manhattan to Houston and from Chicago to Palm Desert, Calif., brokers report that house hunters continue to hunt. They also continue to buy, albeit more slowly in some places. Bidding wars are generally a thing of the past. Across the country, prices have stabilized or, in a few places, "softened," trade talk for a slight dip. In Silicon Valley, not surprisingly, brokers have reported drops of 20 and 30 percent. But in nearby San Francisco, prices are still rocketing, Mr. Shiller said. In suburbs like Montclair, N.J., 20 miles west of the George Washington Bridge, prices are going up, too.
On the Gold Coast of central Chicago and the suburbs to the north, prices "never went up 50 percent, as they did in those dot-com places," said Chuck Goro, a vice president at Koenig & Strey in Wilmette, Ill. "But they are rising at the same steady pace: between 10 and 15 percent."
All this wisdom is shaky to some degree. Certainly, none of the experts are reporting the meteoric rises of 2000, rises that only Donald J. Trump could have imagined a decade ago. In Palm Desert, Ginny Becker, an owner of Becker & Becker, said she thought "offers were coming in a little lower," especially in the last month. But no one knows for certain because statistics usually take three months to ripen: the three months to close on a property and see it recorded.
So for now, a lot of experts are flying blind -- and they admit it. "The perception is that the demand is on a downward slope," said Deborah B. Beck, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, which compiles quarterly statistics on New York City's real estate market. "But I don't know whether we're on a downward slope or on a flat playing field. This is real uncertainty."
Although many pundits are holding their breath, Jonathan Miller, president of Miller Samuel, a Manhattan real estate appraisal company, is one of the few to offer hard statistics. And the statistics show a modest decline in volume -- and a modest increase (yes, increase) in prices in Manhattan over the last two months. (But again, these are closings from three months earlier.)
According to Miller Samuel, volume -- the number of sales -- has declined 11 percent in Manhattan this year, against the same period last year. But prices across the board have risen 4.2 percent on average in that same period. "So it's not doom and gloom," Mr. Miller said. "It shows a remarkable resilience. In an uncertain period, people are being more cautious, but you're not seeing any kind of decline in prices."
That is because interest rates are so low, said Mr. Lereah, the Washington economist. He predicted on Tuesday -- after the Federal Reserve Board dropped the interest rate half a point more -- that real estate prices may drop more in the next six months. But that is not a sure thing, he added, and interest rates may not go much lower. "If you find something you like now," he advised, "go for it!"
So who is buying now?
As DeCourcy E. McIntosh walked into an interview with a Brooklyn Heights co-op board a week ago, New York City's real estate market was much on his mind.
Mr. McIntosh, 58, is moving from Pittsburgh, and although prices here have stabilized in the last six months, he joked ruefully about "buying at the top of the market." 
Nevertheless, he did not want to wait and see whether prices start crashing. He wanted to make the best investment he could right now. Having budgeted less than $250,000, he was faced with a choice: a studio in Manhattan (maybe) or a one bedroom in Brooklyn Heights. 
"I felt that since I was looking for something so modest, I wasn't going to be whipsawed if and when the prices really dropped. I felt that with a one bedroom in a 1929 apartment building -- without a doorman but immaculately maintained -- my downside was not that great." He passed the board and is going through with his deal. He is paying the asking price, but the price had just been reduced 8 percent, so he decided not to haggle.
Prices, real estate brokers in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey report, are increasingly more negotiable, and in celebrity-strewn environs like the Hamptons, some overpriced properties are being slashed to market value. "I'm talking about an owner with a dream price of $5 million," said Diane Saatchi, president of Dayton-Halstead Real Estate in East Hampton, N.Y. "That price is now $2.5 million, which is the real market price. And at that price, it will sell."
In Alpine, N.J., prices have stabilized, but brokers' waiting lists for good houses are longer than they were a year ago, said Dennis McCormack, owner of Prominent Properties. "We're not seeing those crazy run-ups, but our biggest problem is a lack of inventory," he said. A 12,000-square-foot-house on two acres, "with no pool, no tennis court," he said, just sold for $7.4 million. A two-acre lot ("between you and me, it was nothing so great -- it was on a cul-de-sac but with no water and no view") just sold for $2.5 million. 
Mr. McCormack said that one of his customers, "a senior partner on Wall Street," told him he and his friends were putting their past gains into real estate. 
Denise Reardon, president of Schweppe & Company in Montclair, N.J., is even more bullish: "Prices are still going up," she said, although there may be more properties for sale. In Lakeville, Conn., John Borden reported that prices were not rising anymore but that there is still lots of action. In Rye, N.Y., Alix Prince, a vice president of Julia B. Fee Real Estate, concurred.
But Pete Callaway, of N. T. Callaway Real Estate in Princeton, N.J., told colleagues at a conference about a real calamity: three canceled deals during his drive to work last Friday.
"Why didn't he turn off the cell phone?" wondered Jack Turpin, who owns a real estate company in Far Hills, N.J. He reported stable sales volume. 
In Far Hills, Mr. Turpin said, prices have not yet sobered up. "Greed being what it is, sellers need absolute empirical evidence before bringing their prices down," he said. What would constitute empirical evidence? "Sitting on the market for months, and that hasn't been happening," he replied.
Prices may not be dropping like stones, but some house hunters think they might be soon. Tom Pappas, a Midtown lawyer, is like a spider watching a fly circling closer to his web. "I'm watching the Internet," he said. "I see prices coming down. I'm waiting for the $250,000 one bedroom. They're at $350,000 now, and I figure in about a year . . . "
John Dobkin, a consultant to philanthropies, seeks an antique house and a garden in Dutchess County. "Before, I couldn't touch one for anything near a quarter of a million dollars," he said. He called Hudson Valley agents last week and put in his order: no more than a two-hour drive from Times Square and under $250,000. "I predict I'll find something in the next six to nine months -- and I'll be ready to pounce." 
For would-be buyers ready to pounce, brokers counsel hunting for fixer-uppers, which, after a run of having been priced almost the same as the fixed-up, have lost cachet in this uncertain market.
Mr. McIntosh, who is about to close on his one-bedroom co-op on Willow Street in Brooklyn Heights, believes he can't go wrong with it, an apartment in a "dark brick, Tudory" building -- and in the right city. 
"New York is forever," he said. "There may be ups and downs, but this is a blue chip apartment. It's nothing trendy that will go out of style."
Mr. McCormack, the real estate broker in Alpine, feels the same about his part of New Jersey. "No matter what happens with the economy," he said, "Alpine will always be six miles north of the George Washington Bridge."

HEADLINE: Judge Deals Setback to Independent Bookstores 

BYLINE:  By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK 

 BODY:
In a setback for a group of independent bookstores, a federal court judge in Northern California dismissed their claim to damages yesterday in an antitrust suit against Barnes & Noble and the Borders Group.
 The lawsuit, scheduled for trial April 9, is the most ambitious attack yet in the independents' decade-long legal battle against the superstore chains, whose expansion has coincided with the closing of thousands of independent stores. 
 The legal battle carries high stakes for the independent booksellers' powerful trade group, the American Booksellers Association, in part because it is devoting a substantial portion of its financial resources to the trial. 
Previous lawsuits filed by the independents were aimed at publishers, accusing them of unfairly favoring the chains, and were settled out of court. The current lawsuit is the first to take on the chains directly and also the first to go to trial.
In the suit, filed in United States District Court for the Northern District of California, a group of California bookstores and the booksellers' association argue that the chains use their size to extract unfair deals from book publishers and distributors. Both publishers and the chains deny the charges.
The independents are seeking damages for profits that they might have lost in the past as a result of what they contend are the chains' unfair practices. But Judge William Orrick dismissed their claim to damages in part because he rejected the economic model the independents proposed to calculate the magnitude of the damages. Ruling out damages also means that the case will not be heard by a jury, a procedure that people involved said might have prolonged the trial and favored the independents.
The independent stores have also requested an injunction to force the chains to change their business practices. The judge left that matter standing and it will be heard when the suit goes to trial. It is also possible that the independent stores will appeal the decision to dismiss their claims to damages, possibly even before the trial.
The ruling considerably diminishes the suit's threat to the chains. For Barnes & Noble, based in New York, and Borders, based in Ann Arbor, Mich., the worst possible outcome is now some modification in their dealings with publishers and distributors, as well as the payment of the independent booksellers' legal fees.
The suit still carries risks for the American Booksellers Association, because it is spending heavily on legal fees. The association pays for most of its operating costs out of income from a $28 million endowment -- a war chest left over from the sale of its trade show and a payment to settle a previous lawsuit against a publisher. In a recent interview, Avin Domnitz, the association's chief executive, said that it had paid more than $12 million in legal fees so far.
