HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Americans' waistlines have become the victims of economic progress.

BYLINE:  By Virginia Postrel; This column appears here every Thursday. Virginia Postrel is the editor at large of Reason Magazine and the author of "The Future and Its Enemies." E-mail: vpostrel@reason.com

 BODY:
EVER alert for trends that threaten Americans' health, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recently reported some bad news. Only about a quarter of the population is getting enough exercise, and that percentage barely budged from 1990 to 1998. The media may be full of beautiful, fit bodies, but neither those images nor the pleading of health experts is having much effect. Most Americans seem content to stay on the couch. The result is ever greater obesity.
 That doesn't surprise Tomas J. Philipson, an economist at the Irving B. Harris Graduate School of Public Policy Studies at the University of Chicago. Professor Philipson, who applies economic reasoning to public health questions, recently examined the reasons behind increasing obesity. "People understand better now how to control their weight than historically," he notes. "The information has grown, but we're yet getting fatter over time." Something other than ignorance must be driving the trend. 
 In a National Bureau of Economic Research working paper written with Richard A. Posner, a federal appeals court judge affiliated with the University of Chicago Law School, Professor Philipson proposes a simple theory. People haven't changed -- they've always liked to eat high-calorie food and generally disliked strenuous exertion -- but incentives have. (The paper, "The Long-Run Growth in Obesity as a Function of Technological Change," can be found at www.nber.org/papers/w7423.)
For starters, the cost of consuming calories has plummeted, thanks to productivity gains in agriculture and distribution. Food is cheaper and more abundant, encouraging people to consume more of it. But that's an old trend, and it doesn't fully account for recent weight gains.
More important in recent years is that the cost of burning those calories has surged as work has become more sedentary. "To put it simply, it used to be that you got paid to exercise," Professor Philipson says. "If you wanted an income, you engaged in manual labor. Today you pay to exercise, not so much in money, but in forgone leisure time. So if you want to spend time with your kids, you have a choice between that and going to the gym or running." To burn a lot of calories, Americans have to give up doing other valuable things. Exercise is no longer something free that comes along with making a living.
That's good news for the people in the health club business. The International Health, Racquet and Sportsclub Association reports record numbers of members and rising participation. But the nation's 31 million health club members account for just over 10 percent of the population. And only 40 percent of those go to the gym at least twice a week, a rising percentage but still a small one.
"One interpretation of why you've gotten such an explosion in leisure exercise is because work exercise has gone down," Professor Philipson says. "We didn't used to have people going out jogging or going to the gym after work because they got it at work." While leisure exercise was fairly stable in the 1990's, over the long run it has been going up -- just not fast enough to make up for those lost paid workouts.
This theory helps to explain an empirical puzzle. In the United States, poorer people tend to be fatter than rich ones. (The very poorest Americans are still thin, but weight rises rapidly from there, with the heaviest people in the low-to-middle incomes -- an inverted U-shaped curve.) Around the world, however, people in poor countries are skinnier than people in wealthy countries.
"One interpretation of that is that the same technological differences that generate higher per capita income in the rich countries also make them more sedentary," Professor Philipson says. As national income rises, so does the average weight, "because those guys are having desk jobs instead of cutting wheat."
In developed countries, thinness is a costly good that people demand more of as they get wealthier. Not surprisingly, health club members have relatively high incomes, with nearly a fifth reporting household incomes of more than $75,000.
The sharp increase in paid labor among women the last three decades may account for the rapid rise in their weights. Housework, while only moderately strenuous, is more physically demanding than sitting at a desk.
And if women still have the after-hours housework responsibilities, they have less leisure time than men for more intensive exercise, like health club workouts. Burning calories is thus particularly costly for women.
Professor Philipson is testing the work-exercise theory in empirical work with Darius Lakdawalla of the RAND Corporation, using data on how strenuous various occupations are. (These data are usually used in computing worker's compensation insurance rates.) The preliminary results suggest "huge effects of this work-related exercise" on obesity, Professor Philipson says. People in more strenuous jobs are significantly thinner than people of similar backgrounds and incomes who get less exercise at work.
In this view, Americans aren't getting fatter because they don't know what's good for them or because they've suddenly developed a taste for fatty foods. They haven't exchanged self-control for gluttony. Rather, the same economic and technological progress that has produced higher living standards has made work more sedentary. (For children, the issue is entertainment rather than work -- the difference between playing tag and playing video games.) Growing obesity is an unintended consequence of a more productive economy.
This analysis has implications for other health and technology issues. The increasingly popular "precautionary principle" warns against adopting technologies, like genetically enhanced foods, that might have negative side effects. To see the principle's problems, we need only consider the causes of obesity, a far better established health risk than anything the antigenetics campaigners have dreamed up. Would we really be better off picking cotton and cutting wheat by hand? We'd be thinner, true, but with shorter, less interesting lives -- and a whole new collection of physical ailments. Americans may not want to be overweight, but they prefer it to the alternatives.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Americans are increasingly out of shape, but the fault seems to be more in the way they work, not in the way they play. Patrons exercised at a gym in Allentown, Pa., in 1998. (Sal DiMarco Jr. for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
As Stocks Dive and Economy Softens, the Dollar Is Positively Robust

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
With the economy softening, investors fleeing stocks and interest rates dropping -- all forces that normally batter the dollar -- why has it instead grown stronger?
 While few seem to be paying much attention to much but stocks these days, what is going on in the currency market is more baffling than the recent plunges in the Dow Jones industrial average, the Nasdaq composite and the Standard & Poor's 500. 
 The dollar is now near a two-year high against the Japanese yen and has stopped the euro in its tracks, at a time the euro was supposed to rally after declines over most of the preceding two years.
"The dollar should be under pressure," said Robert Sinche, head of currency strategy at Citibank, citing factors that have weakened the currency in the past.
In addition to the slowing economy and a bear market on Wall Street, the Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts are narrowing the gap between rates in this country and those in Europe and elsewhere. The American deficit in trade and services is rising, another usual drag on the dollar's value. Flows of foreign funds into United States markets are slowing. The surge in foreign acquisitions of American companies, or mergers with them, also sources of foreign investment good for the dollar, appear to be reversing. 
"This has become the time when it has been most difficult to understand the dollar," Mr. Sinche said.
The answer to this puzzle, it seems, is that other forces are in play. Despite this country's problems, for example, many investors still think that the United States is better able to deal with its economic troubles than Japan or Europe. Japan is widely expected to change prime ministers, and the European Central Bank, many analysts say, is moving too slowly to cut interest rates and spur growth there.
Many investors, according to some analysts, still see America as a safe harbor if slow or no growth in Europe and Japan turns into a global downturn.
"What central bank," asked James E. Glassman, senior United States economist at J. P. Morgan, "is going to be the most forceful in guiding us through these troubled waters?" His answer: the Fed.
Technical forces are also at work, including a sudden move by American companies to hedge against further declines in foreign currencies and a lot of speculators' taking advantage of zero-level interest rates in Japan by borrowing there, then selling the yen for dollars and earning the higher interest rates here.
In the near term, the dollar's surprising strength provides the Federal Reserve with more leeway in cutting rates. If the dollar had notably weakened, Fed policy makers might feel less flexible.
Although the dollar has not been an overriding concern for policy makers in the past, a weak dollar would complicate their job of turning the economy around. A much weaker dollar would increase inflation pressure as imports became more expensive. And if the dollar plunged, it would take higher interest rates -- not the lower rates a slumping economy needs -- to attract the foreign capital that covers the trade deficit and helps to service the debt.
But if the dollar manages to remain strong, and some forecasters say it will, it could easily be a drag on growth, making American exports less competitive in price. This is especially troubling for manufacturing, which is already in a recession.
W. R. Timken Jr., chairman of the Timken Company, which makes bearings and steel products used by other manufacturers, said his company had been hit twice by the stubbornly strong dollar. His bearings are less competitive abroad, and his rivals in Germany, Japan and Sweden can lower their prices in the United States. "The biggest impact is in the marketplace on the pricing of the products," he said. While he did not put a specific figure on the damage the strong dollar had done, he called it "substantial."
Since the beginning of February, when the stock market plunge accelerated, the dollar's value has risen by 4.6 percent against the euro and by 5.9 percent against the yen.
More surprising is that the dollar, as measured on an inflation-adjusted, trade-weighted basis against most other world currencies, is as strong at it has been since 1986 -- when it was coming down from recent peak levels.
Even with a further cut by the Fed on Tuesday of half a percentage point in short-term rates, the dollar has held its own against the euro and the yen, easing only slightly. And yesterday, the dollar rose, settling in New York at 123.46 yen and at 89.58 cents to the euro.
Analysts are split on the outlook. Some expect the stock sell-off, slow growth and lower interest rates to catch up with the dollar, sending it lower against the euro and probably other currencies. Others say that any sign of an end of the American economic downturn would give the dollar new support.
While currency analysts can cite a lot of reasons for the surprisingly strong dollar, one typical refrain -- especially when talking about the dollar and the euro -- is "I just don't know."
Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company, said, "In August, I stood up and said that the euro has to go up meaningfully from here, and in January, I said it was incontrovertible." Now, he said, "I am soberly considering giving up the forecasting of currencies."
Part of the explanation for the dollar's behavior can be found in Japan, where the financial crisis, and the political uncertainties, have weakened the yen. And the Japanese government may condone a weak yen because it would make exports more competitive abroad. The decision by the Japanese central bank on Monday to shift the focus of its monetary policy away from interest rates is not expected to change the yen's outlook for now.
Canada, the largest United States trading partner, has caught this country's economic cold. The Canadian dollar is again declining, settling yesterday at 63.45 cents.
"The euro is more of a puzzle," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International. "The euro will strengthen against the dollar over the next two or three quarters. But to be honest, I thought it would strengthen this quarter."
David Solin, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics, said he had recently seen American companies with businesses abroad hedging against a further decline in the value of the euro. This has led to transactions in which euros are in effect sold for dollars to lock in current rates, something that would give the dollar a boost. He said many companies had been caught unprotected because the consensus forecast for this year had been for a euro rally.
Mr. Solin also thought investors might reason that the United States was the first troubled economy to ease aggressively and, therefore, could be the first out of trouble. This train of thought might push the dollar higher.
Michael Rosenberg, head of global foreign exchange research at Deutsche Bank, says that the dollar is headed lower and that the explanation of its strength is simple. "The Fed has been too tight," he said, meaning interest rates are too high and the growth of the country's monetary base is too slow.
And, he says, this has happened before. From 1990 to 1995, by this example, stocks were down, the economy was slumping and the currency was rising in value. But this was not happening in the United States; it was in Japan, and in a period when the yen surged more than 90 percent against the dollar.
So when the Fed has cut rates enough, he said -- to a point well below the current level -- "the dollar should retreat."

HEADLINE: Price Index Gained 0.3% Last Month 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21 

 BODY:
Consumer prices rose more than expected in February, led by higher costs for food, clothing and medical care, government figures showed today. 
 The Consumer Price Index rose 0.3 percent last month after a 0.6 percent gain in January, the Labor Department said. The core index, which excludes energy and food, also increased 0.3 percent, matching January's rise. 
 While the index rose more than the 0.2 percent expected by analysts, sluggish economic growth is prompting companies like DaimlerChrysler and Dell Computer to cut prices and offer discounts to attract customers.
Consumer prices "should decline in coming months as slower demand restrains inflation for the rest of 2001," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. Industrial production has fallen for five consecutive months, and the price report "gives the Federal Reserve wider latitude to reduce interest rates again" to increase growth, he said. On Tuesday, the Fed reduced its target rate on overnight loans between banks for the third time this year.
The C.P.I. is the government's broadest gauge of costs for goods and services. About 55 percent of the index covers prices consumers pay for medical visits, airline fares, movie tickets and other services. Prices of food, clothing, appliances and other goods make up the rest.
Medical care costs rose 0.5 percent after rising 0.6 percent in January. Prices increased for prescription drugs, physicians' services and hospital services. Food prices, which account for about a fifth of the index, rose 0.5 percent in February after increasing 0.3 percent in January. 
The price of clothing rose 0.8 percent in February, the largest increase since last September, after falling 0.2 percent in January. Still, apparel costs were 0.6 percent lower in February than in the corresponding month a year earlier.
Prices of other goods and services were tame in February. New-vehicle prices declined 0.3 percent in February after rising 0.1 percent a month earlier. DaimlerChrysler's Chrysler unit offered discounts on a dozen models of cars, trucks and minivans to increase sales. 
The cost of personal computers fell 3.1 percent after dropping 4.1 percent in January.
Until recently, analysts said the main inflation threat was a surge in energy prices. Those increases are starting to subside. Energy costs fell 0.2 percent in February, in contrast to a 3.9 percent jump in January. Natural gas prices fell 2.4 percent after increasing a record 17.4 percent in January. Electricity prices fell 0.3 percent.
Housing costs increased 0.2 percent after a 1 percent increase.

HEADLINE: Scanning For Dollars By Middlemen; 
Medical Brokers Are Cited In Auto Insurance Costs

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
After another driver rear-ended Jean Fitzgerald Hillier's pickup truck near Tampa, Fla., last year, she went to a chiropractor complaining of neck and back pain, headaches, dizziness and numbness in her arms. To try to find the cause of Mrs. Hillier's discomfort, the chiropractor sent her to a medical-imaging center for diagnostic tests.
 The center performed two magnetic resonance imaging, or M.R.I., exams and two computerized axial tomography, or CAT, scans and charged a total of $1,516, according to court documents. Later, insurance investigators said, another corporation with the same ownership and address as the chiropractor's clinic billed Mrs. Hillier's insurer, the Hartford Financial Services Group, $5,700 for the scans -- a 275 percent markup. 
 The insurance company contends in a lawsuit that the clinic was engaged in a practice called brokering that lets medical middlemen reap thousands of dollars from tests, sometimes fraudulently, by exploiting a weakness in no-fault insurance programs. The clinic owner has denied allegations of wrongdoing in court filings. His lawyer declined to elaborate in an interview, except to say that "my client did nothing wrong." 
Investigators say brokers are behind a growing number of abusive and often fraudulent charges in the treatment of auto accident victims in Florida. And across the country, fraud and abuse in diagnostic imaging, one of the most expensive and common medical procedures for auto accident victims, is a major reason injury claims in several states are rising at three times the rate of medical costs in general, experts said.
In New York, claims shot up more than 30 percent last year, driven in part by this kind of diagnostic finagling and other fraud, said Robert Hartwig, the chief economist at the Insurance Information Institute, an industry trade group. In Florida, regulators say claims costs rose nearly 17 percent.
Nationwide, from New Jersey to California and Texas to Illinois, fraud and abuse related to medical treatment for auto accident victims cost insurers about $5.4 billion a year and add an average of nearly $35 to the annual cost of every car insurance policy in America, according to Dennis Jay, executive director of the Coalition Against Insurance Fraud in Washington. In New York, Mr. Hartwig estimated, fraud of this kind adds more than $70 to each policy.
Medical care in auto insurance is particularly vulnerable to fraud and abuse because it is the only area in health care that has not come under managed care controls. As a result, auto insurers routinely pay more for medical services than Medicare and private managed care companies, creating an opportunity for unscrupulous providers.
"This is the way our system has evolved," said Uwe Reinhardt, a Princeton University professor who specializes in health economics. "In auto insurance, the presumption is that the injured person should be made 100 percent whole. No one could ever deny you anything you or your doctor might conceivably want."
With no one to say no, M.R.I. brokers, who most often are independent of doctors and diagnostic centers, and others bent on exploiting the system can pile on charges for services that managed health care insurers would simply reject. They can do that because no authorization is required for treatment, and insurers are required by law to pay the "usual and customary" prices that doctors, hospitals and others ask for -- not the much lower amounts that they routinely accept from health insurers and government agencies.
In Mrs. Hillier's case, the chiropractic clinic owner negotiated a rate of $379 for each scan -- about what health insurers pay -- but he billed Hartford at the diagnostic center's list prices: $1,650 for each of the first M.R.I. and CAT scans and $1,200 for additional tests, according to a lawsuit filed by the insurer.
Medical costs are a particular problem in Florida, New York, New Jersey and other states with no-fault insurance, which requires insurers to pay their customers' claims regardless of who caused an accident -- and pay swiftly -- even though this means less scrutiny of bills.
Moreover, no-fault insurance programs allocate set amounts to cover costs for each accident. This, in effect, creates pools of money that some say have become targets for plunder -- $10,000 per person in Florida, $50,000 a person in New York and up to $250,000 in New Jersey.
Brokers say they are doing nothing wrong. They say they take a scheduling chore off the hands of doctors, help patients find conveniently located M.R.I. centers where there will be little waiting, and provide patients to M.R.I. centers whose equipment might otherwise be idle.
"What we do is buy wholesale and sell retail," said Jack Cory, a state lobbyist in Florida and spokesman for the Association of Diagnostic Imaging Companies, a group formed by some of the brokers. "It's legal, honest, moral and ethical."
Florida investigators, however, say that unscrupulous brokers who buy services at a discount and bill at the full price often hide the fact that they do not do the scans themselves, as required by law. Many brokers, investigators add, also bribe doctors to steer patients their way, though that allegation has not been made in Mrs. Hillier's case.
So far, no criminal cases have gone to court, but just last Friday state insurance investigators arrested a clinic owner in New Port Richey, Fla., in a case involving M.R.I. tests. In civil cases, Florida courts have issued conflicting rulings when brokers sued to force insurers to pay. Only Hartford has challenged brokers in court. Other insurers have begun rejecting brokers' bills but have not sued.
To support contentions that they provide medical services, brokers contract with diagnostic centers to lease blocks of time on their scanners. But insurers and operators of the centers say brokers often ignore the contracts' terms.
"They just schedule their patients whenever they want," said Michael Ross, the marketing representative for the Advanced Imaging Center in Clermont, Fla., just west of Orlando.
Legitimate diagnostic centers discount their fees for brokers because in the unregulated industry the competition for patients is fierce, and they need a certain volume of business to cover their overhead.
Robert A. Bell, a consultant in Encinitas, Calif., estimates that an M.R.I. machine costs about $900,000 a year to own and operate. The roughly 6,100 such machines in the United States averaged 2,200 exams each last year, about 9 each business day, he said. At that rate, a center could break even charging about $400 a test. But up-to-date centers can handle 16 tests in a 12-hour day, he said, so each additional test could mean significant profit.
"Brokers can make a difference," said Dr. Thomas D. Brown, a radiologist and a partner in the Advanced Imaging Center in Winter Park, Fla. If they refer two or three a day, he added, "even with a big discount, that can get you into the black."
While brokers often bill about the same price that legitimate diagnostic centers charge when they deal directly with insurers, brokers add no value, insurers and law enforcement officials say. "They are just exploiting an imperfection in the system," Dr. Reinhardt said.
M.R.I. centers are neither licensed nor regulated in Florida, so no one is sure how many there are. John Arrington, a radiologist and a partner in the University Diagnostic Institute in Tampa, said rivals were approaching "market saturation."
That encourages centers to take clients wherever they find them, and makes centers less likely to challenge orders for scans that might not be medically necessary. Brokers who pocket as much as $1,000 a test are motivated to persuade -- or pay -- doctors to order more tests than needed, investigators said.
"You will find that they are coaching people how to justify M.R.I.'s," said Malcolm K. Sparrow, a researcher at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University who specializes in health care fraud.
Just how many M.R.I. tests should be done on any patient is a judgment call. An independent medical reviewer -- providing the kind of service that has been criticized for being more concerned with costs than patient needs -- said in a report to the insurance company that one of Mrs. Hillier's two M.R.I.'s and both CAT scans were unnecessary. Philip Bomhoff Jr., the lawyer for the clinic that treated Mrs. Hillier and the corporation that billed the insurer, would not comment on the review.
Some clinic owners acknowledge pressure to do superfluous tests.
Tony Talbert, the majority owner of the Advanced Imaging Center in Clermont, said that he agreed to lease time on an M.R.I. machine to a doctor who had planned to send over 10 patients a week. The doctor wanted to pay Mr. Talbert $450 for each test -- then bill insurers for a higher price, effectively acting as his own broker. Mr. Talbert said he insisted on being paid a flat $4,500 a week, as is customary with a lease. That left the doctor to come up with 10 M.R.I. patients every week or take a cut in profits. Mr. Talbert said he ended the arrangement because he was worried that it might be inspiring unnecessary tests.
Regulators have moved to curb abuses. Among the 12 no-fault states, New York, New Jersey, Hawaii and Utah have established set payments for tests and treatment. But New York and Hawaii still pay above the lowest available prices because they use fee schedules for worker compensation, which are higher than Medicare and managed-care fees.
New York also gives accident victims six months to submit bills, making it harder to identify and prevent needless treatment, regulators and antifraud specialists say. The New York State Insurance Department wants to reduce the time to 45 days. Doctors and lawyers oppose the change, and a state court last June struck down the shorter deadline. The state is appealing.
Florida's department of insurance is asking the legislature to impose a managed-care-style fee schedule for M.R.I.'s and some other tests. But neither doctors nor lawyers want any reduction in what insurers pay.
Florida regulators also want to impose mandatory jail time for some auto insurance fraud. Most convictions now result only in probation, so prosecutors are reluctant to take on such cases. Insurance companies are discouraged from suing brokers because they say legal costs often exceed what they recoup.
New Jersey, consistently one of the most expensive places to buy auto insurance, adopted plans two years ago to try to cut insurance costs. But it is only now about to adopt a fee schedule and require accident victims to get approval for some tests and treatments.
Often, the excessive charges and other abuses are invisible to accident victims. But sometimes it eats up their coverage before they recover. Mrs. Hillier fits that category.
When she went to get a prescription filled one day, the pharmacist told her that her insurance benefits had been exhausted. She complained to Hartford, which found that the clinic had billed for a list of therapies that Mrs. Hillier said she never received. The insurance company extended her coverage as it sued the clinic where she was treated. The clinic denied the allegation in its response to the suit.
Mrs. Hillier began seeing a neurologist and last month underwent back and neck surgery.

AUTOMOBILE ACCIDENT -- A broker arranges with a doctor to send the patient to a clinic where the broker has negotiated a reduced fee. The broker then bills the insurer at the usual and customary price, which is two or three times what health insurers pay for the same service. NONAUTOMOBILE ACCIDENTA doctor sends the patient to a clinic where an insurer or health maintenance organization has negotiated a reduced fee, usually less than half the list price that is the usual and customary fee. The clinic then bills the insurer or H.M.O. directly.

HEADLINE: Community Leader to Head Economic Group in Bed-Stuy 

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
A community leader with deep roots in Central Brooklyn was named yesterday to head the troubled Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation, a nonprofit organization that once served as a model for neighborhood revitalization throughout the country.
 Restoration, as the organization is known, has been without a president since August, when Roderick B. Mitchell stepped down after 12 years. Under Mr. Mitchell, the organization had been widely criticized for running large deficits and accused of losing its sense of purpose. 
 Mr. Mitchell's successor, Colvin W. Grannum, has spent most of his career working as a litigator and appellate lawyer. Since 1995, he has served as the founding chief executive of Bridge Street Development Corporation, the economic development affiliate of the Bridge Street African Methodist Episcopal Church in Bedford-Stuyvesant. Bridge Street has 400 units of housing in various stages of development, Mr. Grannum said.
The appointment of Mr. Grannum, 47, to the $150,000-a-year president's post was hailed by several people prominent in the field of community development, who said he had the management skills and temperament to set Restoration back on course. "He is a talented and committed individual who has the ability to make things happen," said Mark Willis, an executive vice president of J. P. Morgan Chase & Company.
Although Mr. Grannum was viewed by many people as a logical successor to Mr. Mitchell, the Restoration board underwent a painstaking selection process to arrive at its decision, said Toni Yuille Williams, who led the search committee. She said 129 names were submitted to the search firm hired by the board.
Ms. Williams said the challenges that Mr. Grannum faced in getting the Bridge Street organization off the ground had given him the experience he needed to revive Restoration, which was created in 1967. She also said the search committee was impressed that Mr. Grannum was "able not only to articulate the passion, but also to feel it."
The job represents a leap for Mr. Grannum, who has been managing 11 people and will now have a staff of 130 and responsibility for managing 900 housing units and 300,000 square feet of commercial property. But Albert C. Wiltshire, the chairman of the Restoration board, who is also a member of the Bridge Street board, said he had no doubt that Mr. Grannum would make a successful transition. "Colvin brings a lot of credibility," he said. "People will be willing to give us another chance."
Raised in what is now called the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn, Mr. Grannum is a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and the Georgetown University Law Center. He worked for the Department of Justice in Washington, the state attorney general's office, New York Telephone Company (now known as Verizon) and the New York City Corporation Counsel.
It was the Rev. Fred A. Lucas, the former pastor of Bridge Street Church, who persuaded him to create a structure for the church's projects that would be comparable to the Abyssinian Development Corporation in Harlem. 
Mr. Grannum, who was a teenager when Restoration was formed, said he recalled hearing Franklin A. Thomas, the organization's first president, described as a revered figure in the community. "There was a tremendous amount of excitement in the creation of Restoration," he said. "That played a role when I was thinking about this job -- that there was an opportunity to help recapture some of the promise."

HEADLINE: Looking Behind Census Numbers as Hartford Works for Resurgence 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 21 

 BODY:
As a landlord and licensed mortgage broker, Norma Aparicio depends on the city of Hartford for her livelihood. She owns 13 residential properties in the city and three vacant lots that she hopes to build on. But as much as Mrs. Aparicio believes in the future of Connecticut's capital city, she does not want her own family to live here, at least not now.
 In 1997, after nine years in the city, Mrs. Aparicio packed up her family's belongings in the West End and moved to West Hartford, an adjacent suburb, where she could send her son and daughter to better schools. "My daughter was in high honors in Hartford, the best in school," she said. "When we moved to West Hartford she was crying. She didn't know anything, and you don't know how she studies, six hours a day." 
 Mrs. Aparicio's decision to move offers insight into results of the 2000 census released this week, which showed a 15 percent decline in Hartford's population over the last decade, a steep drop that was reflected to a lesser degree in all of Connecticut's large cities with the exception of Stamford in Fairfield County.
The declines in Connecticut contrast with a pattern of healthy growth in many cities across the country, including New York. State and local officials, demographers and other academic experts offer numerous explanations for the unusual patterns here, including strong growth in the suburbs that parallels the exodus from the cities and a generally flat statewide population that shows no substantial influx of residents to fill the gaps.
The result is a widening economic and racial segregation in Connecticut, which is the richest state in the country and which, compared with New York and New Jersey, has relatively little diversity to begin with: three out of four of the state's residents are white. Connecticut's cities, populated mostly by blacks and Hispanics, are increasingly surrounded by fast-growing, wealthier "rim" suburbs. But whites are not the only people leaving the city. The new census data show a decline in Hartford's black population as well.
"At the heart of what is a fairly prosperous urban area, you have got this terribly impoverished city center," said David Rusk, a consultant and author on urban policy issues who has studied the greater Hartford area. "And you can say much the same for New Haven and much the same for Bridgeport."
Some of the declines may be reversed, officials suggest, through increased public and private investment to create new housing, entertainment and other attractions that might draw people back to the cities.
This type of investment is already under way in Hartford. The Capital City Redevelopment Authority is now overseeing projects worth $700 million, including the waterfront redevelopment effort known as Adriaen's Landing, which will include a new convention center, a pedestrian walkway and retail and entertainment businesses along the Connecticut River. There are also plans for 1,000 new housing units.
Matt Fleury, a spokesman for the development authority, said the goal was to reunite downtown Hartford, which is now focused on government and corporate offices, with the riverfront to attract both new residents and leisure-time visitors. "The approach is not just to plunk in nice apartments," he said. "It is to try to create a base of attractive downtown residential dwellings that is combined with an enhanced cultural and pedestrian environment."
But other factors -- including local housing and tax policies, the quality of public schools, highways and transportation and questions about regional planning -- are far more complicated, and suggest that the trends may be harder to reverse. In interviews, residents of Hartford said they expected the city's population to continue to decline until the struggling school system improved and crime was noticeably reduced.
"Most of my friends are in the suburbs," said Berneta Halstead, 44, who lives in the poor, mostly black North End. "It's better areas, better schools. I live here, in the midst of everything: the empty buildings, the trash, the noise, the drugs, the violence."
From a policy perspective, several experts said that Hartford needed the help of strong regional planning initiatives, particularly in housing. "If you really want to see these trends reversed," said Mr. Rusk, the urban policy consultant, "the state of Connecticut has to get serious about ending these patterns of racial economic segregation through very strong mixed-income housing policies in the suburbs."
Phil Tegeler, the legal director of the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union, said that Hartford's small size -- about 18 square miles -- and government structure were factors in the city's decline. "We have this municipal government structure that breaks down our metropolitan area into 20 separate small municipalities," he said. "There isn't any kind of regional government."
Without a regional governance, he said, it is hard to fight suburban sprawl. "It's losing population because of the taxes, the schools, the housing and the suburban development incentives that have encouraged sprawl and massive housing development out in the far-flung areas of the region, when in fact the region as a whole should be encouraging development of the center."
Mayor Michael P. Peters also faulted the governance system. "This city stands unto itself," he said. "It's a very poor city in a very wealthy region." One reason the population dropped, he said, was the city's razing of some of its largest public housing projects, which were centers of poverty and crime.
"I believe the quality of life has gotten better with the decline in population," Mayor Peters said. "Where does it say the more people you have the better your city is?"
Mr. Peters said the housing market in Hartford's central business district was tight, with occupancy rates of better than 98 percent. But outside the business district, most of the residential neighborhoods of Hartford are forlorn. Buildings lie vacant and boarded up, local cemeteries are desecrated with tombstones overturned, trash is strewn along sidewalks and in the streets.
But amid the despair, many do see hope. Mrs. Aparicio, the mortgage broker who moved to West Hartford, was standing this afternoon outside her latest purchase: a terribly dilapidated house on Wadsworth Street. "There is a lot of potential in Hartford," she said. "It will come back."

GRAPHIC: Photo: An electrician checks one of many run-down houses near downtown Hartford. Norma and Porfirio Aparicio own it and several others, but they moved to West Hartford so their children could go to better schools. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Access to AIDS Drugs 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "The Scientist's Story," by William Prusoff (Op-Ed, March 19):
 Dr. Prusoff's description of the sequence of events to bring d4T, a costly antiretroviral drug to control AIDS, from the lab to the afflicted poor patients in sub-Saharan Africa reminds us that the pharmaceutical industry is not immune to the global issues of today -- specifically, the prevalence of AIDS and other fatal diseases in third-world countries as well as in developed nations. 
 The giants of the industry must also be sensitive to the fact that just as a large percentage of Americans cannot afford the extravagant prices charged for lifesaving medications, a larger percentage of people in other parts of the world cannot even dream of taking the same medications.
Let the example of the successful efforts to bring d4T to a larger population be a precedent that we are indeed living in a global economy.

PANKAJ GUPTA, M.D.
Framingham, Mass., March 19, 2001

HEADLINE: U.S. Gyrations of Little Effect On ManyAsian Stock Markets 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, March 21 

 BODY:
Stock markets in Asia largely shrugged off the Federal Reserve's cut in interest rates and the sharp fall in American stocks that followed, suggesting that the region is becoming somewhat inured to daily developments in the United States.
 Investors are distracted by Japan's deepening economic woes, which could worsen the drag from the United States, and by the weaker yen, which could put pressure on other Asian currencies. 
 "Everything is going wrong at the same time," said Richard Samuelson, a managing director at UBS Warburg in Seoul. "People are now watching the Japanese stock market as well as the U.S. stock market." 
South Korean stocks rose 0.2 percent today. Other Asian markets had modest declines. In Taiwan, which is particularly dependent on electronics exports to the United States, shares dropped 0.3 percent.
But in Tokyo, the decision by the Japanese central bank to pump money into the nation's banking system by effectively cutting interest rates to zero overshadowed everything else. The benchmark Nikkei index surged 7.5 percent, its biggest rally on a single day since November 1997.
 On Thursday, the Nikkei was down .9 percent by midafternoon, and Hong Kong stocks had lost more than 3 percent. 
Reaction in Asia to the Federal Reserve's rate cut was muted, analysts said, because the markets already reflect the American slowdown. Shares in Tokyo, Hong Kong and Singapore have fallen more than 10 percent since the beginning of 2001, as the breadth of the troubles became clear. "Unless the U.S. is really approaching a cliff, we'd argue that most of this is already priced in the markets," said Ray W. Jovanovich of Indocam Asset Management in Hong Kong.
The bigger debate in Asia now is how Japan's tribulations will affect the region. Other Asians over the years have depended on the Japanese for investment and commercial loans. The last time the Japanese yen rapidly deteriorated, in mid-1998, it worsened problems elsewhere.
But this time, some economists say, Japan's troubles will not have as severe an effect. After years of economic drift, they say, Japan exerts less influence on the region. "If Japan had collapsed five years ago, I would have been extremely worried," said Dong Tao, a regional economist at Credit Suisse First Boston here. "But today's Japan is not the Japan of five years ago."
Mr. Tao said Asian countries were more dependent on exports to the United States than to Japan. As for foreign investments and bank loans, the Japanese turned off the tap on those several years ago. "I'm a lot more worried about the electronics industry cycle in the U.S. than Japan's G.D.P.," he said.
That does not mean that Tokyo can be ignored. The central bank's rate policy decision helped drive the value of the yen down further.
This has put pressure on the South Korean won. And analysts say the currencies of Taiwan and Singapore could be next, since they compete with Japan in exporting electronics to the United States and Europe.
Eroding currencies do not pose the same threat to Asia as they did in 1997, when the collapse of the Thai baht set off financial crisis and a ruinous recession through the region. Mr. Samuelson said South Korea had reserves exceeding $90 billion with which to shore up its currency. "There's no danger of the capital crisis we had in 1997," he said.
Still, weakening currencies add to the impression of a darker outlook for Asia. In December, Credit Suisse First Boston lowered its forecast for Asian growth in 2001 to 3.8 percent from 4.4 percent, and another reduction seems likely. "We're faced with weakness in the two economies that have been the principal drivers of Asia," Mr. Jovanovich said.
As a fund manager, he is finding hope amid the ashes. He thinks that most Asian markets are close to hitting bottom. And he said that hard times in the United States could redound to Asia's benefit, if more American companies send projects offshore to cheaper Asian markets.
"Asia suffered through a difficult few years," he said, "but that suffering came from organic problems. These are not organic problems."

HEADLINE: Food Worker Is Accused Of Corporate Espionage 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM 

 BODY:
The F.B.I. has arrested a catering company employee, saying he stole a confidential document in which MasterCard International outlined a previously undisclosed plan for a $1 billion alliance with the Disney Corporation, officials said yesterday.
 MasterCard would provide no details yesterday about the confidential plan, which the suspect tried to sell to Visa, MasterCard's main competitor, according to a criminal complaint filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan. But a senior law enforcement official said the plan concerned a proposed alliance with Disney. 
 Visa reported the theft to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and an undercover agent posing as a Visa executive negotiated to buy the material in a series of telephone calls and letters and arrested the employee Tuesday night, the complaint said. 
The employee, Fausto Estrada, 36, also suggested to Visa that he could secretly videotape and tape-record meetings of high-ranking MasterCard executives and suggested that Visa pay for special recording equipment for the task, the complaint said.
The case against Mr. Estrada, who worked as a waiter and bartender in the corporate dining room at MasterCard's headquarters in Purchase, N.Y., is the first brought by Manhattan federal prosecutors under the Economic Espionage Act, which was passed in 1996, officials said. About two dozen such cases have been brought around the country, but they are rare, and bringing charges under the law requires the direct approval of the attorney general, officials said.
Mr. Estrada, a native of the Dominican Republic who lives in the Bronx, stole reams of confidential material from the corporate dining room and surrounding areas, including documents, CD-ROM's, binders and other material, a law enforcement official said.
Mr. Estrada, the court papers said, first contacted Visa in February through an anonymous letter to its president and chief executive, using the code name Cagliostro, after an 18th-century Italian mystic. He later told the undercover F.B.I. agent that he had chosen the name because Cagliostro was a master of deception, the official said.
But Mr. Estrada, officials said, was apparently unable to muster the deceitful skills of his namesake. They say he included his own return address on all but one of his letters to Visa, as well as to the F.B.I. agent who posed as a Visa executive. In negotiating with the undercover agent, he also used a cellular phone belonging to a woman identified as his girlfriend, the criminal complaint said.
The complaint, signed by Larissa L. Mentzer, an F.B.I. special agent, charged Mr. Estrada with two counts each of theft of trade secrets and interstate transportation of stolen property and one count of wire fraud.
It said that he offered to sell Visa the confidential MasterCard proposal for $100,000 and also offered additional information from the years 1999 and 2000, as well as additional material for 2001. He told Visa it would have "almost direct contact with your competitor without the competitor realizing the fact," the criminal complaint said.
In a telephone conversation with the agent, Mr. Estrada also offered budget and profit-margin information that he called "very unique" and insisted that any payments be made in cash "because I do not pay taxes," the complaint said.
Mr. Estrada was arrested when he went to meet the undercover agent at a hotel with three milk crates filled with MasterCard documents and other material, one official said.
Federal authorities yesterday praised Visa for contacting the F.B.I. and said that while Mr. Estrada did not appear to be a sophisticated criminal, the case still shows the vulnerability of corporations in intellectual property rights cases.
"I think it shows you the damage that can be done in a corporate industry when internal trade secrets, intellectual property rights material, is fraudulently seized and offered to competitors," said Robert Cordier, the special agent in charge of the criminal division in the F.B.I.'s New York office. "In the hands of a less scrupulous corporation, they could have milked the situation for all it was worth."
Mr. Estrada's lawyer, Philip Weinstein, declined to comment.
Mr. Estrada had worked at MasterCard headquarters for a temporary agency, the Pyramid Agency, hired by the company's caterer, Flik International, which is based in Rye Brook, N.Y., said a Flik spokeswoman, Cheryl Webster. Ms. Webster said he had worked at MasterCard's corporate dining area on and off for about two years.
Marc Weinstein, the assistant United States attorney who is prosecuting the case, said Mr. Estrada was arraigned before Federal Magistrate Ronald L. Ellis and released on $25,000 bond.

HEADLINE: Poor County Feels Domino Effect of Energy Crisis 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA WHITAKER 

DATELINE: CALIPATRIA, Calif., March 21 

 BODY:
Imperial County, located on the border with Mexico, has plenty of problems, but energy is not one of them.
 "We didn't think we had an energy problem," said Ann Capella, the chief executive of the county, which has its power supplied by the vast Imperial Irrigation District. "We have plenty of water and plenty of power." 
 All that changed this week. But instead of confronting rolling blackouts like those imposed elsewhere in California, the county is facing financial troubles arising from the energy crisis. The CalEnergy Operating Corporation, a renewable energy provider with geothermal plants in the county and its largest taxpayer, said it would not be able to make a $3.9 million property tax payment due April 10 because it had not been paid by Southern California Edison for five months. 
"It certainly could become a major crisis for us," Ms. Capella said.
With 10 geothermal plants creating energy by extracting superheated water near the Salton Sea, CalEnergy has helped change the fabric of the county, one of the state's poorest. With only 140,000 residents and little industry, the county has come to rely in the $10 million a year in property taxes paid by the company, which employs about 200 people. CalEnergy, a subsidiary of MidAmerican Energy Holdings Company, is the largest of three renewable energy producers in the county. Together, the three account for 14 percent of the $67 million in property taxes collected in Imperial County. 
School officials estimate that 50 percent of their general budget comes from taxes paid by CalEnergy, and Superintendent James C. Hanks said the crisis had forced the district to put on hold a bond sale for necessary for improvements. 
In a meeting today with CalEnergy's chairman, David L. Sokol, Mr. Hanks said his immediate concern was for students whose parents worked at the plant. 
As fallout from deregulation and the financial troubles of Pacific Gas and Electric and Southern California Edison continue to grow, the impact on California counties that are home to small renewable energy companies, which provide about 12 percent of the state's power, is just beginning to be felt. Renewable energy companies in eight other counties say they may soon be in the same position as CalEnergy if they are not paid soon.
Unlike their larger peers, these smaller companies are not guaranteed payment by the State Department of Water Resources, which agreed earlier this year to buy electricity on behalf of the nearly bankrupt utilities. Instead, these companies have contracts to sell power directly to the utilities.
The problems confronting small alternative generators in California, which include renewable energy companies -- which rely on wind, waste and geothermal water resources -- and co-generators that make electricity as a byproduct, came to the forefront this week as rolling blackouts were instituted on Monday and Tuesday when the state could not meet electricity demands. Among several factors contributing to the problem was that some independents had gone off line because they had not been paid by Southern California Edison and PG&E. Lower temperatures and the completion of repairs at some power plants helped the state avoid blackouts today.
Gov. Gray Davis announced on Tuesday that he would ask the State Public Utilities Commission to order Southern California Edison and PG&E to begin paying for their power from the independent operators as of April 1. Past payments were not addressed. Enabling legislation would be required to support this.
"We're encouraged but we've heard it before," Mr. Sokol said. "We're very skeptical."
After five months of not being paid by Southern California Edison, Mr. Sokol said: "Time has run out. The system is freezing up."
He was in Imperial County to meet with employees, mineral rights holders and public officials, before a Superior Court hearing on Thursday in which CalEnergy will ask to be allowed to suspend sales to Southern California Edison, which the company says owes it $140 million, and sell to paying buyers.
If the company fails in court, he said, he expected renewable energy providers to try within a week to force Southern California Edison into involuntary bankruptcy.
"We are drawing a line in the sand," Mr. Sokol said.
Southern California Edison has opposed legislation that would establish a system for paying the independent energy providers, saying it is inconsistent and unworkable.
Sitting in a meeting room in Brawley, Calif., waiting for Mr. Sokol to appear, landowners with mineral rights remained patient with CalEnergy while disdainful of the state's handling of the crisis.
"If we ran a business like that, we'd be put in jail," said Kathryn Wood. "It's just never ending."

A picture caption yesterday with an article about the effects of the energy crisis on the economy of Imperial County, Calif., gave an erroneous name in some copies for a power company that has missed payments to suppliers. It is Southern California Edison, not Southern California Energy.

HEADLINE: Boeing, Jolting Seattle, Will Move Headquarters 

BYLINE:  By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK with LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, March 21 

 BODY:
After decades as a mainstay of the Seattle economy and a virtual emblem of the Pacific Northwest, the Boeing Company stunned its hometown today with an abrupt announcement that it would move its corporate headquarters out of the region.
 The company said it was evaluating the Chicago, Denver and Dallas areas as possible sites for a new base. The company's chairman and chief executive, Philip M. Condit, said he envisioned a "leaner corporate center" that would give Boeing greater "flexibility to move capital and talent to the opportunities that maximize shareholder value." 
 Boeing said it had no plans to move its giant commercial aircraft unit, which manufactures ubiquitous passenger jets like the Boeing 737, 747 and 767, out of the Seattle area. And thus it is possible, as the company insisted today, that the impact on the Seattle economy will be modest, since about 500 jobs are scheduled to be moved to the new headquarters. 
Nonetheless, the announcement by Mr. Condit in Washington, D.C., was a sharp blow to Seattle's psyche and prestige, as stunning, say, as General Motors pulling out of Detroit or Coca-Cola abandoning Atlanta.
While the 500 headquarters jobs that would be moved were primarily nonunion, many people here expressed fears that it was a precursor to a larger scaling back by Boeing. The company provides jobs for about 80,000 people in the Puget Sound region and is by far the area's largest private employer. 
Seattle's mayor, Paul Schell, said he was "totally blindsided." 
The state's governor, Gary Locke, describing himself as "surprised and deeply sorry," said loss of the headquarters "leaves a void in our economic and cultural life." 
Both pleaded with Boeing to reconsider. 
With the region recovering from a literal jolt last month, Dick Conway, a local economist, took a stab at gallows humor, saying, "Well, it has made us forget the earthquake all of a sudden." 
A local radio station, KIRO-AM, linking Boeing's possible relocation to Dallas with the move of the baseball superstar Alex Rodriguez from the Seattle Mariners to the Texas Rangers, played the country song, "All My Ex's Live in Texas." 
But the dominant emotions were shock and anger. Union leaders were furious at both the news itself and the five minutes' advance notice that Boeing gave them and the area's elected officials before the announcement. 
"This decision is a blow to our entire community," said Mark Blondin, president of the local chapter of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, representing about 25,000 Boeing workers. "Bill Boeing must be turning over in his grave to learn his company is being ripped from its roots and moved cross country." 
Mr. Blondin was referring to William Boeing, who bought a shipyard on the Duwamish River in 1910 and later turned it into an airplane factory. 
He founded the company in 1916 and, taking advantage of the region's once-cheap and abundant hydroelectric power, turned it into the world's pre-eminent manufacturer of planes. Boeing planes helped the Allies win World War II and, in peacetime, helped define jet passenger travel. 
In recent years, however, the company has seen its once-dominant share of the commercial airplane market challenged, especially in its global market competition with Airbus Industrie, the European consortium. 
Perhaps even more importantly, though, the company has been trying to diversify its operations. 
Boeing has transformed itself in Mr. Condit's tenure, buying the space division of Rockwell International for $3.2 billion in 1996 and its longtime rival, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, for $14 billion the following year. 
The deals created a diversified aerospace giant that had $51 billion in sales last year and operated in 145 countries. Boeing still depends on the manufacture of commercial jets for 60 percent of its revenue, but it now also makes and launches satellites and builds fighter jets and missiles. 
Mr. Condit has worked to convince Wall Street that he is focused on creating value for shareholders. Boeing stock rallied last year, becoming one of the markets top performers. But recently it has fallen back. Boeing shares fell $1.15 today, to $53.85. 
Mr. Condit, in a telephone interview yesterday while flying back to Seattle from Washington, said he had concluded that the headquarters had to be physically separate from any of Boeing's operating divisions so that it could make objective decisions about where to deploy the company's resources in the future. "If you are directly with any one of your business units, it changes the dynamic of the way you view that business," he said. 
Asked how he felt about leaving Seattle, where he has lived for most of the last 36 years, Mr. Condit, 59, said: "Given a personal choice, that is not what I would want to do. I love Seattle. But I am looking for what is best for the company." 
Mr. Condit said he was inspired to make the move by talking to other chief executives. He said he first raised the idea with Boeing's corporate strategy council in September and began broaching the idea with the company's board late last year.
Many Seattle residents and some industry analysts scoffed at Mr. Condit's professed rationale for moving the headquarters. And several management experts expressed surprise. 
"Most of the time when corporations move, they do it to get closer to their work force, or for tax reasons," said Jim O'Toole, a research professor at the Center for Effective Organizations at the University of Southern California. "I have never heard of a company changing its location to change its culture or its perspective. This could be a first."
Professor O'Toole added that many corporate relocations ended up being fruitless.
"Geographical solutions to problems seldom work," he said "Changing location doesn't change your mindset, it doesn't change your values, it doesn't change your business. You move that with you." 
Other management experts said that Seattle, which is also the home of Starbucks, Microsoft and Amazon.com, has become one of the country's most desirable locations for corporations, in large part because jet travel has reduced its isolation. 
"Seattle is a rich, culturally diverse place," said Jeffrey A. Sonnenfeld, president of the Chief Executive Leadership Institute in Atlanta. "It's on the Pacific Rim. It's a pretty hot place to be." 
Mr. Condit suggested that top company officials could function more effectively in the global marketplace out of one of the three cities under consideration, Chicago, Denver and Dallas, which are all major international air hubs. But here in high-tech Seattle, such a rationale struck some people as old-fashioned. 
"This whole geographical location argument of his is a bit strange," said Glen Pascall, a senior fellow at the Institute for Public Policy at the University of Washington. "In today's electronically networked economy, being at any major center of economic activity gives you all the connectivity that you should need." 
Some people suggested that one of the reasons behind the move was that Boeing would become more decentralized and increasingly move toward "outsourcing" some of its work -- that is, contracting it to other companies instead of using its own, heavily unionized work force. 
And organized labor, which has had its share of tense contract negotiations and bitter strikes over the years, certainly had the possibility of contracting work to other companies on its mind today. 
"Boeing needs to know the machinists union is here for the long haul," said Mr. Blondin, the local union leader. "We plan to continue building the world's best airplanes here in Puget Sound. 
In any event, the announcement was big news here: "the Boeing Bombshell," as one television station described it. And many Boeing workers, as well as people here with no official connection to the company, seemed shell-shocked. 
"I have no idea what's going to happen," said Rebecca Cranz, who works in the systems support division and has been in Seattle for 20 years, 10 of those at Boeing. "It would have been nice if I had found out a little earlier." 
Eric Lucas, a freelance editor and writer here who does not work for Boeing, echoed a common sentiment when he said his first reaction to the news was that it was an early April Fool's joke. 
Mr. Condit said he did not notify Boeing's employees and political leaders in Seattle and Washington until a few minutes before yesterday's announcement because he wanted "to deal with everyone on an equal basis.
"Clearly they are disappointed," the Boeing chairman said. "I would expect them to be."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rebecca Cranz works in company support at Boeing corporate headquarters in Seattle, which is moving out of the region after eight decades. (Photographs by Larry Davis for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section C; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 570 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Boeing's Corporate Base To Move Out of Seattle
After eight decades as a mainstay of the local economy and a virtual emblem of Seattle, Boeing stunned its hometown with an abrupt announcement that it would move its corporate headquarters out of the region.
 The company said it was evaluating the Chicago, Denver and Dallas areas as possible sites for a new base. Boeing said it had no plans to move its giant commercial aircraft unit, so it is possible, as the company insisted, that the specific effect on the Seattle economy would be relatively slight. Page A16. 

Layoffs Are Expected at Procter
Procter & Gamble has scheduled a conference call with investors today and is expected to announce layoffs, reflecting slowing sales and a need to reduce costs, and thus prices. C14.

New Chief for AT&T Consumer Unit
Trying yet again to find a leader for its troubled consumer-services operation, AT&T announced that Betsy J. Bernard, most recently a top executive at Qwest Communications International, would become the unit's chief executive next month. Ms. Bernard represents the sixth generation of leadership at AT&T's consumer unit in five years. C4.

Disappointment Fuels Stock Decline
Stocks continued to fall after the Federal Reserve's decision to cut interest rates less than investors had hoped. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 233.76 points, or 2.4 percent, to 9,487.00. The Nasdaq composite index declined 27.21 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,830.23, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index decreased 20.48 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,122.14. C8.

Stock markets in Asia largely shrugged off the Fed's cut in interest rates and the sharp fall in American stocks that followed. C8.

Man Accused of Stealing Documents
The F.B.I. has arrested a catering company employee, saying he stole a confidential document in which MasterCard outlined a previously undisclosed plan for a $1 billion alliance with Walt Disney and tried to sell it to Visa International, MasterCard's chief rival. C6.

Judge Rejects Damages in Book Suit
In a setback for a group of independent bookstores, a federal judge in California dismissed their claim for damages in an antitrust suit against Barnes & Noble and Borders. C7.

Profit Falls at Wall Street Firms
Quarterly earnings fell at three of Wall Street's top firms -- Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Lehman Brothers and Bear Stearns -- as a slumping stock market reduced initial public offerings and merger activity -- two major drivers of investment banking revenue. Shares of Morgan Stanley fell $1.86, to $54.64; Lehman dropped $2, to $63.90; and Bear Stearns declined $1.25, to $45.50. C2.

3Com Announces Plan to Cut Costs
Reporting narrower quarterly losses than expected, 3Com announced a cost-cutting plan that seeks to save $1 billion a year but that also means the demise of the company's short-lived kitchen-countertop Internet device. C4.

Consumer Prices Increase 0.3%
Consumer prices rose 0.3 percent in February, more than expected, led by higher costs for food, clothing and medical care. C14.

The Economics of Gaining Weight
Americans are gaining more weight than ever, a trend that can be explained in part by economics. For starters, the cost of consuming calories has plummeted, thanks to productivity gains in agriculture and distribution. But more important, the cost of burning calories has surged as work has become more sedentary. Virginia Postrel: Economic Scene. C2.
